HEADLINE: Coney Island on the Edge;
A Region's Venerable Magic Is Buffeted by Modern Times

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF 

 BODY:
It is historical fact that nearly every inch of Coney Island has burned to the ground at one time or another. The amusement rides, rows of shops on the avenues, a few of the antique hotels and long stretches of the Boardwalk have disappeared. And then they have risen again, reassuring old-timers that Coney Island's magic is somehow invincible, yet making them wistful for the way things once were.
It has always been this way on the tiny peninsula: danger mixed with a cool breeze off the ocean, hurly-burly mingled with the gentle sands, an odd, teetering feeling that leaves many just the slightest bit on edge. 
 A new season is upon Coney Island. This means that the Cyclone has taken on a fresh coat of white paint, the beach has received its first rush of sun worshipers and the streets have regained the expectant feeling of summertime bustle.
 
Images of Pleasure and Pain
 "I love this place," said Milton Grapper, a Manhattan real-estate investor who jumped out of his BMW last week to grab a quick hot dog with relish at Nathan's. "But I know it's a lot in my head."
The illusion of Coney Island works both ways. The carnival atmosphere and the beachfront dreaminess can hide the real problems of drug dealing, gunplay and the assorted violence found on the blocks north of the ocean. But when a notorious crime attracts attention to the community, as the rape of a jogger on April 7 did, it also masks the strides Coney Island seems to have made in recent years.
For the first time since the early 1970's, when public housing projects brought a severe dose of inner-city misery to Coney Island, residents can point to signs of improvement in their neighborhood. Just a decade ago Coney Island was viewed as a neighborhood in inexorable decline, but today neat rows of two-story single-family homes are a sign that the middle class is being replenished, this time by an influx of immigrants.
And despite the news media's attention to the Boardwalk rape, statistics show that in many categories crime is declining in Coney Island. For instance, robberies have dropped from a peak of 1,379 in 1985 to 1,082 last year, in part because of increased summer patrols of the Boardwalk area. And burglaries have fallen from a high of 1,975 in 1980 to 1,203 in 1992 to 975 last year.
 
Businesses, Old and New
 In addition, there is a feeling of renewal on the commercial strips of Mermaid and Neptune Avenues, areas that not long ago had been stagnant. New business spaces are being planned, and longtime merchants are involved in a project to restore their storefronts. The old businesses -- the Gerace & Sons bread shop and Gargiulo's Italian restaurant -- keep the old Coney Island flavor alive. And the Army Corps of Engineers is involved in a long-term, $26.8 million project to rebuild the area's prime asset: the Coney Island beachfront.
Still, the contrasts persist. On a clear, blue afternoon a man with a paint brush stood midway on a rung of one of the Cyclone roller coaster's giant curves, quietly applying a finishing touch to the spindly frame. The carousel spun with a few of the first young faces of a new season, and a couple of eager swimmers emerged shriveled but exhilarated from the Atlantic. It could have been 1930 or 1940 or any year.
But at Faber's Arcade on Surf Avenue, the din of video machines added a decidedly modern intrusion. Nearby, two officers leaped out of a squad car and commanded two youths in baggy jeans to raise their hands. The officers suspected that the teen-agers were concealing guns in their waistbands. They were not.
 
'They're Killing This Place'
 But as soon as the officers drove off, the two youths began screaming and shouting at three young women. Then they began shouting at one another, nose to nose, drawing the officers back to the scene. This time the officers did not leap out of the car.
"I grew up around here," said one officer, with the bitter tone of someone who had seen his old neighborhood transformed over the years by young troublemakers. "They're killing this place, so let them kill each other."
Perhaps because traces of the old Coney Island still exist, and its shoreline vistas still retain their beauty, there is a poignancy to the neighborhood's problems that probably cannot be found anywhere else in New York. Residents complain that City Hall looks at Coney Island and sees just the surface allure, and not a community with a gamut of needs like any other neighborhood.
 
Small but Diverse Area
 "We just don't get as much attention," said Judi Orlando, executive director of the Astella Development Corporation, which has helped to finance and build more than 700 single-family homes in Coney Island in the last 13 years and is building 148 more. The construction has partly transformed an area that runs between West 15th and West 37th Street, between Mermaid Avenue and Neptune Avenue.
Ms. Orlando said Coney Island's small size -- about a mile and a quarter long and a few city blocks wide -- tended to isolate it. It is too often overlooked when it comes time to receive city money, she said. In addition, while Coney Island's mixed population of black, Hispanic, Russian, Italian, Chinese and Middle Eastern residents creates an ethnic charm, the diversity can also deprive Coney Island of any concerted political clout, Ms. Orlando said.
The result, perhaps, is that while there are enough restaurants and auto repair shops and other businesses, there are few outlets to keep many of the teen-agers from idleness or worse, turning to violence and drugs.
Still, hope has seeped in of late. Diane Bowman lives in the Ocean Towers on West 24th Street and is the mother of three children, including two teen-agers. She said she had to be constantly vigilant to shield them from the perils just downstairs, in the courtyards of the housing development and in the streets.
But Ms. Bowman said she was committing herself and her family to the community, in part through her work with Coney Island United Services. The program, which has counseling sessions for youths, AIDS workshops, leadership projects and volunteer work programs, is something of a recent phenomenon in an area that for years had no such programs. Ms. Bowman said she was in the process of buying one of the new homes through the Astella company.
"Sometimes I forget, too," she said. "The water, the air. It's hard not to love Coney Island."
Dick D. Zigun, the closest thing to Coney Island's curator, is also optimistic. He is the artistic director of Coney Island U.S.A., a small production company that presents off-Boardwalk theater and circus sideshows. He also owns a refreshment stand on the Boardwalk and a large room filled with relics from Coney Island's golden age: a rolling chair for two, bathhouse signs and wooden bottles enshrined in a glass case, looking as unshakable as ever.
After watching all the rides west of Stillwell Avenue disappear over time, he has seen new amusements open in the last few years. And he said the old Steeplechase Park, which closed in 1964, may yet be reborn.
Mr. Zigun issued what amounted to a kind of battle cry, saying Coney Island always seems to be able to survive in the face of disaster. When a great fire swept through Coney Island in 1903, he said, people kept dancing at the Steeplechase ballroom.
In Coney Island, though, there is always a bittersweet counterpoint. Only a few blocks from where Mr. Zigun spoke on the Boardwalk, Raymond Leary stood on Surf Avenue and braced himself against a persistent wind off the ocean.
 
'Looking for Trouble'
 Mr. Leary is 22 years old, unemployed, and said he spends a good deal of his time doing exactly what he was doing at that moment, "just looking around."
"Everywhere you look, there are guys looking for trouble," he said. "Sometimes they rob. Sometimes they're selling drugs. Sometimes, like me, we do nothing."
But the mere mention of a new season, he said, had him excited, and instantly gave him the wistful, narrow-eyed look of a true Coney Island veteran.
"The Coney Island when I was a kid -- that was some kind of Coney Island," Mr. Leary said.

HEADLINE: In a Pinch, Philanthropic Spirit Stays Afloat

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH 

 BODY:
Philanthropic giving in the nation rose 3.5 percent, to $126.2 billion, last year, as donors stepped up their contributions to an increasing number of charities, officials said.
In the New York region, gains were more modest, but on a per capita level among employees in 152 major corporations, the increase was 4 percent. 
 But nationally, charities found these modest gains were eroded by higher operating costs for things like salaries and benefits, according to "Giving USA, 1994," the yearbook of the Trust for Philanthropy of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, which released the annual figures.
"Given the sluggish economy and given the persistent, relatively high unemployment rate in 1993, the generosity of Americans continues to be encouraging," said Martin Grenzebach, chairman of the trust.
In 1992, charitable giving rose by 4 percent over the previous year, and officials held out hope that contributions would continue to increase at a similar pace.
"We're very optimistic for next year's performance," Mr. Grenzebach said.
The United Way of Tri-State, which conducts fund-raising campaigns for corporations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, also reported slightly higher giving.
The 32 local United Ways secured pledges of $108.4 million in the most recent drive, an increase of $250,000. The year before, donations for the Tri-State drive actually declined, as giving was adversely affected by the recession and the questions about the salary and spending of William A. Aramony, who was ousted as president of United Way of America in February 1992.
The Tri-State campaigns reported successes last year despite substantial job cutbacks at companies like International Business Machines, American Express and Nynex.
 
Some Major Factors
 "Giving in the New York region showed a 4 percent increase in per capita contributions, suggesting those who had jobs wanted to give more," said Betty Beene, president of Tri-State. At least 62 percent of the contributions to Tri-State drives came from employees' voluntary payroll deductions, she said.
"That smaller workforces would raise more money succeeded against all odds," she said.
Mr. Grenzebach predicted that charitable contributions could grow markedly in coming years based on a number of factors. First, the coming two decades will likely see a transfer of trillions in wealth from parents' estates to their children, creating more millionaires; secondly, the so-called baby-boomers will be moving into the 34-to-65 age group, when people typically have more discretionary money to give.
Furthermore, charities are getting more sophisticated in their fund-raising techniques, and more institutions are seeking out donors. In the affluent Chicago suburb of Winnetka, for instance, the school district is developing a privately financed foundation to raise money to enhance education in four local public schools, modeled in part on one in Bronxville, N.Y.
The new Giving USA yearbook shows that individual living donors, historically the major provider of philanthropy, gave $102.5 billion; another $8.5 billion was from bequests. Giving by foundations rose to $9.2 billion, reflecting improvement in their investment returns, while corporate giving accounted for $5.9 billion, showing no gain.
As always, the largest share of giving went to religious organizations, which received $57.1 billion, while education received $15 billion, human services $12.4 billion and health $10.8 billion, with smaller shares going to arts and environmental and other organizations.

HEADLINE: Go-Ahead on Altered Crops Is Met by a 'Go Slow'

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EAST LANSING, Mich., May 18

 BODY:
A genetically altered tomato and a genetically engineered cow hormone are on the market, each winning Federal approval after years of scrutiny.
But other new products are likely to have a much easier journey to the grocery store. The Clinton Administration is planning to give the agricultural biotechnology industry broad authority to market most other genetically engineered crops without intensive Government review. 
 To the delight of biotechnology executives, President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore are enthusiastic about the technology. They consider it largely harmless and see huge economic potential. Some scientists, however, including a number here at Michigan State University, one of the nation's leading centers of agricultural research, dissent from that view.
Two Michigan State scientists have called aspects of the Government's work on regulating the crops of the 21st century scientifically inadequate. Dr. Gus A. de Zoeten, the chairman of the botany and plant pathology department, and Dr. Richard Allison, a plant virologist, say that a broad class of the gene-altered crops -- those engineered to resist viral diseases -- may be more risky than the Government believes and should not be exempted from Federal oversight, as the Clinton plan proposes.
 
Opinion Versus Science
 The Michigan State scientists also say that the Government has not supported enough research to assess the risks of genetically engineered plants, and that in the absence of clear scientific data Federal agencies are relying too heavily on the opinions of experts.
"Everybody has a stake in this area of plant research," said Dr. de Zoeten. "The companies have billions of dollars invested in new crop varieties. Scientists at the agricultural universities are working closely with these companies, and they have an interest in seeing that the technology is successful. My stake is to have scientists lead the way in doing the research on safety and not just to base their opinions on what they think will happen."
Many consumers, too, are uneasy about the new techniques. In February, a genetically engineered dairy hormone intended to increase milk production in cows went on sale to farmers, prompting protests in New York, Atlanta, Seattle and other cities about the safety of milk.
The significance of the protests was not lost on Calgene Inc., the biotechnology company that won the Food and Drug Administration's approval to sell a tomato engineered to stay on the vine longer for better taste. Calgene voluntarily sought Government review to quell public worries about the safety of the tomato and to smooth its path to the market this summer.
 
Following Established Policy
 The Clinton Administration's proposal for overseeing the new crops essentially follows the hands-off approach to plant biotechnology of the Reagan and Bush Administrations, but with two important differences. Since 1987, depending on the plants being tested, the Department of Agriculture has required companies either to submit applications for field trials involving genetically engineered crops or, more recently, to simply notify the Government. Roughly 2,000 field trials have been conducted without incident in 42 states and Puerto Rico on vegetables, fruits, and grains containing genes from species as diverse as chickens, fish, bacteria and viruses.
Where the Clinton plan differs is that after the field-testing stage, the Administration proposes to exempt most of the new crops from Federal oversight when they are sold to the public. Virtually the only altered crops the Administration wants to watch more closely are those containing bacterial genes that produce a natural defense against insects.
Under the plan, the marketing of such pesticidal plants will be regulated for the first time by the E.P.A. under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act, the nation's pesticide control law. The Administration is proposing safety tests for such plants, though precisely what sort of tests has not been decided.
The Administration proposal would take effect through the adoption of Federal regulations, requiring their being printed, giving the public time for comment, possibly being revised and then assuming the force of law.
Some scientists who support crop-engineering have criticized the proposed rules as unnecessary. They note that classical plant breeding, which produces the bounty that most Americans take for granted, never came under Government regulation. They argue that producing new crop varieties through genetic engineering is just as safe as classical breeding and that any regulation at all of plant genetic engineering could squelch innovation.
 
Overregulation Feared
 "Genetic engineering has provided agriculture with the most important set of tools for making plants resistant to diseases and insects ever discovered," said Dr. Susanne Huttner, a molecular neurobiologist and director of the University of California Systemwide Biotechnology Program. "If the E.P.A. had been around to regulate crop development 50 years ago, we would not have the remarkable variety and quality of fruits, vegetables and grain we enjoy today."
Dr. de Zoeten and Dr. Allison of Michigan State disagree with that view. They say the Administration's regulatory program is not strict enough, especially for the class of new plants engineered to resist viruses. Dr. Allison and a colleague, Ann E. Greene, drove the point home in March, when results of their research were published in the journal Science.
The idea of such alterations -- first performed in 1986 -- was to vaccinate plants by inserting into them pieces of genes from plant viruses. Most scientists considered this safe. They also believed it would enable farmers to reduce the use of pesticides to kill insects that carried the viruses.
Dr. Allison's research, which was jointly sponsored by the Department of Agriculture and the Monsanto Company, showed that the inserted genes can recombine with natural plant viruses and produce wholly new viruses at a rate higher than had been theorized by experts at the E.P.A. and the Department of Agriculture. The implication of the research, said Dr. Allison, was that engineering plants to be resistant to viruses might lead to entirely new types of viruses that could cause widespread damage to American crops.
 
Old Assumptions Questioned
 "Before this, everybody assumed there were no or very low risk factors with genetically engineered plants," said Dr. Robert G. Gast, a soil chemist and director of the Agricultural Experiment Station at Michigan State. Dr. de Zoeten, he said, "has had concerns that this assumption was not necessarily true." Dr. Allison's work, he said, "showed specifically it wasn't true."
Dr. Allison's paper was disputed in the same issue of Science by a team of California researchers, who said he was overestimating the risks. Nevertheless, his conclusions caused a small commotion in the scientific community not only because of the thoroughness of the research but also because of where it occurred. Michigan State University has played a central role in developing the machines and farm chemicals that have driven modern agriculture for half a century; rarely has it been a center of criticism of farm technology or the Government.
Dr. Walter R. Fehr, a plant breeder and director of the Biotechnology Program at Iowa State University in Ames is one of a number of top scientists around the country who have expressed support for Michigan State's new spirit of criticism. "What Michigan State did was a piece of research which allowed them to ask a question that's legitimate," he said. "We are shirking our duty to the public if we do not examine those questions with the best science we have."
But west of here, in Kalamazoo, Mich., where the Asgrow Seed Company is engineering cucumbers, squash and melons to be viral-resistant, executives worry that the Michigan State paper will prompt the Government to reconsider its view and impose stricter controls on testing and marketing such crops.
"The important question always when you are talking about Government regulation is: What is the danger and what are the consequences of the event if something goes wrong?" said Dr. Hector D. Quemada, a molecular biologist and associate director of vegetable biotechnology at Asgrow, a subsidiary of the Upjohn Company.
In Washington, Terry L. Medley, an administrator at the Department of Agriculture, and one of the Administration's biotechnology policy leaders, said Dr. Quemada need not worry. Mr. Medley said that one-fifth of the field tests of genetically engineered crops have involved viral resistance, and that all occurred without any problem. "As far as we can tell, the Government is asking the correct questions to determine safety," Mr. Medley said.

HEADLINE: Panel Clears Fed Nominee

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
The Senate Banking Committee today approved President Clinton's nomination of Alan S. Blinder as Federal Reserve Board vice chairman by a vote of 15 to 0, with Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat, voting "present."
Mr. Blinder is expected to win confirmation by the full Senate with ease. He will join the Fed at a time when the central bank has been raising short-term interest rates to head off a possible increase in inflation. 
 A member of Mr. Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, Mr. Blinder will replace the former Fed vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., who departed for Wall Street in February.
The Senate committee will later consider Mr. Clinton's other nominee to a vacancy on the Fed board, Janet L. Yellen, an economist with the University of California at Berkeley.
She would replace Wayne D. Angell, who left the Fed on Feb. 10 to become an economist with Bear, Stearns & Company.

HEADLINE: Sar A. Levitan, 79, Economist And Social Policy Scholar, Dies

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Sar A. Levitan, an economist widely known for his analysis of social policy and influence on government programs as diverse as employment training and rural development, died on Tuesday in Washington. He was 79.
Friends said he had died of cancer. 
 Dr. Levitan came to the United States from Lithuania as a teen-ager. Garth Mangum, a longtime colleague, said, "He was expected to follow his father as the fifth-generation rabbi in his family." Instead, he attended the City College of New York, where he developed a fascination with public policy.
After a four-year stint in the Army in World War II, in which he rose to the rank of captain, he completed a doctorate in labor economics at Columbia University in 1949.
After teaching briefly at the Plattsburgh campus of the State University of New York, Dr. Levitan moved to Washington and was an aide on the Wage Stabilization Board during the Korean War. He then became a researcher for the Legislative Reference Service of the Library of Congress.
 
Helping the Rural Poor
 Working with Senator Paul Douglas of Illinois, a liberal Democrat who served in the Senate from 1949 to 1966, Dr. Levitan helped to formulate the Area Redevelopment Act, one of the Federal Government's initial efforts to break the cycle of poverty in rural communities.
The project inspired his first book, "Federal Aid to Depressed Areas" (1964), and began an association with the Ford Foundation that lasted until his death.
Dr. Levitan served on the faculty of George Washington University since 1967, directing what is now called the Center for Social Policy Studies. He wrote dozens of books, including "Big Brother's Indian Programs -- With Reservations" (1970) and "The Promise of Greatness" (1976), a call on liberals to keep the faith.
Dr. Levitan's influence extended far beyond what might be expected from a prolific researcher and skilled polemicist. John T. Dunlop, who was Secretary of Labor under President Gerald R. Ford, attributes Dr. Levitan's influence to "a rare combination of dedication to the truth and a passion to fit the facts to the new realities" of society and politics.
 
Link to the New Deal
 Gordon Berlin, a senior vice president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, called Dr. Levitan "one of the last New Deal liberals, with great faith in the capacities of individuals as well as government."
Lawrence Katz, the Labor Department's chief economist, said Dr. Levitan had "an encyclopedia of knowledge on labor and education -- on what works and what doesn't."
His fingerprints can be found on a number of policy initiatives, including welfare reform and child care. And work that Dr. Levitan completed decades ago is still leaving marks.
Mr. Katz said suggestions made in the 1970's by the Levitan Commission on Employment and Unemployment Statistics were just now finding their way into the method the Government uses to track discouraged workers.
Dr. Levitan is survived by his wife of 47 years, Brita Ann Buchard, and, as Mr. Berlin put it, "a whole generation of social policy scholars."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sar A. Levitan (The New York Times, 1990)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Obituary (Obit); Biography

HEADLINE: Ukrainian Accuses Yeltsin of Making Threats

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 24

 BODY:
As negotiations continued in Moscow and Kiev over Crimea and control of the formerly Soviet Black Sea Fleet, the Ukrainian President criticized President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today, accusing him of issuing threats to another sovereign state.
Leonid M. Kravchuk, the Ukrainian leader, is already under considerable political pressure at home with a presidential election scheduled for next month. He promised that Crimea would remain Ukrainian and that Kiev would not use force. 
 In Moscow, the acting Ukrainian Prime Minister, Yefim Zvyagilsky, took part in a second day of negotiations with the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, in an effort to resolve their dispute over the Black Sea Fleet, which is based in Crimea. There are disagreements over how to divide up the fleet, where it will be based and who will own the shore-based installations. Those talks will continue on Wednesday.
Crimea, which is 70 percent ethnic Russian, was handed over to Ukrainian administrative control by Khrushchev in 1954. Russian officials have acknowledged Ukrainian sovereignty over the peninsula, a position also repeated in recent days by the United States and British Governments.
Crimea already has a kind of federal status within Ukraine. But driven by the poor state of the Ukrainian economy, the Crimean Parliament and its new President, Yuri Meshkov, elected in January, have pushed for closer ties to Russia and last week voted to approve a new constitution for Crimea that verges on secession from Ukraine.
Ukraine gave the Crimeans 10 days to bring their new constitution in line with Ukrainian law, and negotiators from the two parliaments agreed today to set up a working group on the issue.
But the problems between Ukraine and Russia run deeper than Crimea. Eastern Ukraine is also dominated by ethnic Russians seeking closer economic and political ties to Moscow, leading to fears that newly sovereign and economically unreformed Ukraine may fall apart.
Speaking to a group of war veterans today, Mr. Kravchuk criticized the Russian leadership and accused the Russians of aggravating tensions between the two former neighboring Soviet republics.
"A president can only issue warnings to his own government bodies and ministers and not to the president of other countries," Mr. Kravchuk said, without referring to Mr. Yeltsin by name. "This is at variance with accepted norms and undemocratic."

HEADLINE: Hungary Schools Seeking Past Glory

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
When cigarette smoking among the students at a local high school spun out of control, in much the way it often does in the United States, the school administration called a referendum, inviting students and parents to vote.
Should 18-year-olds be allowed to smoke? Should those over 16 be allowed to smoke with parental consent? The vote was yes to the 18-year-olds and no to the younger students. Such a vote would not have been unusual in many American schools. But for Hungary, it was revolutionary. 
 In Eastern Europe for the past 40 years, education has meant authoritarian rule and confined curriculums intended to mold obedient citizens. In contrast, Hungary's Alternative High School for Economics is a trailblazer for the notion of liberal education. Here students sprawl on the carpeted halls during study periods, and the dress code allows ponytails -- for boys -- and T-shirts emblazoned with graffiti more suited to a rock club than a traditional classroom.
 
Fresh Start at New School
 Hungarian schools, renowned before World War II for the quality of their education, include among their graduates John von Neumann, the mathematician, and Edward Teller, the physicist. Now they are trying to recapture glory lost during the Communist era. The Budapest Evangelical Gymnasium, which produced Dr. von Neumann as well as George Lukacs, the Marxist theoretician, reopened five years ago as a high school after decades of academic decline.
About the same time the Gymnasium was reborn, a bearded young educator named George Horn came to believe that the public -- despairing over the lamentable state of education -- would welcome an experimental school. He had already tried to modernize the program at an existing school but realized that reform of the old was impossible, as with many things in Eastern Europe, and that only a fresh start would work.
After his lengthy negotiations with the fading Communist Government, the Alternative School opened its doors in 1990 in a handsome turn-of-the-century gabled brick building. Nearly 6,000 students applied for 80 places.
"At first this was the only school program that offered something different," said Mr. Horn, who is now the principal but who dresses in jeans and a work shirt and prefers a more egalitarian title, roughly translated as coordinator. "For example, students study what language they want for as long as they want. Ninety percent of the students will learn a language fluently, 90 percent will get a driver's license and I hope 75 percent will get into one of the universities."
 
Essentially a Private School
 The school has grown to 400 students. It offers a distinctive policy of self-discipline, and several other aspects make it novel.
While Mr. Horn does not like to call the school private, it essentially is. The Government contributes an annual subsidy but students must still pay an annual fee, the equivalent of $370, or a little more than the average Hungarian monthly salary.
To attract the best teachers and allow the school to pay them double the standard salary, Mr. Horn persuaded banks and insurance companies to contribute. Each entering class of 90 students includes 30 students whose fees are subsidized by these businesses.
But the most startling difference is in the classroom.
Take Orsolya Gosztony's advanced English. This is small class size to perfection: nine students. Her aim is to make her students talk. "I'll do anything to get them to open their mouths," said the exuberant 26-year-old teacher.
 
Hitchcock Movie and Scrabble
 She divided the students into small groups and assigned them roles -- one pair, for example, was to play an elderly father and his teen-age son.
Miss Gosztony tries other nonconventional methods, like a recent screening of Alfred Hitchcock's "Rebecca" on the classroom video. Or she sets up Scrabble.
"They realize they can't do anything without languages," said Miss Gosztony, whose English is almost flawless. "No one in the world speaks Hungarian except Hungarians and the students know it."
English is compulsory in the first year, with 10 hours of instruction a week. After that students can keep up the pace or reduce to five hours. A handful of business-oriented students are taking Russian voluntarily after years when it was compulsory and unpopular.
Since attending the school requires not only brains but some money, most of the students come from Budapest's affluent families. Many have traveled abroad and some drive to school in the second or third family car from homes in the Buda Hills.
But wealth aside, the interests of the students reflect changing Hungary. School has suddenly become more crucial in a competitive society that no longer guarantees a job.
Economics, the underlying theme of the school, has replaced engineering as the course most likely to insure a successful career.
Andras Danko, 18, said he planned to be a "businessman," a word used across Eastern Europe to convey a focus on making money. Asked what he meant, Mr. Danko replied, "I would like to work with an international company and then own my own company." To accomplish this, Mr. Danko is taking advanced English -- he is fluent -- five hours of economics a week and nine hours of mathematics.
 
Adjustment Problems
 Since most of the students are academically talented, what seems to impress them most is the atmosphere. "It's like university -- you come to class when you feel like it," said Andrew Bognan, 17.
In a society in transit from the conformist standards of the Communists to the more freewheeling style of the West, some of the students may find it hard to adjust after graduation. "The students are more open and independent than the average and at the same time they have less tolerance for the formal life outside the school," said Mr. Horn.
"So they may have more conflicts outside the school. But one thing is certain: they love to come here."

HEADLINE: California Schools Vying for New Students Under a State Plan for Open Enrollments

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The television ad for the high school promotes the computer labs, the caring teachers and the ethnic mix of students.
The school is not a private academy; it is Lincoln High School in downtown Los Angeles. And the advertisement is the most immediate response to California's new open-enrollment policy in its public schools. 
"The parents are out there shopping, and I didn't want to take any chances," said Lupe Lopez-Sonnie, the principal of Lincoln, which has lost about 400 students -- and $4,600 per pupil in state aid -- in the last few years. "I wanted to market our school as best as I could."
So the school produced a 30-second ad that appears on the district's public-access channel. It ends with the words on the screen, "Lincoln High is the place to be."
 
Voter Complaints
 At least 22 California schools have employed some form of advertising. In the San Fernando Valley, teachers at Grant High School in Van Nuys raised $400 to buy a newspaper ad to lure up to 300 new students to replace those whose families were driven out of the area by the recession or who had gone to private schools. The ad shows a Grant High cheerleader beside the message, "Why pay $12,000, when you can get the same, plus much more, for FREE?"
The Legislature passed the open-enrollment law last year in response to voter complaints about the declining state of public education and to the momentum, at the time, for a voucher system that would have given parents $2,600 per child to send their children to the school of their choice -- public or private. The referendum on vouchers was defeated in November, four months after the Legislature passed the open-enrollment law that will take effect this fall.
The law allows parents to send their children to any public school within their school district, space permitting. The new program, the most sweeping choice plan in the country, affecting 5.7 million children, is being watched by school districts nationwide as parents clamor for more control over where their children attend school, the operation of the schools and the quality of the education that their children receive.
In Long Beach, Maria Palma, a Nicaraguan immigrant who cleans houses for a living, said that she would now be able to send her son, Alex, to first grade at the school that her sister's children attend in another part of town. "It seems to do a better job than the school he is attending now, and for my part I think it is good that we as parents are given a choice," she said as she helped Alex with his kindergarten homework.
School officials say the policy will allow the best schools to toot their own horns and, they hope, prod mediocre or poor schools to improve.
"In the past, we have had a regular clientele, if you will," said Larry Higgins, principal of Canoga Park High School. "Now we have to get out in the forefront, let the public know what we can do."
In many California school districts, some form of open enrollment already exists -- often through magnet schools or busing for desegregation.
But because of the scale of this plan, which could affect every public-school student in the city, Los Angeles school officials say they do not know what to expect. "Some, all, a few or none of the students in our district will take advantage of this," said Dale Braun of the Los Angeles Unified School District, the nation's second-largest district, after New York, with 640,000 students.
The district has been saddled with problems of overcrowding, violence and poor test scores that have led to battles over how best to improve student achievement.
Last week , the district began taking applications for the 22,000 open spaces in 366 of its 650 schools. If a school gets more applications than it has spaces after all neighborhood students are served, officials must hold a random drawing to determine which new applicants to admit. There are no academic criteria.
Some critics say open enrollment alone will do little to change the composition of schools -- let alone the quality of education -- especially since the law does not provide for transportation costs for students to attend a distant school.
"It may offer hope to some inner-city kid that he can go to school somewhere else to get a better education, but most people won't be able to afford to do that," said John Perez, a vice president of the United Teachers of Los Angeles. He predicted most people would continue sending their children to schools near home.
Proponents of choice have long theorized that competition for students -- and the fear of losing enrollment and money -- would force schools to improve. But as the enrollment period begins, some school officials say they feel little pressure to change.
 
Too Poor to Be Affected
 Alphonse Edwards, principal of 112th Street Elementary School in the Watts section of Los Angeles, said he had made little effort to let parents know that he has about 19 open seats. He said he thought his area was too poor to be affected by competition for students. This is more likely in richer areas, like parts of the San Fernando area northwest of downtown Los Angeles, where public schools are losing students to private schools.
"I doubt that this will help anyone but a small percentage of parents who can afford the transportation," Mr. Edwards said.
Open enrollment could also make a difference at schools in which enrollment has been eroded by a combination of factors, from natural disasters to the state's sluggish economy.
At Taft High School in Los Angeles' San Fernando Valley, enrollment is at 2,400, from a high of 3,000 a few years ago. The earthquake in January, which was centered nearby, drove out many families or made transportation difficult for students who were driving from far away under the district's transfer plan to relieve overcrowding. The school had already lost some students whose parents worked for the depressed aerospace industry and had to move.
The principal, Ron Berz, said word of mouth about the school's accomplishments, including its high test scores and two victories in the National Academic Decathalon, had attracted 200 applicants.
Mike Roos, a former state assemblyman and the leader of a reform movement for the Los Angeles schools called Learn, said the usefulness of open enrollment would not be seen for several years.
"The more that we get into the analysis of the movement of children within the district," he said, "the more we'll find out which schools are doing well and why, and which are doing poorly and need fundamental reorganization."
Open enrollment, he said, will do nothing absent other improvements. "If anyone believes all you have to do is institute choice and you've made great educational advancements," he said, "they're dead wrong."

HEADLINE: Rise in Key Futures Index Fuels Inflation Debate

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
With the financial world attuned as perhaps never before to any sign of faster inflation, the commodity futures index popularly known as the C.R.B. suddenly took center stage this week by posting its biggest rise in nearly a year.
The index, formally known as the Knight-Ridder Commodity Research Bureau's Futures Price Index, follows 21 commodities, such as cocoa, orange juice, lumber and pork bellies, and is updated every 15 seconds on computer screens. 
 A surge on Monday, which lifted the index to its highest point since October 1990, spooked the securities markets, driving interest rates up and stock prices down.
 
Dominated by Grains
 But like the Dow Jones industrial average for stocks, the C.R.B., the most widely followed commodity index, is probably not the best gauge of overall price trends, at least not of the course of future inflation, according to market analysts.
"It's very much dominated by the grains," said Elliott Platt, chief economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "That makes it very misleading."
Agricultural items are highly dependent on the vagaries of weather, which means not only that they tend to be highly erratic, but that they are largely beyond the influence of the Federal Reserve and other policymakers.
Indeed, the gauge fell back today as soybeans and cocoa reversed direction.
Nor is Robert W. Hafer, the Chicago-based bureau's director of research, yet concerned about the recent behavior of the C.R.B., which he noted was up only about 3 percent so far this year and 20 percent above its lows of early 1993.
"We don't see any real bells or whistles going off here," Mr. Hafer said. In fact, he added, "It's still very possible the index is in a down trend, as it has been since 1980."
Yet while there is no reason to panic, many analysts said, the rise in the C.R.B. -- though not uncommon at a time of year when crops are just starting to take root -- should not be dismissed.
Mr. Hafer and others point not only to what they say is its solid history as a predictor of inflation but also to the fact that other commodity indexes are pointing generally in the same direction.
"We expect inflation to start going up late this year," said Anirvan Banerji, research economist at the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University. He predicted that consumer prices would rise 3 to 4 percent in 1995; they have risen only 2.4 percent for the 12 months ending in April.
"It's the unanimity that is compelling," Mr. Banerji said, referring to the fact that the C.R.B. and other indexes are showing increases not only of significant magnitude but of duration and scope as well.
This includes the 18-item industrial price index compiled by The Journal of Commerce, which is also owned by Knight-Ridder. The calculations for this index are done by the Columbia center.
The Journal's index, which has no food components, has risen every month since December and reached a new high this week.
Many economists, in fact, favor this barometer for predicting inflation even though it measures spot prices, not the price of items for delivery in the future, as does the C.R.B.
The dominance of the C.R.B. owes much to the fact that since 1986 it has been the subject of a futures contract itself -- traded in New York -- and because it is available on computer screens throughout the financial community.
The Journal of Commerce index, by contrast, is calculated only once a day and is not available until the following morning's newspaper.
The two indexes typically move in tandem, their followers note, though the C.R.B. sounded what many regard as a false alarm last summer when its farm components were driven higher by flooding in the Midwest and drought in the Southeast.
"Both of them are reasonable indicators of inflation" trends, Mr. Banerji said. "The broad cyclical moves are similar."
But he and others contend that the Journal of Commerce index, though confined to spot conditions, is a superior predictor to the C.R.B. futures index since its prices, including those used in manufacturing and construction, are more likely to be passed along the production chain than are prices of, say, soybean meal or wheat. Indeed, wages and other costs of labor are far more important to the inflation rate than any commodity price, economists said.
 
'An Accurate Representation'
 There is also no reason to assume that people who trade futures have better information than those who trade spot commodities, analysts said.
Nonetheless, Mr. Hafer said, the C.R.B. has an impressive record.
"The index is an accurate representation of the overall price trend," he said, adding that a 10 percent rise, which is what has occurred since last summer, typically implies a one point advance in the Consumer Price Index about one year later.
Mr. Platt, however, has just concluded some research that he said casts doubt on any such link. He said he could find no relationship, when food and energy are excluded, between prices of raw materials and those charged by producers for finished goods, much less with retail prices.
"Wages are much more significant," he said.
For those who care to look for an alternative, the Columbia researchers have created their own predictive index of inflation, which includes the Journal of Commerce index as one of its seven elements. The others are import prices, debt, the employment-population ratio, the proportion of businesses expecting higher selling prices and what purchasing managers say about delivery times and prices.
Mr. Banerji said he expected inflation "to start going up late this year."
Mr. Hafer, whose index appears to be causing the most market distress, is perhaps as hopeful as any that the expected rise in inflation will not be serious.
"This still could be just another minor blip," he declared.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Widely as U.S. And Japan Agree to Talks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen and most other major currencies yesterday after the United States and Japan agreed to resume formal trade negotiations.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said negotiators would begin talks today under guidelines aimed at increasing Japanese imports of American products and services. The breakthrough came after four days of meetings in Washington. 
 With progress on trade, the Clinton Administration is considered less likely to call for a strong yen to curb Japan's trade surplus with the United States, a strategy, whether real or imagined, that has caused the dollar to fall sharply against the yen.
"There's less risk that the dollar will go lower" now that trade talks are under way, said Chris Widness, international economist at Chemical Bank. "We're very close to a bottom."
 
Market Assimilated News
 The dollar was quoted at 104.72 yen, up from 104.40 on Monday. It failed to rise further in part because press leaks Monday said negotiators would agree to restart talks, bracing traders for yesterday's announcement.
Gains in the stock and bond markets helped the dollar strengthen against the mark. It rose to 1.6552 marks from 1.6435.
Speculation that the White House would resume calls for a strong yen is one of many reasons traders cite for the dollar's 6.5 percent decline against the yen and 5 percent slump against the mark so far this year. A flight from American assets and concern about President Clinton's leadership also weighed on the American currency.
The dollar tumbled more than 5 percent against the yen on Feb. 14 alone after trade talks with Japan collapsed unexpectedly. The dollar has a far better chance to rebound now that talks are back on track, traders say.
"This is a good first step," said Peter Gloyne, manager of institutional foreign-exchange trading at First National Bank of Chicago. "They still have a lot of work to do."
Traders say the dollar will not make big gains against the yen until Japan shrinks its trade surplus with the United States.
Elsewhere, the British pound was last quoted at $1.5058, down from $1.5075 in New York on Monday. The dollar rose to 5.6630 French francs from 5.6245 francs. It rose to 1.4145 Swiss francs from 1.4045 francs. The dollar rose to 1,598 Italian lire from 1,589 lire. The Canadian dollar fell to 72.53 United States cents, from 72.69 cents on Monday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Rise, Ending a 2-Day Slide

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, ending a two-day skid, following the first decline in commodity prices in five days. A steady dollar also helped to support bonds as the United States and Japan agreed to resume trade talks.
The closely watched 30-year bond rose 14/32 , to 8613/32 , for a yield of 7.39 percent, down from 7.43 percent on Monday. In today's trading, the bond recouped less than a quarter of its losses from the previous two days. 
 Peter Hirsch, managing director and head of the government trading desk for Salomon Brothers, said that soybean and grain prices fell as the Midwest received rain, with more rainfall predicted next week. Other commodity prices fell along with the grains, helping to push the Commodity Research Bureau index down 3.67, to 234.69. "As a result, buying interest in Treasuries picked up as investor fears of inflation were dampened," Mr. Hirsch said.
 
 
 
Highest Yield Since '91
 Traders were cautious ahead of yesterday's $17 billion Treasury auction of two-year notes, which produced a high yield of 5.94 percent -- the highest yield since October 1991, when it was 6.01 percent. Economists had expected the auction to produce good results because the Federal Reserve is not expected to increase short-term interest rates again soon after raising rates four times in four months. This stable environment makes the two-year note an attractive investment.
While the yield awarded was slightly higher than expected, some traders, like Peter Hirsch, said it was a good auction. Others would say only that it was not terrible. Mr. Hirsch said "some market expectations were incredibly unrealistic" as to where the two-year notes should trade.
In response to higher yields, noncompetitive bids, a gauge of small investors' interest, were quite strong. The $1.42 billion of these bids that were made yesterday eclipsed the $1.39 billion of the previous month's auction.
The Treasury will auction $11 billion of five-year notes today. In when-issued trading yesterday, the five-year maturity was being offered at a price to yield 6.75 percent, a slight improvement from the previous day.
With no important economic data released yesterday, bonds were susceptible to anything that might hint at inflation, with commodity prices and the dollar providing the direction.
The dollar ended slightly higher against the Japanese yen on news that the United States and Japan would resume trade talks, helping to keep bond prices on the positive side. Bond traders fear a weak dollar because it causes import prices to rise, possibly spurring inflation. The dollar also moved up a bit against the German mark.
 
 
 
Chicago Skyway Bonds

 
 Among the new municipal paper issued yesterday, the City of Chicago sold $102.4 million of Skyway toll bridge refunding revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.
The issue was initially priced to yield a maximum 7.15 percent for a bond due in 2017. The city is also offering a yield of 7 percent for a bond due in 2010 and 7.05 percent for a bond due in 2014. The bonds are rated Baa by Moody's Investors Service, BBB- by Standard & Poor's and BBB by Fitch.
Among corporate issuers, Money Store Inc., a consumer and commercial loan company, priced $350 million of triple-A-rated certificates backed by home equity loans through a group of underwriters led by Prudential Securities.
The sale included $96.1 million of certificates with an average life of one year, which were priced to yield 6.06 percent. Another $88.9 million of certificates with a two-year average were priced to yield 6.67 percent. For $70 million of certificates with a three-year average life, the yield is 7.035 percent, and for $50.3 million with an average life of 5.9 years it is 7.637 percent. Finally, $44.3 million of certificates with a 10-year avergae life were priced to yield 8.025 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Industry Is Learning to Love Agility

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LANSDALE, Pa.

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company's electronic components plant here is a complicated place, producing 124,000 engine controllers, anti-lock brake sensors and speed-control units a day. Since each product has 400 to 500 parts, managers have to keep track of more than five million individual pieces daily.
Nevertheless, Dudley C. Wass, the plant's manager, says that when an order to change a product is received, the altered units usually can be shipped within 24 hours. 
 The reason is that the two-year-old plant has been designed with a high level of flexible automation, extensive computer controls and lean inventories in an effort to emphasize fast response time.
"We are more of a software business than hardware," Richard A. Chow-Wah, an engineer at the plant, said. "When we get changes, the software allows us to accommodate it."
Mr. Wass and his associates say they are trying to become "agile" manufacturers -- able to switch quickly and economically from one product to another with very little disruption. They are also working to establish closer relationships with suppliers and customers in an effort to react more quickly to shifts in markets.
It is a philosophy that is being acted upon throughout Ford, which intends to rely heavily on its international computer networks to combine its North American and European automotive operations into a single organization by the end of this year.
Such an approach, being adopted by a growing number of corporations, is a change from the old mass production model that sought to reduce costs by carefully tuning a process and then churning out products in large numbers. That time-honored technique -- elevated to an industrial art form by Ford Motor's founder, Henry Ford -- reduced the amount of fixed cost in each copy of the product. But it also tied up a lot of resources in inventory and partly finished products and made it less likely that defects would be found before a large volume of production was affected.
Making extensive use of bar-code technology to label and track virtually every circuit board, and relying heavily on computerized equipment that can be reprogrammed on the fly, factory managers like Mr. Wass are able to pare inventories, reduce turnaround times and respond more quickly to customer demands.
"Our model is the cheetah," Mr. Wass said. "We want to be able to stop on a dime, direct all our energy toward a goal, turn quickly and accelerate rapidly."
The approach is meeting with favor in the higher ranks at Ford. "The plant is on the leading edge; it's one of our best," said Charles W. Szuluk, the company's vice president for process leadership. He said the Lansdale plant's ability to respond quickly to customers allowed it to bid for added business and its ability to manufacture different products on the same assembly line reduced investment requirements.
The concept of agile manufacturing has been taking shape in industrial America as companies struggle to compete with foreign producers, particularly in areas like electronics. Although there are no statistics on how many companies are adopting agile ways, the approach has the enthusiastic backing of the Government. The Defense Department recently sought bids for $30 million in projects incorporating agile manufacturing.
Unlike traditional manufacturers, with their hierarchical management and emphasis on sheer output, agile companies stress sharing of information and power across the organization, alliances with suppliers and customers, and fast responses to changing market conditions. Engineers at Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., can put design changes into a computer system, then send the information electronically to production plants like the one here in Lansdale.
Some researchers of industrial organizations say that this new agility may lead to "virtual" enterprises, in which several companies come together to make a specific product for a certain length of time, and then dissolve as the participants go on to other projects. The central concept is that each organization would do what it does best, with one company designing the product, another manufacturing it and others handling marketing and sales.
An early version of this approach, researchers say, is the new Boeing airliner, the 777. Boeing designs, assembles and markets the aircraft, but for the most part does not manufacture it. Instead, an international network of suppliers actually makes most of the components, including some of the plane's basic structure.
Although the Boeing confederation is intended to be a temporary alliance, it will probably last longer than many formal mergers since the airplane is likely to remain in production for 30 years.
The key to agility, researchers say, is the ability to quickly respond to changing customer tastes, without regard to the number of products to be made. "We are going from the era of mass production to the era of mass customization," said Roger N. Nagel, operations director of the Iacocca Institute, a research center at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa.
The institute, named after Lee A. Iacocca, the former chairman of the Chrysler Corporation who helped raise the money to establish it, is also home of the Agile Manufacturing Enterprise Forum. The forum, which seeks to spread information about agile techniques, was organized with the support of the Defense Department, which was concerned that a deterioration of the domestic manufacturing base would leave the nation incapable of meeting military needs.
Indeed, with the cold war over, many of the institutions that helped fight it are turning their attention to competitiveness in manufacturing.
"The fact is that a real war, a global economic war, continues, and our national security is still at risk," said Albert Narath, the president of the federally financed Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M. With demand for its principal product -- nuclear bombs -- waning, leaders at Sandia and at other Government laboratories are trying to redefine their mission as helping American manufacturers become more agile and competitive.
Just about everyone connected with agility says that information -- especially the rapid collection, processing and transfer of it -- is central to the concept. Mr. Nagel observed that supermarket scanners were developed to speed up the checkout line. But the real value, he said, has been the ability of supermarket managers to monitor sales patterns and automate the reordering of products as they are sold.
 
A Different Application
 At the Ford factory in Lansdale, such technology enables Mr. Wass and his colleagues to apply supermarket efficiencies to the making of electronic car parts. Each circuit board in the plant is given its own serial number on a bar-code label. Since the boards are the heart of the engine controllers and other control devices, the data from the labels give managers information on each product as it moves through the plant.
If a product defect is discovered in the field, there is an electronic audit trail to help trace the flaw back to the precise spot in the production process where the error exists.
Computer screens are plentiful on the floor of the sprawling one-story Lansdale plant so that the 2,300 workers can keep track of product changes and production problems. "Too often, information is aimed solely at managers," Mr. Wass said. "Now, we're aiming it at operators so they will have it at their fingertips."
This approach to information also helps close the communications gaps that can develop in a plant with round-the-clock shifts. "If an operator solves a problem and enters the information, then the next shift knows what was done," Mr. Wass said.
In contrast to the hierarchical approach of mass production, the workers here are put in teams of 8 to 10 people, each responsible for an area of the plant. In one area, the amount of partly completed product was reduced 73 percent and scrap was cut 90 percent within three months, Mr. Chow-Wah said.
 
Working With Suppliers
 Lean inventories and quick changeovers require dependable supplies. Once again, information is being used as a tool to manage relationships with the plant's suppliers. "We issue a monthly report card to suppliers listing quality rejects, conformance with schedule and overshipments," Mr. Wass said. "It puts our relationship with them on an objective basis."
Mr. Wass said the plant's various agility techniques had wrought measurable improvements. In January 1991 an average of 7.8 days elapsed between receipt of an order and the shipment of the finished product. By last December that average had been cut to 1.2 days.
This year's goal, Mr. Wass said, is to cut that response time to a single day. Each improvement, he said, translates into much smaller inventories and much more responsiveness to customers. "If you have eight days of stuff," Mr. Wass said, "that means it is going to take eight days to make a change."

HEADLINE: Stocks Post Slight Gains; Dow Up 2.76

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders, taking their cue from a brighter bond market and a better outlook for commodities prices, bid stock prices upward yesterday in below-normal trading.
But the rise in the stock market was anemic, a fact that could be traced to the fluky performance recently of an index that tracks commodities prices and is looked to as an indicator of inflation. 
 The index, known as the Commodities Research Bureau futures price index, shot up Monday and the Dow Jones industrial average and other stock indexes fell. But yesterday the index broke its five-day climb to a three-and-a-half-year high, declining 3.67 points, to 234.69.
"You see, nothing fundamental has changed in the value of commodities," said David D. Holt, vice president-research and strategy of Wedbush Morgan Securities in Los Angeles. The bureau index, he said, is rising and falling because of short-term strategies by commodities traders, not because it is signaling higher inflation.
Blue chips like Merck and I.B.M., conglomerates like General Electric and banks like Norwest, as well as technology stocks like Microsoft and Intel all contributed to the market rise
Moreover, at a cable-television industry convention, the head of the Federal Communications Commission, Reed E. Hundt, seemed to indicate that the agency would consider softening Government cutbacks in cable rates that the industry has blamed for hurting profits and slowing growth.
 
Cable Rate-Cut Hopes
 Even a hint of a softened cable rate cut lifted the prices of cable operators. Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, rose 1 1/2, to 20 1/2, and was the second-most-active stock yesterday at 6.8 million shares. Time Warner, the No.2 cable company, rose 1 3/8, to 39 1/4.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.76 points, to 3,745.17, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.61 points, to 454.81. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 6.52 points, to 731.47.
One reason behind yesterday's fall in the Commodity Research Bureau index may be as random as the weather. Futures prices for soybeans and soybean oil, major components in the recent bureau rise, declined as rain began to fall in the Midwest and more rain was forecast for next week, possibly indicating a plentiful crop. The bureau index had largely risen because of the prospect of scarce soybeans and other agricultural commodities, like coffee and cocoa.
Another reason may be commodities traders' intense speculation in the movement of the 21 commodities of the index, especially soybeans. If commodities prices rise, then traders who had bet on prices falling by selling short are forced to buy shares to repay loans, prompting artificial spikes in price. That is probably what has happened recently to contribute to the jump in the index, said Mr. Holt of Wedbush Morgan.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal, with 280.2 million shares changing hands, about 7 percent below this year's average of 301 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.62 point, to 251.40, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,243 to 908. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.54 points, to 439.18.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 18 rose, led by I.B.M., which rose 1 3/8, to 63 1/8, following traders' expectations of more I.B.M. personal-computer sales.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 256 rose, led by General Electric, which rose 1/2, to 47 1/2, on no discernible news. (Stock prices sometimes move for reasons related to individual portfolio managers' priorities rather than external news events.)
The most active stock, at 7.8 million shares, was Merck , which rose 5/8, to 30 7/8. The rise followed news that Martin Wygod, who merged his Medco Containment Services into Merck in a huge merger earlier this year, was leaving the company. Analysts said his resignation might simplify choosing a successor to Roy Vagelos, chairman, this week.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Enzyme By Genzyme Is Approved

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The Genzyme Corporation said yesterday that it had won Food and Drug Administration approval to start marketing a genetically engineered enzyme to treat Gaucher's disease, a debilitating and sometimes fatal genetic disorder that afflicts about 5,000 people in the world at any given time.
To be sold under the trade name Cerezyme, the drug was developed to overcome supply constraints of Genzyme's Ceredase, a natural form of the enzyme extracted from human placentas, which had been the only effective treatment for Gaucher's disease. Genzyme has found that at current dosages, it can make only enough Ceredase to supply about 1,200 patients. 
 People with Gaucher's disease lack an enzyme that removes certain fatty substances from the body. Symptoms include easy bleeding and bruising, spleen and liver enlargement and deterioration of bones, leading to frequent fractures. If the disease is detected early enough, treatment with Ceredase or Cerezyme appears to eliminate the symptoms, with no significant side effects.
Genzyme, which derives nearly all its earnings from Ceredase, received the approval after the market closed. Its shares rose 50 cents, to $29.50, in Nasdaq trading. Analysts said that the approval had been anticipated and that Genzyme's stock would probably rise today.
"The company has been giving us guidance of earnings in the $1.45-to-$1.50 range for this year, and they needed this approval to make those numbers," said Carol Werther, an analyst with Cowen & Company.
 
Limited Production at First
 Although production will at first be limited to a small pilot plant, Cerezyme could ultimately have worldwide sales of $300 million, analysts said.
"It's not going to have a huge effect immediately because the commercial plant is not on line yet and won't be until mid-1995," said Edmund Debler, an analyst with Mehta & Isaly. "But they probably will be able to manufacture a decent amount in the pilot plant, which could add $15 million to $20 million to 1994 sales" in addition to the $130 million in Ceredase sales.
At an average cost of $150,000 for a year's supply, Ceredase is the most expensive drug sold in the United States; the price reflects the complex process needed to extract the enzyme from human placentas. About 96 percent of Gaucher's patients are covered by insurance, which pays for the drug; Genzyme supplies Ceredase free for the remaining 4 percent. Initially, the cost of Cerezyme will be the same, because the manufacturing cost at the pilot plant remains high.
"Once we have the new plant running and approved, we will start to see some economies of scale," the chairman, president and chief executive of Genzyme, Henri Termeer, said in a telephone interview. Then, he said, "we can start to pass on some of these economies to the marketplace while at the same time improving the financial results of the company."
Dr. Termeer said that he expected Cerezyme to replace Ceredase in the market but that the transition would not be immediate. The company needs approvals to market Cerezyme in Europe and Japan, where it now sells Ceredase.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Dell Computer's Earnings Climb Strongly in Quarter

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The Dell Computer Corporation reported quarterly earnings yesterday that were surprisingly strong, nearly doubling despite a $26.3 million charge for losses on bad financial investments.
Investors focused on the improvement in operating profits, which were well above analysts' estimates, and were relieved that its losses on financial derivatives and other investments were not higher. Last month, Dell said that it would lose money on its investments, but did not estimate how much the loss might be. 
 The Austin, Tex., personal computer company's stock price rose $3 yesterday to close at $29 a share.
Dell's sales for its first fiscal quarter, ended May 1, increased 14 percent, to $766.6 million, from the earlier quarter. Its operating income -- before taxes, interest and the special charges -- jumped to $60 million, from $14.1 million the year before.
The company's net income, because of the charges, rose much less, to $19 million, or 42 cents a share. In the quarter a year earlier, the company reported net profits of $10.2 million, or 25 cents a share.
Analysts closely watch small movements in the gross profit margins for companies in the personal computer industry, which can be particularly significant in this high-volume, low-margin business. In its first quarter, Dell's gross profit margins as a percentage of sales rose to 22.2 percent, up 3.6 percent from the fourth quarter.
"That is substantially higher than we expected," Thomas Meredith, the company's chief financial officer, said in an interview.
Mr. Meredith attributed the better-than-expected profit margins to three factors: higher sales of powerful new machines that use the Intel Corporation's Pentium microchip, a more tailored marketing program, and a more efficient system of buying components from suppliers.
For example, as part of a cost-cutting effort, Dell has trimmed its list of component suppliers from 130 to 80. As a result, Mr. Meredith explained, the company tends to buy more from each supplier, giving it more clout to bargain for better prices.
Like several other companies, Dell placed bets in the financial markets earlier this year that interest rates would hold steady or decline. And Dell, like others, guessed wrong, losing substantially when interest rates rose.
Dell reported that it took a $15.6 million charge in the quarter on its interest-rate derivative instruments. Derivatives are investments whose value is derived from an underlying security such as stocks, bonds or currency. The company also took a $10.7 million charge for losses on other investments .
"In retrospect, we made a mistake," Mr. Meredith said. As a matter of policy, he added that Dell would no longer invest in derivatives, except to hedge interest-rate risk on its own debt.

HEADLINE: European Inflation Rate

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 24

 BODY:
The European Union's annualized inflation rate was 3.2 percent in April, unchanged from March and down slightly from 3.4 percent a year earlier, the statistical office Eurostat said today. Figures showed that inflation last month was lower than in April 1993 in all countries except Denmark, Britain, the Netherlands and Spain. The European rate compares with 2.4 percent in the United States and with seven-tenths of 1 percent in Japan.

HEADLINE: Rome Has a Show Of Stolen Artworks To Highlight a Fight

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
High up in the dank interior of Castel Sant'Angelo, just below the parapet from which Tosca leaped to her death, a curiously eclectic art exhibition is on view until June 15. Called "Treasures From the Darkness," it consists of stolen artworks that were recovered by the Italian police.
No certified masterpieces are on display. About the closest the exhibition comes to a well-known artist's name is an 18th-century scene of the Piazza San Marco in Venice "attributed to the school of Canaletto." 
 But that doesn't mean what's on view is negligible. There is Classical statuary, pottery and coins; religious sculptures in wood, bronze and marble, and paintings from the Middle Ages to the 19th century. Each work comes with an attribution and helpful information on when and where it was stolen and on its recovery.
This exhibition and others like it, such as one presented recently at the Ministry of Culture in Paris, call attention to the problem of art theft worldwide and especially in Italy, which is so rich in its archeological and artistic patrimony. They also call attention to the increasingly refined technologies used by Interpol and specialized art-recovery police divisions in some countries.
The Rome exhibition calls particular attention to the carabinieri division for the recovery of stolen art, which helped organize it and which early in May held a two-day conference of officials from 16 countries to discuss progress in the continuing battle.
 
Mafia Enters the Market
 The conference was in the stately halls of the Carabinieri Officers' School here, full of earnest cadets and officers dressed in their ornately festooned black uniforms. If the uniforms looked to non-Italian eyes like costumes for a comic operetta, the agenda was deadly serious.
Italian police experts discussed the gravity of the art-theft situation, especially in Italy. One, Giuseppe Amato, suggested that the Mafia had become involved in the traffic, using stolen art as a safe investment, as payment for drugs or to launder money. Mr. Amato said the Mafia could either buy stolen art or organize the thefts itself.
Mark Fionda, who is in the United States Customs fraud division in Manhattan, and other foreign representatives reported on their art-recovery operations. In Eastern Europe, where an anarchic economy has made art theft particularly virulent, the police are especially hampered by legal and bureaucratic muddles. Alberto Soldani from Poland said that his unit was frustrated by the refusal of regional officials to cede authority in such cases to his national agency in Warsaw.
Col. Roberto Conforti, who has headed the Italian art-recovery division for three years, initially organized the conference to discuss problems posed by the opening of the European Community's internal borders last year. "We must counteract this problem with higher technical responses," he said in an interview. He added that he hoped the conference would be held annually.
 
The New Approaches
 His main plea was for more cooperation between national police agencies both in the European Community and outside it. He said this could come in part from increased compliance with European Community laws and Unesco conventions on stemming the flow of stolen art. But it could also involve increased use of computer technology.
Already his Italian division has a growing data bank of descriptions and photographs of stolen artworks. Other countries are following suit, and the eventual goal is to create a Europe-wide or even fully international data bank beyond those already maintained by Interpol and such private agencies as the Art Loss Register in London.
One new device, flashily presented at the conference with diagrams and films by Bull, a computer company, is a hand-held camera that can photograph a suspect artwork (on sale in a gallery, for instance) and transmit the image by cellular telephone to a data bank for nearly instant identification. Colonel Conforti said Italian law permitted the immediate seizure of any stolen artwork so identified.
To combat such technologies, thieves have grown increasingly aggressive in altering stolen art. Their painted overlays can often be removed, Colonel Conforti said. "The worst is when they cut things up to make more items to sell," he added.
 
The Size of the Problem
 Given the loopholes in the laws, the porousness of borders and the incentives to steal, fighting this kind of crime might seem nearly impossible. The conference was told that 29,000 artworks were stolen in Italy in 1993 and only 5,500 were found. Famous pictures are still stolen from leading museums, as witness the February theft of "The Scream," by Edvard Munch, from the National Art Museum in Oslo and its recovery on May 7. Annually, some $10 billion worth of fine art is stolen worldwide, not including looted archeological sites. Only 10 to 15 percent is recovered.
The situation in Italy is unsettled at the moment. Alberto Ronchey, who has been widely credited with the increased effectiveness of Italian measures against art theft while he was the Minister of Cultural Artifacts and the Environment, has been replaced by Domenico Fisichella, a member of the neo-Fascist National Alliance. Indeed, Mr. Ronchey's closing address at the carabinieri conference, in which he warned of the need to enlist "the big markets to the north" in the fight against international art smuggling, was one of his final official acts.
Colonel Conforti said after the conference that the recession had a mixed impact on art theft in Italy. The rise in unemployment encouraged such relatively petty theft as the stripping of provincial churches. But the collapse of the big-time art market, which he gloomily called "just temporary," may have led to a decline in highly visible thefts from major museums.
To the extent that there has been such a decline, however, Colonel Conforti was unwilling to credit mere economic factors.
"Better security and police work have affected this kind of theft as well," he said proudly.
