HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
DEERE & CO. (DE,N)

 BODY:
Shares of Deere & Company jumped by $2 in early trading yesterday after it reported earnings for its second quarter ending April 30 that were well above Wall Street's projections. The stock then slumped to end the day down $2.375, to $71.625, as investors worried about the company's cautious projections for growth.
Deere's reported earnings of $2.20 a share were substantially above Wall Street's consensus estimate of $1.95, and the company projected that worldwide production in 1994 would exceed last year's level by 16 percent -- up from the 13 percent it had previously announced. But Deere, a farm, lawn and garden and construction equipment maker based in Moline, Ill., also noted that production during the second half of this year would be down 3 percent from the first half because of normal vacations and the introduction of a new tractor line. 
 In a conference call with analysts, Deere suggested that margins and sales might not grow as fast in 1995 as some had projected. With investors already worried that rising interest rates could hurt cyclical companies like Deere, the warnings were enough to cause several analysts to adjust their projections down and initiate a selloff.

HEADLINE: Commissioner Under Fire Over Job Cuts

 BODY:
In a contentious budget hearing at City Hall, Marva L. Hammons, the commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, was berated by City Council members yesterday for being unable to specify what effects the city's proposed budget cuts would have on social services.
Under the plans of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Ms. Hammons's department will lose 4,305 of its 23,343 workers. Although administration officials have pledged that the cuts would not affect caseworkers, they have not said specifically which jobs would be eliminated. 
 And yesterday, two weeks after Mr. Giuliani released his budget, Ms. Hammons was unable to delineate the positions the agency was prepared to lose.
"This is what you're supposed to know," said Stephen DiBrienza, chairman of the council's committee on general welfare, who was cheered by agency employees in the chamber's gallery.
Ms. Hammons insisted that while the personnel cuts might have a short-term impact on the $7 billion agency's ability to deliver services, streamlining the bureaucracy that includes public assistance, foster care, child development and home care would eventually allow the agency to be more economically efficient and more responsive to clients.
But Mr. DiBrienza insisted that loading extra work onto the shoulders of fewer workers "flies in the face of any sense of understanding."
"You're going to end up doing less with less," he said.

HEADLINE: Trade, the Real Engine of Democracy

BYLINE: By Bill Bradley; Bill Bradley, a Democrat, is senior Senator from New Jersey.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The mandatory linkage between trade privileges and human rights is obsolete. President Clinton and Congress need to replace this cold war relic with a new approach that broadly engages China on human rights while promoting our strategic and economic interests.
U.S.-China relations are shackled by the linkage, which embodies two aspects of old-think that should join the era that spawned them on the dust heap of history. 
 First, the yearly "most favored nation" requirement -- for waivers from high U.S. tariffs on imports from Communist countries -- dates from the bygone era of U.S.-Soviet competition. Under the 1974 Jackson-Vanik Amendment, China may retain lower tariffs only if the President certifies that such benefits facilitate emigration. (China's current trade benefits expire July 3 unless Mr. Clinton announces by June 3 that he intends to extend them.)
Second, the new conditions for an extension that Mr. Clinton set last year -- such as adherence to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and protection of Tibet's cultural heritage -- originated in Congressional opposition to George Bush's precipitous re-engagement with Beijing after the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989. These and the other demands are legitimate, but they can't be achieved by the linkage policy.
Even partial revocation of trade benefits, which the Administration is said to be considering, would not work. For example, targeting goods produced by military-owned factories would invite retaliation against our exports and antagonize a key actor in China's succession struggle without advancing human rights.
Our task is to foster the emergence of a responsible, outward-looking China as a force for stability in Asia. We cannot do so if we hold the U.S.-China relationship hostage to an annual "most favored nation" review.
America's interests require a multifaceted engagement with China. With its nuclear arsenal, growing military strength, unresolved border issues and permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council, China must be reckoned with. America's strategic agenda in Asia (such as controlling North Korean nuclear proliferation) requires cooperation with China.
With a large economy that is growing by more than 10 percent a year, China is an engine for global growth. Our exports to China rose more than 18 percent last year and have tripled in the last decade. America companies have committed billions of dollars in investment.
Obviously, we have a strong interest in improving the lives of China's 1.2 billion people. Today's linkage between trade benefits and human rights is simply too narrow to do the job. To be truly effective, our human rights policy must go hand in hand with the forces of economic growth that are remaking China: information, investment and goods, which are flowing in and out of China in an unprecedented volume.
Beijing's centralized control over the provinces has loosened. The rigor of law is slowly replacing the whim of the Communist Party in many economic sectors. Individuals now have personal freedom that, while inadequate, is unparalleled in modern Chinese history.
The first element of an effective human rights policy lies in further increasing China's exposure to the outside world. Beijing has agreed to discuss the jamming of our radio broadcasts; we must use those discussions to insist upon meaningful expansion of unjammed Voice of America and Radio Free Asia programs. We should also increase the number of educational and cultural exchanges that expose young Chinese to our multi-ethnic democracy.
The second element is an expansion of trade, which is is the motive for China's opening outward. I support China's membership in the World Trade Organization, which will be the successor of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Membership would require adherence to legal standards. For example, Beijing would have to accept dispute-resolution procedures and disclose rules governing state enterprises.
Growth alone will not democratize China. But it does create a fluid political and social environment and the emergence of a class of prosperous Chinese -- all of which fuel democratization and improved human rights practices. Evidence from South Korea, Taiwan and elsewhere shows that prosperity breaks down old controls and generates demands for improved political and social conditions.
A third feature of a beneficial human rights policy is genuine dialogue on human rights. All too often, the U.S.-China "dialogue" consists of American officials' presenting their Chinese counterparts with a list of demands. China responds that Western human rights standards are not applicable in Asia. The result: an empty exchange of monologues.
The alternative is a genuine exchange of views. While we will not agree that human rights are relative, we can listen to the Chinese with the aim of finding common ground on which to build. For example, helping the Government strengthen the rule of law will advance human rights by reducing arbitrary interference with people's lives, while also improving Beijing's ability to govern a vast and diverse country.
Fourth, as we wait for Mao Zedong's Long March generation to leave the scene, we must continue our efforts to protect individual dissidents by raising their cases at every opportunity. Once we are talking effectively with the Chinese, appeals on behalf of such dissidents will have a greater impact.
There are many ways to institutionalize this dialogue -- for example, by creating a binational human rights commission or exchanging parliamentary delegations to investigate human rights practices, as China now does with Australia. (Yes, the Chinese would be free to come to the U.S. for this purpose.) Once the Chinese stop viewing human rights as a weapon deployed against them, they will be willing to have a systematic dialogue.
 Fifth, China's craving for international legitimacy gives us additional leverage. We must make it clear thatso long as China does not uphold basic human rights standards, we will continue to work to deny China such symbols of legitimacy as playing host to the Olympics and international meetings.
Sixth, we must ask business to help by supporting voluntary ethical investor principles as part of an Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum investment code. I have in mind adherence to such principles as safe working conditions and a prohibition against the export of goods produced by forced labor.
To revoke or place conditions on China's trade status would be a historic blunder. Unlike 1949, when America could ignore Red China, in the Asia of 1994 we would isolate ourselves from the world's most dynamic region. The cold war is over. Let us delink most-favored-nation status from human rights and begin to realize the full potential of the U.S.-China relationship.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 468 words

HEADLINE: Must Phone Rates Block Information Highway?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"In Twist, Consumer Group and F.C.C. Back Cable TV" (Business Day, May 12) reports that cable television companies argue that "phone companies are trying to finance their ventures at the expense of ordinary phone customers, who may end up with higher bills and services they may not want." This argument constitutes a serious challenge to those of us calling for a long-range goal of expanded universal service. 
 Cable companies and others would have us believe that the Administration's interim goal for the information highway -- advanced telecommunication services to public institutions such as schools, clinics and libraries -- is sufficient, while for the home this same goal would be utopian. What this argument ignores:
* Until citizens are aware of the potential of the new technology to improve their daily lives, they will assume that these technologies are only useful for someone else.
* People are already paying more than we acknowledge. Many critics use today's telephone rates only as the basis for affordability. However, the new technologies will replace the television and videocassette recorder, as well as the telephone. They may even substitute for the radio, newspapers or magazines, providing services very different from anything we can now imagine.
Therefore, the real basis of comparison should not be just a household's telephone bill but its entire information budget -- nearly $80 for many, including low-income families.
Ironically, those most unaware of the potential benefits are often those who stand to gain most from their widespead introduction. As to their not needing these services, ask the rural diabetic whose life was saved by a doctor 60 miles away through telemedicine, or ask the young woman from West Virginia who was accepted to a college based on classes she took by television from a teacher more than 200 miles away.
The information highway derives much of its value from ubiquity. Connecting everyone enriches all our lives. We should not allow concern for keeping telephone service rates low to deflect us from the important goal of insuring that all Americans have access to a new form of universal service -- one that provides benefits to individuals and to society that will be much greater than the costs.
We must adopt a goal that insures every citizen the benefits of the information highway, including two-way video communication to the home. Otherwise, we will condemn our country to a double standard: those who have full access to the economic and social life of the nation, and those who can only have access when public facilities are open. Can we bear this cost?
 
SUSAN G. HADDEN
Professor of Public Policy
Lyndon B. Johnson School of
Public Affairs, University of Texas
Austin, Tex., May 18, 1994

HEADLINE: The Tramp Dined Out To Wind Up in Jail Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Thief Dines Out, Hoping Later to Eat In" (front page, May 19): Gangaram Mahes's ordering of expensive restaurant meals -- which he cannot pay for -- to have himself arrested and put in prison, may be a case of life imitating art. In "Modern Times," Charlie Chaplin's classic 1936 satire, the Tramp uses the same means to get jailed and escape a world of unemployment, poverty and urban chaos. Has so little changed in 60 years?
 
JONATHAN D. REICHMAN

HEADLINE: CLINTON REJECTS PENALIZING CHINA

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to extend China's trade privileges even though the country has not made as much progress on human rights as the United States had hoped for, senior Administration officials said today.
They said Mr. Clinton, who will announce the decision as early as Thursday, will not impose sweeping tariffs on goods made by China's military. Such a move had been recommended by a number of influential Democratic lawmakers. 
 Rather, Mr. Clinton will either extend the trade benefits with no strings attached or impose only minimal, largely symbolic duties, perhaps on such items as Chinese-made weapons and ammunition, they said.
Mr. Clinton told aides today that he had not made a final decision about whether to impose any penalties on China, the largest emerging market in the world. He was said to be debating in his own mind whether it is wiser to make a clean break with the strategy that rewards China's progress on human rights with the same low tariffs on Chinese exports that most other countries enjoy.
Given Mr. Clinton's tendency for last-minute hesitation, aides said there was a possibility that the announcement could be delayed. Under his 1993 executive order that links human rights and trade benefits, he could wait until June 3 to announce his decision.
There is no joy at the White House about the impending announcement. Officials know that commentators and human-rights organizations are poised to point out the yawning gap between Mr. Clinton's campaign language on China, in which he excoriated the Bush Administration for "coddling" dictators in Beijing, and his decision to abandon his own strategy to push China to do more.
Last year, when Mr. Clinton announced his executive order, it was widely praised by lawmakers, China experts and even human-rights advocates as a brilliant compromise that acknowledged the concerns of Congress on human rights but deferred any punishment of China for a year.
 
Shift in Congress
 But the mood of Congress has shifted dramatically in favor of "delinking" human rights and low tariffs, and the substance of Mr. Clinton's emerging policy now seems very close to that of the Bush Administration: a determination that human-rights concerns should not be the arbiter of United States-China relations and a recognition that the United States has much broader security interests with China.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher has made that point in a series of meetings with Mr. Clinton this week, including private conversations on Tuesday and today.
Mr. Clinton is also poised to announce a series of steps that he now believes would provide better tools for influencing China on human-rights issues.
To that end, he is expected to announce the creation of an advisory committee that will try to find ways to improve China's human rights record, senior officials said. The committee will be composed of Administration officials, business and labor leaders and human rights advocates.
The Administration abandoned the idea of creating a joint human rights commission with the Chinese Government. During the Bush Administration, the Chinese flatly rejected a similar proposal, and senior Administration experts on China and on human rights were concerned that China would either reject the idea again or agree to a commission and then simply refuse to cooperate.
Mr. Clinton framed the basis for his decision after a meeting at the White House on Monday, in which Mr. Christopher stated that China had met the two mandatory conditions for renewing its "most favored nation" status. Those are cooperation on ending the export of prison-made goods to the United States and allowing close family members of certain dissidents to leave the country.
At a meeting of Mr. Clinton's senior national security and economic advisers on Tuesday, Mr. Christopher suggested that there might be some symbolic punishment of China, senior Administration officials said. He listed two options: placing high tariffs on weapons and ammunition exported to the United States or on some of the goods that could clearly be defined as military-made.
Senior Administration officials have told diplomats and lawmakers that Mr. Christopher will in effect tailor his recommendation on a course of action to Mr. Clinton's wishes, and that "there will be no daylight" between the recommendation and Mr. Clinton's final decision.
The Administration rejected the imposition of high tariffs on all goods made by the Chinese military for both technical and strategic reasons.
The Customs Service, among other agencies, argued that the military makes a number of consumer items -- from clothing to toys -- that are also made by private businesses in China and that such sanctions would inevitably punish the wrong people.
More important, China specialists in the State Department, Pentagon and Central Intelligence Agency argued that it would be counterproductive to single out China's military for punishment.
 
Help on Korean Situation
 These officials argued that the military must be wooed, not alienated, particularly during the crucial time in which the future of China's leadership is unknown and in which the United States needs China's help in preventing a crisis with North Korea over its nuclear program.
In his discussions with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Christopher also laid out the progress and the slippage in five other human rights areas covered by the executive order where the Administration wanted the Chinese to make "overall, significant progress."
He said that China had released some important political prisoners, but that others remained behind bars; that the International Committee of the Red Cross had begun discussions with China on visiting Chinese prisons, but that the visits had not yet begun; that Foreign Minister Qian Qichen had made a statement expressing the importance of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, but that China was still violating it; that China had opened talks with the United States on the jamming of the Voice of America, but that it had not stopped the interference.
Finally, Mr. Christopher indicated that China was continuing to improve the economy of Tibet and was restoring an important monastery, but had taken no concrete steps to open discussions with the Dalai Lama.

HEADLINE: Republicans and Conservatives Solidify Efforts Against Cuomo

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
New York Republicans cemented a potentially vital alliance with the Conservative Party yesterday to rally behind one candidate, George E. Pataki, to challenge the three-term Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, this fall.
In a muscular display of old-fashioned ticket-balancing, the Republicans completed their three-day convention in Manhattan by endorsing for comptroller a Conservative favorite, Herbert London, the New York University economics professor. The convention had resoundingly rejected Mr. London two days earlier for governor when it instead chose Mr. Pataki, a 48-year-old State Senator. 
 Mr. London had vowed to press ahead as a candidate for governor, a strategy that would have split the votes of conservative New Yorkers and aided Mr. Cuomo's campaign.
Earlier this week Mr. London had derided Mr. Pataki as "the last choice of Al D'Amato," the Republican Senator from New York, and said, "The simple truth is George Pataki has not earned his place in this campaign." But Mr. London was persuaded yesterday to withdraw from the gubernatorial race for another spot on the Republican ticket, and Assemblyman John J. Faso, the front-runner for comptroller, was prevailed upon to step aside for Mr. London.
"If I ran on the Conservative line and it generated even half a million votes, it would have insured Mario Cuomo's re-election, and that I could not countenance," Mr. London said yesterday. He said that in deciding to run on a ticket with Mr. Pataki, he had "put my ego aside to do what's best for the party."
Running four years ago as a Conservative, Mr. London almost outpolled the Republican nominee for governor, Pierre Rinfret. Mr. Cuomo was re-elected in 1990 with 2.2 million votes on the Democratic and Liberal lines, to 865,000 for Mr. Rinfret and 827,000 for Mr. London.
At a breakfast yesterday, even before Mr. London was endorsed, Mr. Pataki said, "The Conservatives should be very happy with the ticket they got." He quoted Michael Long, the Conservative Party state chairman, as saying the party's goal last year in fielding a candidate against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani "was to make a philosophical statement -- this year it's to defeat Cuomo."
The compromise endorsement of Mr. London also averted a showdown with Mr. Giuliani, a Republican who had all but threatened to boycott the ticket if his party sacrificed Assemblyman Faso and instead designated George J. Marlin of Queens, who was Mr. Giuliani's Conservative rival in last year's mayoral race.
Fashioning a ticket that Republicans and Conservatives could embrace represented a political and personal triumph for the Republican state chairman, William D. Powers, and his mentor, Senator D'Amato.
"This makes the parties come together," said Mr. Long, whose Conservative Party convenes next week to, in effect, ratify most or all of the Republican ticket.
But Senator Pataki still faces the prospect of a primary challenge from Richard M. Rosenbaum, the former state Republican chairman from Rochester, who served under the last Republican Governor, Nelson A. Rockefeller. It would be the party's first gubernatorial primary contest in 12 years.
Mr. Rosenbaum said last night that a Republican-Conservative alliance in a state where Democrats have the edge in enrollment is "a recipe for losing" and said of Mr. Pataki, "I don't see him as a moderate at all."
Two candidates who were swamped by Mr. Pataki when the convention voted on Monday, Bill Green, a former Congressman from Manhattan, and Evan G. Galbraith, a former Ambassador to France, have not ruled out primary campaigns, too.
 
A 'Stature Gap'
 Should he win the Sept. 13 primary, Mr. Pataki would have to surmount what Dr. Lee M. Miringoff of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion characterized yesterday as a "stature gap" with Mr. Cuomo. "I don't think people are angry with Cuomo," he said. "I think they're fatigued."
The official party ticket, still subject to challenge by other candidates who choose the petition route to the primary ballot, also includes Elizabeth P. McCaughey (pronounced Muh-COY), a 45-year-old Manhattan academician, for lieutenant governor; Bernadette Castro of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., the 49-year-old businesswoman whose name has been linked since childhood with her family's convertible furniture, for United States Senator, and Dennis C. Vacco, a 41-year-old former Federal prosecutor from Buffalo, for attorney general.
Mr. Vacco said yesterday that while he, like Mr. London, was personally opposed to abortion -- government financing for it, in particular -- he would as attorney general enforce the law. As United States Attorney in Buffalo, he had been criticized by a Federal judge for his handling of the criminal-contempt case against anti-abortion protesters from Operation Rescue.
Asked whether he would withhold Medicaid funds for abortions by invoking his authority to sign state checks, Mr. London said, "I don't believe that's within my authority."
Mr. Pataki describes himself as an unequivocal supporter of a woman's right to abortion, but critics recall his opposition to Medicaid-financed abortion and his support for requirements that teen-agers notify their parents before having an abortion.
The Democrats, who will convene next week, are certain to endorse Mr. Cuomo and his Lieutenant Governor, Stan Lundine; United States Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Comptroller H. Carl McCall. A three-way primary looms for attorney general among the interim incumbent, G. Oliver Koppell; Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, and Karen Burstein, who resigned as a Family Court judge to run.
 
Breakdown of Ticket
 The Republican ticket completed yesterday includes only one upstater (Mr. Vacco) and two women (Ms. McCaughey and Ms. Castro) -- all of whom are neophytes in electoral politics -- but is heavily weighted toward farmers and their offspring (Mr. Pataki, Ms. Castro and Mr. Vacco). Mr. Pataki, Ms. Castro and Mr. Vacco are Roman Catholics; Ms. McCaughey is Episcopalian; Mr. London is Jewish.
Earlier yesterday, party leaders assured a unanimous endorsement for attorney general when they nudged out Joseph Holland, a Harlem businessman, who had impressed many Republicans as a promising candidate or political appointee. Mr. Vacco was designated as the party's official candidate by acclamation.
But after hours of closed-door persuasion, a motion to endorse Mr. London by acclamation was greeted with a chorus of nays nearly as loud as the ayes. Mr. Powers proclaimed Mr. London endorsed by acclamation anyway and he was joined on the stage of the Sheraton New York by Mr. Faso -- who had been campaigning for nearly a year and had come to the convention with a majority of state committee votes committed.
"He has the heart of this convention," Frances Werner, the Queens Republican chairwoman, said earlier of Mr. Faso as Mr. Powers conferred with Faso supporters in a third-floor conference room at the hotel. "They're taking leaders in to twist their arms."
 
'A Single Purpose'
 And they were successful. Flanked by his family, Mr. Faso announced that he had been persuaded by Mr. Pataki to withdraw because "there is a single purpose that must unite us: for the good of the people of this state, we must defeat Mario Cuomo."
Mr. Faso made clear that he, like Mr. Giuliani, had balked at the prospect that the convention would endorse Mr. Marlin in his place to appease the Conservatives. But he said the goal of defeating Mr. Cuomo, coupled with Conservative Party commitments to ratify the Republican ticket pieced together yesterday, were "more important than the fate of one Assemblyman."
At City Hall Mr. Giuliani warned, "If they consider Marlin, what the Republican Party is saying is that it is no longer a Republican Party, that you can run against the party, you can try to destroy the chance to have a Republican mayor, that you can run a largely negative, nasty campaign and then the party is going to reward you by either giving you a nomination or a part of a nomination."

For Comptroller

Background: Graduated from Columbia University and received a doctoral degree from New York University. In 1967 joined the history faculty of New York University and later helped create the Gallatin Division, dedicated to the study of great books. Now the John P. Olin Professor of Humanities at the university.
 
Political Involvement: Briefly a Republican candidate for Mayor of New York City in 1989. Made a strong third-place finish on the Conservative Party line in the 1990 gubernatorial race and immediately began campaigning for the 1994 race for governor.

HEADLINE: Clinton Agrees to Welfare Financing

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
After months of struggling over how to finance his welfare proposal, President Clinton has decided to spend about $9.3 billion over five years, with about $7 billion of that coming from cuts in other social programs, Administration officials said today.
Most of the remaining money would come from the corporate environmental income tax, which is currently devoted to the Superfund program. Officials called the move an accounting measure that would not reduce the amount actually spent on environmental clean-up, because the program is accruing more than it is allowed to spend. But environmental groups criticized the action, saying the tax money should be used to expand environmental programs. 
 Mr. Clinton's decisions all but conclude months of debate among his aides over how to fulfill one of his central campaign pledges. Mr. Clinton repeatedly promised in 1992 to "end welfare as we know it" by expanding the training available to parents on welfare but making those still unemployed after two years join a work program.
The drafting of the plan, however, has been complicated by political balancing acts concerning its timing and financing. Mr. Clinton put welfare on a slow track to keep it from conflicting with health care, which must travel through the same Congressional committees.
 
A Deadline Looms
 And, the White House found itself torn between the desire to put forth a expansive plan and the political price of raising taxes or cutting other programs to pay for it. The Administration considered dozens of possible tax increases or program cuts, but rejected them, sometimes after lobbying onslaughts from well-heeled interest groups.
The gambling lobby fought off a possible excise tax, for instance, and the insurance lobby staved off a measure that would have limited the amount of money affluent people placed in tax-deferred anuities. In the end, the President decided that most of the money would be raised by reducing existing programs for low-income people.
Administration officials had known that about $1.9 billion in paper savings were available from the Superfund program, but some had argued for using them to finance the proposed new accord under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. By allocating the money for welfare, the Administration must now find a new source of trade money.
The decision to seek a $9.3 billion package was a disappointment for some Government officials and advocates, who had hoped for a plan that would have spent as much as $16 billion over five years. Much of the additional money would have been spent on child care for low-income workers to reward them for staying off welfare.
Mr. Clinton's decisions came during a meeting on Tuesday where he also agreed to let states deny additional money to welfare recipients who give birth to additional children while on the rolls.
Supporters, including some Democrats, argue it will force parents to take responsibility for their behavior.
But the option was vigorously opposed by many church and advocacy groups. Some of Mr. Clinton's own aides warned him last week in a confidential memorandum that there was "little evidence" the move would deter births and that it might be seen as "penalizing children for the transgressions of the parents."
The memorandum did not advocate a position but summarized the arguments for and against. Aides said Mr. Clinton largely based his own decision on his belief in giving the states flexibility. He would allow, but not require, states to withhold additional payments. Several states, including New Jersey, already do so under experimental programs.
Mr. Clinton also discussed, but did not resolve, a second issue: what happens to families who spend several years in the work program, but still cannot find private jobs?
Can they re-enroll indefinitely, as long as they are willing to work? Or can states end assistance, leaving families with neither welfare nor the work program's minimum-wage pay?
Those who oppose limits on the work program argue that some families may never find private jobs, no matter how hard they try.
Leaving those families with neither welfare nor the work program could force them into homelessness, they say. But the supporters of limits fear the President will be accused of a costly guarantee of lifetime employment.
The memorandum to Mr. Clinton warned of the political stakes. Even modest limits on the work program could "drive some Democrats away," it said. But it also noted that, to other Democrats, "the rhetoric of 'ending welfare' requires some sort of ultimate end."
Mr. Clinton has already decided what would happen to families who after two years of training refuse to join the work program. They would receive no further money.
Mr. Clinton's plan would raise about $3.5 billion by cutting payments to elderly immigrants under the Supplemental Security Income program.
Current law makes immigrants wait five years before applying for the program, unless their sponsoring family is indigent. The move would make immigrants wait 10 years. The plan would also raise about $1.5 billion by cutting disability payments to people collecting them because of drug or alcohol addictions. It would put a limit of three years on the payments. It would raise about $1.8 billion by capping the emergency assitance program, which helps families in distress, and about $500 million by cutting food subsidies to day care programs run by private families.
Bill Roberts, legislative director of the Environmental Defense Fund, acknowledged the Superfund move would not reduce the $1.5 billion a year the program now spends, but said, "the money ought to be used to expand environmental programs."

HEADLINE: Clinton Stokes Party Fires For His Health Care Plan

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Conducting pep rallies with Democrats and taking the pulse of Senate Republicans, President Clinton promised Congress today that he would keep pushing this year for passage of health care legislation that would provide insurance for every American.
The tone in the closed door meetings switched back and forth, said those who took part. To the Republican senators, he stressed his readiness for compromise, so long as his basic goal of universal coverage was met. 
 Then, to the House Democrats, one lawmaker said, the President declared, "We can do it, but we have to fight."
And he and Vice President Al Gore said success on health care would be very important to the Democrats in the elections this fall.
Mr. Clinton sought repeatedly to dispel any idea that his enthusiasm for health care legislation was flagging. Even though all five Congressional committees with important roles on the bill will miss their self-imposed Memorial Day deadline for action, the President said he was pleased with the progress so far.
 
Republicans Voice Concerns
 In the meeting with three Democratic senators and six Republicans, Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, told Mr. Clinton that the Republicans would not support requiring employers to buy their workers' insurance. He said Democrats would have to decide whether they wanted to fight an election over the issue or to drop that demand to get legislation. Mr. Clinton did not respond. He did not answer most Republicans as they went around the room stating their concerns and hopes.
Nor did Mr. Clinton ever become involved with specific legislative detail, like how small an employer could be to avoid the obligation of buying insurance for workers.
But he told the Democratic leaders, "We are going to keep open, keep flexible, reach out to Republicans, do it this year and cover everybody."
And Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, the senior Republican on the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, said that when she asked Mr. Clinton to restate his principles, he told her, "First security -- that Americans will feel secure that they have health benefits, though everyone can differ on the size of it."
Then, she said later, he cited the importance of a system that would contain soaring costs and offer economies of scale to small business. And she said he had also cited the importance of reforming insurance law to eliminate the anomalies that now characterize health insurance practices.
The meeting with House Democrats was not dominated by talk of health care. The President and Mr. Gore cited a list of achievements and said Democrats could speak proudly of this Congress's record. But Mr. Gore warned much of that would be forgotten if health care failed.
"He gave a really fine pep talk," said Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, who is likely to become acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee if Representative Dan Rostenkowski is forced to step down because of the charges against him of misusing his office expense accounts. Earlier, among the leaders, Mr. Rostenkowski had assured Mr. Clinton that he would find the votes among Democrats to get a bill out of his committee.
Representative David Skaggs of Colorado called the session a "terrific pep talk" and said it was important because two recent special election losses had discouraged some Democrats.
 
No Sign of Despair
 Meeting with leaders, the President was cheered on by several lawmakers who said it was important for him to keep pressing for action and to show no sign of despair. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said that it was now both "High Noon" and "D-Day" for health care and that the President's leadership was vital.
Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, said it was "obvious, at least to me, that there is a growing desire to get something done, to reach a bipartisan agreement and to pass a bill." But, he noted, "the number of different views far exceeds the number of senators."
Earlier today the President's wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, said the Administration could accept some compromise under which big companies are required to buy insurance for their employees, while companies with fewer than workers would not have to. "It would depend upon the level of subsidy we were willing to provide to low-wage workers," she said. "It is certainly conceivable it could be done in a fair and cost-effective way."
While Mr. Clinton's proposal would require all employers to contribute to their workers' insurance costs, with subsidies for small companies, various proposals on Capitol Hill have gone further, especially those of Mr. Kennedy and Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who heads the House Energy and Commerce Committee.
In her speech before the International Women's Media Foundation today, Mrs. Clinton also denounced the news media for its reporting on health care, saying it was focused on political conflict over the bill.
She said the coverage "reminds me of a very unsatisfying argument in a schoolyard: 'Yes, you did.' 'No, I didn't.' 'Yes, you did.' 'No, I didn't,' " she said, mimicking childish voices. "And at the end of it, who knows who did or didn't."
 
Money for Research
 As for the Senate Labor Committee, which Mr. Kennedy heads, it continues to plow through his plan to modify President Clinton's proposal. Today, it adopted without change provisions that would provide more money than President Clinton had recommended for teaching hospitals and academic health centers and would allow Federal authorities to set limits on how many medical residencies could be in special fields as against primary care.
Mr. Kennedy's bill was hailed by Senator Barbara Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, who said that without extra help academic health centers "could be red-lined out of health care plans." Because of the extra costs of having the most up-to-date equipment and of training medical personnel, the rates at teaching hospitals have historically been higher than those of other hospitals. Insurance companies are increasingly unwilling to pay those higher charges and consequently send patients elsewhere.
Mr. Clinton's plan provided $40.2 billion over five years for these hospitals from special Medicare payments -- $6.3 billion more than they get now. Mr. Kennedy raised that by another $24.8 billion. The Kennedy bill also provided another $8 billion, beyond the President's proposal, for biomedical research grants through the National Institutes of Health, much of which goes to academic health centers.
On the other side of the Capitol, a subcommittee of the House Education and Labor Committee voted out an even more expansive modification of the Clinton bill, a generous measure intended to provide bargaining leverage against efforts in Congress to trim the plan.

HEADLINE: Russian Aide Says Gangsters Try to Steal Nuclear Material

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
A senior Russian law enforcement official said today that organized crime in Russia was trying to infiltrate military installations to steal nuclear material and sell it on the black market.
"These crime groups in recent years are demonstrating more and more interest toward the defense facilities of the former Soviet Union," Mikhail Yegorov, head of the organized crime control department of the Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs, said in an appearance before a Congressional committee. 
 Mr. Yegorov insisted that Russia's military bases were well guarded, but he acknowledged that 47 criminal investigations had been opened into attempts to steal radioactive materials.
But Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, provided a less reassuring picture.
Mr. Freeh told the Senate Government Affairs Committee that while the F.B.I. did not have any evidence to confirm reports that Russian criminals have stolen nuclear warheads or bomb-grade materials, Interpol, the international police agency, had reported the disappearance of two kilograms (4.4 pounds) of highly enriched uranium from an institution near St. Petersberg.
Mr. Freeh indicated that the report was being taken seriously and was under investigation. Six to 10 kilograms of highly enriched uranium are needed to make a small nuclear bomb.
More broadly, American officials are worried that the growth of organized crime in Russia and the fact that the Russian mafia has targeted military installations have greatly increased the risk of nuclear theft.
"We are gravely concerned Russian organized crime members may have already attained or will attain the capacity to steal nuclear weapons," Mr. Freeh said.
The Russian mafia's interest in nuclear materials is just one result of a crime wave that has occurred in Russia since the collapse of the former Soviet Union. Mr. Yegorov told the Senate panel that crime was endangering economic reforms in Russia and added that Russian criminals were beginning to make inroads in Europe and the United States.
"At the present time, organized crime is a real threat to the stability of the country's economic and social life," Mr. Yegorov said. "Up to 50 percent, in some cases, of the profits that these criminal organizations get they use to bribe official persons."
Russians officials say that organized crime existed under Soviet rule, mostly in black markets, but that it has flourished in recent years with the growth of a private economy.
Mr. Yegorov said that there were nearly 5,700 criminal groups in Russia with about 100,000 members, and that 101 Russian criminal organizations operate abroad, in 29 countries.
He said 183 Russian police officers were killed and over 800 wounded fighting in gun battles with organized crime last year.
Mr. Yegorov said that the Russian criminal organizations were involved in drug dealing, money laundering and other activities in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Miami, Chicago and New York.
And Mr. Freeh said Russian organized crime was linked to a $1 billion health care fraud case in Los Angeles. To work with Russia, the F.B.I. is setting up an office in Moscow.
He added that there were 47 Russian groups in Germany involved in extortion, fraud and economic crimes, and that more than 60 such groups operated in Italy.
Trying to defend Russian handling of the nuclear issue, Mr. Yegorov insisted that military installations had good security. He also detailed some of the attempted 47 thefts, saying the vast majority of them involved attempts to steal very small quantities of nuclear material or low-enriched uranium that were thwarted by the Russian authorities.
But he said nine of the cases involved allegations of attempted thefts of highly enriched uranium. He said one of those nine cases was linked to organized crime.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy to Haiti Sees Glaring Gap in Embargo

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 25

 BODY:
Surveying the border with the Dominican Republic this morning, the United States Ambassador to Haiti declared what has seemed obvious for many weeks to the reporters accompanying him.
"It looks like a staging area for some of the contraband coming across," the Ambassador, William L. Swing, said, lowering his binoculars. While the traffic in gasoline had stopped momentarily because of his visit, all around stood the clutter of a makeshift smugglers' city. 
 Even as Mr. Swing spoke, Haitian peasants who have been thwarting the international embargo against Haiti readied their containers -- everything from empty bleach bottles to large oil drums -- for a resumption of the trade once the diplomatic entourage moved on from the border observation point near the town of Malpasse.
For many Haitians frustrated with the failure of measures taken to force the military to relinquish power, the scene captured the problems the United States and the United Nations face in seeking to return the exiled Haitian President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power by shutting down the most impoverished economy in the Western Hemisphere.
 
Ship Runs the Blockade
 Even while an embargo on oil supplies was being broadened by the United Nations over the weekend, a seagoing tug chugged by American ships, ignoring their warning shots, hugging the coastline from the Dominican Republic and finally docking at Jacmel, a small Haitian port.
Whether by sea or by land, the Dominican Republic, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, has shown little inclination to help enforce the sanctions against Haiti.
Now, with the Dominican Republic also plunged in a political crisis because of allegations of fraud in recent national elections, many diplomats in both countries say there is little prospect of getting Haiti's neighbor to enforce an embargo across a snaking 270-mile land border and a coastline pocked with small coves and makeshift ports.
With President Clinton's special adviser for the Haitian crisis, William Gray, visiting the Dominican Republic today to urge President Joaquin Balaguer, a longtime enemy of Father Aristide, to stop the contraband, Mr. Swing expressed new confidence that things would change.
"He gave every indication that he wants to be cooperative," the American Ambassador said, referring to Mr. Balaguer, who narrowly won re-election in the contested Dominican vote.
But in recent days Haitian businessmen whose factories have been shut down by the new international ban on all exports from this country say they have received feelers from their Dominican counterparts indicating that far from cracking down on the violations, many in the Dominican Republic are seeking new ways to exploit what has become a highly lucrative situation.
"You have investors over there calling people here telling them that if they want to relocate their factories just across the border, they will allow our workers to come in every day and return home in the evening," declared a Haitian businessman here who said he had recently received such an offer.
In recent days, Dominican political leaders, including close advisers to the main opposition figure, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, have said that the unbridled violation of international sanctions prohibiting oil supplies, in place since last October, has resulted in the creation of an entrenched smuggler class in the Dominican Republic that includes many members of the military.
Although Mr. Pena Gomez has said publicly that his country should try to enforce the sanctions, his advisers are privately criticizing them as too little too late, and say that enforcement now by the Dominican Republic is a practical impossibility.
Haiti's military leaders appear confident they can withstand any measures short of a foreign intervention here. Haitian analysts and foreign diplomats say that the army has stockpiled large amounts of fuel in case its supplies are ever completely shut off.
After a Bahamian vessel ran the embargo, cruising past the warning shots of an American ship early on Saturday, a businessman here said he had received a telephone call from a Haitian military officer bragging of the exploit.
"You see how serious this embargo is," the officer said, chuckling as he concluded the conversation.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. to Freeze Assets
 WASHINGTON, May 25 (Reuters) -- The United States intends to freeze the assets of Haitian businessmen identified as backers of the military leaders, the State Department said today.
"We continue to work with the Treasury Department to define criteria for putting business executives who fall into the category of supporting the regime onto the assets freeze list," the department spokesman, Michael McCurry, said.
"The number of people now targeted on that list exceeds 600, and the names could include members of the business community as information on their activities accumulates," he said.
So far the freezing of assets is being applied only to Haiti's senior officer corps and their civilian allies in government.
Under an executive order issued by President Clinton on May 8, three categories of Haitians were made the targets of sanctions, including having their foreign bank assets frozen. The three groups are officers of the Haitian military and police and their families; people who played a major role in the 1991 military coup in Haiti and their families; and people employed by or acting on behalf of the Haitian military and their immediate families.
Mr. McCurry said that it was relatively easy to establish the identities of those in the first two groups, but that solid evidence was needed against individuals for them to be included in the third category.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Mark As Rates Increase in Europe

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday as traders sold dollars after a disappointing United States economic report and a rise in European interest rates.
Gold prices fell 50 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, where the June contract, the most active, settled at $386.80 an ounce. 
 A Commerce Department report on factory orders for big-ticket goods prompted an early selloff in the dollar. The report showed that durable goods orders edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in April, below most expectations. The selloff accelerated when interest rates rose in Europe, traders said. Stock prices also dropped sharply on many European exchanges.
 
'A Bond Market Meltdown'
 "There has been a bond market meltdown in Europe today, and the mark has become an attractive alternative," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics.
In periods of market turmoil, investors typically shift assets into what they see as a safe-haven currency. The dollar often benefits from such uncertainty, but yesterday the mark was the prime beneficiary.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6455 marks, down from 1.6560 on Tuesday. Earlier in London, it rose to 1.6465 marks, from 1.6530 on Tuesday.
Much of the rise in European interest rates was attributed to a growing perception that the German central bank would slow the pace of interest-rate reductions. That view was encouraged yesterday by a reduction of just 3 basis points in the German repurchase rate, to 5.20 percent. And a member of the Bundesbank's rate-setting council cautioned that the bank would have to move cautiously in making future rate reductions.
"I think the market is getting too worried about the short end and there are more cuts to come, but it's going to be at a slower pace," said Brian Hilliard, senior economist at Societe Generale Strauss Turnbull in London.
 
U.S.-Japan Trade Talks
 The dollar's decline against the yen was less pronounced, and some attributed it to optimism over the revival of trade negotiations between the United States and Japan.
"I think the trade talks are going to play an important role," said Stefan Carlsson, chief dealer at Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken. "Hopefully, we should see some progress."
On Tuesday, American and Japanese officials said they would end a three-month-long stalemate in trade negotiations aimed at reducing Japan's growing trade surplus.
The dollar fell to 104.40 yen, from 104.72 yen on Tuesday.
The British pound rose to $1.5085 in New York, from $1.5055 on Tuesday. In other trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4025 Swiss francs, down from 1.4145 on Tuesday; 5.6275 French francs, down from 5.6550; $1.3835 (Canadian), up from $1.3778, and 1,595 Italian lire, unchanged.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Sharply disagreeing with a Congressional study, the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, testified that new legislation was not necessary to supervise derivatives, the rapidly growing and sometimes profitable family of products offered by banks and brokerage firms to corporations and investors. [Page D1.]
Orders for durable factory goods edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in April, below most expectations, Commerce Department figures showed, more evidence of slowing business expansion. Separately, home resales climbed 1.2 percent. [D1.] 

Companies
Philip Morris said it would take no action for the moment on splitting its tobacco business off from food and beer operations. But the company made executive changes that prompted speculation that a split might still be in the offing. [D1.]
Sandoz executives said the Swiss company's purchase of Gerber Products is part of a strategy to expand its nutrition business globally while remaining a drug industry leader. [D1.]
Southern California Edison won clearance from regulators to pass costs of two nuclear plants on to its clients faster. [D5.]
A principal architect of Bell Atlantic's plunge into interactive television resigned, offering little explanation. [D5.]
Hewlett-Packard shares dipped after its executives told analysts the growth rate for orders and revenues would slow. [D5.]
National Airlines became the latest transportation brand to be revived, as a small Atlanta carrier began using the name. [D5.]
Kopin plans to open the nation's largest factory for production of flat-panel display screens. [D6.]
 
International
The travel industry, which has been slowly discovering Vietnam as a tourist destination over the last few years, is scrambling to cut more deals there since President Clinton lifted the American trade embargo in February. [D1.]
President Clinton has decided to extend China's trade privileges, even though the country has made less progress on human rights than the U.S. had hoped, Administration officials said. [A1.]
 The Venezuelan state of Lara may lack oil, but its diverse and growing manufacturing economy is charting a Venezuelan future that depends less on oil revenue. [D2.]
Trying to revive Russia's economy, President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a series of decrees that would cut taxes on foreign and Russian companies and end restrictions on exports. [D7.]
 
Markets
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly, reversing early losses. The turnaround came after a decline in a commodity price index and a solid Treasury auction. [D7.]
Stocks again followed the wobbly path of the bond market, which sank then rallied after demand for the Government's debt issues proved brisk. The Dow rose 10.13 points, to 3,755.30. [D8.]
The dollar ended lower against most leading currencies because of weaker-than-expected U.S. economic data and rising European interest rates. [D15.] Cattle futures prices fell to a nearly six-year low amid concerns about burdensome supplies. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Breaking With Tradition, Smithsonian Chooses Lawyer as Head

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
After a behind-the-scenes struggle involving Vice President Al Gore, the Smithsonian Institution has gone outside the scholarly world for its 10th leader, choosing a lawyer in the Clinton Administration.
The new secretary is I. Michael Heyman, a legal adviser to Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley. He was chosen by the Smithsonian's Board of Regents over Mr. Gore's candidate, Thomas Lovejoy, an environmental biologist who is the Smithsonian's assistant secretary for environmental and external affairs. 
 Mr. Heyman, 63, will be the first nonscientist to lead the institution in its 148-year history. He will succeed Robert McC. Adams, 67, who is retiring in September.
"Clearly there are a lot of daunting challenges with this wonderful place, not the least of them that we've got a resource problem that is significant," Mr. Heyman said today at a news conference, adding that he would try to balance the problems of raising money from the private sector "without giving away one's soul."
The Smithsonian's 17-member board had been expected to name Mr. Heyman on May 9, after a search committee had recommended him, but it postponed the announcement at the request of Mr. Gore, a board member by virtue of his office. The Vice President, in South Africa at the time, asked for the delay so he could continue to argue the case for Dr. Lovejoy, said officials familiar with the selection process who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 
Meeting in the Amazon
 Mr. Gore and Dr. Lovejoy became acquainted in January 1989, when Dr. Lovejoy led a Congressional delegation that included Mr. Gore to inspect reforestation in the Amazon region.
Despite his advocacy, Mr. Gore joined his fellow regents yesterday in endorsing Mr. Heyman.
Mr. Heyman will take over an institution that has expanded enormously in recent years. It operates 16 museums, the National Zoological Park and 11 research institutions on a budget of $445 million and has about 6,700 employees.
The deficit he must confront is a result of lower Federal contributions, decreased corporate donations and greater expenses. It is the first deficit in the Smithsonian's history and threatens to force layoffs.
The financial pressure prompted intense debate in the search committee about whether the new secretary should be a scholar or an administrator. Maxine Singer, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington and head of the Commission on the Future of the Smithsonian, had urged the committee to choose the former.
"The institution should be in the hands of someone with a vision," Ms. Singer said she told the committee. "You can always find a manager to run the day-to-day operation."
 
Criteria in Mind
 But Barber B. Conable Jr, a former World Bank president who led the search committee, disagreed. "We need someone who can run a very complex institution," said Mr. Conable, a former Republican Congressman from upstate New York. "There was some feeling in the committee that having a scientific background was not the most important qualification. Some felt it was more important for the person chosen to be able to relate to Congress and to deal with an institution of this size."
Mr. Heyman earned a bachelor's degree at Dartmouth College in 1951 and a law degree from Yale Law School in 1956. He was chief law clerk to Chief Justice Earl Warren from 1958 to 1959 and later taught law at Yale and Stanford Universities. He was Berkeley's vice chancellor in 1974-80 and chancellor in 1980-90.
Others on the search committee were William G. Bowen, president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation; Jeannine S. Clark, a Washington civic leader; Hanna H. Gray, a former president of the University of Chicago; and Wesley S. Williams Jr., a Washington lawyer.

HEADLINE: Stray Gunfire Kills Man in Bronx

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
A young Bronx man who was killed on a basketball court yesterday was the third victim of stray gunfire in New York City in a week, the police said. But despite the cluster of such shootings -- and the constant fear in some neighborhoods that an innocent stroll can lead a bystander into a deadly crossfire -- police statistics indicate that such random shootings have actually declined significantly in the last few years.
In a densely populated city where easy access to guns has reached down to schoolchildren, bystanders have been killed or wounded by bullets intended for others, or by shots fired randomly for target practice or fun. And the risk of such shootings rises as the weather turns warm and sends large groups of people milling in the streets, the experts say. 
 The most recent victim, David Echevarria, was part of a group of young men who played basketball around midnight in the University Heights section of the Bronx. Last night, hours after celebrating his 29th birthday, he waited inside a playground for the game to start when three men nearby started shooting at one another. A stray bullet struck Mr. Echevarria in the head, the police said, killing him on the spot.
But while random shootings became increasingly common in the 1980's, the number of bystanders shot in New York has fallen since 1991, when a spate of random shootings of children moved the Police Department to keep track of bystander shootings. The number of such shootings dropped from 535 in 1991 to 335 last year, the police say.
 
Rise in Semiautomatics
 The police and outside experts attribute the decline in part to a crackdown on drug dealers and the addition of about 6,000 police officers to the department since 1990.
Experts say the shooting of bystanders began climbing in the mid-1980's with the rise in popularity of semiautomatic handguns, which can hold many rounds of ammunition and fire rapidly. The crack epidemic fueled the explosion of semiautomatics as drug dealers became richer and began buying even more powerful weapons. Drug dealers began spraying gunfire into crowds, aiming at someone in particular but often hitting bystanders. Dealers called bystanders "mushrooms" that popped up and got in the way of a bullet.
During this period semiautomatic pistols became fashionable among teen-agers, as arrests of juveniles for homicide doubled between 1985 and 1989, said Lawrence Sherman, a professor of criminology at the University of Maryland. As a result, more guns were in the hands of inexperienced people who often shot bystanders accidentally or fired in the air to practice their aim.
"Since you have such a proliferation of weapons, you get people just target shooting to build proficiency," said Joseph E. Lovelock, deputy inspector of the Police Department's Office of Management Analysis and Planning. "So you have young men going on the roofs of projects shooting. They just let the shots go up in the air. Unfortunately, the bullets have to land somewhere, so you get innocent people getting shot."
Many bystanders are shot during holidays, like the Fourth of July and New Year's, Inspector Lovelock said, when people fire guns to celebrate. Also, the number of such incidents rises sharply during the summer when teen-agers are out of school and large groups of people gather on neigborhood streets, late in the night.
On Sunday, a young man firing shots in the air to celebrate the Knicks' playoff victory killed a woman who had gone to look outside the window of her third-floor apartment in Crown Heights. And on Tuesday, a 15-year-old girl, steps away from the entrance to Springfield Garden High School in Queens, was shot in the right temple by a 16-year-old youth who told the police he had been testing a new gun by firing it into the air. The girl was expected to lose the vision in her right eye.
 
High-Crime Areas
 In New York, bystander shootings are centered in high-crime areas like East New York or Bedford-Stuvesant where guns are plentiful, as well as in housing projects, said Inspector Lovelock.
The shooting of bystanders reached a peak in 1990 when a number of random shootings of children prompted Mayor David N. Dinkins to announce the "Safe Streets, Safe City" program, including a record expansion of the police force.
At the playground on 183d Street and Ryer Avenue in the Bronx where Mr. Echevarria's blood still stained the asphalt yesterday, Amparo Ramirez said: "There's no safe parks. They shoot every single night. By my house on Tiebout Avenue, they're always shooting."
Harvey Dudley, a 31-year-old unemployed construction worker who lives a few blocks from the site of the shooting, said frequent gunfire had made him afraid to go outside. "It's real scary," he said, "and a stray bullet don't know no name."

HEADLINE: A Region Without Oil Is Redefining Venezuela

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BARQUISIMETO, Venezuela

 BODY:
In the oil boom of the 1980's, the Venezuelan state of Lara was a slighted stepsister. Lara had no oil wells, no refineries, not even a petrochemical plant.
Without oil, workaday Lara trudged along -- growing potatoes, picking coffee, bottling beer, forging steel, exporting onions and assembling vacuum cleaners. 
 But today, Venezuela's oil income, compared with population, has dwindled to the lowest level since the 1950's. Though the country sits on the largest known sea of oil in the Americas, prices have fallen almost 40 percent in the last five years.
Business is instead looking to Lara's thriving, diversified economy as a model for a Venezuela after the oil era.
"We are getting a reverse flow -- professionals and laborers are now moving here from Caracas," said Rafael Marcial Garmendia, a local rancher who is president of Proinlara, a private-investment promotion service. "We don't depend on oil. We don't depend on the state. Over the last 20 years, we have had the fastest rate of industrial growth."
Growth has meant a new baseball stadium and modern buildings sprouting along spacious boulevards. A state capital with a suburban atmosphere, Barquisimeto frequently ranks in polls as Venezuelans' second-most-desired place to live -- after Puerto La Cruz, a Caribbean resort. Last year, Barquisimeto, a metropolitan area of more than 800,000, won a status symbol coveted by every Venezuelan city -- daily flights to Miami.
Barquisimeto has a higher income than the national average. With increasing frequency, this crossroads of agriculture and industry is being called "Venezuela's Chicago."
For the rest of the country, it remains hard to kick a decades-long dependency on oil. Venezuela, the largest supplier of oil to the United States after Saudi Arabia, was once described as a nation glued to an oil industry. The state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., is Latin America's largest company.
 
Broadened Tax Base
 As recently as five years ago, exports by Petroleos de Venezuela accounted for 82 percent of the national budget. This year, the Government expects oil to contribute 47 percent.
Partly because of this slipping revenue, the Venezuelan bolivar has lost about half its value in a month.
"For my generation, it will be the first time that we have seen oil fall below half of the national budget," Julio Sosa Rodriguez, the 70-year-old Treasury Minister, said in an interview in Caracas. "The most foolish thing of the last 20 years was to not diversify the economy."
Selling more oil for less money, Venezuela is seeing its other exports gradually rise -- from 20 percent of total exports in 1990 to an anticipated 30 percent this year. In 1992, for the first time in memory, other economic activity surpassed oil.
In a country where newspapers publish the previous day's oil prices on their front pages, a diversified economy is slowly taking shape.
"We have to abandon the oil-royalty model," said Adolfo R. Taylhardat, executive director of Conapri, a group that lobbies for improved investment conditions. "Previously, the only sector that had a policy was oil, and oil dragged along Venezuela."
Gold mining in the Venezuelan Amazon is attracting $1 billion in investments, largely from Canadian, South African and Venezuelan companies. By the end of the decade, the nation's annual gold exports are projected to increase tenfold, to $2 billion.
"Mining is going to be the next oil of Venezuela," predicted Gustavo Cisneros, president of a local group that is joining with South Africans to invest $100 million in a gold mine.
 
Other Industries
 Pulp and paper are attracting $1 billion in investment projects, largely from Colombian and United States companies. In telecommunications, a consortium led by GTE is investing $6 billion to modernize Venezuela's telephone company, Cantv.
Investment in tourism is expected to rise, too, with the Government planning to privatize eight hotels, three race tracks and an airline in the next year. Construction and repair of 14 highways is to be opened to bidding by foreign and domestic contractors.
Much of the new economic activity is centered in this vital region. Eighty percent of Venezuela's population is within four hours by truck from Lara, a farm state that has become a breadbasket for a country that once had to import eggs from Florida.
"A lot of Caracas companies are moving out here," said William T. Smith, general manager of Nabisco's Venezuelan subsidiary. In a three-year, $20 million program, Nabisco concentrated its 10 production lines in Barquisimeto, doubling capacity.
Easing the highs and lows in Venezuela's economy, industries are increasingly exporting to Colombia. Since the neighboring countries created a free-trade customs union in 1991, trade has quadrupled in this combined market of nearly 55 million people. By contrast, Venezuela has minimal commerce, and no air connections, with Guyana to the east.
"Companies are expanding here all the time," said Allan J. Robinson, a Briton, who is general manager of the Barquisimeto Hilton. "People may take a salary cut after Caracas, but they get a better quality of life -- less traffic, less crime."

HEADLINE: One Standard For Courses Is Presented

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines yesterday tried to bring order to what gets taught in New York City's 1,100 public schools, issuing a new 200-page curriculum guide that suggests minimum standards for what every student in each grade should learn.
The new document represents the first attempt to impose instructional standards across the city's public schools since William H. Maxwell, the first schools superintendent, ordered a similar curriculum guide for lower schools in 1903, Board of Education officials said. 
Mr. Cortines ordered the preparation of the curriculum guide last October, after he visited a series of schools in his first weeks as Chancellor and found that course offerings often varied radically among the city's 32 community school districts. Mr. Cortines asked the principals to "field test" the instructional outline in their schools next year.
The standards will become mandatory in fall 1995, Mr. Cortines said. But he acknowledged there was little he could do to force its use.
"This book will not be worth the paper it's printed on unless you make it your Bible," Mr. Cortines told the principals gathered in an auditorium at Manhattan's Fiorello La Guardia High School.
All of the city's nearly 1,100 principals were invited to yesterday's gathering. But only about 300 attended, pointing to the difficulty of coordinating any systemwide initiative.
In recent years, the only citywide curriculums that have been a focus of widespread debate have been two course guides, written at board headquarters in Brooklyn, both touching on sexuality: a multicultural guide, distributed in 1992, that in a few passages urged the teaching of tolerance for homosexuals, and an AIDS curriculum that some parents felt introduced sexual topics too early. The ensuing storm over the guides led to the ouster of Mr. Cortines's predecessor, Joseph A. Fernandez. Mr. Cortines's framework does not include the word AIDS until the sixth-grade health class outline. It does not discuss homosexuality.
The frameworks, distributed to principals yesterday in three-ring binders, were written by 300 teachers, parents, administrators, academics and businessmen, organized into seven working groups by Mr. Cortines. The curriculum guide draws from several sources, including voluntary standards written by national educational organizations under the Federal Goals 2000 legislation for improving schools and State Education Department curriculums.
The guide offers a page of guidelines for each grade level for nine courses: social studies, mathematics, science, English, languages other than English, health-physical education-home economics, performing arts, visual arts and occupational and technical studies.
The framework for ninth-grade social studies, for instance, says students will focus on Africa, South and Southeast Asia, East Asia, Latin America and the Middle East. It says students will "interpret geography-related data to hypothesize, predict, and draw conclusions about the impact of geography on the development" of those countries and will "demonstrate an understanding of the diverse economic systems and decision-making processes as they relate to the development of individual national economies."
 
Specific Guidelines
 The science framework offers similarly specific guidelines. Third-grade science students will, among other pursuits, "observe, describe and classify plants by their physical characteristics; conduct simple experiments to explore the properties of electrical energy; investigate the characteristics of vertebrates and invertebrates, and investigate and explain seasonal changes in different regions of the world."
The document is not as specific on other subjects. The mathematics framework, for instance, does not even state explicitly when students are to learn to add, subtract, multiply and divide. Since the English framework does not require study of any individual works of literature, it mostly offers vague recommendations, as for 10th-grade classes: "Students will independently read and enjoy complex texts in all genres on a wide range of subjects," it says.
Milton Fein, principal of Public School 7 in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx who was one of the 800 school leaders who did not respond to Mr. Cortines's invitation yesterday, sounded less than enthusiastic about the new document.
"I've been a principal for 24 years and we've seen curricula introduced from time to time," Mr. Fein said. "The best that you usually get is an outline of vague expections."
But several principals who traveled to La Guardia High School to hear Mr. Cortines, however, said they would begin using the guides to refocus their instructional programs. "This is a guide, a road map for education," said Carl Sanfilippo, principal at Intermediate School 259 in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. "For many years, we haven't had this kind of direction."
In fact, the city has not provided this kind of detail for all its schools since 1903, five years after the system's 1898 consolidation, when the Board of Education approved a 40-page document entitled "The Course of Study for the Elementary Schools of the City of New York," said Dr. Stephan F. Brumberg, an adviser to Mr. Cortines.
In the decades since, the State Education Department has provided a series of general curriculum guidelines, usually little more than a sentence or two of course description for all subjects and grades. Local districts have had the responsibility to build curriculums based on those descriptions.
