HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Derivatives Get a Key Supporter

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Strongly disagreeing with a new Congressional study, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, said today there was "negligible" risk that the rapidly growing market for financial derivatives might someday require a taxpayer bailout.
In testimony before a House subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan and other senior financial regulators said there was no need for new legislation to supervise derivatives. 
 Derivatives are highly profitable products offered by banks and brokerage firms to corporations and investors. They are contracts with cash values that are tied to, or "derived" from, the price of financial assets like stocks, bonds, commodities or currencies.
 
Variety of Uses
 Most often, derivatives are used by companies as a form of financial insurance; they can, for example, help protect against a decline in the dollar's value that would raise the cost of a company's imports. Derivatives can also be used by investors as a substitute for owning securities.
Several large companies recently reported losses from unusual derivative transactions that combined normal hedging of risks with speculative bets on interest rates.
Last week, the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, released a study that called for vastly expanded regulation of the dealers and users of derivatives. In particular, the G.A.O. called for much closer supervision of the derivatives activities of brokerage firms and insurance companies, which are not regulated as tightly as federally insured banks.
 
Fears of a Bailout
 The G.A.O. said that because derivatives activity was concentrated in a few big banks and brokerage firms, there was an increased possibility of a market crisis leading to a taxpayer-financed bailout that might have to be extended even to uninsured brokerage firms.
Mr. Greenspan challenged the G.A.O.'s assertion that the Government could be at financial risk. He noted that brokerage firms can borrow from the Federal Reserve's discount window in case of emergency but he emphasized that such loans are backed by collateral and, in his view, pose virtually no risk to the Government.
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan played down the risk of derivatives to commercial banks. "There is no presumption that the major thrust of derivatives activities is any riskier, indeed it may very well be less risky, than commercial lending," he said.
Mr. Greenspan argued repeatedly that additional Government regulation was not necessary because of "private regulation" by investors, credit rating agencies and others that insist on financial soundness in those with whom they do business.
 
Safeguards Are Seen
 "The G.A.O. report's concern that there are gaps in derivatives regulation is true only in the narrow sense that Government regulations or regulators are not in all cases involved," Mr. Greenspan said. "In a more important sense, today's markets and firms, especially those firms that deal in derivatives, are heavily regulated by private counterparties who, for self-protection, insist that dealers maintain adequate capital and liquidity."
Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the agency did not need additional powers to oversee the derivatives activities of affiliates of the brokerage firms it regulated. Still, under intense questioning from Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts, the chairman of the Telecommunications and Finance subcommittee, Mr. Levitt said the S.E.C. did not have the legal authority to compel these derivative dealers to submit to examination by regulators.
"If they wish to deny us information, they could do so," he said, although he noted that the agency had found no evidence of unsafe derivatives activities at brokerage firms.
Mr. Markey said he was worried that the S.E.C. was dependent on voluntary cooperation by the brokers. "Securities and insurance regulators have to rely on the kindness of strangers, like Blanche DuBois," he said, referring to the character in "A Streetcar Named Desire."
The regulators also rejected Mr. Markey's assertion that derivatives regulations should be made consistent for banks and brokerage firms.
 
Variations Are Noted
 "The markets are different," Mr. Levitt said. "The banking industry is protected by an insurance fund that guarantees its safety and soundness." Brokerage firms, by contrast, are regulated to prevent fraud and theft of securities from customer accounts, but they are regularly allowed to fail, he said.
Mr. Markey said he hoped to introduce and have passed in this Congressional session legislation that would expand regulation of derivatives. That goal may be made more difficult by the actions of Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the full Energy and Commerce Committee. Mr. Dingell today released letters that he had sent to Mr. Levitt and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen asking for formal comments on the G.A.O.'s recommendations.
Because Mr. Dingell gave the regulators 45 days for their reports, financial industry lobbyists suggested that the move would delay consideration of a derivatives bill until next year.
Mr. Markey said he would hold more hearings on derivatives, perhaps with testimony from some of the companies that have lost money using them.
 
Learning Lessons
 In today's hearing, Mr. Greenspan also argued that legislation was less needed now because in the last few years regulators had learned more about derivatives and how to press dealers to manage their risks better. "As far as the Federal Reserve Board is concerned, we feel we are ahead of the curve on this issue," he said.
Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency and the regulator of national banks, said that the 8 to 10 banks with the biggest derivatives activity were complying with new Government standards on risk management of derivatives. Still, there are 362 national banks involved with derivatives, and Mr. Ludwig said examiners had found defects in the procedures of some of the smaller ones.

HEADLINE: Party Chairman Attacks 4 Democrats Who Failed

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Stung by the loss of a House seat in Kentucky that had been held by Democrats for 129 years, the Democratic Party chairman today turned against his party's candidate as well as three others who have lost high-profile elections since 1992.
In a highly unusual breach of party decorum, David Wilhelm, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, leveled a harsh attack against the candidate in Kentucky, Joe Prather, saying that he waged "a lackadaisical campaign," was "caught flat-footed" and "explicitly refused Democratic Party help." 
 Though he had been so confident of victory that he had gone house hunting in Washington, Mr. Prather lost to Ron Lewis, a fundamentalist Christian minister, by 55 percent to 45 percent on Tuesday. The special election was to fill the seat held by Democrats since 1865, the last 41 of those years by Representative William H. Natcher, who died two months ago.
Seeking to follow in the tradition of Mr. Natcher, something of a political legend who spent virtually no money on his campaigns, Mr. Prather greatly limited donations and took no money from political action committees. Mr. Wilhelm said that Mr. Prather refused his "repeated offers of assistance." National Democratic organizations, he said, could have given more than $60,000 to help Mr. Prather.
 
Heavy Republican Spending
 The Republicans, by contrast, pumped thousands of dollars into the race, paying for television commercials that depicted Mr. Prather as a tax-and-spend clone of the President.
A parade of Republican leaders today hailed the victory -- the latest in a Republican winning streak -- as evidence that President Clinton, who campaigned as a moderate Southern Democrat, had become so unpopular in the region that he could spell defeat for dozens of candidates in November.
"The tidal wave of Republican victories continues," declared Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. "This election sends a powerful message to the White House. On issue after issue, the American people aren't swallowing this Administration's big Government medicine."
Since Mr. Clinton's election, Republicans have picked up eight formerly Democratic seats in important contests, including one special election earlier this month to fill the seat of Representative Glenn English of Oklahoma. The Democrats have not won any major elections for seats that were held by Republicans.
 
Feeding Party's Fears
 The Kentucky results only add to the fears of Democrats that they will lose many seats, particularly those of several conservative Democrats in the South who are retiring this year. That could damage the prospects of Mr. Clinton's programs in Congress.
In conceding the race, Mr. Prather, a former state Senator and state party chairman, said that the President had been a drag on his campaign. But Mr. Lewis went further in a telephone interview, attributing his victory to Mr. Clinton.
"Everyone that I talked to felt that the programs that Mr. Clinton was pushing -- the tobacco farmers with the tobacco tax and the gun control situation -- they just felt that Government was getting too involved in their personal lives," Mr. Lewis said. "We said in an ad, 'If you like Bill Clinton, you'll love Joe Prather.' "
Even before Election Day, Democratic Party officials, fearing a loss in a district where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans, distanced themselves from Mr. Prather in public comments. But today, Mr. Wilhelm, a usually amiable political professional who was Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign manager, went further. He insisted that even though the Western Kentucky district had favored the Republican candidate in the last four Presidential races, Mr. Prather's "fatal mistake" was not running with the Democratic Party.
 
Arrows for Others
 In a news conference at party headquarters, Mr. Wilhelm also singled out three other defeated Democrats -- Bob Krueger, who lost a Senate race in Texas; Mary Sue Terry, who lost her race for Governor of Virginia, and Dan Webber, who lost the special election in Oklahoma for Mr. English's House seat two weeks ago. He said all three had failed largely because they did not embrace President Clinton or his agenda.
"As best I can tell, Joe Prather got into a defensive crouch and stayed there," Mr. Wilhelm said. "This crouch strategy, which might be called the Bob Krueger/Mary Sue Terry/Joe Prather strategy, is a dead-bang loser."
Senator Bob Graham of Florida, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, took issue with Mr. Wilhelm's characterization of Mr. Krueger. "Bob Krueger had defined himself," Senator Graham said. "He had been in the Congress for a number of years. He was not a person who was waiting around for somebody else to draw in the dots and the colors to give him texture."
While several analysts agreed that Mr. Prather had run a poor race, they also said it would not have helped him to align himself more closely with Mr. Clinton. The President is not popular in this largely rural district, where voters are nervous about the costs of his health care proposal and about his proposed cigarette tax, which could hurt the local economy.
 
Low Turnout Noted
 "I don't think tying himself to Clinton and Clinton's programs would have helped him all that much, because Bill Clinton's just not all that popular in the district," said Carl P. Chelf, a professor of government at Western Kentucky University in Bowling Green. "But he could have been more aggressive in establishing what his own agenda was."
He also noted that Mr. Prather had suffered from a low turnout in what was otherwise a primary election and the Republicans' successful mobilization of the religious right.
Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of moderate Democrats close to Mr. Clinton, disputed that the Kentucky outcome was the latest demonstration that the President was viewed as too liberal in districts that have been long held by conservative Democrats.
But a gleeful Representative Bill Paxon of New York, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, accused Mr. Wilhelm of "throwing his own candidates to the wolves."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Idaho and Arkansas Elections
 The Associated Press
 Idaho Democrats have nominated an American Indian as their candidate for Governor, while Arkansas Republicans chose a longtime foe of President Clinton as their gubernatorial nominee.
In the Arkansas primary on Tuesday, James B. McDougal, the former owner of a failed savings and loan and a business partner of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Whitewater Development Company, came in last in a three-way race for the Democratic nomination for the 4th Congressional District.
In the race for the Republican nomination for governor, Sheffield Nelson, a Clinton critic who provided tips on Whitewater to reporters, won the right to challenge Jim Guy Tucker, the Democrat who became Governor of Arkansas when Mr. Clinton was elected President in 1992.
Mr. Nelson, who lost a bitter gubernatorial race to Mr. Clinton in 1990, barely avoided a runoff, with 51 percent of the vote to defeat State Senator Steve Luelf, who won 44 percent in the three-way race.
In Idaho, where Gov. Cecil Andrus, a Democrat, is retiring after an unprecedented fourth term, Attorney General Larry EchoHawk defeated two other Democrats for his party's nomination. Mr. EchoHawk, a Pawnee and former tribal lawyer, got 74 percent of the vote. If Mr. EchoHawk wins, he would become the first American Indian in the nation to be elected governor.
On the Republican side, former Lieut. Gov. Phil Batt easily won nomination with 48 percent of the vote in a four-way race. A victory in the general election for Mr. Batt would end 24 years of Democratic control of the governor's office.

HEADLINE: Sculpture Garden Rises in a New Patch of Green;
The Latest Addition to New York City's Park System, Named for a Philosopher

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
One man's dream to clean up a garbage dump and build a park -- a sculpture garden beside the East River with the jagged skyline of Manhattan a distant backdrop -- officially became a reality yesterday.
Since Mark di Suvero first wondered a decade ago whether there was a better way to make use of the littered lot beside his Queens studio, hundreds of his neighbors have worked tirelessly to help him create Socrates Sculpture Park, already a powerful draw for art aficionados from the city and beyond. Yesterday, it was formally dedicated as a city park, the first major addition to the park system in more than a decade. 
 With the pull of a cord and the falling away of a blue drape, the Parks and Recreation Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, declared that the 4.5-acre former wasteland had been reclaimed as part of the city's green space.
 
The Trunk of a Cedar
 Under the drape stood the trunk of the old blue Atlas cedar, a tree donated by the Emperor of Japan to the 1964 World's Fair that had been dealt a lethal blow when it was improperly uprooted during its transplanting in Flushing Meadow Park in March. An artist, Ron Ressler, had carved the dead tree into a 13-foot-high sculpture titled, "On Fertile Ground."
"It's such a wonderful confluence: a sculpture park dedicated and the blue Atlas cedar reborn as a work of art," he said.
Socrates Sculpture Park, named for the philosopher, was conceived by Mr. di Suvero after he set up his studio in an old brick factory amid the warehouses and transmission shops along Vernon Boulevard. The site, facing the northern tip of Roosevelt Island and just south of Hell Gate, the treacherous juncture of the Harlem and East Rivers, had once been a marine terminal. The slip was filled in about 20 years ago, but some of the concrete moorings remained; ideal pedestals for sculpture, in Mr. di Suvero's mind's eye.
"This is where they used to do illegal garbage dumping," Mr. di Suvero said. "There was no fence. There were huge puddles: broken steel, old cars. It took us about a year to clear this place."
Mr. di Suvero set up a nonprofit organization and began hiring unemployed people from the neighborhood who, along with volunteers and donations from local businesses, began the gradual task of creating the park.
The property belonged to what was then the city's Department of Ports and Terminals, now called the Department of Business Services. "The city wanted to develop it," Mr. di Suvero said. "I wouldn't say we fought the city, but it was nip and tuck to save it."
Mr. di Suvero credited a former Parks Commissioner, Gordon Davis, and a former Deputy Mayor, Barbara Fife, with sharing his vision for what might be. Yesterday's ceremony celebrated the culmination of the campaign, the assigning of management of the site from the Business Services Department to the Parks Department in a lease that was actually signed last October.
The park, Mr. Stern said, "means that there will be a place for monumental sculpture to be exhibited year round on the east bank of the East River."
"New artists will be discovered here," he said.
"And they did it," Mr. Stern said of the community, "That's the great part. The city cooperated but the people did it."
Before its incarnation as a city park, Mr. di Suvero had leased the land from the city and raised money from private donors to hold sculpture exhibitions in the park. Since then, it has become a vital part of Long Island City, a place for lectures and tours and several youth programs.
More than 20 sculptures now grace the swath of green beside the river. Most are abstract sculptures, like a 50-foot-high complex of jutting steel girders.
Among the works is a grouping of larger-than-life figures: a basketball player with his foot propped on a large portable radio; a man and his pit bull, and a young girl roller skating. By the boulders of the shoreline, a giant wind-chime-like sculpture turned in the breeze, converting its energy into the delicate tinkling of little bells.
Lovers rested beneath a nearby tree. As the dedication ceremony neared its end, Claudia Glover's class of toddlers from the N.A.A.C.P. Day Care Center in Long Island City thumped on the metal drums of a nearby work of art. "We come here all the time," Ms. Glover said. "They get to play and sing around these sculptures."
At that moment, Mr. di Suvero told the 200 or so guests at the dedication: "Here in Socrates Park we have made a unity with joy. So on this glorious day I ask you to join me and give the Great Spirit, the Earth Mother and the flowing river three yippees."
And the crowd did.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise Modestly, With Dow Up 10.13

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market yesterday again followed the wobbly path of the bond market, which sank then rallied after demand for the Government's debt issues proved brisk.
Other factors also lifted stocks. The outlook for commodities prices improved for a second day and yet another economic report, for durable-goods orders, showed the economy was growing only moderately, good news for bonds. 
 But despite these factors in favor of a rally, which have led to robust sessions in the past, stock prices rose only modestly in below-average volume.
Some analysts say that the market will not only remain sluggish but may temporarily decline in earnest in the next few weeks. That will be in advance of a summer rally, which analysts say is more and more likely because pessimistic investor sentiment is so lopsided. Often, when bearish opinion is extreme, markets can quickly turn bullish, analysts say.
Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.13 points, to 3,755.30, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.53 points, to 456.34. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.60 point, to 732.07.
 
A Sluggish Performance
 Part of the reason behind yesterday's sluggish performance may be a statistical fluke. Philip Morris, a major component in the Dow, did not open for trading in advance of a board meeting that ultimately took no action on a proposal to split the food and tobacco businesses.
Philip Morris was listed as unchanged at 53 3/4 yesterday. When the stock opens this morning, its price is likely to drop sharply, perhaps below $50 a share.
Nonetheless, blue chips like Walt Disney and Aluminum Company of America, as well as health care companies like Abbott Laboratories and electric utilities like the Entergy Corporation rose yesterday. Over-the-counter stocks like Microsoft and MCI Communications also rose.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief market strategist for the First Albany Corporation, says traders are beginning to wonder whether the economy, which they once feared was overheating, may now be slowing down too much. "Investors are starting to wonder about the trade-off between higher bond prices and a softer economy and lower earnings," he said.
Philip J. Roth, chief technical market analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds, also said the markets continued to be confused by two major and conflicting trends. "One is that secular disinflation is alive and well," he said. "But the other is that the economy is strengthening and that means that commodities prices are going up."
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, a proxy for bond traders' inflation outlook, rose 16/32 , to 8629/32 . Its yield fell to 7.34 percent, down 5 basis points. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Five-Year Notes Auction
 Bond prices improved after the 1 P.M. auction of $11 billion of five-year notes showed brisker demand than expected. An auction of two-year notes the day before showed lackluster demand.
But the brisk demand for the five-year paper, analysts say, may simply reflect an arcane trading theory that medium-term notes are intrinsically less risky than short- or long-term notes.
The Commodity Research Bureau index, a proxy for commodities traders' inflation outlook, improved for the second day. It fell 3.10 points, to 231.59, on a fall in prices for futures contracts for soybean oil, coffee and pork bellies.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.66 point, to 252.06, on below-average volume of 254.4 million shares. Advancing stocks barely outnumbered declining stocks by 1,111 to 1,029. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.07 point, to 439.25.
The most active stock, at 7 million shares on the American Stock Exchange, was Exploration Company of Louisiana, which rose 7/16 , to 1 3/4, on little discernible news.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cattle Prices at 6-Year Low; Other Commodities Also Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Cattle futures prices plummeted to a nearly six-year low yesterday amid concerns about burdensome supplies. Most other commodity prices also fell for the second consecutive day, reducing inflation fears.
The widely watched index of 21 commodities tracked by the Commodity Research Bureau fell 3.1 points, to 231.59. Among the other losers were hogs, pork bellies, soybeans, corn, coffee, precious metals and crude oil. 
 Live cattle for June delivery plunged 1.50 cents on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the permitted daily limit, to 62.47 cents a pound, the lowest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since June 23, 1988. August feeder cattle also fell the 1.50-cent limit, to 71.60 cents a pound; June live hogs sank 1.17 cents, to 47.05 cents a pound; July frozen pork bellies dropped 1.78 cents, to 41.62 cents a pound.
 
Results Called a 'Debacle'
 "My word for the day is debacle," said Dennis Smith, research director for Linnco Futures Inc. in Chicago. "This thing is really getting extreme."
Live cattle futures have tumbled 14.15 cents, or more than 18 percent, since April 1 as larger numbers of heavier cattle have appeared on the market.
An Agriculture Department report on Friday showed the largest number of May 1 feedlot cattle -- animals being fattened for slaughter -- in 11 years, implying no letup in supplies. Cattle weights, which last month averaged 5 percent above a year earlier, are rising as well.
Hog and pork-belly futures were under pressure as a result of larger supplies of hogs coming to market than analysts had expected based on Agriculture Department reports.
Soybean futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade as rain and rain forecasts in the Midwest continued to wash away drought fears.
Coffee futures continued to retreat from the five-year high of $1.4550 a pound posted early in Tuesday's session. Analysts said speculative buying had pushed prices to inflated levels. Unroasted coffee beans for July delivery fell 5.35 cents on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange to $1.2775 a pound.
Most energy futures headed lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange because of declining demand. Natural gas hit a 15-month low.
Light sweet crude oil for July delivery fell 22 cents, to $17.70 a barrel; June heating oil rose 0.03 cent, to 47.63 cents a pound; June unleaded gasoline fell 0.09 cent, to 51.67 cents a gallon; July natural gas dropped 4.8 cents, to $1.836 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Durable Orders Up Just 0.1% As Home Resales Rise 1.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Orders for long-lived factory goods languished in April, more evidence of slowing business expansion, Commerce Department figures showed today.
Durable goods orders, which lead to activity in coming months, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, below most expectations, and would have been solidly in negative territory without a presumably temporary surge for military aircraft. 
 Separately, home resales rose by 1.2 percent last month, to a 4.12 million annual pace, as higher interest rates continued to induce buyers to act before rates moved still higher. But sales were down in the Northeast and South, the National Association of Realtors found.
The report on durable goods, a category ranging from aircraft carriers to clothes dryers, was regarded by many analysts as a sign of slackening economic growth and thus would diminish pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates again.
"The economy has shifted into lower gear since the beginning of the new year," said Robert D. Barr, deputy chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
"Today's report adds to earlier evidence that the economy was already slowing down on its own" before the Fed began raising rates in early February, he added.
In St. Louis, Laurence H. Meyer, a consultant, said he saw "waning" economic momentum and cited three consecutive months of declines in orders for nonmilitary capital goods.
But others had less pessimistic interpretations of the report on orders, pointing to the hefty rise in March that was at least sustained in April and to a jump of 8.6 percent last month in orders for electronic and other electrical equipment.
"Durable goods manufacturing continues to be expanding meaningfully," said Robert G. Dederick, a former Commerce Department official and now chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Mark P. Vitner, economist at First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C., largely agreed. "There is not much of a letup in sight in the manufacturing sector," he said. "There's plenty of fuel in the pipeline."
And Paul W. Boltz, economist at T. Rowe Price Associates, an investment firm in Baltimore, said, "We're not worried yet."
Still, orders fell by seven-tenths of 1 percent when the Pentagon's orders are not counted, and overall orders -- 13.5 percent higher than in April 1993 -- have now fallen at an annual rate of 4 percent over the last three months.
Primary metals posted the biggest decline last month, skidding by 6.6 percent after two solid gains. Transportation equipment, where declines for railroad equipment and motor vehicles more than offset an advance for aircraft, fell by 1.6 percent, the smallest of three consecutive declines. Industrial machinery rose by three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Total New Orders Up 2 Percent
 In capital goods, total new orders climbed by 2 percent as the relatively small military sector jumped by 23.3 percent, while the civilian sector fell by nine-tenths of 1 percent -- seven-tenths of 1 percent when aircraft are excluded.
Shipments of durable goods, those designed to last at least three years, fell by six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department figures also showed. It was the second decline in four months.
Unfilled orders, or backlogs, inched up by one-tenth of 1 percent, to $423.8 billion, the first rise since January.
The report on home resales listed increases of 5.4 percent in the West and 3 percent in the Middle West, partly offset by a second consecutive decline of 1.7 percent in the Northeast and a decline of 1.3 percent in the South.
"With the start of the spring home-buying season, many consumers decided to lock in before volatile investment markets pushed the possibility of buying a home out of their financial reach," said Debbie Johnson, economist at C. J. Lawrence in New York, referring to a rush by home buyers to act before interest rates rose again.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Economists see an intellectual ally in Supreme Court nominee.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WHO is Judge Stephen Breyer, and where does he stand? While groups at war over social issues ranging from abortion rights to discrimination have yet to take the measure of the President's Supreme Court nominee, both economists and lawyers well versed in economics are dancing in the aisles.
"Breyer is better educated in economics than any justice in the Court's history," said William Landes, an economist at the University of Chicago's law school. 
 "He knows more about regulatory law and policy than any justice since Brandeis," echoed Robert Pitovsky, a former member of the Federal Trade Commission now teaching at the Georgetown University Law School.
This still leaves open the question of whether Mr. Breyer can change a court in which he will have just one of nine votes. But his many admirers (and few detractors) have some ideas.
The current Supreme Court is widely viewed as conservative. However, few of the economic questions faced by the courts have much to do with ideology. Is it liberal or conservative, for example, to give Government regulators the benefit of the doubt on rulings that are challenged as arbitrary and capricious? Is it liberal or conservative to broaden the reach of copyright law to include computer software?
"They pick a shred here and a shred there" to justify their economic logic, concludes F. M. Scherer, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. And as a result, the Court's opinions on antitrust issues have been, at best, unpredictable, and, at worst, inconsistent.
In the Brook case in 1993, for example, the Court smiled on the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company in what had seemed to be an open-and-shut case of predatory pricing against it. The Court held that there had to be proof that there was a conspiracy to drive a competitor out of business. Yet just a year earlier, in a decision that reminded observers of the activist acrobatics of the Warren Court, the Justices ruled that Eastman Kodak could be sued for trying to corner the servicing of its own brand of photocopiers -- in spite of the fact that Kodak was a minor force in the photocopier market.
"The Brook decision, in light of Kodak, came as a big surprise," dryly noted Howard Kitt, an economist with National Economic Research Associates, a consulting firm in White Plains.
Judge Breyer, it is generally agreed, will drive the court toward consistency on economic cases. And he may even drive the Court's other legal intellectual, Antonin Scalia, to recast his always clever and usually esoteric opinions in terms of workaday economic substance.
Among the economic issues Judge Breyer is likely to influence are these:
Property rights. Property used to mean what it sounded like -- this chunk of land or that machine. Today, the courts face a bewildering set of property issues ranging from "takings" questions in which the Government's right to limit land use without compensation is challenged, to intellectual property cases involving the exclusive use of ideas.
Mr. Landes expects that Judge Breyer will view these newfangled property issues through an economist's prism, focusing less on equity and more on efficiency. Thus instead of asking who is entitled, he is more apt to wonder whether a ruling will raise or lower productivity. In software cases, for example, he is likely to look at the impact on the pace of innovation or the potential waste in building legal walls to protect new ideas.
Antitrust. This is a precedent-bound corner of the law, but one in which Congress has given the Supreme Court broad discretion to make policy as well as to interpret it.
Like most people trained in modern economics, Judge Breyer has been strongly influenced by the Chicago School view that the ultimate test of antitrust policy is the pragmatic test -- whether it encourages the efficient use of scarce resources. His pragmatism is reflected in a case on predatory pricing in which he argued that intent is irrelevant as long as producers sell above cost, as well as one in which he ruled that attempts by Blue Cross to bludgeon down physicians' fees were legal.
One antitrust area in which Judge Breyer's cool logic may have the most impact is "vertical restraint" cases, where economists have been far more receptive than the courts to arguments as to why producers should be allowed to dictate the behavior of wholesalers and retailers.
Health and safety regulation. Judge Breyer's latest book, "Breaking the Vicious Circle" (Harvard Press), is an eloquent meditation on how to regulate perilous activities in a world that cannot afford to reduce risk to zero. And while much of the book is a sympathetic look at the difficulty of regulating in a political context, it is safe to say that he will be unsympathetic to policies that ignore economic trade-offs.
"Justice Breyer will worry about the costs of regulation as well as the benefits," predicts Lawrence White, an economist at the Sloan School of Business of New York University.

HEADLINE: Ambiguity Saves Trade Talks

 BODY:
The trade agreement announced this week by President Clinton and Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata does not obligate Japan to stimulate its economy so that it will absorb more imports or open up markets or settle any other dispute. But it does get trade talks back on track -- a welcome reversal after the breakdown in February. Talks should relieve the friction that has focused undue attention on a secondary issue -- the $50 billion bilateral trade imbalance -- that drives these allies apart rather than on Mr. Hata's stalled agenda of political and economic reforms that can pull them together.
Though Japan's overall trade surplus results from its high savings rate, the imbalance with the U.S. is in part because of barriers that shut out U.S. exports and investment. Most economists agree that the harm to the U.S. economy is small. But Japan's practices undermine confidence in trade rules and, most important for Mr. Clinton and Congress, hurt powerful constituents -- like Motorola in the cellular phone market. 
 Though the actual wording has not been released, U.S. officials say Japan has pledged to negotiate higher foreign penetration in five specific sectors and use quantitative criteria to measure success. Japan won a pledge that the U.S. would not seek numerical targets.
Exactly what these pledges mean is unclear. "Numerical targets," for example, is not defined. The U.S. uses the term to refer only to targets that would set market shares for foreign goods; that leaves the U.S. free to demand other types of numerical benchmarks, such as the number of Japanese automobile dealers that sell foreign cars.
The danger is that this type of ambiguity, as so often in the past, will trigger mutual animosity as each country accuses the other of failing to live by its promises. But both leaders need resolution: Mr. Clinton wants to reassure anxious currency traders that he can settle trade disputes with Japan without driving the dollar to lower levels; Mr. Hata needs to prove at home that his fragile coalition can govern. They have good reason to hammer out a series of accords that will give exporters a fair shot at Japanese consumers and thereby end spats over the bilateral trade deficit.

HEADLINE: Reagan Forced South Africa Sanctions Issue;
Yes, They Worked

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a former senior South African Government official assigned the task in the 1960's and 70's of countering sanctions, and having recently completed a doctoral dissertation on the political and economic effect of United States sanctions against South Africa, I find myself on middle ground between Anthony Lewis ("Help From Outside," column, May 6) and Herman Nickel ("South Africa Sanctions Didn't Undo Apartheid," letter, May 15). 
 Mr. Lewis has ample reason to state that sanctions played a significant role in the demise of apartheid.
 He singles out, with sufficient justification, George Houser's American Committee on Africa as having played a significant role in making sanctions stick. As early as the mid-50's the committee had recruited the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other luminaries to the anti-apartheid pro-sanctions cause in a campaign that eventually culminated in the adoption of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act by Congress in 1986.
Mr. Nickel, former United States Ambassador to South Africa, is equally justified in arguing that the "sanctions of the markets" may have had a more debilitating effect than officially imposed sanctions. But United States banks and other businesses pulled out of South Africa not out of their own free will, but under severe pressures from the American Committee on Africa and other anti-apartheid groups -- and, ultimately, the growing threat to their domestic business as Federal, city and state sanctions were adopted.
President F. W. de Klerk, in his historic February 1990 speech, which brought the bastion of apartheid crumbling down, offered all kinds of reasons for his change of heart and direction -- except sanctions. At the same time he moved at breakneck speed to fulfill to the letter all the conditions for the lifting of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act.
It was only two years later, after the repeal of this act, that Pik Botha, South Africa's Foreign Minister, would publicly admit the role that these sanctions played in Mr. de Klerk's dramatic transformation from apostle of apartheid to majority-rule reformer.
Pik Botha simply confirmed in public what South African officialdom had repeatedly and freely admitted to me privately in interviews for my study, scheduled to be published next fall as "In Sight of Surrender." While determining in exact measure the role sanctions played in the ultimate demise of apartheid proved to be an impossible task, I found beyond any doubt that United States and other punitive measures significantly dictated the form, substance, timing and pace of change in South Africa In this sense -- notwithstanding strenuous arguments to the contrary -- sanctions did work.
 
LES DE VILLIERS
New Canaan, Conn., May 16, 1994

HEADLINE: Why Economic Systems Need Overhaul

 BODY:
To the Editor:
No political-economic system or theory is applicable at all times to all situations. That maxim might have leavened "Life's Hard? Blame the Market" (The Week in Review, May 8), on the confused economic scene. 
 The cold war obscured the fact that free market theories, used in defense of "capitalism," are ideologies as dogmatic as Marxism and only slightly more representative of reality. The constant need to "refine" theory and the astounding policy gyrations from Keynesianism to supply-side econom-
ics to monetarism to Keynesianism once again to remedy the failures of forecasts and policies that are based on these theories tell us that we are far from using a reliable analytical tool of social change.
However, you make an observation that points in the right direction: "In the 1950's and 1960's prosperity marched in lockstep with diminishing inequality." This happy state of affairs was largely due to a growing economy supplemented and guided by New Deal policies dedicated to equalization of social reward. The abandonment of these policies in favor of winner-take-all economics coincides with the start of social problems rooted in increasing inequality.
Due to changing goals, tastes and institutions, no social system will automatically serve equally well forever. Like a complex organism it will accumulate malfunctions that eventually destroy it. The Soviet Union's collapse is but the latest example, a system that failed out of rigid adherence to a theory divorced from reality. Free market capitalism will be no exception if it is observed as rigidly.
Government is charged with adapting a system to changing circumstance. Prudence dictates that such adapting be done with care, but done it must be. The health-care debate shows we must again abandon economic ideology to achieve the balance between social justice and efficiency that we once had.
 
RICHARD HYSE
Oswego, N.Y., May 16, 1994
 
The writer retired as a professor of economics at SUNY-Oswego.

HEADLINE: Big-Time Tourism Courts Vietnam

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Da Nang is now a stop for cruise ships. Cam Ranh Bay may get Club Med as a neighbor. And the Hoa Lo Prison, nicknamed the Hanoi Hilton by Americans held there during the Vietnam War, is really becoming a hotel.
The travel industry, which has been slowly discovering Vietnam as a tourist destination over the last few years, is scrambling to cut more deals there since President Clinton lifted the American trade embargo in February, making it easier for Americans to invest and travel. 
 Cruise lines are adding Vietnam's ports to their itineraries. Avis, National and Hertz are negotiating to rent cars there. Club Med wants to open a multimillion-dollar resort 30 miles north of Cam Ranh Bay, which, like Da Nang, was the site of an American military base.
And several hotel chains, including Radisson, Marriott and Choice, are talking to developers about opening hotels in Vietnam.
"It's estimated Vietnam needs as much as $40 billion to upgrade its infrastructure," said Jim Olson, senior vice president for Hawaii and Asia-Pacific development of Minneapolis-based Radisson. "With that kind of demand you'll have lots of businessmen, technicians and support personnel needing roofs over their head, in addition to the growing number of tourists."
To prevent "our competitors winding up serving our guests," as Mr. Olson put it, Radisson and potential partners from Thailand and Malaysia anticipate putting up hotels in Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City (the former Saigon), and Da Nang.
Avis is also moving aggressively. "We've had a lot of interest from investors who want franchises in Hanoi and Saigon," said Michael Collins, an international vice president, "and because we see good growth opportunities there, we're moving as quickly as we can to stay ahead of the pack."
Travel companies view Vietnam as an important link in an expected surge in travel to and within Asia.
Tourist receipts in the Asia-Pacific region will account for 30.6 percent of $527 billion in worldwide tourist revenue in the year 2,000, up from 15.1 percent in 1990, according to the World Tourism Organization. Air travel in the region is expected to grow 7.5 percent a year -- nearly twice the world average.
"All the statistics show that Vietnam tourism is on a faster growth track than any country in Asia, maybe even more than the rest of the world," said Chuck Y. Gee, dean of the School of Travel Industry Management at the University of Hawaii.
 
Competition Intensifying
 Some travel experts warn against over-optimism and note that Vietnam is far from ready to play host to visitors on a large scale. Still, the tourist companies elbowing to the front of the line envision a market that can average 10 percent annual growth in the number of visitors throughout the decade and generate much more than the $230 million that the Vietnamese Tourism Department said the country earned from 670,000 foreign visitors last year.
Nguyen Thi Hong, a press officer with the Vietnamese Mission to the United Nations, said the country expected a million tourists this year and 1.6 million by the end of the century. While that is a far cry from Hong Kong's 8.9 million annual visitors, or Singapore's 6.4 million, it would be a vast leap from the 20,000 who visited Vietnam in 1986.
"We want to develop tourism, so we welcome everyone," Mrs. Hong said. Americans, she said, would receive a warm welcome.
Expatriate Vietnamese and American veterans of the Vietnam War are expected to account for much of the first wave of American visitors. Americans, no longer forced to obtain Vietnamese visas in Thailand and Hong Kong, can get them in three to five weeks by applying to the Vietnamese Mission in New York.
 
Credit Cards in the Future
 Lifting the embargo also ended the Treasury Department's $200 daily limit on expenditures by Americans in Vietnam. When the regulatory agencies work out details, prohibitions are also expected to be lifted on the use of credit cards issued by American banks.
Because only a quarter of Vietnam's estimated 22,000 hotel rooms are up to international standards, dozens of hotels are under construction, most as joint ventures between the Government and European and Asian hotel companies. A Singapore group, for example, is teaming up with Vietnam in a $33 million project to turn the Hoa Lo Prison into a 22-story hotel and office tower in Hanoi.
About $200 million is being invested in five golf courses. A few months ago, the Da Lat Golf Club opened the country's first 18-hole course. Memberships in the club, a $40 million joint venture with Hong Kong investors, range from $15,000 to $60,000.
Several United States airlines are awaiting permission to fly to Vietnam. Which carriers are awarded the routes will ultimately depend on Washington and Hanoi, but United, Continental and Northwest have already staked claims to routes. And Delta Air Lines, with few Pacific routes, recently agreed with Vietnam Airlines to coordinate flight schedules to an intermediate city in Asia that has not yet been designated.
Many cruise lines are considering offering Vietnam visits this year, while Royal Cruise, Holland America, Royal Viking, Orient Lines and Seven Seas Cruise Line may add more Vietnamese ports to cruises, some of which have been stopping at Vietnamese ports for several years.
Seabourn Cruise Line was so pleased with two sold-out cruises that called at Vietnam that it is adding two more next year. The Club Med 2, Seabourn's sailing ship, will have five weeklong Vietnam cruises. And starting Nov. 21, Pearl Cruises is offering a 17-day Vietnam trip that will include a 30-hour on-board seminar with Vietnamese officials and foreign investors in Vietnam.
Book publishers are getting into the act, too. Houghton Mifflin, Lonely Planet and Passport Books recently published new or revised guidebooks on the country.
While some experts say that the number of American tourists, drawn by the allure of a destination that has been off-limits for so long, will increase substantially after normalization of diplomatic relations -- something the travel industry hopes for no later than next year -- they also warn that some assertions about Vietnam's tourist potential are overblown.
 
Skepticism From Rambo
 "Some investors will strike it rich," said Dr. A. Terry Rambo, a specialist on Indochina at the East-West Center in Honolulu. "But everybody and his brother seems to want into Vietnam, for reasons not entirely economically rational."
"Vietnam only has a few good hotels and not much other infrastructure necessary to handle a big increase in visitors," said Dan Sullivan Jr., head of Collette Travel Service in Pawtucket, R.I., a major tour operator. "Our customers are not talking about visiting Vietnam."
Passport Books warns in its guidebook that the Vietnam tourism industry "is still unable, because of bureaucratic obstacles, to offer many of the different services that are readily available in the rest of Asia."
A group of French bankers recently discovered as much when they spent the night searching for a hotel in Hanoi because the Orient Hotel forgot that the group had made reservations. And the Vietnamese Investment Review, a journal published in Hanoi, recently reported that some Vietnam tour agencies sell package tours without having hotel rooms or rental cars available.
Charles Man, the owner of Sino-American Tours in New York's Chinatown, said it is hard to sell Vietnam as a single destination. "Because of the distance and cost," he said, "Vietnam visits have to be combined with other destinations," often Hong Kong and Bangkok.
Sino-American, Absolute Asia, South Sea Tour and Travel, All Adventure Travel, Myths and Mountains and Creative Travel are among the growing handful of companies offering tours that include Vietnam. Depending on length and stopovers, most tours from the United States run $1,800 to $5,000 a person, plus air fare. Visitors from Asian countries tend to spend less.
 
Trade First
 Tourism experts acknowledge that trade, rather than educational or leisure travel, will initially be more profitable, although they expect each to complement the other.
"Our best estimate is that there's likely to be $2 billion to $4 billion in trade between the two countries in the next couple of years," said Virginia Foote, director of the United States-Vietnam Trade Council in Washington. About 90 percent of that is expected to come in the sale of American goods, she said, especially consumer products.
But for tourism to develop into a big business, the Vietnamese must have repeat customers.
"So unless Vietnam improves its inadequate infrastructure," Professor Rambo said, "all those rosy tourism projections are likely to prove disappointing."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A victim of I.B.M.'s big account shift, a small fledging agency believes in life after Big Blue.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE executives of the smallest, and newest, agency that I.B.M. will dismiss in the biggest account shift ever are gamely trying to pick themselves up, dust themselves off and start, well, not all over again, but somewhere that takes advantage of their brief, tempestuous tenure as an I.B.M. agency.
"It's just a fascinating piece of business to work on," Jane Newman, the executive vice president and director of strategic planning at the agency, Merkley Newman Harty in New York, said yesterday. 
 "I wouldn't have had it any other way," she added, agreeing that at least in this instance it was better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all.
Merkley Newman was among the more than 40 agency casualties on Tuesday, when the International Business Machines Corporation rocked Madison Avenue by announcing that it would combine a myriad of accounts, with annual ad spending of $400 million to $500 million, at a single global shop, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide.
Merkley Newman was perhaps the most prominent of the victims because the agency was a mere fledgling -- only six months old, with billings of $40 million -- when I.B.M. unexpectedly selected it in October to share the estimated $100 million account of the IBM PC Company with the Paris office of a sibling agency, DDB Needham Worldwide. Merkley Newman, which survived a lengthy, competitive review to land the personal computer assignment, opened in April 1993 as a creatively focused spinoff of Doremus & Company, an Omnicom Group shop specializing in financial advertising.
The IBM PC Company account catapulted Merkley Newman into a prominence that was amplified by the paucity of success stories in the recession-racked advertising industry. It seemed like the quintessential Cinderella tale until the client abruptly rewrote the ending, taking back the glass slipper and giving a veritable shoe store's worth of footwear to Ogilvy.
"Of course, it's not good news," said Bruce Crawford, president and chief executive of Omnicom in New York. "On the other hand, it's not the end of the world. We didn't put them in business with the idea they work for I.B.M. They just go back to where we were before they hit this home run."
Mr. Crawford disputed reports in trade publications that Merkley Newman's ties to I.B.M. executives had been fraying even before the decision to hire Ogilvy.
"All I know is that I.B.M. told me they were totally happy," he said. "Merkley Newman was the innocent bystander when I.B.M. decided they were going to make agency changes and then, in the end, decided to consolidate with one agency."
And Ms. Newman disputed a report yesterday by Bloomberg Business News that the loss of the IBM PC Company account had placed the agency's survival in question.
"It's going to be fine," she said.
In the best industry tradition of making lemonade from lemons, Mr. Crawford echoed a suggestion of Ms. Newman's that Merkley Newman could exploit its experience with I.B.M. in seeking other clients.
"The whole process, if anything, has raised their profile and benefited them," Mr. Crawford said. "The fact is, a major corporation thought well enough of them to give them its business."
Ms. Newman said that because of the needs and demands of I.B.M., the agency had to "turn down a lot of opportunities in the technology area since Christmas."
"I love new business," she added, "and we haven't been doing enough of it."
Actually, Merkley Newman is a likely contender for two computer accounts, with billings estimated at $75 million, that require new agencies because Ogilvy must resign them to avoid conflicts as it begins work for I.B.M. One is product advertising for the Microsoft Corporation, handled by Ogilvy's Los Angeles office, and the other is the European account of the Compaq Computer Corporation, which uses Ammirati & Puris in New York as its American agency. Ogilvy will also withdraw from a review that Microsoft is conducting to name its first agency for a worldwide image-advertising account, with billings estimated at an additional $40 million.
Indeed, Ms. Newman said Merkley Newman had no plans to lay off any of its 80 employees, about half of whom were hired after the agency was awarded $50 million in IBM PC Company billings.
Apart from any other computer accounts the agency wins, a significant amount of the I.B.M. work remains to be done through the summer, including the production of a television campaign to accompany a series of print advertisements that Merkley Newman introduced only last week. Parry Merkley, the agency's president and creative director, flew to Los Angeles yesterday to oversee work on the commercials.
In addition, Merkley Newman retains billings that Ms. Newman estimated at $65 million for clients including Bankers Trust ; Casio, for watches and electronics products; Forbes magazine, for trade advertising; the International Wool Secretariat, for the American portion of its Woolmark branding account; Great Brands of Europe, to create the initial American campaign for Volvic, a still water imported from France; Harman International Industries, for its American stereo components account, handling brands like Harman Kardon and JBL, and Wordperfect, for corporate advertising.

Those agencies, which specialize in direct marketing, are Bronner Slosberg Humphrey and Barry Blau & Partners; they have not been dismissed, and continue to work for I.B.M.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says 17 Ran Murder Gang That Ruled Heroin Sales in Bronx

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
Seventeen people identified as gang members were indicted yesterday on murder and racketeering charges in what Federal prosecutors called a sophisticated operation that forced dealers to pay rent in order to sell drugs on street corners in the South Bronx.
For seven years in Mott Haven, prosecutors said, the gang, called C & C, controlled drug trafficking in the area by strictly enforcing where and during what hours it could occur. Those who did not cooperate, the authorities charged, were killed or tortured. 
 C & C, named for its founders, George Calderon and Angel (Cuson) Padilla, grossed more than $100,000 a week through an intricate extortion system, the authorities said. While other drug gangs made profits selling heroin and cocaine, they said, this one profited primarily through the intimidation and control of a seven-block area.
Mr. Calderon, investigators said, mixed brute force with careful gestures intended to gain the acceptance of the community. For example, they said, he set up a rule that forbade dealers to sell when children were on the way to school, and imposed limits on the number of customers congregating on a corner at any one time.
The arrests of C & C members have already led to upheaval among the area's drug sellers, investigators said. But they said it was not clear whether the arrests would lead to new violence as newcomers vied for position, or whether a disruption of the tribute reportedly exacted by the gang would alter the economics of the neighborhood's drug trade.
In Mott Haven yesterday, residents said that neither the price of heroin nor the torrid pace of sales had changed.
"You have leaders and you have followers," said a young man with close-cropped hair who lives on East 139th Street. "The followers have been trained to step up when the time comes. They know what to do."
The United States Attorney, Mary Jo White, said the indictment was only part of a larger plan to prosecute C & C, which she called one of the five largest gangs operating in Manhattan and the Bronx. A continuing investigation, she said, may lead to more charges against C & C members.
"We hope to obliterate them entirely, but that has not happened yet," Ms. White said.
Ms. White said prosecutors had evidence that since 1986, gang members killed 14 people who in some way obstructed their business, including Juan Cruz, a professional boxer who was murdered in 1992 after inquiring about the death of his brother Luis. An investigator added that the gang was suspected of committing dozens of other murders that would be harder to prove.
All 17 defendants were charged with murder, including Anna Rodriguez, 63, the mother of Mr. Calderon.
 
Sold Their Own Brand
 Those indicted yesterday were arrested over a period of many months, investigators said. Some, including Mr. Padilla, have been in jail for almost a year. Others were arrested in recent weeks. Ms. Rodriguez was the last to be taken into custody, arrested at her home at 647 East 138th Street in the Bronx at 5 P.M. Wednesday.
The gang was formed about 1987 by Mr. Calderon and Mr. Padilla, who were first cousins, according to the indictment. They sold their own brand of heroin, "D.O.A.," and groomed a cadre of 20 to 30 loyal lieutenants.
Investigators said that as the leaders of C & C devised a system of collecting protection money for street-corner drug sales in the area of Brook Avenue and East 139th Street, they found that extortion carried a far better risk-to-reward ratio than drug dealing. Although they and their gang members did not abandon heroin trafficking entirely, extortion became their main source of income, investigators said.
"If you wanted to deal in their area, you had to pay rent and abide by their rules," said a Federal agent involved in the case, who was reluctant to discuss many specific aspects of C & C's operations because the investigation is continuing.
 
Flat Weekly Rate
 "They would actually designate spots," said the agent, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "It wasn't like you started selling and then paid them protection money. They would actually assign you the location."
Some drug suppliers paid C & C on a commission, increasing their rent as their income grew. But most paid a flat weekly rate. The price and arrangement varied from site to site, but a typical fee was a few thousand dollars a week, the agent said.
C & C's downfall, prosecutors said, can be traced to a feud that erupted in early 1992 between factions of the gang headed by its founders, Mr. Calderon, then 36, and Mr. Padilla, then 45.
At a meeting in early May, the Federal complaint says, Mr. Padilla told Ivan Rodriguez that Mr. Calderon was "bringing too much heat to C & C" and needed to be killed.
 
Sister Murdered in Car
 Mr. Calderon was shot to death as he emerged from a meeting with his parole officer on East 161st Street near Yankee Stadium on May 21, 1992. Mr. Rodriguez was accused of the murder today, and the Federal complaint charges Mr. Padilla with ordering it.
Two months later, Mr. Calderon's sister, Lourdes Cintron, was murdered as she sat inside a car parked on East 146th Street. Citing a confidential witness, prosecutors charge that Gregory Cherry, an ally of Mr. Padilla, shot Ms. Cintron and then ran down the street, jumped on a bicycle and rode away.
When a large wall mural was painted near East 138th Street later that year, it commemorated Mr. Calderon and his sister, with their names in large block letters, a law-enforcement official said.
Another law-enforcement official who helped investigate the gang said that it regularly used a room in a basement of a building near 139th Street to torture victims. "It was a torture chamber," the official said.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS TO MAINTAIN TRADE PRIVILEGES FOR CHINA'S GOODS;
Clinton Votes For Business

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
President Clinton's decision to renew China's trade benefits was the culmination of a titanic clash between America's global economic interests and Washington's self-image as the leading advocate of human rights. In the end, economic interests won the day. It wasn't really even close.
Faced with a choice between disrupting the vast American economic relationship with China or eating a little crow on his human rights promises, Mr. Clinton chose crow.
Many foreign policy experts feel that President Clinton made exactly the right decision. 
But look how he got there. During the campaign he denounced President Bush for his claim that engaging China rather than threatening it with trade sanctions was the best way to promote human rights and protect Washington's interests in Asia.
Once in office, Mr. Clinton followed up his campaign speeches with a concrete threat last May to withdraw China's "most favored nation" trade benefits if Beijing did not meet his human rights conditions by this June.
China fell short. But the President, instead of imposing sanctions, junked his threat and today gave what was surely the most eloquent defense of the Bush Administration's China policy ever uttered at the White House, including by President Bush.
In an almost surreal moment at his news conference today, Mr. Clinton seemed to be quoting Mr. Bush.
Mr. Clinton said: "To those who argue that in view of China's human rights abuses we should revoke M.F.N. status, let me ask you the same question that I have asked myself: Will we do more to advance the cause of human rights if China is isolated, or if our nations are engaged in a growing web of political and economic cooperation and contacts?"
In adopting this approach, Mr. Clinton was only acknowledging the underlying shift evident in all the industrial democracies: economic concerns have taken center stage in foreign affairs. This is the age of the Finance Minister.
It was the Treasury Department and the Chamber of Commerce whose institutional instincts dominated this decision, not the State Department and Human Rights Watch. And this is hardly unique. Economics dominate Japan policy, Asia policy and Latin American policy as well. The game of nations is now geo-Monopoly, and it is first and foremost about profits, not principles.
 
Putting Tiananmen Aside
 By making the decision he did today, President Clinton also closed a chapter in American foreign policy. It was called "Tiananmen Square."
Ever since the June 1989 shootings of democracy campaigners, watched live and in color by millions of Americans on CNN, Chinese-American relations have not been normal. Liberal Democrats, led by the Senate's majority leader, George Mitchell of Maine, have demanded some punishment of China's leaders for the cruelty they showed toward dissidents who chose the Statue of Liberty as their symbol.
Hard-boiled strategists, led by Mr. Bush, argued that while the violence in Tiananmen Square was terrible, United States interests in China went beyond human rights -- to economics, security matters, nonproliferation of weapons and environmental cooperation -- and that it was this panoply of interests that had to guide the relationship, not a single-minded and probably futile drive to turn China into a democracy.
In renewing China's trade benefits despite its spotty record on human rights, President Clinton has effectively declared that foreign policy toward China will no longer be guided by those four days in June 1989 known as Tiananmen Square. It is over.
 
The Site of McDonald's
 Remember that famous Tiananmen intersection where that lone Chinese dissident stopped a tank in June 1989? It is now overseen by Ronald McDonald, who sits on a bench there outside the world's biggest McDonald's, bearing silent testimony to this new age of mercantile diplomacy. Like it or not, the nightmare of Tiananmen has given way to the daydream of an Asian gold rush.
From now on, human rights will be one among several interests shaping the American-Chinese relationship.
In many ways Mr. Clinton got steamrolled into this decision by his own vision.
From his first day in office, the President emphasized the importance of economic interests in post-cold-war foreign policy. He called on the nation to shift its gaze from across the Atlantic to the new economic frontiers of China, Japan and Latin America. He used the Oval Office to announce the sale of $6 billion in aircraft to Saudi Arabia.
Having so elevated economics, it became impossible for him to turn around suddenly and say he was going to abort Washington's relationship with the most lucrative, most expansive foreign market of them all by punishing China for not meeting his human rights demands.
Even if he had wanted to, Congress probably would not have let him.
For many lawmakers had been listening to what the President had to say. So had the American Chamber of Commerce. So had the U.S.-China Business Council, Boeing, AT&T, Wal-Mart and millions of Americans who invested money in mutual funds that were buying up stocks in Shanghai and Hong Kong by the billions.
 
Yielding to Forest Fire
 Together this had produced a quiet sea change in the Congress and the public over the last two years on the question of China. Mr. Clinton was only yielding today to the forest fire he helped ignite.
Lawmakers came to understand the economic stakes their constituents had developed in the United States-China economic relationship -- whether it was consumers who gobbled up inexpensive Chinese sweaters at Kmart or exporters who gobbled up billion-dollar contracts from Beijing.
Three numbers told the story: $31 billion in Chinese exports to the United States and $9 billion in American exports to China, which are worth about 150,000 American jobs.
Why didn't Mr. Clinton recognize all this when he threatened to withdraw China's benefits last May? Because the President was acting both on his campaign promises, which none of his advisers had yet told him were unrealistic, and to satisfy liberal Democrats in Congress who were telling him that if he did not do something about China on his own, they would do it through legislation.
The President's basic mistake was overestimating the power of the Congressional lobby on human rights in China; they were not nearly as strong in Congress as they claimed to be, and were growing weaker with every business day.
 
Business Is Business
 In the end, the Chinese understood this political change better than anyone. They could see exactly what was going on in this country. They could read it on the editorial pages, they could hear it in the debates and they played on it deftly.
Consider today's perfectly timed story on the front page of The Wall Street Journal, which stated that Boeing is within weeks of cutting a deal to sell China more than 50 commercial airliners valued at $5 billion.
For an authoritarian regime, the Chinese understood a lot more about how to play American politics than the Clinton Administration understood about China's politics.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS TO MAINTAIN TRADE PRIVILEGES FOR CHINA'S GOODS;
A Policy Reversal

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
President Clinton renewed China's favorable trade status today with virtually no conditions, and said he would abandon his effort to use trade as a lever to force Beijing to make progress on human rights.
While Mr. Clinton said there had been some improvement in human rights, he acknowledged that China's actions had fallen far short of the steps he set forth a year ago as conditions for renewing the trade privileges. But he said that as punishment he would do little more than prohibit imports of Chinese guns and ammunition. 
 Sounding anguished and defensive, the President said at a White House news conference that China's economic and strategic importance had grown so great that it would be unwise to impose the broad sanctions he had threatened.
"We have reached the end of the usefulness of that policy," Mr. Clinton said, "and it is time to take a new path toward the achievement of our common objectives." [Excerpts, page A8.]
Many American corporations and consumers welcomed his decision. [Business Day, page D1.]
But Mr. Clinton's announcement came after weeks of agonizing at the highest levels of the Administration, where officials had to contend with shifting signals from the Chinese Government and a last-minute campaign from rights advocates. While his decision had been expected, Mr. Clinton had not been expected to offer so frank an argument that his own approach had been misguided.
Congress could still seek to impose sanctions on China, as it sought unsuccessfully to do during the Bush Administration. But Mr. Clinton's remarks amounted to a call for an end to a rite that since the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 has caused annual battles linking China's trade status to its human rights conduct.
Thus Mr. Clinton cast aside the executive order issued last year, when he became the first President to tie China's trade benefits to progress in the treatment of dissidents and political prisoners. He also cast aside his 1992 campaign language, when he accused President Bush of "coddling" Chinese dictators by blocking legislation that would have punished China for its human rights record.
While saying that China continues to commit "very serious human rights abuses," Mr. Clinton noted that Beijing had made some progress toward meeting his demands.
But he made clear his belief that broad trade sanctions had become too heavy a club to wave at a time when commerce between the two countries has grown to billions of dollars and accounts for tens of thousands of American jobs.
As a single punitive act, Mr. Clinton ordered a ban on imports of Chinese guns and ammunition, which amount to $200 million a year. He also said he would maintain the few Bush Administration sanctions that remain in effect, including prohibitions on shipments of United States weapons and other goods to the Chinese military.
But those measures will affect only a tiny fraction of the $31 billion in goods that China sold to the United States last year. Thus Mr. Clinton has sided with those in Congress and his Administration who warned against jeopardizing relations with Beijing.
Members of Congress who had called for firmer action expressed anger and disappointment. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said he planned to introduce legislation on trade sanctions that would "be more likely to encourage the Chinese Government to improve its practices on trade and human rights."
Human Rights Watch, which led the battle to block renewal of the trade benefits, voiced even greater disdain, accusing Mr. Clinton of "effectively removing all pressure on China to improve its human rights practices."
 
Business Groups Pleased
 But the decision was applauded by business groups, including the United States Chamber of Congress, which likened the policy of tying human rights to trade to "using a blunt instrument for brain surgery."
The decision by Mr. Clinton leaves intact the Jackson-Vanik Amendment of two decades ago that ties trade benefits for Communist countries to their immigration policies. But since it first won the privilege in 1980, that barrier has never prevented China from winning renewal of its "most favored nation" trade status, which allows it to send its exports to the United States at the lowest applicable tariffs.
Instead, Mr. Clinton's approach becomes roughly comparable to Washington's strategy toward other nations -- using diplomatic pressure but not holding trade hostage in efforts to make progress on rights.
Today, Mr. Clinton mentioned China's importance in putting pressure on North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program as one of the reasons he believed it wise to tread softly. He also cited China's role as the most populous country, with 1.2 billion people, and the third-largest economy.
 
The Vanity of Pressure
 But the fundamental reason he offered for the shift amounted to a repudiation of a year's worth of American pressure tactics. He said there would be "inevitably a reluctance" for China to act on rights issues "if it looks like every step that is taken, is taken under the pressure of the United States, some outside power making them do it."
Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, nevertheless suggested that the President's strong stance during the 1992 campaign and last year had "allowed us to achieve the progress that has been achieved this year" in focusing Beijing's attention on human rights.
Among the areas Mr. Clinton singled out as examples of progress were China's resolution of all emigration cases involving dissidents and its agreement to a plan to prevent goods produced with prison labor from being shipped to the United States.
But he used strong language to criticize China for its "arrest and detention of those who peacefully voice their opinions" and for its continued repression of religious and cultural traditions in Tibet.
 
A Round of Consultations
 Before making his announcement, just after 5 P.M., Mr. Clinton spent much of the day on the phone with Congressional leaders and foreign policy experts to gauge their reactions to the steps he might take. He also met for 30 minutes with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who urged the President to impose at least symbolic sanctions, Administration officials said.
Among those who welcomed Mr. Clinton's decision was Rep. Gary Ackerman, Democrat of New York and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific. Mr. Ackerman said the separation of trade policy from China's human rights record "will promote American prosperity while enhancing our ability to advance American values and interests throughout the world."
But the minimal penalties Mr. Clinton imposed for what he described as China's "very serious human rights abuses" left labor leaders, human rights advocates and some Democratic lawmakers voicing scorn.
Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., called the step "a disappointing setback to those who are risking their lives and liberty in China for the values and principles that America was created to advance."
Rep. Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who joined Senator Mitchell in efforts to persuade Mr. Clinton to hew to a hard line, described her reaction as one of "great disappointment." She said she would join in efforts to overrule Mr. Clinton with legislation in the belief "that sanctions on China are in order."
