LENGTH: 1456 words

HEADLINE: FLORIDA PREPARES NEW BASIS TO SUE TOBACCO INDUSTRY

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 26

 BODY:
The State of Florida is preparing the ground for a new attack on the tobacco industry that is intended to make it easier to hold cigarette manufacturers responsible for diseases associated with smoking.
Gov. Lawton Chiles today signed legislation that would allow the state to file a suit on behalf of all its Medicaid patients who smoke. Such class-action suits make it more difficult for cigarette companies to defend themselves by using the two main arguments they have successfully employed in cases brought by individual smokers. 
 In beating back every individual suit that has been brought against them, the companies have maintained that anyone who takes up smoking knowingly assumes all the risks associated with smoking and that those who sue did not conclusively prove that smoking caused their illnesses.
Such arguments are generally less successful when people sue as a class or group and show through broad-based demographic and health statistics that they were harmed by a product or activity. Class action suits have been brought successfully in recent years to recover damages in cases of exposure to asbestos and the use of breast implants.
Other states are likely to follow Florida's lead and the tobacco industry is concerned that Florida's action could make it vulnerable to new efforts to collect hundreds of millions of dollars in damages.
The industry suffered a new public relations setback today when the chairman of the Council for Tobacco Research, which identifies itself as an independent research organization run by a board of distinguished scientists, told a Congressional subcommittee that the council had carried out research suggested by lawyers for tobacco companies. [Page A16.]
At a news conference this morning in Tallahassee, the state capital, Mr. Chiles made it clear that Florida planned to move promptly to seek reimbursement from tobacco companies for the costs of treating Medicaid patients with smoking-related health problems. "We're going to take the Marlboro Man to court," Mr. Chiles, who is running for a second term in office, promised today after signing the bill.
A report just released by the state of Florida's Agency for Health Care Administration concluded that smoking-related illnesses, including lung cancer and emphysema, have cost Florida taxpayers at least $1.2 billion in Medicaid payments since 1989. The state agency also estimates that tobacco products are responsible for the deaths of about 28,000 people in Florida each year, many of them elderly people who have recently retired to the state after living most of their lives elsewhere.
Under the new law, which the Florida Legislature approved last month without public discussion as an obscure amendment to a Medicaid fraud bill, the state is authorized to sue tobacco companies on behalf of its Medicaid patients who suffer from smoking-related illnesses. The law also allows the state to introduce new types of statistical evidence, while prohibiting cigarette manufacturers from using the assumption-of-risk defense, with which they have fended off legal challenges in the past.
The threat of the new legislation to tobacco companies lies not only in Florida's ability to act on behalf of the entire class of smokers on Medicaid but also in the state's more privileged legal position as a sovereign entity. "The state can change the legal criteria for a suit and that is what we have done," said Harold D. Lewis, general counsel of the state health care agency. "Once we are past the threshold of showing that a cigarette is a harmful product, we can use statistics rather than bring in all 650,000 Medicaid patients."
 
Suit by Mississippi
 Earlier this week, Mississippi filed suit against 13 tobacco companies seeking to hold them legally responsible for the health consequences of smoking.
"Mississippi filed its suit under existing common law, whereas Florida has changed the law to make it easier to bring this sort of case," said Jennifer Lew, managing lawyer for the Tobacco Products Liability Project, an anti-smoking group based in Boston. "It basically tilts the playing field in favor of the state and streamlines the process of getting money from the tobacco companies."
Governor Chiles predicted during a telephone interview that the law, which goes into effect on July 1, will be the tobacco companies' undoing. "I think this will go through all kinds of legal tests, but at the end, I don't think the tobacco companies are going to be able to brag any longer that they have never paid out a dollar in a law suit," he said.
The law enables the state's Attorney General to use a formula based on each tobacco company's market share in collecting damages from cigarette manufacturers whenever they are found guilty of damaging the health of smokers. And it permits the state to sue for any additional harm to Florida residents stemming from fraudulent activity or other criminal violations by tobacco companies.
 
Power Granted Only to State
 The new law, the Medicaid Third Party Recovery Act, applies only when the state of Florida sues on behalf of its Medicaid patients. It would not change the standard of proof required when individual smokers or their families sue tobacco companies for damages. The law covers only economic damages incurred by the state and does not allow it to seek damages for the pain and suffering of patients.
Tobacco companies likely to be affected by the new law declined to comment on the measure. But the Tobacco Institute, an industry trade group based in Washington, attacked Florida's action as inherently unfair. "It is a travesty and poor public policy when legitimate businesses operating legally in the state of Florida are forced to the courthouse steps defenseless and guilty long before the first trial gavel is struck," the organization said in a statement today.
But anti-smoking advocates hailed Florida's action as an important blow against the tobacco industry and a model for the nation. Richard A. Daynard, chairman of the Tobacco Products Liability Project, said the new law was "the most important legislation ever adopted anywhere in the United States" on the issue of "holding cigarette manufacturers financially responsible for the health care costs their products and conduct produce."
The National Association of Attorney Generals said it had no information on how many other states are considering similar legislation. But Ms. Lew of the Tobacco Products Liability Project predicted that many other states would follow Florida's lead as news of the measure spreads.
Lawyers for the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration described the state as an innocent third party.
Governor Chiles said: "Our authority comes from the same place as the authority to sue in breast implant, asbestos and a whole line of other cases. The state does not buy that package of tobacco, so we don't read the warning on the side. We just pay for the carnage."
The law was strongly opposed by Associated Industries of Florida, one of the state's principal business organizations. In a letter to Mr. Chiles last month, Jon L. Shebel, president of the state business group, complained that the legislation "is tailor-made to foster a cottage litigation industry" that would affect all businesses in the form of higher insurance premiums.
In an interview today, Mr. Shebel said he was also concerned that the legal principles contained in the law could easily be extended to other industries, like dairy, beef, sugar, pharmaceuticals and automobiles. He said the language of the statute is so broad that the state could conceivably hold sugar manufacturers responsible for tooth decay and obesity.
Mr. Chiles has already said he was willing to modify the language of the new statute so that it applied only to cigarette manufacturers. But Mr. Shebel said such a change would not be acceptable to Florida businesses and vowed to work for quick repeal.
"It is against the principles of American justice to take all the defenses away from somebody because you don't like them or their product, so that when they arrive at the courthouse steps they are are already guilty by innuendo," he said. "This law makes conviction automatic. There is just no way to defend yourself under this law and that is wrong."
But Mr. Chiles was not sympathetic to the complaints of the tobacco companies. "These are the most arrogant people who have ever lived," he said. "They cover up material they've had for 30 years saying how addictive cigarette smoking is and hide research that could have made smoking less harmful, and then they have the gall to put on this face and say they don't know if they have caused any harm."

PUB-DATE: May 27, 1994,

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1623 words

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
In a Dissonant White House, The Economics Team Hums

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Normally, conflict is what makes news. But what makes the way economic policy is developed in the Clinton Administration newsworthy is the remarkable absence of conflict among prominent officials with strong ambitions, personalities and opinions.
President Clinton's health and welfare policies are being put together in an atmosphere of continual bickering within the Administration, the unhappiness underlined by a spate of unauthorized disclosures by disappointed officials hoping to change preliminary decisions. Foreign policy seems so cacophonous at times that it is often unclear who stands where and what the President thinks. 
 The selection process for top appointments, like Supreme Court Justices, could hardly be more unruly.
But on economic policy, when sharp edges have arisen in internal discussions, they have generally been sanded down before anyone's feelings have been hurt and before they have become public. This has happened on some of the most politically explosive issues faced by the Administration: deficit reduction, environmental regulations, trade with Japan and China, and the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The design of economic policy has gone smoothly in part because the Cabinet members involved have been willing to work as a team and because Mr. Clinton's chief assistant on economic matters, Robert E. Rubin, has been careful not to steal the thunder from the Cabinet secretaries. It is also a result of the President's own deep engagement in economic issues.
Two recent examples illustrate how potential snags have been overcome without bitterness.
In early March, top economic policy makers could not agree on whether President Clinton should invoke a tough trade law provision, called Super 301, that would allow him to impose trade sanctions quickly against Japan if it failed to open its markets.
Mr. Rubin, whose job is to coordinate the team, arranged for a session with the President. With all the top economic officials assembled, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, was given 10 minutes to present the case for Super 301, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, was allotted 10 minutes to argue against it.
Mr. Clinton came down on the side of Mr. Kantor, but no one's nose got out of joint. "When you're all around the room and the President hears all sides fairly presented and then makes a call, people don't go away grumpy," said Alan S. Blinder, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers.
 
No Undercutting Allowed
 The other example involves the drafting of the budget for the next fiscal year. Normally, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown would have been central players, since their influence over economic policy ranges far beyond matters directly before the departments they head.
But Mr. Rubin worried that other Cabinet secretaries might feel that those at the budget table would have an unfair advantage in getting money for their own departments. So at Mr. Rubin's suggestion, Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Reich and Mr. Brown stepped aside, except when budget items in their own departments were debated.
"We are all careful not to undercut each other," Mr. Reich said. "We understand that if one of us does, that is an open invitation for others to."
They coordinate their public relations as well as their policies. Early last week, anticipating correctly that the Federal Reserve Board would raise short-term interest rates, an action over which they have no control, the officials who deal with economic matters decided not to criticize the Fed.
Mr. Rubin said the system was successful "because everybody has come to see that it is in their self-interest to work together and not to go running off on their own to the President or the press every time there is a disagreement."
 
Working as a Team
 Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush basically delegated the making of economic policy, and it was usually to one person: David A. Stockman in Mr. Reagan's first term; James A. Baker 3d in his second term, and Richard G. Darman during the Bush Presidency.
Other senior officials, feeling frozen out, regularly sought back channels to the President to undermine the dominant figures and frequently bad-mouthed colleagues and their policies behind their backs.
Mr. Clinton criticized this process during his Presidential campaign and said he was determined to have his economic policy developed by a team. The first appointments he announced after the election were in the economics area: Mr. Bentsen; Leon E. Panetta, budget director; Ms. Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Mr. Rubin, head of a new coordinating structure called the National Economic Council.
"The success of our economic action agenda will depend not only on the talents of these people," Mr. Clinton said as he announced the appointments, "but also on their capacity to work together."
 
A Model From Truman Era
 Mr. Clinton said he was modeling the National Economic Council on the National Security Council, a White House agency dating from the Truman Administration that is charged with coordinating the Government's foreign and military policy. And, expressing his admiration for the foreign policy process of the Bush Administration, he said he wanted Mr. Rubin to function as Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, did: working more or less behind the scenes to collect the views of other officials in the Government and then offer them to the President in a coherent fashion.
By all accounts, that is what Mr. Rubin has done. Most economic issues are simply decided within one department or another. The Treasury, for example, has sole jurisdiction over the question of the value of the dollar, and, despite his years of experience on Wall Street, Mr. Rubin has not intervened. But he serves as a filter for the big issues that involve more than one department or agency. The National Economic Council is less a structure than a process of funneling big decisions through him.
He is clearly the most influential member of the President's economic team. But he has been so careful to stay in the background that not one American in a thousand would recognize him.
Mr. Rubin proved his mettle early on. Just before Christmas in 1992, the main economic advisers went to Little Rock, Ark., for their first long meeting with Mr. Clinton. Mr. Rubin organized the trip and decided who would make presentations to the President-elect on what. But he stayed in the shadows and made no presentation himself.
"Bob is not a high-profile fellow," observed Mr. Bentsen, who said he would never have joined the Clinton Administration if anyone else had been given the job Mr. Rubin took. The two have known each other for years. Mr. Rubin, who was co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, the Wall Street investment bank, was the administrator of Mr. Bentsen's blind trust when Mr. Bentsen was a Senator from Texas.
 
Clinton's Grasp of Issues
 Mr. Rubin, who hardly ever makes public statements or goes on television, said he understood that it was important for Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Panetta and others to be the public spokesmen. "If I were in competition with them for the limelight," he said, "this thing wouldn't work."
Mr. Rubin's task of encouraging teamwork was eased somewhat because Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Panetta, veterans of Congress, were used to working in a group. "The National Economic Council is the equivalent of caucusing with a group of members on your committee who represent different viewpoints," said Mr. Panetta, who, as a Congressman from California, was chairman of the House Budget Committee.
But what really drives the process, Mr. Rubin and others agreed, is Mr. Clinton's grasp of economic issues. The President himself makes the big decisions on economics.
On the most important economic and political question of the year last year -- how much deficit reduction to seek -- the advisers disagreed. Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Panetta, among others, sought much deeper cuts in the budget than did Mr. Reich, Mr. Brown or Ms. Tyson. Mr. Rubin presented both sides without taking a position himself. The President decided in favor of the bigger cuts.
"He understands this; he really does," Mr. Rubin said. "I don't mean he just read a paper on some topic or other. He has a feel for these economic issues."
 
Making It Look Easy
 That helps explain why economic policy seems to run more smoothly than foreign policy in this Administration and why the reverse was true under Mr. Bush.
"It's clear," said Michael J. Boskin, who was chairman of Mr. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, "that there's a mirror image in their interests and in their allocation of time."
Mr. Boskin said that while he objected to much of the Clinton economic program, he admired the way it was developed. But he said he was not sure that the Clinton process could be transferred to another Administration with different personalities.
Walter Williams, a professor of public affairs at the University of Washington in Seattle and an expert on the organization of the White House, agreed. The process can only work, he said, when the President's style is to hear different points of view. On economic policy, he said, Presidents Nixon, Reagan and Bush wanted the staff to present them with a finished product.
And Labor Secretary Reich offered another reason that the Clinton system might not work in other circumstances. "It's easy for trust to develop and to avoid leaks and finger-pointing and back-stabbing when the economy is going well," he said. "The real test will come when things are not going well."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Call: Avoid Isolating China

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from today's remarks by President Clinton on the renewal of China's status as a favored trade partner:
Our relationship with China is important to all Americans. We have significant interests in what happens there and what happens between us. 
 China has an atomic arsenal and a vote and a veto in the U.N. Security Council. It is a major factor in Asian and global security. We share important interests, such as in a nuclear-free Korean peninsula and in sustaining the global environment.
China is also the world's fastest-growing economy. Over $8 billion of United States exports to China last year supported over 150,000 American jobs.
I have received Secretary Christopher's letter recommending, as required by last year's executive order -- reporting to me on the conditions in that executive order. He has reached a conclusion with which I agree, that the Chinese did not achieve overall significant progress in all the areas outlined in the executive order relating to human rights, even though clearly there was progress made in important areas, including the resolution of all emigration cases, the establishment of a memorandum of understanding with regard to how prison labor issues would be resolved, the adherence to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and other issues.
Nevertheless, serious human rights abuses continue in China, including the arrest and detention of those who peacefully voice their opinions and the repression of Tibet's religious and cultural traditions.
The question for us now is, given the fact that there has been some progress but that not all the requirements of the executive order were met, how can we best advance the cause of human rights and the other profound interests the United States has in our relationship with China?
I have decided that the United States should renew Most Favored Nation trading status toward China. This decision, I believe, offers us the best opportunity to lay the basis for long-term sustainable progress in human rights and for the advancement of our other interests with China.
Extending M.F.N. will avoid isolating China and instead will permit us to engage the Chinese with not only economic contacts but with cultural, educational and other contacts, and with a continuing aggressive effort in human rights -- an approach that I believe will make it more likely that China will play a responsible role, both at home and abroad.
I am moving, therefore, to delink human rights from the annual extension of Most Favored Nation trading status for China. That linkage has been constructive during the past year, but I believe, based on our aggressive contacts with the Chinese in the past several months, that we have reached the end of the usefulness of that policy, and it is time to take a new path toward the achievement of our constant objectives. We need to place our relationship into a larger and more productive framework.
In view of the continuing human rights abuses, I am extending the sanctions imposed by the United States as a result of the events in Tiananmen Square. And I am also banning the import of munitions, principally guns and ammunition, from China.
I am also pursuing a new and vigorous American program to support those in China working to advance the cause of human rights and democracy. This program will include increased broadcasts for Radio-Free Asia and the Voice of America, increased support for nongovernmental organizations working on human rights in China, and the development, with American business leaders, of a voluntary set of principles for business activity in China.
I don't want to be misunderstood about this. China continues to commit very serious human rights abuses. Even as we engage the Chinese on military, political and economic issues, we intend to stay engaged with those in China who suffer from human rights abuses.
The United States must remain a champion of their liberties.
I believe the question, therefore, is not whether we continue to support human rights in China but how we can best support human rights in China and advance our other very significant issues and interests. I believe we can do it by engaging the Chinese.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The actions I have taken today to advance our security, to advance our prosperity, to advance our ideals, I believe are the important and appropriate ones. I believe, in other words, this is in the strategic economic and political interests of both the United States and China, and I am confident that over the long run this decision will prove to be the correct one.

HEADLINE: Proposal Gains to Impose Antitrust Rules on Insurers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Efforts to modify the McCarran-Ferguson Act, which exempts insurance companies from antitrust rules, advanced yesterday when Representative Jack Brooks, a Democrat of Texas, said he would introduce such a bill when Congress returned from the Memorial Day holiday.
Mr. Brooks, who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee and a longtime critic of the insurance industry, has already gained the support of many insurance companies, consumer groups and the Justice Department. Supporters say the bill will produce more diversity in the prices and types of insurance policies. 
 Some insurers, including small- and medium-sized companies represented by the National Association of Independent Insurers, remain opposed to the proposal.
 Mr. Brooks said the bill he planned to introduce would revoke the insurance industry's 49-year-old exemption from antitrust laws except for activities where cooperation among companies is thought to help make insurance more widely available.
For example, insurers could continue to use similar policy forms and band together to insure large risks like nuclear reactors. States could continue to require companies to join pools to insure customers who might be shunned by individual companies.
An important part of Mr. Brooks's proposal would change the way insurance companies analyze data about claims and costs to set their prices. Companies could continue to share information about losses, but they would have to stop using industry-owned organizations to make estimates about inflation, interest rates, overhead costs and legal trends. Rather than use industry-run organizations, insurers would be required to make estimates themselves or buy them from independent companies.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Drop Again

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing the first time for state unemployment benefits declined by 1,000 last week, less than expected but enough to drop the claims level to the lowest in a month, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said a seasonally adjusted 366,000 people filed initial claims in the week that ended last Saturday, down from 367,000 the previous week. It was the second consecutive decline and the lowest number of claims since April 30. 
 A somewhat larger decline was predicted by most economists as warmer weather creates demand for additional workers in some seasonal industries. Analysts say the nation's job picture is steadily improving.
The four-week moving average of initial claims was up to its highest level in more than three months. The Labor Department said the average rose 7,500, to 366,750, from the previous week's revised figure of 359,250. That was the highest level since Feb. 19, 1994, when frigid winter weather forced workers off jobs across the Northeast and Midwest.
The four-week average was higher because two weeks of declines followed two weeks of bigger increases.

HEADLINE: Solzhenitsyn Flies Home, Vowing Moral Involvement 88

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, May 26

 BODY:
Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn flew away today from the nation that was his home in exile for nearly two decades. In an hourlong exchange with reporters at the airport, he paid tribute to Vermont, where he was granted the privacy to write, and promised to "take an active part in the social life" of his native Russia.
"We were very friendly with the Vermonters, and the people and the environment -- all of that put together -- created for me 18 years of so intense creative work that really I could never have dreamed that this would be possible," he said. "This was the most creative period of my life, the most productive period of my life, and of course I leave with much emotion." 
 Mr. Solzhenitsyn, his 20-year-old son Stephan, and his wife, Natalia, left Anchorage International Airport aboard a regularly scheduled Alaska Airlines flight to Magadan and Vladivostock shortly before 1 P.M. Magadan, a city in Russia's Far East, served as an administrative center for the Russian prison system that the author has painstakingly documented.
[Mr. Solzhenitsyn arrived Friday in Magadan, Russia. He stooped and touched the ground with both hands after emerging from the Alaska Airlines plane, The Associated Press reported.
["I come to bow to the land where many hundreds of thousands of our countrymen, who were executed, are buried," he said. "Today, in this period with so much political change, people easily forget these millions of victims."]
 He planned a slow journey across Siberia by train to his new home in Moscow, 4,200 miles to the west.
Mr. Solzhenitsyn, 75, said he wanted to make a moral and spiritual difference in Russia. Speaking in Russian, with his son interpreting, he said he did not intend to take any position in government.
 
A New View of the Gulag
 "But, I will take an active part in the social life of Russia," he said. "And in so much as my voice will be heard, I would like to have some influence on the recovery of Russia's health from the most grave situation in which Russia finds itself today."
Asked why he chose to travel to Moscow through Alaska and Siberia, he referred to his life in internal exile. "Siberia I only saw from the window of a prison convoy car, with the exception of one short moment," he said.
Russia's current problems were also on his mind. "On a basic level, the first thing in my opinion as a writer, the most important thing," he said, is that the former atmosphere be cleared -- be aired out.
"For example, in Germany there was a long period of de-Nazification, not just in a legal or judicial sense, but in a spiritual and in a moral way. But in the U.S.S.R.," he went on, "none of this happened at all.
"The atmosphere remains heavy, stained with Communism. And upon all of that came the onslaught, really th epidemic, of incredibly fast, quick, rampant capitalism, in which some people grew incredibly rich very soon; an enrichment of a few, not by production, but rather really by stealing from others.
"But before we can get to economic problems, of which there are mountains and mountains, and talk about government, we must first clear the spiritual atmosphere, without doing which we would simply suffocate."
 
Thanks to Vermont
 Mr. Solzhenitsyn was a victim of the prison camps himself, serving eight years as a political prisoner after criticizing Stalin in letters to a friend.
His experiences led to his novel "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich." He was labeled a traitor for exposing Stalin's repressive rule in "The Gulag Archipelago" and was expelled from the Soviet Union in 1974, spending two years in Europe and the last 18 in Cavendish, Vt.
Mr. Solzhenitsyn thanked the people of the United States, particularly his neighbors in Vermont, for providing him with a home.
"All of the 20 years that I lived in the West I was stateless," Mr. Solzhenitsyn said at the news conference. "I would not take the citizenship of any other country. Now, as I return to Russia, I have a passport."
The author withdrew a red passport from his khaki jacket and, smiling broadly, said: "Unfortunately, it still says Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. But this is a Russian passport."

HEADLINE: Back to Business on China Trade

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Now that President Clinton has decided to keep China in the family of America's most favored trading nations, despite that country's human rights violations, sighs of relief are coming from much of Corporate America and from many individuals -- certainly those who think about China as a source of inexpensive consumer goods.
China is booming. And that means big business for American companies like Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, which together sold $2 billion in aircraft to China last year, and AT&T, which describes China -- not the United States -- as its fastest-growing market. These companies were loud voices in the lobbying effort for an extension of China's trade privileges.
 
 
China Is 'Critical for Us'
 "If 'most favored nation' had not been extended, we would have been impacted greatly; it is critical for us to be successful in China," said Susan Berman, a spokeswoman for AT&T, which expects to collect $3 billion in revenues from its China operations by the year 2000, up from $500 million last year and $250 million in 1992. 
 Alongside the multinationals, there is the ordinary American. Without realizing it, he or she may have obtained a few more dollars in selling the family car because of the China market. This is because Chinese families who are affluent enough to buy cars are putting upward pressure on American car prices. The Chinese spent $600 million last year to purchase American-made passenger vehicles, many of them used cars, the Commerce Department reported.
 But American exporters are not the primary winners. The China boom has opened up a market for American products, but it is not a big one yet. Exports rose to a modest $8.7 billion in 1993 from $3.9 billion in 1985. Most of that was the commercial aircraft and the telecommunications equipment that AT&T is shipping to China to build a modern telephone network there, one in which AT&T already has an ownership stake.
 
 
A $150 Million Investment
 "Over the next 24 months, we will invest $150 million in projects that we know of now," said Andrew Myers, an AT&T spokesman, "and we have a Chinese work force of 800, and that will triple over the next two or three years."
The much bigger business, for the moment, is imports. While China shipped only $3.8 billion worth of products to the United States in 1985 -- roughly equivalent to what it bought from this country -- by last year Chinese shipments had jumped to $31.5 billion, or 3.5 times the level of exports. There was some Chinese machinery and raw materials in the mix, but for the most part, Americans purchased Chinese toys, bicycles, shoes, kitchenware and, especially, fabric and clothing.
"If you look at the imbalance of imports over exports, there is more imbalance with China than with any other country," said Thea Lee, a trade expert at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. "Even our trade imbalance with Japan is less."
Nearly 15 percent of all textiles and apparel shipped to the United States now comes from China, said Jay Meltzer, a textile analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. That does not please some American textile manufacturers, and they were not among the lobbyists pushing for the extension of trade benefits for China.
But American retailers were. They buy from China about 6 percent of all the clothing sold in stores across the country, especially inexpensive clothing. A few companies, among them Levi Strauss, are cutting back imports from China out of concern for human rights. But they are far outnumbered by companies like the Gap, J. C. Penney, Sears, Roebuck and Kmart, which applauded Mr. Clinton's action yesterday.
The President did, however, cut back the amount of clothing and fabrics that China can export to the United States, even as a favored nation. If the President had not extended China's status as a "most favored nation," tariffs would have shot up for virtually all Chinese imports.
 
 
 
View Held by Retailers
 And if that had happened, would these retailers have turned back to American manufacturers for the same goods?
If the President had canceled China's trading privileges, would the higher tariffs have made American manufacturers competitive with the Chinese?
Probably not, Mr. Meltzer at Goldman, Sachs said, reflecting the view held by most retailers.
"The fact is that there are so many other low-wage countries poised to ship to us, that the goods now coming from China would come from another country," he said.
"Let's say the China price is 100 and now it will go up to 125. American manufacturers would still have to compete at 100. If American retailers did not get cheap dresses from China, they would get them from Mexico, or, hey, Vietnam."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
17 IN BRONX FACE EXTORTION CHARGES
The Federal Government charged 17 people with running a sophisticated extortion ring in the South Bronx that required drug dealers to pay for the right to sell heroin. The gang grossed more than $100,000 a week for seven years, the authorities charged, killing and torturing those who did not cooperate. A1.
 

POLICE SERGEANT CHARGED
A New York City police sergeant was arraigned in Brooklyn on charges that he agreed to provide protection to a drug dealer during a cocaine sale, and that he offered to help another dealer through the use of a police computer. The sergeant, Robert Santana, 33, is one of the first supervisory officers in the city to be arrested for direct involvement in drug trafficking during corruption inquiries in the last two years. B3.
 
EVIDENCE GONE IN STATEN ISLAND INQUIRY
A hooded sweatshirt that Ernest Sayon was wearing during a fatal struggle with police officers on Staten Island last month has been either lost or destroyed, police officials said. It is not clear whether the sweatshirt would be crucial in the investigation into whether the police used excessive force in arresting Mr. Sayon. B3.
 
HINTS OF AN ECONOMIC RECOVERY
New York City added almost 10,000 jobs in the first three months of this year, the largest such increase since the recession began in 1989. B3.
 
SCHLESINGER'S FAREWELL
Delivering a commencement address at Town Hall that also served as his farewell to the City University of New York Graduate School, the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. condemned campus speech codes and "the agitation for censorship" in the name of multiculturalism. B3.
 
GIRL, 6, IS RAPED IN CHINATOWN
A 6-year-old girl was raped on the roof of a Chinatown apartment building, the police said. Investigators believe the same man has accosted at least four other girls in the area in the last year. B3.

OH, TO BE IN ALBANY
The last time Alfred B. DelBello was in the State Senate chamber in Albany, he was presiding, a function of his job as Lieutenant Governor. Now Mr. DelBello, a former Westchester County Executive, wants to return to the Senate, this time as a member. B4.
 
PARK ACQUISITION SHOWS PROMISE
A financial package began taking shape today for the public acquisition of Sterling Forest, a 17,500-acre private woodland in Orange County. It would be the largest new public park in the Northeast in 50 years. B5.

HEADLINE: Assessing the Odds for Carter Hawley's Overhaul

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
There are two schools of thought on Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.: One is that the West Coast department store operator is destined to crawl back into bankruptcy protection and the other is that it will be one of the decade's most remarkable corporate turnarounds.
The dubious, Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service among them, point to the duct tape holding together the carpeting in many of the company's 83 stores. And that is only the most obvious sign that the retailer, whose three chains, the Broadway, Emporium and Weinstock's, which operate mostly in the West and Southwest, is overdue for a stem-to-stern overhaul that will require hundreds of millions of dollars. 
 They note that it shoulders more than $1 billion in debt, that its cash flow is really more of a trickle, and that its lenders have waived or amended the requirements of its credit agreements at least six times in the last 12 months.
 
'All the Tools They Need'
 Even David M. Schulte, a general partner in the Zell/Chilmark Fund, the $1 billion investment fund that brought Carter Hawley out of bankruptcy in 1992, concedes that that the future of the $2 billion-a-year retailer, based in Los Angeles, is less than clear-cut. "Right now, they have all the tools they need for the foreseeable future," he said. "If they make their plan, the company should be self-financing. Of course, I have no idea if they will make their plan."
Nevertheless, he and the other optimists have stubbornly pinned their hopes on David L. Dworkin, the soft-spoken, enigmatic merchant who has weathered a little more than a year at the company's helm, and his team of executives. "I think he's an absolute genius," said Daniel D. Barry, a retail analyst at Merrill Lynch whose doubts about Carter Hawley evaporated after a long conversation with Mr. Dworkin. "You haven't seen it in the numbers yet, and you haven't really seen it in the stores yet. But you're going to."
Analysts expect that sales of the company, which is scheduled to release its first-quarter earnings today, will be flat compared with the corresponding period last year, largely because of four stores that are still closed as a result of earthquake damage. Cash flow is also expected to match last year's, although the net loss may increase.
Other news this week was no more comforting. Carter Hawley said two senior merchants would depart as part of a move toward greater "lateralization," the term Mr. Dworkin uses to describe efforts to flatten a previously rigid hierarchy. But they leave the company with only one merchant, Mr. Dworkin, in its senior ranks.
The high hopes for Carter Hawley take root in Mr. Dworkin's track record at a British retail chain called BHS that many had written off as moribund before he arrived in late 1989. Six months later, sales had jumped about 20 percent because of a few simple if unorthodox changes the upstart Yank imposed.
His fans are betting he can pull off the same sort of miracle at Carter Hawley. In fact, many of the strategies he has put into effect were first tested at BHS, where he shook up a hidebound corporate culture and slaughtered several sacred cows. "We've been blowing up the place," Mr. Dworkin is fond of saying about the changes at Carter Hawley.
Or as his right-hand woman, Elayne M. Garofolo, executive vice president of sales promotion and marketing, says, "The best thing about this job is that the only rule we have is not to do anything the way it was done before."
The experiment that Mr. Dworkin's team is most proud of is the Home Dome, an enormous tent set up in the Northridge area of Los Angeles, on the site of a Broadway store that collapsed during the earthquake. The store was one of the company's most productive, and Home Dome, built to supply customers replacing goods damaged in the quake, has been an unexpected home run for Carter Hawley.
But Carter Hawley's problems are more extensive than those of BHS. While BHS needed a clearly defined merchandising strategy, its stores did not require the immense investment in physical refurbishing that Carter Hawley's stores do. The 83 Carter Hawley stores have worn carpeting, chipped cosmetics cases and whole departments that are so off the beaten path that customers need a road map to find them. They will need between $500 million and $600 million to refurbish.
 
Facing Big Competitors
 Nor did BHS have to confront the level of feisty competition that Carter Hawley faces in the California market, where Robinsons-May, Macy's, Bullock's and Nordstrom are all clamoring for a pool of customers that shrank during the recession.
Moreover, while retailers consolidate to achieve greater efficiencies and buying power, Carter Hawley will have difficulty matching the advantages of competitors with six or seven times its revenues. In fact, its potential as an acquisition target has helped support its shares at an unusually high multiple despite its many challenges and a disappointing performance last year.
Mr. Dworkin believes Carter Hawley's critics are shortsighted. "There's a surprising naivete about our situation here," he said. "In England, everyone understood that a turnaround wasn't going to happen overnight -- that things might get worse before they got better."
He predicts that Carter Hawley will begin to show signs of a turnaround by late 1995 or early 1996, once new strategies have taken hold and about 30 or so stores have been remodeled.
The company is making extensive use of demographic research to find niches that the Robinsons-Mays of the world may overlook. Ms. Garofolo has mined the data base linked to Carter Hawley's proprietary credit cards and spent almost $2 million to understand who the company's customers are.
Mr. Dworkin estimated that as much as 70 percent of the company's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- Ebitda, a measure of cash flow used to gauge the performance of highly leveraged companies -- reflect "quick wins," quick, low-cost improvements in displays and the location of merchandise. These changes are intended to punch up a store's business until the company starts a full remodeling project.
 
Away With Furniture
 Carter Hawley has pared whole categories of merchandise like furniture and consumer electronics, which took up floor space but never were blockbusters. The five least-profitable categories occupied roughly a third of total space but generated only 11 percent of profits. "What I wish people would look at is that we've managed not to lose sales, even though we've just wiped out several categories," Mr. Dworkin said.
Mr. Dworkin has also jettisoned almost half of the company's traditional suppliers in hopes of making Carter Hawley a more significant customer for the remaining vendors. A new cast of characters populates the company's executive offices, some of whom worked with Mr. Dworkin when he was at Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman Marcus and Bonwit Teller.
Carter Hawley will need sales of at least $150 per square foot before it can finance capital expenditures without going to the market for additional help. Last year, its sales per square foot were $138, markedly lower than at competitors.
Both Mr. Dworkin and Mr. Schulte of Zell/Chilmark said the nearly $300 million in new financing raised last year, combined with improved cash flow, would cover capital needs through 1996 -- if the company can also meet projections in its business plan.
That's a big if, considering that Carter Hawley projected in late 1992 that it would produce $96 million of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization last year and instead served up a little more than $22 million.
But Mr. Schulte said the forecasts in the disclosure statement Carter Hawley filed when it emerged from bankruptcy had been radically revised. He argued that the original projections, drawn up by the company's old management team, were based on "faulty premises and a business plan with no intellectual status."
The company is amending its credit line, supplied by the GE Capital Corporation, to reflect more realistic targets, Mr. Schulte said.
"David & Company are responsible for the business, and we're responsible for giving them what they need to do it," he said. "It's our job to make sure the resources are there, and we're in this for the long pull."

HEADLINE: Group Urges Tough Limits on Logging in Southeast

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 26

 BODY:
As the Forest Service reassesses policies on logging on public lands, a report released here contends that recreation and tourism in the forests bring in far more money than timber harvests.
The report by the Wilderness Society recommends that the Forest Service strictly limit logging in the 3.8 million acres in six national forests that it manages in five states in the Southeast. 
 The study said the average annual gross timber sales in the area totaled $32 million compared with $379 million in gross economic benefits associated with recreation and tourism.
"It is clear that current management, which continues to emphasize timber production and associated programs at the expense of biodiversity and recreation, is out of step with economic realities in the area," said Peter Morton, a forest economist who conducted the environmental group's study.
 
Logging on Private Land
 The public land in the region amounts to only 10 percent of the region's timber producing property. A vast majority of the forest land is privately owned and is subject to few if any restrictions on logging. But Robert Slocum, the executive vice president of the North Carolina Foresters Association, said the industry was concerned about the conservation group's study and recommendations. Many in the industry fear that any restrictions on public land are eventually imposed on private land.
At Sparks Lumber Mill, a family-owned operation in Ellijay, Ga., 120 miles north of here, Sandy Sparks, the general manager and co-owner of the mill which employs 31 people and has contracts with 120 loggers, said, "We would be devastated if they cut back more and so would the local poultry industry, which buys everything from wooden pallets to building lumber to sawdust for the floors of their chicken coops from us."
Robert Lentz, the deputy regional forester for the Southeast, said the agency welcomed the group's study. He said the group's study dovetailed with the agency's new mandate from the Clinton Administration to reassess regulations, viewing the entire region, its wildlife and biodiversity as an ecosystem rather than a timber production resource.
 
Drawbacks of Tourism
 He said the agency was hearing more and more about eco-tourism, which he said was a valid part of the economies of communities in the region. But, like the industry officials, Mr. Lentz also contended that the region needed a diversified economy rather than one that depends on a single sector. He also pointed out that tourism and recreation could also cause environmental damage in forests as troublesome as that caused by logging operations.
The Wilderness Society report, called "Charting a New Course: National Forests in the Southern Appalachians," also comes at a time of rising demand for timber from the Southeast because of new restrictions on logging in the vast public lands in the West and Northwest. There, efforts to save endangered species have severely limited the private and public acres available for logging, said Thomas J. Straka, a forest economist at Clemson University.
"Can the South and Southeast make up for the shortfall in supply from the West?" Mr. Straka asked. "No, it can't. But the price of lumber is up and they are going to harvest timber more and more on private land if they can't do it on public land here to try to meet the demand for lumber."

HEADLINE: Alzheimer's To Be Focus Of New Effort

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
A major private center for research into Alzheimer's disease will be established at Rockefeller University in Manhattan to refocus the nation's efforts against the debilitating condition, scientists and philanthropists said today.
Zachary Fisher, a prominent figure in the real estate and construction industries, and David Rockefeller, the executive committee chairman of Rockefeller University's board of trustees, said they would together donate $5 million to establish a major center that would combine basic research with clinical treatment of Alzheimer's. 
 The effort would also involve the bringing together of many of the world's leading experts on Alzheimer's disease to help develop a longterm, national research strategy. Up to now, the research has been scattered among many institutions, including 28 comprehensive Alzheimer's research and treatment centers sponsored by the National Institute on Aging, which is part of the National Institutes of Health.
The initiative's sponsors said they hoped that this public-private initiative would make it possible within a decade to delay the onset of the disease and slow its progress.
 
Progress in 5 Years
 Dr. Paul Coleman of the University of Rochester Medical Center, an Alzheimer's researcher who attended the meeting at which the announcement was made today, said that scientists believed that they would first be able to slow the progress of Alzheimer's disease before they discovered a way to stop or reverse it.
"In five years, we want to be able to delay onset of the disease by five years, and in 10 years we want to delay the onset by 10 years," Dr. Coleman said. "This is a goal we believe is technically feasible."
Hillary Rodham Clinton, who attended the luncheon meeting, said, "This is an example of what we need -- the ability of the Government and private citizens to bring together the best minds on a problem." It costs between $30,000 and $50,000 a year to care for one Alzheimer's patient, she said, an amount that can bankrupt many families.
In a pitch for changing the health insurance system, Mrs. Clinton said that much existing insurance coverage for Alzheimer's was inadequate because many necessary services were not covered, the cost of longterm care was often excluded and many policies had lifetime limits on benefits that could leave people uncovered. "We have an economic imperative to solve the problem of Alzheimer's disease," she said.
Alzheimer's is a lethal, progressive, incurable brain disease that slowly destroys the mind. Its cause is unknown and there is no effective therapy for most patients. About 4 million Americans have Alzheimer's, which kills more than 100,000 each year and costs the nation up to $80 billion annually for care and lost wages, experts said.
 
'Never Enough Money'
 The Federal Government will spend $310 million this year on Alzheimer's research, up from $47 million five years ago.
"For a disease like this, there is never enough money," Mr. Fisher said. "It's time for a determined and national assault on the scourge of Alzheimer's disease." To sponsor the new center, Mr. Fisher agreed to give $2.5 million, to be matched with money from a fund provided to the university by Mr. Rockefeller.
The announcement by Rockefeller University, on the Upper East Side, followed the first of three symposiums to be held this year to draft a national research policy on Alzheimer's. These meetings of leading scientists, sponsored by the Mr. Fisher's Fisher Medical Foundation and the Federal aging institute, are intended to produce a national blueprint for Alzheimer's, as called for by Congress, participants said. This strategy will help guide national plans for research, for developing and testing treatments, and for dealing with patient care.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a luncheon at which new efforts against Alzheimer's disease was announced, Hillary Rodham Clinton noted yesterday that the disease was inadequately covered in many current insurance plans. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ex-Leaders of '89 Uprising Send a Petition to Beijing

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 26

 BODY:
A group of former student leaders of the 1989 Tiananmen Square uprising petitioned the Communist Party leadership today to begin healing the national wounds from the lethal confrontation.
In defiance of the current clampdown on dissent in China, the seven young dissidents called upon the country's leaders to lift the harsh indictment that branded the pro-democracy students as guilty of "riot and counter-revolutionary rebellion." 
 "The movement was a nationwide, popular, patriotic movement with young students as its main body," the petition said. "Within the movement, we consistently adhered to the principles of peace, reason and nonviolence."
They termed the criminal verdict "unjust" and said it "should be reassessed as soon as possible."
"Untying this knot in the people's heart will help heal up the social contradictions," the signers said in the document that was distributed to news agencies in Beijing. "We sincerely wish that the Government can courageously take this sensible step for the sake of the people's interests and the nation's future."
 
Deng Bars the Issue
 The reversal of the Tiananmen verdict is a delicate issue that the paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, whose health is in serious decline, has decreed should never be revisited. Mr. Deng has acknowledged his part in ordering the military crackdown, and many Chinese intellectuals see a reversal of the verdict against the students as a test of whether political reform will return to China with the decline of Mr. Deng's power.
Though the petition did not mention the decision by President Clinton to formally renew China's low-tariff trading access to the American market under the "most favored nation" rules, it underscored the reality that political repression is still the rule in China five years after the Communist Party forcibly put down the largest rebellion in its history.
Most of the former students who signed the petition were released from prison with the help of American pressure exerted during the annual renewals of China's trading status.
In their three-point petition, the young democracy campaigners, all of whom served time in prison for their actions, called upon the National People's Congress, the ceremonial Parliament under the Communist Party, to provide "generous compensation" to the families of those who were killed when tanks and machine guns smashed the student and worker barricades in the center of Beijing.
 
Aide May Be Sympathetic
 The petition is addressed to the Parliament's standing committee, which is headed by Qiao Shi, a one-time chief of China's security forces who is regarded by some analysts as being sympathetic to reversing the Tiananmen verdict.
"On the occasion of the fifth anniversary of the 1989 democracy movement, " the one-page document says, "we are exercising our political rights granted to us by law in making a three-point petition to the country's highest legislative body."
In stanching all such political dissent this spring, the authorities have stressed the national imperative of maintaining "social stability" as China enters a crucial stage of the economic reforms begun by Mr. Deng 15 years ago. Unemployment and widespread labor unrest have shaken the confidence in the leadership.
The petitioners said, "We, as well as the Government, wish to see a stable social environment."
Six of the seven signers were on China's most-wanted list after the military crackdown on June 4, 1989. The seven are Wang Dan, one of the top leaders of the Tiananmen demonstrations, Ma Shaofang, Zhai Waimin, Shao Jiang, Li Hai, Zheng Xuguang and Guo Haifeng.
 
Signers Unavailable
 Attempts to reach the signers today were unsuccessful, and there were reports they had secluded themselves as they released the petition.
Mr. Wang's telephone was out of service. All of the signers risked arrest in putting their names to the petition. A general clampdown on dissent continues in advance of the fifth anniversary of the military assault.
Ten days ago, Mr. Wang and an American television crew that had taped an interview with him were detained briefly for questioning by the police.
Mr. Wang, Mr. Zhai and Mr. Ma were detained during the March visit to Beijing by Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
Earlier this month, the Chinese President and Communist Party chief, Jiang Zemin, referred to the 1989 crisis as "a bad thing that has been turned into a good thing," adding, "As a result, our reform and opening-up program has forged ahead with steadier, better and even quicker steps, and our advantages have been brought into fuller play."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing Stock Rises on Report of Deal in China

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Shares of the Boeing Company rose yesterday after a published report said the company was about to receive a $5 billion order from China for more than 50 commercial jetliners, including some of Boeing's largest aircraft.
Boeing officials declined to comment, except to say that China remained an important customer. After President Clinton approved China's trading status yesterday, Larry Clarkson, the senior vice president for planning and international development at Boeing, said the company believed that if China's trading privileges had not been approved any deal would have been off. 
 The report, which appeared in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, implied the order was imminent, but one Boeing official said the company did not believe that was true.
Shares of Boeing rose $2.50, to $47, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Analysts said the order had been at least partly anticipated, because of the rapid growth of China's economy and the current review of the country's trading status. The Clinton Administration approved the trade privileges, known as most-favored-nation status, despite limited improvement in China's human rights record.
 
Other Large Orders
 Analysts said the chairman of Boeing, Frank A. Shrontz, had told them earlier this week about specific large orders from Singapore and Saudi Arabia, but had made only passing remarks about China.
The Chinese "are in the midst of planning and we are in discussions with a number of airlines," a spokesman for Boeing, David Jensen, said. "But as far as whether a definite order will be placed any time soon, we can't say."
Mr. Jensen said the Chinese economy had been growing at a rate of 9 to 11 percent annually, and that air traffic normally correlated very closely to the growth of gross national product. "Air China is a predominantly Boeing carrier, with 43 Boeing aircraft and six on order," he added.
 
Aircraft Orders Down
 During the last few years, the worldwide recession and the resulting reduction in demand for airplanes have caused Boeing to cut its production and lay off workers. Orders from China account for 14 percent of Boeing's commercial aircraft orders and have helped the company, which is based in Seattle, avoid deeper cuts.
From 1991 to 1993, China's national carrier was split into about a dozen small airlines, with Air China of Beijing as the largest.
"The size of the order is a surprise to me because I don't see which of the carriers would be the logical buyer of that large a block of long-distance aircraft," said Wolfgang Demisch, an aerospace industry analyst with BT Securities in New York. "I don't think China has a single airline with the financial clout to bring an order like this to fruition."
Still, he said, Chinese air traffic has grown at a rate of 22 percent annually for the last 20 years, creating a great demand for aircraft.
The order "does reaffirm that China is going to be an important customer for Boeing and for the United States," said Howard Rubel, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. "But the order does not erase the fact that Boeing will have very low levels of earnings for the next 18 months. It doesn't change any production schedules."
The deal with China would be only slightly smaller than a $6 billion Saudi Arabian aircraft order in February that was split between Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, with Boeing building 46 of the 61 aircraft.

HEADLINE: Texas Plans to Sue U.S. Over Illegal Alien Costs

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, May 26

 BODY:
Following the lead of three other states, Texas announced plans today to sue the Federal Government to recover costs of public services for illegal immigrants.
In doing so, Gov. Ann W. Richards and other Texas officials appeared to go out of their way to refrain from casting the lawsuit as a direct attack on the immigrants themselves, as such moves have often been interpreted elsewhere, especially in California. Florida has already filed a suit against the Federal Government to recover money spent on educating, housing, hospitalizing and jailing illegal immigrants, and California and Arizona, which have already sued over prison costs, have also announced plans to broaden their lawsuits. 
 Texas officials said today that the suit was a legal means to correct a glaring budget imbalance under which many illegal immigrants paid taxes that were collected by the Federal Government while the state and local governments were left with the financial obligation for providing services ranging from emergency medical care to public education.
"While undocumented immigrants make contributions to the Texas economy, they also contribute substantially to the Federal coffers in the form of income taxes and Social Security payments, which are matched by businesses," said the Attorney General of Texas, Dan Morales, who announced the state's intention to file the lawsuit.
 
Legal Moves by California
 "However," he added, "the costs of delivering services to the immigrants is imposed upon the state and its communities."
In California, Gov. Pete Wilson accompanied an announcement of plans to file a similar lawsuit earlier this year with proposals for cutting the undocumented immigrants' eligibility for some services. He also proposed amending the Federal Constitution so that their United States-born children would no longer qualify for American citizenship and such automatic rights as Medicaid and welfare services.
But here in Texas, which shares a border of almost 1,200 miles with Mexico and where Governor Richards has been careful not to alienate heavily Hispanic South Texas with any anti-immigrant comments, the lawsuit is being cast as little more than a budget dispute with Federal officials.
"This wrangle has been going on for years and years and years and years," Ms. Richards, who is facing re-election this fall, said in Austin, the state capital. "There's nothing new. The only thing new is, states have made a commitment they're going to fight back."
A spokesman for Mr. Morales, Ward Tisdale, said he expected the lawsuit to be filed within a month or so, but he said the state had not arrived at a final estimate of how much it spends on services for illegal immigrants.
Last fall, the Texas Office of Immigration and Refugee Affairs calculated that the overall cost of state and local services was nearly $500 million, though it said some of that was offset by sales taxes and other indirect taxes paid by an estimated 550,000 illegal immigrants in Texas. Mr. Tisdale said that estimate of the net costs might be revised.
 
Florida Sues for $1.5 Billion
 Florida filed a lawsuit last month seeking $1.5 billion, which Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, estimated as the rough cost over two years of providing a range of services to roughly 350,000 illegal immigrants there.
California has also sued, though the only motion currently in Federal court deals solely with the costs of jailing 17,000 illegal immigrants convicted of felonies. Governor Wilson wants $377 million in Federal payments, plus another $1.6 billion to build more prisons. He also has said the state will file additional lawsuits dealing with education and health-care costs.
Arizona, with a smaller population of illegal immigrants, filed its own lawsuit earlier this month, seeking $121 million.
In New York, which is generally believed to have the second largest population of illegal immigrants after California, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been seriously considering a lawsuit to recover the costs of a broad range of social services but has taken no action to file one, a spokesman said.
The various lawsuits' chances of success are unclear. Past attempts in court by New York and California to get more Federal money for the costs of jailing illegal immigrants failed. But they were not specifically based upon the legal theory that such costs were incurred as a direct result of the Federal Government's failure to enforce its own immigration laws.
Last month, President Clinton asked Congress for $350 million to help states pay for imprisoning illegal immigrants, but governors of several states quickly said that would be nowhere near enough money even if Congress agreed to appropriate it.
Here in Texas, Republicans who have been calling for such lawsuits wasted no time in condemning Governor Richards, a Democrat, for waiting so long and for not acting with more determination.
Her Republican opponent this fall, George W. Bush, a son of the former President, said in a statement issued today, "While other states have moved forward aggressively to force the Federal Government to either control the borders or pay the cost for their failure, Governor Richards has hung back and failed to lead on the issue, leaving Texans no other explanation than her desire to protect Bill Clinton from further criticism."

HEADLINE: House Bill on Derivatives Introduced

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Two powerful members of the House of Representatives introduced a bill yesterday to tighten the supervision of the derivatives activities of banks.
The bill was introduced by Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, and Jim Leach of Iowa, the ranking Republican member on the committee. It combines, in a somewhat milder form, separate derivatives legislation that each had introduced earlier this year. 
 Derivatives are customized financial contracts that have values based on underlying financial assets like stocks, bonds, currencies and commodities. A handful of big banks are the largest dealers in derivatives. Other banks use derivatives as investments and to reduce their vulnerability to changes in interest rates.
Derivatives have become controversial because some people have worried that their complexity could lead to unexpected losses or even contribute to a systemwide crisis.
 
2d Bill in Works
 Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who is the chairman of the House telecommunications and finance subcommittee, held hearings this month on derivatives and said he intended to introduce a sweeping bill on the subject soon. Mr. Markey's subcommittee mainly oversees the brokerage industry, and his bill mainly would expand the regulation of derivatives activities by securities and insurance companies.
The bill introduced yesterday by Mr. Gonzalez and Mr. Leach applies only to the banks and other institutions regulated by the House Banking Committee, including credit unions and Government-sponsored housing agencies like the Federal National Mortgage Corporation.
The bill orders the bank regulatory agencies to develop consistent standards relating to derivatives for capital, accounting, disclosure, examinations and suitability. It would force them to create a plan to get information on derivatives activities of banks quickly in the case of a crisis.
The bill would force a bank's management and directors to approve derivatives activity. And it would order regulators to seek widespread cooperation from other countries in creating uniform international standards on derivatives.
Banking executives conceded that these were mild measures that did not ban or restrict any specific derivatives. But they argued that the bill would impose additional paperwork and other burdens on banks and was not needed because current laws allowed bank regulators to supervise derivatives adequately.
"The timing of this is a bit curious," said Mark Brickell, a managing director at J. P. Morgan who is the vice chairman of the International Swap and Derivatives Dealers Association, a trade organization. "It is only yesterday that banking regulators, and indeed all five financial supervisors, testified that they already have the powers they need."
 
Federal Reserve Sees No Need

 
 On Wednesday, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and other regulators testified that the possibility of a taxpayer bailout caused by derivatives was remote and that no legislation was needed.
But Mr. Gonzalez dismissed those comments, saying that regulators had been lax in preventing failures of savings and loan institutions and other banking problems. "Sadly, the country is still paying for the last time the regulators fell asleep at the switch." Mr. Gonzalez said in a statement.
A spokesman for the banking committee said it would try to pass the bill this year. But others said that would be difficult in the time remaining in the session.
"Barring some unforeseen crisis in the next 60 days, I think the chances anything will pass this year are essentially zero," said Bert Ely, a bank policy consultant.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
When sudden baldness is bad for business, a lawyer decides to beard the rumors.

BYLINE: By David Margolick 

 BODY:
Until about a year ago Jeremiah Gutman, a man with a mane of flowing, slightly unruly white hair, bushy eyebrows and moustache, was periodically mistaken for a famous physicist. Standing at a bus stop in Los Angeles once, Mr. Gutman, a fixture in Manhattan's civil liberties bar for 40 years, was even asked for his autograph. "The guy gave me whatever he was carrying and I signed 'Albert Einstein,' " he recalled.
Almost overnight, however, Mr. Gutman, who is 70, has come to look more like Telly Savalas or Yul Brynner. Disease has clear-cut his distinguished head and, for a time, threatened to decimate his law practice as well. Therein lie several lessons for lawyers about the fragility of small law practices, the fickleness of some clients, the squeamishness of colleagues and the ravages of rumors. 
 Mr. Gutman once wore a beard that made him look like a beat poet; now, he has not had to shave for months. His hair was once luxuriant; now, a single strand grows on his nose. He trims it periodically, but there is little else either north or south.
"When I see myself in the mirror, I don't know who I am," he said. "I've turned into Kojak. Worse than that: Kojak had eyelashes."
Late last year, Mr. Gutman learned that he had alopecia generalis, an illness whose only physical effect is that it claims all of one's hair. Within a few months the man who once represented such hirsute sorts as Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin has come to resemble another, balder client of his in the 1969-70 trial of the Chicago Seven, David Dellinger.
Most of the the world, and the bar, however, know nothing about alopecia (pronounced ala-PEA-sha). They assumed that Mr. Gutman's hair was a casualty of chemotherapy, that he had cancer; that he was dying. And both the world and the bar began acting accordingly.
Some old allies, like Henry Schwartzchild and Ira Glasser of the American Civil Liberties Union, did not mince words. "What's the matter with you?" they asked. When he told them, they commiserated with him.
Many others in his concentric circles -- groups like the National Coalition Against Censorship, the American-Israeli Civil Liberties Coalition and others with the words "civil" or "liberties" usually in their names -- blanched but didn't want to ask. Others, fearful of anything smelling of death or dying, didn't want to know. Still others, like Norman Siegel, head of the New York Civil Liberties Union, were so steeped in the constitutional right to privacy that they didn't think they should pry.
Mr. Gutman -- who used the locker he was given as editor of the New York University Law Review in 1948 to store the guns he had hussled up for Israel -- initially agreed. He figured that hair loss, like hemorrhoids, were not anybody else's business. But he underestimated how much some people cared.
"People were very concerned," said Lesly Lempert of Ithaca, president of the New York State Civil Liberties Union. "No one could possibly imagine the N.Y.C.L.U. without Mr. Gutman's presence."
Had it remained strictly a matter of appearances, Mr. Gutman might have remained silent. But business began dropping off nearly as quickly as his hair, down 70 percent in the last half of 1993.
Part of the loss, he knew, was attributable to the recession. The small businesses that make up half his clientele -- the rest are public interest matters he handles for nothing -- had economic troubles of their own, and stopped paying their legal bills.
"When half your business is not for money and half of the other half stops paying, you're in trouble," Mr. Gutman said recently in the cluttered offices of Levy, Gutman, Goldberg & Kaplan, in Suite 1776 of 275 Seventh Avenue, in the heart of the garment district. On his wall is perhaps the world's largest collection of "No Smoking" signs -- in 40 different languages, stolen, er, borrowed from Italian trains, Athenian buses and the like -- plus an assortment of paintings, mostly poor man's Rothkos.
There was evidence, however, that public perceptions of Mr. Gutman's health was partly to blame for his financial perils, that old clients were taking their business elsewhere. The Levy in Levy, Gutman, Goldberg & Kaplan has been dead since 1929; the Gutman, Mr. Gutman's father, died in 1948, and Mr. Goldman has been dead since 1982.
Indeed, there are more lawyers in the firm's name than there are in the firm, which now comprises Mr. Gutman, Philip Kaplan and a junior associate. When one of the three gets sick, or when the world thinks that he is sick, the whole place founders.
Mr. Gutman pondered his options. He thought of placing a notice in The New York Law Journal, or at the bottom of the front page of The New York Times, or sending out one of those printed cardboard announcements of the sort that are thrown out thousands of times in hundreds of law offices every morning: "Levy, Gutman, Goldberg & Kaplan is proud to announce that Jeremian Gutman is not suffering from cancer, is in good health and is looking for business," it would have said.
Instead, he decided to come clean, then rely on word of mouth. To friend and foe and client alike, he started volunteering the obvious and then providing the explanation.
It now seems that gossip runs both ways. Business has bounced back, and so has the mood of his once fearful colleagues. But the hair hasn't been so resilient. Mr. Gutman and his friends are still getting used to it.
"His new look is sort of a Wall Street corporate type," Mrs. Lempert said. "I think that's as troubling to him as anything."
