HEADLINE: 10,000 Jobs Are Added In City for First Quarter

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
New York City added almost 10,000 jobs in the first three months of this year, the largest quarterly increase since the start of the local recession in early 1989, according to a report issued yesterday.
The report, produced by the city's Economic Policy and Marketing Group, provides the strongest evidence to date that what has long been a weak and hesitant local economic recovery is finally starting to produce meaningful employment gains. The group provides coordinated planning and marketing strategy for the city's economic development agencies. 
 Increased hiring by the private sector outweighed a continued decline in government jobs that will be accelerated by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to reduce the city's work force. In addition to the 10,000 jobs added in the first quarter, 4,400 private jobs were added in April, preliminary figures showed.
 
'Very Encouraged'
 "I am very encouraged about the growth in employment, which suggests that we are getting the economy back on track," Mr. Giuliani said at a City Hall news conference. But he said an improving local economy should not be counted on to bail New York out of its budget distress.
"It would be very imprudent to think that," he said. "I don't think this is going to have an immediate impact on the budget."
Since the local economy hit bottom at the end of 1992, New York City has added about 41,000 private-sector jobs, with more than half of the gains in the last six months alone. But the rebound remains quite modest. Only 12 percent of the 342,000 jobs lost from 1989 to 1992 have been regained.
Despite severe winter weather, hiring increased across most sectors of the economy. Wall Street led the pack, adding 5,700 employees in the first quarter. But the report warned that the financial sector, which has chalked up record profits in each of the last three years, cannot be counted on to generate similar gains because of the market uncertainty caused by rising interest rates.
 
Expansion in Queens
 Local manufacturing, which has been losing jobs almost without interruption for three decades, actually reversed direction for the first time in years. It was bolstered by a healthy expansion of industry in Queens, which has been steadily overtaking Brooklyn and Manhattan as the heart of the city's manufacturing sector.
Construction, devastated by the collapse of the commercial real-estate market after the 1987 stock market crash, also produced gains.
Manhattan and Queens, which dominate employment in the city and were the boroughs hit worst by the recession, showed the first real signs of life near the end of 1993. The other boroughs continued a rebound that began earlier.
"This broad-based hiring in the first quarter helped support the early stages of job growth in Manhattan and Queens," said James Parrot, chief economist of the city organization that prepared the report. "Brooklyn, Staten Island and the Bronx edged closer to regaining their previous employment peaks."
While the quarterly job increase was the strongest in years, it made only a slight dent in the city's unemployment rate. Unemployment averaged 10 percent during the first quarter, down only slightly from 10.3 percent for the fourth quarter of 1993 and a yearly average of 10.2 percent.
The report noted that health care has become a crucial anchor of the local economy, accounting for close to 11 percent of total city employment and as much as 30 percent of the jobs in the Bronx. Employment by nursing homes and home health-care agencies is rising faster than in any other sector and now totals 69,000 jobs. That is as many people as are employed in all the law firms in the city.
The report, echoing other studies, found that the city was plagued by a shortage of "middle-level jobs" caused by a growing "polarization between high-skill, high-wage jobs and low-skill, low-wage employment." That trend, it noted, "will leave many New Yorkers with little access to the career ladders which have traditionally pulled them out of poverty and into the middle class."
Despite the city's job gains, the report found that employment growth in all major sectors of the local economy still lagged well behind those of the nation as a whole and that a much lower proportion of adults in New York City were employed than in most other places in the nation.

HEADLINE: Withdrawal Pace Slows At Mutual Bond Funds

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Mutual fund investors seem to be growing less alarmed about the prospect of higher interest rates, and withdrawals from bond funds have slowed. But there are still only limited indications that investors are willing to risk more cash, fund company executives said yesterday.
"It is a wait-and-see environment," said Joan Miller, a spokeswoman for the State Street Research group of funds. "We're not seeing mass redemptions, but we're not seeing much buying either." 
 At the T. Rowe Price group of funds, cash continued to flow out of bond funds in May, said Steve Norwitz, a spokesman, but he added that the pace was more moderate. And at Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest fund group, it appeared that bond funds will approximately break even in terms of cash flow this month, after two months of net redemptions.
"They are not putting money in, but they have stopped taking money out," said Neal Litvack, an executive vice president of Fidelity. A survey of investors, done for Fidelity by the University of Michigan, found that 33 percent of those questioned in May expected interest rates to rise over the next six months, compared with 77 percent of those questioned in April.
 
Stock Funds Still Popular
 Stock mutual funds, meanwhile, continued to draw in money despite choppy performance and bearish talk, with international funds again growing popular, fund managers said. But the flows into the funds are well below those of earlier this year.
The comments by the fund companies came as the Investment Company Institute, a trade group, released figures for cash flows in April, showing that investors took a net $4.8 billion out of bond funds, compared with withdrawals of $7.7 billion in March. In stock funds, however, a net $11.3 billion was put into funds, up from $6.6 billion in March.
The cash-flow figures include new investments and withdrawals, as well as transfers between different types of funds. But they exclude reinvested dividends.
 
Some Investors Surprised
 Rising interest rates have damaged bond fund returns, evidently surprising some investors who did not understand the risks they were taking. Christian Twaites, a vice president of Aetna mutual funds, said that the company was getting more calls from investors who believed the funds were guaranteed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits but has nothing to do with mutual funds.
Municipal bond funds saw their third consecutive month of net withdrawals in April, with investors taking out $1.6 billion, which was lower than the $2 billion that came out in March. Prior to February, the last month in which there were net withdrawals from such funds was August 1990, and the last time this occurred for three consecutive months was from August through October 1987.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Coffee Prices Fall for 3d Day In Broad Commodity Selloff

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A slide in coffee futures prices steepened yesterday as a broad collapse in commodity prices worsened.
Analysts said coffee and other commodities had climbed too far, too fast on heavy speculative buying. Cocoa, precious metal and grain futures also fell. Livestock and energy futures were mixed. 
 An index of 21 commodities tracked by the Commodity Research Bureau of Knight-Ridder Inc. retreated for the third consecutive day yesterday after reaching a three-and-a-half-year high of 238.36 on Monday. The commodity index, which is regarded as a gauge of inflation, fell 1.98 points, to 229.61.
Analysts attributed the sharp moves in some markets partly to positioning ahead of the three-day Memorial Day holiday weekend.
Unroasted arabica coffee beans for July delivery plunged 9.95 cents, to $1.178 a pound, on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. The contract has fallen 27.7 cents, or 19 percent, since peaking on Monday at $1.455 a pound, a five-year high.
 
 
Cutback in Coffee Supply
 Coffee futures prices had more than doubled this year as supplies tightened. Large producers like Brazil and Colombia have exported less coffee than they did in 1993, and analysts had predicted smaller harvests this year because of cutbacks by growers after five years of low prices.
The sharp advance in coffee prices, most of which occurred in the last six weeks, had raised inflation fears along with increases in soybean, corn, crude oil and precious metal prices. All those markets have weakened substantially this week.
Cocoa for July delivery also fell for the third consecutive day, tumbling $32, to $1,330 a ton.
Crude oil futures steadied on the New York Mercantile Exchange after three days of losses.
Light sweet crude for July delivery rose 4 cents, to $17.74 a barrel; June heating oil rose 0.19 cent, to 47.82 cents a gallon; June unleaded gasoline fell 0.18 cent, to 51.49 cents a gallon; July natural gas rose 2.6 cents, to $1.862 for 1,000 cubic feet.
 
 
Wheat Falls on Russian Deal
 On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures fell sharply on the news that Russia bought European wheat instead of American wheat this week.
July wheat fell 9 cents, to $3.2175 a bushel; July corn fell 2.25 cents, to $2.645 a bushel; July oats fell 2.25 cents, to $1.1675 a bushel; July soybeans fell 2.75 cents, to $6.7225 a bushel.
Cattle futures rebounded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after plunging on Wednesday to their lowest price in nearly six years. Analysts said traders had overreacted to rising cattle supplies.
Live cattle for June delivery rose 1.5 cents, the permitted daily limit, to 63.97 cents a pound; August feeder cattle also rose 1.5 cents, to 74.82 cents a pound; June live hogs rose 0.37 cent, to 47.42 cents a pound; July frozen pork bellies sank 0.40 cent, to 41.22 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Are Mixed; Long Bond's Price Dips

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the long bond's price bouncing up and down before ending lower.
Many market participants said trading drew tentative near the close in New York because the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is scheduled to testify today about monetary policy before the Senate Banking Committee. 
 With no new economic data yesterday, investors and dealers seemed transfixed by movements in the Commodity Research Bureau index, one measure of inflation pressures. Prices were helped as the index fell for the third straight day, finishing down 1.98, to 2229.61.
Prices were also aided for a time by a rebound in the dollar. A weak dollar tends to raise concerns that overseas investors will find dollar-denominated investments less attractive.
 
Yield Rises to 7.36%
 But the 30-year bond fell 4/32 , to 8625/32 , for a yield of 7.36 percent, up from 7.34 percent yesterday. Among the short maturities, the rate for a three-month bill was unchanged at 4.15 percent, while a six-month bill rose a basis point, to 4.57 percent. A 10-year note rose 4/32 , to 1015/32 , for a yield of 7.09 percent, down from 7.10 percent on Wednesday, while a seven-year issue was unchanged at 6.72 percent.
"Greenspan's testimony on monetary policy and interest rates, two of the market's favorites, could be an interesting discussion," said Matthew Alexy, a government-trading strategist at CS First Boston. "He will be giving more insight to the recent policy moves."
Mr. Alexy said the Fed essentially entered a new phase with the 50-basis- point increase in the Federal funds rate that it announced earlier this month. "It was an exclamation point and now the phase is one of assessment as the Fed judges the impact of higher rates and where the economy is going," he said.
Although today's testimony may not produce any surprises, "with Greenspan you can never be certain about what he says or how it will be interpreted by the market," Mr. Alexy said. "That's why the market drew cautious near the end of the session," he added.
In early trading, bonds gained on some of the momentum from the previous day's trading. The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing the first time for state unemployment benefits declined by 1,000 last week, but the market was aided by the department's report that the four-week moving average for unemployment claims rose to 366,750 from 359,250. The average, they said, was the highest since mid-February.
 
Views Differ on Economy
 Traders said the initial gains in the market were pared as views differed on whether the high level of unemployment claims implied a slowing of economic growth and if interest rate increases have been enough to slow the economy.
Analysts said the rise in employment claims appeared to contradict an increase in employment that was reflected in the Labor Department's monthly payroll report. One theory is that claims may have been artificially inflated by the Government's decision in late April to end a program that gave emergency benefits to the long-term unemployed.
The May jobs report is due June 3, and an early survey by MMS International projects a rise of 275,000.
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $16.5 billion of one-year bills, and with the conclusion of the auction the supply picture for short-term Government paper lightens considerably, traders said. This, they say, will help improve prices.
The auction drew good retail interest, particularly from small investors who are finding rates offered by short-term Treasury issues as good as some other consumer alternatives. At auction the average yield for the new one-year bill was 5.01 percent, up from 4.77 percent last month and the highest yield since October 1991, when it was 5.12 percent.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
When Some Give Up the Ghost
Spring is usually the time when galleries that are in trouble finally decide to close, and this season is no exception. With the contemporary-art world still suffering from a sluggish economy, many galleries, most of which deal with younger or lesser-known artists, simply can't make a go of it.
"I gave it 10 years, but I became a bit of a dinosaur," said Josh Baer, whose Broome Street gallery in SoHo has featured contemporary artists including Nancy Spero, Chris Burden and Annette Lemieux. "It's just not going to work anymore, giving clients the services they need and paying the overhead while showing difficult art the market can't support." Mr. Baer, who is closing his gallery in mid-June, said he would be working with artists privately. "If I need a space to hold a show, I'll rent it," he said. 
 For Barbara Toll, a 13-year veteran of the SoHo gallery scene, the "level of frustration" has just risen too high. Her Greene Street space is to close on June 25. Ms. Toll said her decision was based on a combination of factors, partly economic and partly the realization that there was a shrinking audience for the avant-garde art she was showing.
Midori Nishizawa, director of the Akira Ikeda Gallery at 130 Prince Street in SoHo, expressed similar sentiments when she confirmed that the gallery would shut its doors at the end of July. "This is only our second year," she said. "Every gallery needs three years to get established, but it's difficult for someone like us, who show new artists where there is no easy market." Ms. Nishizawa said she was trying to move the gallery, but her plans are up in the air. She said Mr. Ikeda's three other galleries -- in Tokyo, Nagoya and Taudra Yokosuka, Japan -- are going strong.
Not so for Daniel Newburg's Greene Street gallery. Mr. Newburg said he saw the closing of his SoHo space in June as the "conclusion of a 10-year project."
"June will be my 10th anniversary," Mr. Newburg said. Producing 10 shows a year has simply become too much, he explained, adding, "I want to concentrate on more in-depth projects." He plans to continue working with many of the American and European contemporary artists he represented at his gallery, including the Swiss abstractionist John Armleder and the American installation artist Matthew McCaslin. "I won't represent them exclusively," he said. "But I'll work with them on a project-by-project basis."
Meanwhile, Mr. Newburg's next-door neighbor David Zwirner, is planning to expand into Mr. Newburg's space. "We had a good season, and we're optimistic," Mr. Zwirner said.
 
. . . aAnd Others Look to Expand
 In spring, many galleries also announce plans to move and open new spaces in the fall. Pat Hearn, who has been at 39 Wooster Street in SoHo for six years, isn't sure where she's going. "My lease is up, and there are so many spaces around at better prices," she said. She said she planned to close in August and reopen in a new location on Sept. 18.
Uptown, the Spanierman Gallery will be moving from 50 East 78th Street to 45 East 58th Street in August. "The old neighborhood has been slowly eroding," Mr. Spanierman said. "There are more women's boutiques and far fewer galleries. We're moving into much bigger quarters in a place I want to be, between the Fuller Building and Christie's."
 
Showcase for New York Artists
 The Hamptons have always been a popular spot for artists to play and work, which may be one reason the area is also popular with collectors and dealers. Many begin their annual migration to the East End of Long Island today. It makes sense, then, that a new gallery has just opened to showcase 23 New York City artists, many of whom own houses in the Hamptons.
The gallery, Off Shore, is at 74 Montauk Highway, at the Red Horse Market complex in East Hampton. It is a collaboration between Janelle Reiring and Helen Winer, co-owners of the SoHo gallery Metro Pictures, and Rachel Lehmann, owner of the Lehmann Gallery in Lausanne, Switzerland. Its director, David Maupin, was formerly the director of the Mary Boone Gallery in SoHo.
"The gallery is a product of the times," said Janelle Reiring. "This couldn't have ever been done in the 80's." In these tougher times, the artists involved, all of whom are represented by Manhattan galleries, are more than willing to give a gallery like Off Shore works on consignment. "It's crucial that we have cooperation from the artists and their dealers," Ms. Reiring said.
The gallery is to be open year round and feature artists like Donald Baechler, Ross Bleckner, Barbara Kruger, John Chamberlain, Chuck Close, Laurie Simmons, Eric Fischl and David Salle. The first show, a group exhibition, runs through June 13. An exhibition of paintings by April Gornik and sculptures by Bryan Hunt follows, on June 16.
 
Images in Calvin Klein Ads Attacked
 Maciej Toporowicz, a Polish-born artist, is obsessed with Obsession, the Calvin Klein perfume. He also has strong feelings about the designer's use of what the artist considers rather perfect Aryan types in ad campaigns. "Calvin Klein is consciously or unconsciously using Nazi images in his campaigns," Mr. Toporowicz said. "It's sexist and exclusionary."
A spokeswoman for Calvin Klein said the company had no comment at this time.
To make his point, Mr. Toporowicz created a poster featuring a photograph of "The Army," a sculpture of a male frontal nude by Hitler's favorite sculptor, Arno Breker, with the Obsession logo added to its bottom edge. The artist's favorite spot to paste up the poster is the corner of Prince and Mercer Streets in SoHo, not far from the bus stops that often display the real Calvins.
Referring to the names of Mr. Klein's three fragrances, Mr. Toporowicz's press release announces, "There is no escape from obsession to eternity."
The artist said he had put up more than 200 posters of this image around Manhattan. "This is a difficult issue," he said. "What's interesting is that when people see me putting up the posters, they think they're really Calvin Klein posters. The Nazi image blends so perfectly with his campaign, it's hard to recognize the difference."
 
McEnroe Helps Restore a Library
 Another art institution has found a naming opportunity encouraged by a cash donation.
The New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture in Greenwich Village announced last week that the tennis player John McEnroe was financing the restoration and expansion of its library, which is to bear his name.
The donation, which amounts to $183,000, is to be given over a four-year period. "We're thrilled," said Lori Blount, a spokeswoman for the school. "John knows we have really needed a library."
Coincidentally, Graham Nickson, the school's dean, is represented by the Salander-O'Reilly Galleries in Manhattan, where Mr. McEnroe worked as a volunteer for six months last year, learning the art trade.
Mr. McEnroe, who recently opened a by-appointment gallery on Greene Street in SoHo, is at the French Open this week and could not be reached for comment.
 
More (Not Less) Than Expected
 Even in a down auction market, some things exceed everyone's expectations. At Sotheby's sale of American paintings in New York on Wednesday, John Singer Sargent's "Spanish Dancer," from the estate of Wendell Cherry, brought $7.5 million. Not only did the price set a record for the artist, it was also far above Sotheby's $4 million estimate. Sotheby's declines to identify the buyer.

HEADLINE: Shortchanging Rights in China

 BODY:
Succumbing to enormous pressure from business interests, President Clinton has walked away from his own sensible policy of linking Beijing's trade privileges to modest human rights progress.
By abandoning its public threat of meaningful sanctions, the Administration harms its foreign policy credibility and gravely endangers those brave Chinese citizens who stood up to a brutal dictatorship in the mistaken belief that Washington would defend their cause. 
 Mr. Clinton did not pretend that China had shown much progress in many of the areas he specified last year. But instead of imposing the serious trade penalties he then threatened, he has imposed useful but excessively narrow sanctions. Targeting only China's export of guns and ammunition, they will affect perhaps $100 million of China's more than $30 billion a year in exports to the U.S.
Mr. Clinton argues that he will continue to pursue human rights objectives, but mainly by non-economic means like broadcasting, supporting human rights groups and promoting a corporate code of conduct. He thus abandons America's most powerful tool for expanding freedom: negotiating the terms of access to America's indispensable market.
Congress, which first raised using America's trade leverage to support human rights, can mitigate the damage by broadening the President's proposal to penalize other categories of goods produced principally by companies associated with the Chinese Army. That approach, endorsed by Senator George Mitchell and Representative Nancy Pelosi, would affect $900 million a year in Chinese exports without damaging economic reform.
Meanwhile, business leaders who have argued that trade and investment are the best ways to advance human rights can show their sincerity by taking up the President's proposal for a voluntary code of corporate conduct. Such a code should, minimally, bar products made by prison labor, discourage political indoctrination and surveillance in the workplace and encourage U.S. executives to discuss human rights with Chinese authorities.
A year ago, Mr. Clinton offered China an honorable way out of the yearly wrangle. Beijing merely had to live up to some of its own past commitments to respect internationally recognized human rights.
But China, encouraged by kid-gloves treatment from past Administrations, divided messages from the Clinton team and vocal lobbying by American business, chose to ignore the offer. Now Mr. Clinton has renewed China's trading status anyway. Washington thus signals Beijing that it is more concerned about the profits of Boeing and AT&T than about China's commitments or its citizens' rights.
Economic interests are a legitimate component of foreign policy. But with China enjoying a huge bilateral trade surplus and Beijing's development model dependent on continued access to American dollars, the U.S. had plenty of leverage to exert. Many people argue that encouraging China's economic boom is the most effective way to improve human rights. But experience elsewhere suggests that muscular diplomatic pressure helps.
The U.S. also has security interests with China, like cooperation on North Korean nuclear issues, regional stability and proliferation. But Washington has nothing to gain on any of these fronts by confirming China's suspicions that the U.S. is a paper tiger whose threats can safely be ignored. It is now up to Congress to correct that impression by enacting broader sanctions.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Bill Clinton's Teachings

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
China's 75 million Christians are forbidden to worship how and where they see fit. Protestant and Catholic clerics are often imprisoned and tortured.
President Clinton is a religious man. He talks of how much his religion means to him. He goes to church regularly. 
 So it was natural that when, on May 28, 1993, he signed an executive order giving the Chinese Communists one more year to show progress on human rights or face tariff penalties, he dealt with religion. "Overall significant progress" in releasing and accounting for religious prisoners was made a condition.
Mr. Clinton believes in the decent treatment of political prisoners too -- at least that they not be flogged daily or left in their own excrement. So the condition of significant progress was made about them too.
President Clinton is against the export of forced labor products so essential to Beijing's profits. The order demanded that China abide by formal pacts to keep them out of the U.S.
Mr. Clinton thinks quite poorly of wiping out a captive nation. Therefore the order demanded easing the destruction of Tibet's religion and culture.
No kowtowing to foreign pressures. Before his election, Mr. Clinton talked scornfully of President Bush coddling the Chinese tyranny.
Bill Clinton believes a President should provide leadership in political morality and democratic idealism. He thinks of himself as a teacher for those who serve under him.
Now he has decided that his own executive order does not mean what the American public and Congress thought and wanted -- no real human rights progress, no low-tariff privileges.
Somehow he thinks Americans will believe night is day -- that the Chinese Communists have imperfectly but sufficiently met the conditions of human rights progress. So he permanently "delinked" trade and human rights -- a complete, smarmy turnaround of every moral and political position he has taken on Communist China.
Mr. Clinton and those around him know that more political dissidents, more priests and bishops are being arrested than released, that crackdowns continue, harsher. And they know that China still exports slave labor products to the U.S. and to the world, that Tibet's blood still flows.
So the price of serving Mr. Clinton is to pretend that retreat is achievement. Government servants who have built careers and honor now are abandoning the latter to keep the former.
The moral contagion extends to some members of Congress. They saw the error of their ways after the China lobby began its hugely funded campaign against relating tariffs to human rights progress.
Two years ago Senator Bill Bradley, the proudly intellectual Democrat from New Jersey, voted for using the threat of higher tariffs to soften the wardens of the Chinese gulag. Now he says the idea is just a relic of the cold war.
That would brand the following as cold warriors: 60 percent of the American people, the majority of Congress, human rights organizations worldwide, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the U.S. Council of Catholic Bishops, and of course some tens of millions of Chinese in slave labor camps, torture cells and forced-abortion clinics.
Mr. Bradley is known for speaking on morals and values.
Mr. Clinton's retreat is important far beyond the question of whether economic pressures would help human rights in China as they did in South Africa. The President showed his willingness to bow to business pressure at home on a major issue of foreign and human affairs. He showed himself surrendering to a dictatorship, turning himself inside out.
The Chinese gave him only contempt. Their only promise was that repression would continue. The President did not blink -- he surrendered, to China and the lobby.
Mr. Clinton already is criticized abroad for about-facing on foreign affairs. The surrender at Beijing will make it impossible for friend or foe to trust his foreign policy word -- even when he writes it into law himself.
When friends cannot trust a Presidential word, alliances erode. When foes do not believe a President, the risk is war by miscalculation, as in Korea and the Persian Gulf.
The teaching of Mr. Clinton is: Don't coddle tyrants, just surrender. For the President and his country, that is a sad and dangerous message to send.

HEADLINE: Past Looks Brighter Than Future for Robb

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The old Chuck Robb was back. If only for a moment, he was not one of the most endangered Democrats in the Senate, fighting to keep his seat and to restore a reputation tarnished by beauty queens, massages and secret tape-recordings.
On this evening in his Senate office, Mr. Robb drifted back a quarter of a century, to the glory days when he had returned from Vietnam laden with medals, to a bride whose father had been President and to whispers that he might even end up in the White House himself. He was in Philadelphia, he recalled, a fresh-faced marine from Virginia who managed to win over a crowd of anti-war protesters. 
 "I'm there in my major's uniform -- dress blues, ribbons, badges, medals and everything," he remembered with pride, "and I walked into a complete anti-war demonstration for my benefit."
But in the end, he was so successful in defusing the confrontation, he said, that after reports of it in the press, "I got a real nice note from President Nixon complimenting me."
 
Days of Glory
 Charles Spittal Robb takes comfort from the past, when he was known as the upstanding officer who married President Lyndon B. Johnson's daughter, Lynda Bird, and as a Governor of Virginia who brought fiscal responsibility to the state. But the past is also what has brought Mr. Robb, 54, the lowest popularity ratings of any Democratic Senator seeking re-election this year.
Soon after he took his seat in the Senate, news reports of his extracurricular behavior as Governor began to emerge, at first a dribble but then a humiliating string of disclosures. They portrayed him as a reckless womanizer who attended wild parties at Virginia Beach where drugs were used and said he accepted a nude massage from a former Miss Virginia U.S.A. There were also reports of his aides' plotting to use a secretly tape-recorded telephone conversation of his longtime political rival, L. Douglas Wilder, to embarrass the fellow Democrat, who succeeded him as governor.
So damaging were those reports, that by most accounts, the only thing standing between Mr. Robb and sure defeat in November is Oliver L. North, the Iran-contra figure who is seeking the Republican nomination -- assuming that both men win their respective party primaries next month.
"It's easy to characterize this as a race between a number of less than perfect candidates," Mr. Robb said in an interview. "You have pundits who will just ratchet up the rhetoric on that. And so I am constantly pulled down into a matchup that causes people to say, 'A pox on both houses.' "
In a rather cynical recipe for victory, Mr. Robb's supporters hope that the pox on Mr. North -- with his bitter relations with many Republicans and his conviction on charges, later dismissed, that he lied to Congress about the arms-for-hostages deal -- will cancel out their own candidate's character weaknesses.
"Ollie North is far and away the best thing that Chuck Robb has going for him," said Thomas R. Morris, the president of Emory and Henry College in southwestern Virginia. "Ollie North is No. 1 and Lynda Johnson Robb is No. 2. Obviously, he'd be politically dead in the water without her strong support. With her at his side, it certainly mutes the criticism about past personal behavior, at least in terms of unfaithfulness, in the same way that Hillary Clinton stood by Bill Clinton."
 
Comparisons With Clinton
 There was a time when Mr. Clinton and Mr. Robb were linked not because of accusations of marital infidelity but as up-and-coming Southern Governors, known for their work in the Democratic Leadership Conference, a group of moderate Democrats. Mr. Robb recalled his successful efforts to persuade Mr. Clinton to succeed Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia as chairman.
Mr. Robb offers a careful, lawyerly response when asked if he identifies with the attacks on the President's character. "It's fair to say that he and I have had some interesting conversations," he said. "If you have been through certain fire, you have a shared empathy, no matter what the factual basis."
Perhaps taking a cue from Mr. Clinton, Mr. Robb's strategy is to persevere. Like the President, Mr. Robb at first refused to discuss the accusations about his personal life. But as he moved closer to the next month's primary, he issued a carefully worded confessional admitting "socializing under circumstances not appropriate for a married man," but denying knowingly being in the presence of drug users. The statement was reminiscent of Mr. Clinton's vague explanations on avoiding the draft and experimenting with marijuana.
In the interview and in campaign appearances, Mr. Robb dwelled more on his four years as Governor than his six years in the Senate, which have been overshadowed by disclosures about his behavior when he was Governor. He wants voters to remember the fiscal restraint he brought to Virginia's economy, and the jobs he helped create for the military industry.
But it will not be easy.
Although they are viewed as little threat to his nomination, Mr. Robb's two challengers in the primary, Virgil H. Goode Jr., a State Senator, and Sylvia Clute, a Richmond lawyer, kept the character issue at the forefront of a televised debate this week. "A vote for Chuck Robb, unfortunately, is a vote for a scandal-ridden campaign," Ms. Clute said.
The usually subdued Mr. Goode posed this question: "Do we want a Senator whose judgment is so flawed that despite warnings, he continued to hang out with cocaine users and drug doers?"
If that were not enough, former Governor Wilder is planning to run as an independent -- a move that some view as an effort to defeat Mr. Robb by dividing the Democratic vote. Mr. Wilder would no doubt remind voters of the long-running feud over the illegal tape-recording of a conversation Mr. Wilder, who was then Lieutenant Governor, had on a car phone with a political supporter in which he criticized Mr. Robb.
Mr. Robb's critics go well beyond the people who want his job. This week, Mary Sue Terry, a former State Attorney General who lost in a bid for Governor last year, endorsed Mr. Goode. She was a law school classmate of Mr. Robb and had supported him in the past.
Another influential Virginia Democrat who previously backed Mr. Robb, Representative James P. Moran Jr., also announced recently that he would not support the Senator. He would not explain why, but in an interview this was the best thing he could say about the Senator, "Some might suggest that he's a better politician than legislator."
One reason Mr. Robb has had difficulty blotting out the negatives is because it is never easy for a freshman Senator to make a mark; and he, in particular, has been distracted by the litany of personal disclosures.
While Mr. Robb has not distinguished himself by steering significant legislation, he cites his votes for the Persian Gulf War and for budgets to reduce the deficit as showing his mettle as a leader. He does not mention perhaps his most controversial vote: in favor of the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court.
Mr. Robb defends his record, and in a familiar strategy for besieged politicians, blames the press for inaccurately portraying him while refusing to say exactly how he has been misrepresented. He said his achievements were not well known because he had never been one "to run for the cameras."
"To be reduced to a caricature is not anybody's idea of either a pleasant experience or of making life any easier for you," he said. "I've managed to stick to my knitting and get the job done in a difficult period."
But it may take more than knitting and Oliver North to deflect all the bad publicity. So in another, rather risky move, Mr. Robb has begun emphasizing his record of support for homosexual rights, and for overturning the ban on homosexuals in the military. Most notably, he appeared this month before the Human Rights Campaign Fund, a national gay political group.
While the move could backfire in a state as conservative as Virginia, Mr. Robb hopes that if the general election is splintered with a handful of candidates, homosexuals and liberals will be spurred by his stand to support him.
So far, Mr. Robb has avoided dwelling on Mr. North, though he said he would never underestimate "the fierce loyalty" of the Republican's supporters, nor the circumstances that allowed a man who worked in the White House to portray himself as "a martyr poking his finger in the eye of the establishment."
As Mr. Robb talks about hanging on to his Senate seat, the Washington whispers about his running for Vice President, or even President, could not seem farther away. Such a question, Mr. Robb said, "doesn't get asked by journalists anymore."
But the once-pristine Senator from Virginia says that "believe it or not" some people harken back to the magical days when he first squired Lynda Bird and think that bigger things are still in store for him.
"People go back to a storybook wedding or something, and they just think that the stars were supposed to work out a certain way," he said with a trace of wistfulness.

HEADLINE: George W. Ball Dies at 84; Vietnam's Devil's Advocate

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
George W. Ball, who as Under Secretary of State in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations argued forcefully but unsuccessfully against United States involvement in the Vietnam War, died Thursday night in New York Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.
The cause of death was not immediately determined, but his son, Douglas, said that Mr. Ball had entered the hospital on Wednesday and that his doctors had made a diagnosis of terminal abdominal cancer. 
 Mr. Ball's opposition to the Vietnam War was based on his belief that Europe, not Southeast Asia, was the central political arena and that the key to East-West rapprochement and world peace lay in a strong, unified Western Europe.
Mr. Ball, who also served as United States delegate to the United Nations in 1968, retired in 1982 as senior managing director of the New York investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.
 
Career Began in New Deal
 In a career that began in the New Deal and spanned half a century, Mr. Ball was a lawyer, economist, author, investment banker, high Government official, diplomatic troubleshooter and adviser to Presidents. He never ran for elective office and rose no higher than Under Secretary, the No. 2 post in the State Department, which he held from 1961 to 1966. But he was an influential and often dissenting voice in the making of American foreign policy in the 1960's.
Mr. Ball was a leading exponent of European economic and political unity and of aid to underdeveloped nations; a mediator of crises in Cyprus, Pakistan, the Congo and elsewhere and a member of President Kennedy's inner circle in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis.
But he was perhaps best known as an early and consistent opponent of American involvement in Vietnam: a devil's advocate who challenged the basic assumptions about the war, yet never lost his influence within the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.
As early as 1961, when most Americans had no inkling of where Vietnam was, let alone what was going on there, Mr. Ball was urging President Kennedy not to send American servicemen, warning that hundreds of thousands of troops might ultimately have to go.
 
The Vietnamese Detour
 Later, when the Johnson Administration built up American involvement in the war, he argued against "the Vietnamese detour with its deep ruts and treacherous quicksands." Later on, he did not favor unilateral American withdrawal, but sought reduced involvement and a political settlement with the Communists.
"By a series of small steps, taken in good faith over a period of years," he said as the conflict swelled, "we have mired ourselves in a frustrating war that turns our otherwise sensible countrymen into placard-carrying hysterics and impedes our coming to grips with fundamental problems in our cities, our society and the world."
His opposition was not founded on pacifism, morality or other principles espoused by antiwar demonstrators. Indeed, he found it "stupid and unattractive" that antiwar protesters engaged "in self-flagellation, declaring in sanctimonious tones that American policy is thoroughly in the wrong and that we as a nation are as brutal and viciously ambitious as the other side."
His dissenting views stemmed rather from his belief that Southeast Asia was peripheral to American interests, diverting attention from the main arena, which he said lay in Europe.
 
Focus on Europe
 This theme -- that a united Western Europe was the key to American foreign policy because it would strengthen the Atlantic alliance and provide a cushion between the United States and the Soviet Union -- was, in fact, the touchstone of Mr. Ball's vision of global politics.
In this vision, the United States, a unified Europe and the Soviet Union would come finally to an East-West rapprochement, and these stronger nations of the northern half of the world, working together, would help the poorer peoples of the Southern Hemisphere, ultimately bringing peace and plenty to the planet.
With Europe and its problems as his immediate focus, Mr. Ball thus concluded that the whole Asian mainland, not merely Vietnam, was peripheral to American interests and that fighting there constituted an enormous waste of human and national resources.
Communist China, he contended, was overrated as a menace, and its existence should be accepted forthrightly. He favored trade with China, United Nations membership for Beijing and abandonment of the "myth" that Chinese Nationalists on Taiwan represented China.
 
Views Did Not Prevail
 Mr. Ball's views, for the most part, did not prevail while he was in office, though by the end of the Johnson years many top policy makers believed, as he had, that the Vietnam War could not be won. For most of his tenure, however, Mr. Ball was regarded in the Government as a kind of loyal oppositon.
"I've become," as he once said, "a champion of lost causes."
Detractors contended he was being used by Secretary of State Dean Rusk and President Johnson as a sophisticated yes man who could be relied upon to raise cogent objections and then be overruled, so critics could not say dissenting views were unheard in policy-making circles. But Mr. Ball's admirers called him a team player in the best sense and said his views were valued and had a moderating influence.
When he resigned as Under Secretary in 1966 to return to private life, Mr. Ball left on friendly terms and silenced his criticism of the war during the remaining Johnson years. It was not until after President Nixon took office that he attacked America's Vietnam policy publicly again.
He was called back several times in the Johnson Administration, serving on a Presidential advisory group that urged an end to a further buildup of the Vietnam War and providing counsel when North Korea captured an American intelligence ship, the Pueblo, in January 1968.
 
Author and Counsel
 In May 1968, President Johnson named Mr. Ball as the United States delegate to the United Nations after Arthur J. Goldberg, another opponent of the Vietnam War, resigned, apparently in frustration over his diminishing influence.
Mr. Ball returned to work as an investment banker when President Nixon entered the White House in 1969, but was called back by President Carter for counsel on crises in Iran and the Persian Gulf and on the Panama Canal Treaties. He also continued to write articles and books, occasionally stirring controversy with his views on Israel, the Middle East and other subjects.
Mr. Ball was the author of five books, "The Discipline of Power: Essentials of a Modern World Structure," published in 1968; "Diplomacy for a Crowded World," in 1976; "The Past Has Another Pattern," a memoir, in 1982; "Error and Betrayal in Lebanon," in 1983, and "The Passionate Attachment," a history of American-Israeli relations, written with his son, Douglas, in 1992. At his death, he was working on a book about America at the end of the 20th Century.
Tall, burly, with white wavy hair, a cleft chin and gray eyes behind dark- rimmed spectacles, Mr. Ball was a forceful speaker whose style, in writing too, struck an academic tone with literary flourishes. His sentences often began ponderously but wound up with stingers in the tail. In a memo to President Kennedy, for example, he wrote: "Whenever we extend the hand of friendship to President de Gaulle, he puts into it a dead fish."
 
Native of Iowa

George Wildman Ball was born on Dec. 21, 1909, in Des Moines, the third son of Amos and Edna Wildman Ball. His mother was a teacher and his father was a Scottish immigrant who became a vice president of Standard Oil of Indiana.
The family moved to Evanston, Ill., when George was 11, and he later enrolled at Northwestern University. He majored in English, founded a literary magazine, graduated in 1930 and earned his law degree from Northwestern in 1933.
Eager to become a part of the New Deal, he went to Washington and worked in the Farm Credit Bureau and in the Treasury Department. But his enthusiasm soon paled and he returned to Chicago in 1935 to join a tax law firm, one of whose partners was Adlai E. Stevenson. The two became close friends, and Mr. Stevenson, who went to Washington in 1941, helped place Mr. Ball in 1942 as a lawyer with the Lend-Lease Administration.
In London in 1944-45, Mr. Ball was director of the United States Strategic Bombing Survey, appraising the effects of the air war against Germany. It was in this capacity that he met and became close to Jean Monnet, who was to become known after the war as the architect of the European unification movement.
Captivated by Mr. Monnet's vision of Europe as a unified political-economic entity that could be a bulwark of Western strength, Mr. Ball after the war supported the unification cause, in effect becoming its Washington representative.
 
Lobbied for Common Market
 He became a founding partner of the law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Ball, which represented the Common Market and the European Coal and Steel Community, and he pushed the first abortive efforts of British entry into the Common Market.
It was a short step into the political arena after Mr. Stevenson, then Governor of Illinois, joined the race for President in 1952. Then, and again in 1956, Mr. Ball was chief of volunteers in the Stevenson Presidential campaigns. In 1960, he backed John F. Kennedy.
When the Kennedy Administration took office, Mr. Ball was named Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. But less than a year later, when Chester Bowles resigned in November 1961, Mr. Ball was named Under Secretary of State.
Mr. Ball became an Administration trouble-shooter, shuttling between Athens, Ankara and Nicosia to mediate crises over Cyprus, and dashing off to Pakistan, the Congo, the Dominican Republic and other trouble spots to ease tensions or halt fighting. He was a prodigious toiler and traveler, often working six days a week and 70 hours at a stretch, and was usually at his best under pressure.
 
In Kennedy's Inner Circle
 He was one of a small circle of advisers to President Kennedy in the Cuban missile crisis in 1962, when the discovery that Soviet missiles were being transported and installed in Cuba raised the specter of nuclear war with the Soviet Union. Mr. Ball urged a naval blockade of Cuba coupled with a demand that the Soviet missiles be withdrawn, the course that was successfully followed.
After Mr. Kennedy's assassination in November 1963, Mr. Ball was one of the leaders who went to the White House to work out a transition to the new Administration. Resigning as Under Secretary in 1966, he joined Lehman Brothers and, except for his service at the United Nations and occasional duty as a Presidential adviser, remained with the firm for the rest of his career.
In the Carter Administration, Mr. Ball helped draft long-range American policy in the Persian Gulf. As an adviser to the National Security Council on Iran, he was critical of supporting Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, and favored formation of a broad coalition government in Teheran. He also helped mount a bipartisan effort for Senate ratification of the Panama Canal Treaties.
Mr. Ball's wife, Ruth Murdoch Ball, whom he married in 1932, died last August. He is survived by two sons, John Colin Ball, of West Concord, Mass., and Douglas Bleakly Ball, of Rockville Centre, L.I., and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York on June 21.

He conferred with Secretary of State Dean Rusk, second from left, President Johnson and Defense Secretary Robert McNamara. (United Press International, 1964)

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
Joining the gift of water with the gift of love at a baptismal ceremony in Manhattan.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
"We thank thee, Almighty God, for the gift of water." The water that the Rev. Howard T. W. Stowe was praying over last Sunday was in the baptismal font at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church on West 87th Street in Manhattan, where he is the rector and where he was about to baptize three young parishioners.
At Father Stowe's side was the Rev. Thomas Mafora, who had his own special reasons to be thankful for the gift of water. Father Mafora is the rector of All Saints' Anglican Church in Khuma, South Africa, a black township in the western Transvaal. 
 In the best of times, Khuma is not exactly paradise on earth. But in recent years, with the closing of some of the gold mines that had drawn thousands of workers to the area, many of Khuma's 35,000 people have been unemployed. Then the region was blistered by South Africa's worst drought in the 20th century. In February 1992, the white farmers on the Town Council of Stilfontein cut off Khuma's water supply.
The consequences of this were not altogether lost on the white authorities. Almost immediately, they warned whites in the area that their domestic servants who lived in Khuma had no water or sanitary services available and therefore could contaminate their employers with cholera, dysentery, diarrhea or other diseases.
"You are hereby requested to insure that your domestic servant/employee does not prepare any foodstuffs or handle any utensils unless she has washed herself properly," the Town Council announced.
While the whites may have been spared, Khuma's blacks were not. Word of the deaths and diseases wracking the township soon reached St. Ignatius of Antioch, a sister parish with All Saints since 1990.
St. Ignatius is an unusual parish. The Mass on Sunday, celebrated with the priests' backs to the congregation and rich with more Latin than one is likely to hear this side of Rome, would make the heart of the Vatican's Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger leap with joy -- until he realized that two of the celebrants at the altar or in the pulpit were women.
The solemn ritual does not keep the parish from offering help to parishioners and neighbors with AIDS or from running a soup kitchen and weekend shelter for the homeless. Informed of Khuma's plight, St. Ignatius quickly raised $20,000 from parishioners, friends and several other Episcopal parishes to pay for the drilling of a well in Khuma.
"We thank thee, Almighty God, for the gift of water," Father Stowe said in his prayer. "Over it the Holy Spirit moved in the beginning of creation. Through it Thou didst lead the children of Israel out of their bondage in Egypt and into the land of promise."
Last Sunday was the feast of Pentecost, or Whitsunday, and so Father Mafora preached on the transformation of Jesus's disciples by the coming of the Holy Spirit. Recounting the dissipation of the disciples' fear, he could not help but speak of his country and its passage out of bondage.
In June 1976, he said, the schoolchildren of Soweto, armed with "no weapon but the weapon of the Holy Spirit -- hope," were able to galvanize black South Africans to express their outrage over apartheid.
Father Mafora, a short, solid man who is 52 years old, had witnessed that protest. After Mass last Sunday he recalled his days as a priest at St. Paul's Anglican Church in Soweto. It was near a crossroads where the marching schoolchildren confronted the police on June 16, 1976. The children fled into the churchyard, which was bombarded with tear gas, he said, and the first one killed was Hector Peterson, a 13-year-old parishioner of St. Paul's.
At All Saints' Church in Khuma they call it Jacob's Well, after the place where Jesus told the Samaritan woman that he would give the water of eternal life (John 4:14). The well is in the churchyard, and people can get water free when they need it.
Since late last year the rains have returned. ("We call them rains of blessing," Father Mafora said.) The local authorities have begun to construct a better water supply for the whole township. "But the push came from this well," he said.
"We thank Thee, o Father, for the water of baptism," Father Stowe continued. "In it we are buried with Christ in His death. By it we share in His resurrection. Through it we are reborn by the Holy Spirit."
When the thanksgiving over the water was completed, Father Stowe poured some on the heads of Anthony Clemons, Caroline Metz and Randolph Shorter, welcoming them into the community of the baptized.
It was water from Jacob's Well. It was, Father Mafora said, "pure from the ground and all across the sea."
Could anything better illustrate the idea of a sacrament? When the St. Ignatius parish put out a flyer seeking donations for the well, it had carried a line from W. H. Auden: "Thousands have lived without love, not one without water."
On Sunday, surely, the two were one.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At St. Ignatius of Antioch Church in Manhattan last Sunday, Randolph Shorter, 6, was baptized as his godmother, Saundra Cornwell, looked on. The Rev. Thomas Mafora, right, of Khuma, South Africa, poured water from a well that St. Ignatius parishioners had helped to pay for. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CHINA WELCOMES U.S. TRADE POLICY

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 27

 BODY:
China today welcomed President Clinton's decision to separate trade from human rights, saying a "historic opportunity" exists to improve relations between the United States and China, and pledging to make "major efforts" in that direction.
At a minimum, United States officials expect China to release several more well-known political prisoners, some with serious medical problems, and to complete an agreement with the International Committee of the Red Cross to open China's prisons to outside inspection. 
 "If we get momentum in the relationship, and if there are some human rights improvements in coming months, then the President can very legitimately continue to stand up and say he did the right thing and not be pressured by Congress into reimposing the linkage," one Western diplomatic official said.
"It is absolutely critical that China in the coming weeks and months genuinely cooperate in a variety of areas to send the right signals," said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Those signals, he said, would include China's continuing to release political prisoners as well as being seen as "addressing human rights issues important to the United States, including Tibet."
Over the last several months, China has arrested a number of dissidents as part of a nationwide clampdown in the name of maintaining "social stability." Labor organizers in Shanghai and Beijing have been jailed for drafting petitions to the Government, and intellectuals have been rounded up for calling for a new national debate on democracy and political reform.
Among those arrested was Wei Jingsheng, the country's best-known dissident, whose release last September after 14 years of imprisonment seemed to signal political relaxation. Western officials are now hoping that after the sensitive 5th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre on June 4, these dissidents will once again be freed from detention.
In a lengthy statement issued today on Mr. Clinton's decision to extend China's special trading benefits, China's Foreign Ministry said: "The Chinese Government and people welcome this decision of President Clinton. The current situation offers a historic opportunity for the enhancement" of relations between the two countries.
The Chinese statement added, without providing specifics, that Beijing would make "major efforts for the improvement and growth" of relations and called on Washington to do the same.
 
Months of Talks
 Talks between White House emissaries and the Chinese leadership have been under way for several months, the Western official said, "and I think the dialogue has helped to clarify for the Chinese what it is the President is looking for."
"I know Washington is looking very carefully at what the deeds as well as the words actually are, and it is very important that the Chinese take the high road," the Western official said. "If there is only grudging acceptance of the new approach, combined with many more arrests and other sorts of acts that could be interpreted as 'in your face,' then it will make it much more difficult for the President to get through the next political season.
"I hope that what has come out of this private dialogue," he said, "is that the Chinese now do have a real stake in the relationship, and they realize President Clinton himself has personally put a lot at stake."
 
Diplomatic Visits to Increase
 The diplomat also said high-level diplomatic visits are likely to increase in the months ahead to consolidate Mr. Clinton's new policy, including talks to lay the groundwork for mutual state visits by the Chinese and American Presidents.
"There is definite talk about high-level visits," the official said. "One could imagine a series of exchanges and visits that would demonstrate an obvious improvement in the relationship. Under an optimistic scenario, Washington is ready for that."
China's Communist Party leaders did not comment directly on the decision in a day of meetings that centered on the visit of Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia. On evening news broadcasts, the story of Mr. Clinton's decision appeared near the end of the program.
The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Wu Jianmin, met with foreign journalists twice during the day, but declined to characterize Mr. Clinton's decision as a victory for China. Instead, he chose diplomatic language and reiterated China's theme that trade relations are mutually beneficial and should not be the battleground for clashes over China's human rights record.
 
Call for End to Sanctions
 He called on the Clinton Administration to remove the last sanctions placed on high technology and military sales after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown by army troops on pro-democracy demonstrators that left hundreds dead.
"What the U.S. side did in the past few years," Mr. Wu said, "has impaired the bilateral trade and economic exchanges and the overall relations between the two countries, to the strong dissatisfaction of the two peoples."
"We have to point out with regret that while announcing the renewal" of China's low-tariff trade benefits, "the U.S. side stated that the existing sanctions against China would be maintained," Mr. Wu said. He added that he hoped the United States "will immediately remove all sanctions against China and abandon all measures detrimental to the development" of better relations.
In Beijing, American and Western business leaders were more demonstrative in their support for the decision, with most managers expressing relief that the annual uncertainty over the course of Washington's China policy has been removed.
 
Praise of U.S. Business Group
 "The President's decision should avert a trade war that would have wrought havoc on U.S. businesses, workers and consumers," a business coalition for United States-China trade said in a statement.
"American business serves as a positive force for change in China," said Calman J. Cohen, a spokesman for the coalition. "Our Chinese employees, managers and workers are exposed to Western values, encouraged to think independently, and offered opportunities previously unavailable in China."
Human rights organizations appeared determined to challenge Mr. Clinton's decision, and they expressed concern that the change will spell harsh consequences for dissidents in China.
Asia Watch, a human rights monitoring group, warned in a statement that "outspoken intellectuals, workers and religious activists who had the courage to express their views might now be more vulnerable to persecution and arrests, given that Chinese leaders understand that a crackdown would not bring about a disruption in trade."
Most dissidents in recent days have slipped out of Beijing or into seclusion as China's security authorities have made it clear they will not tolerate any attempt to commemorate the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

HEADLINE: Christopher Presses Policy Of Engagement With Asia

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, speaking in New York yesterday, cast President Clinton's decision to renew China's preferred trade status as part of a stepped-up policy of engagement throughout Asia.
In a speech to the Asia Society, Mr. Christopher said President Clinton's decision on Thursday to engage China, rather than punish it, was part of a strategy to build stability in Asia and share the continent's prosperity. 
"The President's decision reflects a comprehensive U.S. strategy of engagement and leadership in the Asia-Pacific," arena, he said. "It encourages Chinese cooperation in building a new regional and international order based upon peace and security."
He said extending China's trade privileges was part of a policy the Administration pursued in several ways this week: exchanging diplomatic missions with Vietnam, resuming talks with Japan over its trade barriers, and announcing talks with North Korea on its nuclear program.
 
The North Korean Angle
 Eager to respond to criticisms of the President's decision, Mr. Christopher also noted that China's cooperation was important for a chief foreign policy goal: persuading North Korea to abandon its nuclear program.
"Our relationship with China is important to all Americans," he said. "China possesses the world's largest army, a nuclear arsenal, and, not insignificantly, a veto in the United Nations Security Council."
Defending the President's decision, Mr. Christopher said China was too important to be isolated and too big to be pushed around. He added that its huge, fast-growing economy is a lucrative market for American companies.
Mr. Christopher asserted that the United States would continue to keep the heat on Beijing to improve its human rights performance.
"We're not backing away in any way from pursing human rights problems," he said, asserting that Washington's human rights dialogue with Beijing would intensify.
His speech was part of the Administration's damage control after lawmakers and human rights groups accused the President of flip-flopping after he had condemned President Bush for coddling China's rulers.
In an interview, Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who heads a House caucus that has pushed for tough measures on China's human rights performance, said that although the President said on Thursday he would ban imports of Chinese weapons and ammunition, he "didn't announce any real sanctions yesterday."
She and other lawmakers are drafting a broader sanctions bill that is expected to call for denying favorable tariffs to products made by industries owned by China's military -- a measure that is expected to cover close to $1 billion of China's $30 billion in exports to the United States. It is estimated the ban on munitions will affect only $100 million in trade.
At the address, Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, voiced concern that the sanctions adopted were of only "token" significance.

HEADLINE: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT BRISK 3% RATE IN FIRST QUARTER

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
In a recalculation of first-quarter growth, the Government reported today that the economy expanded at a steady 3 percent annual clip during the winter because spending by consumers, business and the Federal Government was more than had originally been thought.
The surprising upward revision, from a preliminary estimate of 2.6 percent, touched off a decline in the bond market as investors reacted to fears that the stronger growth could cause inflation and erode the value of fixed-income securities. 
 The figures coincided with Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who said the economy was not yet reflecting any of the restraining effects from the four increases in short-term interest rates since early February. [Page 35.]
The latest figures -- while showing only half the growth rate of the fourth quarter of last year -- pointed to further solid expansion, with analysts predicting a rate of perhaps 4 percent in the April-to-June quarter. After that, they expect the economy to settle back to a pace it can sustain without risking revived inflation -- roughly 2.5 percent.
"Three percent G.D.P. in the face of the California earthquake and unusually severe weather is pretty darn impressive," said Joshua N. Feinman, an economist at the Bankers Trust Company. Like most economists, he had been anticipating a modest decline, not an increase, in the Commerce Department's revision of figures, a recalculation the agency performs twice each quarter as it obtains more complete information.
With the quickened first-quarter growth in mind, traders and economists began to focus on the release next Friday of the Government's figures on the job market in May. The employment report is considered the most important single gauge of economic conditions.
"Recent comforting hopes that the expansion is slowing significantly were undermined today by an upward revision to first-quarter G.D.P.," John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, told his clients. "Such hopes could vanish altogether next week if job growth remains strong. Robust hiring would remind markets that a 125-basis-point increase in the Federal funds rate will not be sufficient to dramatically slow economic growth."
As a result, Mr. Lipsky suggested, a resumption of Federal Reserve moves to raise short-term interest rates could seem "much less distant."
Although the growth rate for the first quarter was a good deal less than the boomlike 7 percent rate in the final three months of 1993, it was higher than the 2.5 percent or so that analysts generally consider to be sustainable in the long run without sparking a surge in inflation. This estimate is based on the assumption of an annual rise of 1.5 percent in productivity, combined with growth of 1 percent in the work force.
Perhaps the most important element in the revision of the G.D.P. reported today was the growth in final sales -- spending and investment without regard to what happens to inventories -- at a rate of 2.2 percent, more than double the rise of nine-tenths of 1 percent reported for the quarter in the first G.D.P. report in late April.
 
Consumer Spending Up
 Spending by consumers was raised to a rate of 4.6 percent, from 3.8 percent, with purchases of nondurable goods like clothing up substantially while spending on services and on cars and other durable goods was modestly higher.
Business investment was higher than first estimated and the import-export sector was less of a drag, the department also found.
But the most startling change -- and the biggest after the increase in personal consumption -- was in nonmilitary spending by the Federal Government, which now shows an 18.3 percent rate of advance instead of a 7.6 percent rate of decline.
The biggest negative influence, though widely expected, was that inventories rose much less than previously estimated -- at a rate of $19.1 billion instead of $30.5 billion. But while this adjustment cut into first-quarter growth, it implied more potential demand for production in subsequent months as merchants replenished shelves and warehouses.
G.D.P., which measures the output of all goods and services in the country, counts everything produced regardless of whether it reaches the ultimate user.
 
Decline in Savings Rate
 As a result of continued heavy spending by consumers, combined with modest income growth and an end to a huge push of mortgage refinancings, the personal savings rate is now calculated at an unusually low 3.5 percent. This compares with 3.7 percent last month and 4 percent for the final 1993 quarter.
The dwindling amount of cash freed up by refinancing is one reason to expect some slackening of economic growth, said John E. Barnds, director of business and banking analysis at the NBD Bank in Detroit. He projects expansion at a rate of 2.75 to 3 percent in the second half of the year.
Today's report also brought an upward revision in inflation, to a 2.6 percent annual rate from 2.3 percent, as measured by the fixed-weight price index for gross domestic purchases. Analysts expressed no particular concern, however, noting that another inflation statistic in the report, the G.D.P. deflator, remained at the previously reported rate of 2.6 percent. The deflator takes account of changes in the composition of output.
Corporate profits, in today's first estimate for the quarter, fell $33.5 billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate after rising $39.4 billion in the fourth quarter of last year. About $29 billion of the decline was attributed to the Los Angeles earthquake in January, which caused insurance companies to pay out benefits and led companies to take write-offs of uninsured damage to their property.

HEADLINE: Boutros-Ghali Says Sanctions on Haiti Need 'Several Weeks'

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said today that he would wait no more than several weeks before asking the Security Council to consider whether tougher measures are needed to oust Haiti's military leaders.
To give expanded trade sanctions against Haiti some chance to work, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said, the United Nations plans to provide helicopters and other equipment to the Dominican Republic to encourage the country to patrol its border with Haiti and prevent embargoed goods from getting through. 
 The Secretary General's comments, made after a meeting at the White House with President Clinton, suggested that he is in rough accord with Administration officials, who have expressed a growing determination to end the dictatorship in Haiti.
 
No Word on Force
 Mr. Boutros-Ghali would not say whether he would favor using military force to restore democracy to Haiti, a step Mr. Clinton and his aides have said they would consider if the near-total embargo imposed last weekend fails to oust military officers who took power in a 1991 coup. But Mr. Boutros-Ghali said that it would be "a question of weeks" before he would ask the Security Council to debate tougher action.
That is far less time than Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France suggested. He said sanctions should be allowed as long as four months to work.
A senior Administration official cautioned today that no change in the American course is likely until after Mr. Clinton, Vice President Gore, and Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott complete a broad effort in the next two weeks to consult with other countries.
The official also noted that Mr. Boutros-Ghali must report to the Security Council by June 30 about the sanctions' effect and said that his comments today may in part reflect that deadline.
A senior White House official who described the sense of urgency about Haiti within the Administration referred to it "a matter of political and economic reality."
While Mr. Clinton has promised for now to provide hearings for Haitian refugees before sending them back to Port-au-Prince, the official suggested that it had become increasingly clear that the policy would serve as no more than an interim solution.
William Gray, Mr. Clinton's special adviser on Haiti, said after meetings this week with the Dominican Republic he was "feeling very upbeat" about the prospect of curbing shipments across the frontier.

Most were from an area in the town of Gonaives where 25 people were killed last month by backers of the military. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Korea Speeds Nuclear Fuel Removal, Impeding Inspection

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
In a new challenge to Washington, North Korea has stepped up its removal of fuel from a nuclear reactor, prompting concern that it may prevent international monitors from carrying out crucial inspections, Clinton Administration officials said today.
The move surprised the Clinton Administration, which only a week ago offered to begin high-level talks with the North Korean Government in Pyongyang. 
 Clinton Administration officials said they did not know whether the quickened pace reflected a determination on North Korea's part to destroy possible evidence that it had diverted fuel to its nuclear weapons program or was merely a bluff intended to throw inspectors and the United States off balance.
But it generated alarm and pessimism within the Administration, which has been taking a conciliatory tone toward North Korea this week.
At the same time, the Administration has warned that if the evidence is destroyed, not only will the high-level talks be called off, but the United States will have no choice but to press for international economic sanctions -- a move that North Korea has said it would consider an act of war.
The offer to hold talks was made on the condition that the North Koreans not divert fuel from the reactor at Yongbyon to make bombs or prevent inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency from inspecting some of the fuel rods currently in the reactor.
Specifically, the atomic energy agency wants North Korea to put aside 300 of the 8,000 rods from specific parts of the reactor so that measurements might be carried out in the future to determine how much plutonium the North Koreans might have diverted in past years.
 
Difficulty of Verification
 Hans Blix, the director general of the atomic energy agency, told Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the United Nations Secretary General, today that North Korea's discharge of fuel was now proceeding "at a very fast pace." He said the country had already removed more than 3,000 of the rods, effectively discharging nearly half the fuel in the reactor's core.
If the North Koreans continue to withdraw the rods at the current rate, they will have removed the rods the agency wants to inspect in a matter of days.
"Almost half of the fuel in the reactor core has been discharged and in a pattern that has precluded the agency's ability to implement the full range of the safeguards measures required," Mr. Blix said in a letter to Mr. Boutros-Ghali.
Should that happen, the atomic energy agency "would not be able to verify the amount of plutonium produced" in North Korea, Mr. Blix added.
The head of the nuclear monitoring agency also reported that talks between the agency and North Korea over inspecting the fuel rods had broken down and that the North Koreans had refused to discuss the agency's concerns.
 
Exchanges Go Poorly
 Adding to the renewed sense of crisis, Clinton Administration officials reported that working-level exchanges between American and North Korean officials this week did not go well.
When the American side proposed that the high-level talks be held in early June, the North Koreans responded by rejecting the Americans' demand that North Korea put aside some of the rods at the Yongbyon reactor for future inspection, a senior Clinton Administration official said.
In the hope of reaching an accommodation with North Korea, Washington and the atomic energy agency have taken a flexible stance. They have not insisted on immediate measurements of the fuel rods, but rather demanded that the possibility of inspecting them in the future be preserved.
A senior Clinton Administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said he was baffled by the North Korean move. He said there was no technical or safety reason for withdrawing the rods and noted that their removal would preclude the high-level talks with Washington.
Worried by Mr. Blix's report, American officials were hurriedly consulting diplomats at the United Nations today about the possibility of issuing a warning to North Korea. The C.I.A. and most other intelligence agencies say they believe that there is a "better than even" chance that North Korea has already produced one or two nuclear bombs, an assertion North Korea has denied.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
