HEADLINE: Street Peddlers in New York

 BODY:
New York City has lost 325,000 jobs -- that's a third of a million paychecks -- over the last five years. With unemployment on the rise and immigrants still streaming in looking for work, people by the thousands have turned to hawking goods illegally in the streets. Street vendors and their clamor are an integral part of life in the city. But the makeshift markets they create often make sidewalks impassable, allow opportunities for protection rackets and undercut legitimate merchants.
The Giuliani administration is right to crack down on illegal vendors, especially on dangerously crowded thoroughfares like Harlem's 125th Street. But the administration must also make it easier for those who wish to operate within the law to do so. That means creating more vendor licenses and establishing locations where they can sell their wares without creating a hazard to public safety. 
 Immigrants have always treated New York's streets as a marketplace where hard work and grit could lead to economic security. Early in the century, lower Manhattan was so choked with pushcarts that stores could not get deliveries and police and fire wagons had trouble navigating the streets. Licensing requirements and street restrictions have eased the crush in most of Manhattan's business districts. But uptown neighborhoods and areas of Brooklyn and Queens have recently become problems.
Along 125th Street in Harlem, laws governing street vending have no effect at all. Two years ago when David Dinkins, then Mayor, tried to sweep illegal vendors from the street, they staged a demonstration that shut the business strip down. A truce was called and illegal vending continued.
Vendors from all over the region took the truce as an invitation and swarmed into Harlem. Once there were about 200 vendors on 125th Street, some of whom had occupied the same spaces for as long as 10 years. These days on weekends as many as 1,000 hawkers clog the sidewalks, impeding police work and openly competing with legitimate merchants. The merchants are fined for garbage that vendors leave on the sidewalks. Competition among the vendors for space leads to street fights.
The city now proposes moving the vendors off the main thoroughfares and into open-air markets. The markets would be license-free zones where people pay a fee to operate. Those who refuse to relocate and continue illegal vending would be prosecuted.
Even the vendors concede that 125th Street is out of control. At the same time, they fear going out of business if the open-air sites are too far from prime shopping areas. The vendors also complain that the city's cap of 853 licenses for general vendors gives them no choice but to operate outside the law. The Department of Consumer affairs, which administers the licenses, has a waiting list of 5,000 people.
A report three years ago from the Department of Consumer Affairs pointed out that the cap was arbitrary, and recommended raising it. "Under this proposal," it said, "more vendors would have a stake in the regulatory system and an incentive to adhere to restrictions, to pay taxes, and to generally behave as a good neighbor." Unlicensed vendors have no such commitment; they operate with impunity, where and how they please.
By all means, enforce the law against illegal street peddling. But also make it possible to work within the law.

HEADLINE: Beach Season Begins Without a Cloud in the Forecast

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELMAR, N.J., May 26

 BODY:
After years of bad news about fouled water, pinched vacation budgets and storm-damaged beaches and boardwalks, the summer of 1994 appears to be shaping up as a good one both for beachgoers and those who depend on the summertime sun-and-sand crowd to make a living.
"We've received very positive indications from a cross-section of businesses at the shore that bookings for beach rentals are up above last year and water quality is excellent," said Karen Shaffer, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Department of Tourism. 
 There is optimism as well in New York and Connecticut. Joan K. Davidson, Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation for New York, said: "Early reports on beach conditions are good and we hope they hold up. It may be the best year in a long time."
 
Pure Fun and Big Bucks
 There are those who speak almost mystically of the lure of the ocean and its eternal rhythms. But for people like 19-year-old Cindy McGuire of West Orange, N.J., the attraction is as plainly evident as a nut-brown suntan or a roiling ride on a breaking wave.
"Summertime without the beach would be a complete drag," said Ms. McGuire, a secretary for a data analysis company who skipped a half-day at work this week to ride with friends to the beach at Belmar when temperatures reached the 80's. "The beach is pure fun."
It is also big bucks. The local and state economies of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have billions of dollars riding on how many people throng to area beaches this summer, which unofficially begins this Memorial Day weekend no matter what the calendar says.
Day-trippers and vacationers to the Jersey Shore's 127 miles of beaches contribute as much as $10 billion a year to the state's tourist economy. New York and to a lesser extent Connecticut also have extensive public and private investments that can soar or plunge depending on millions of decisions made each day of the summer by people who look at the sky and wonder if it is a good day for the beach.
They did not always think so in the late 1980's, when beachfronts were plagued with floating garbage, sewage and litter, including discarded hypodermic needles.
By the time New York City stopped ocean dumping of waste materials and other sources of pollution were halted, a new problem washed ashore in the form of a serious recession that cut into vacation budgets.
Then the coastline was battered by three powerful northeasters between October 1991 and December 1992, and millions of tons of sand were stripped from beaches and dunes.
Beachfront businesses like Lynne Watt's Beach Sweets, an ice cream and candy shop on the boardwalk in Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., were wrecked by waves.
"Last summer was a nightmare because we were still rebuilding," Mrs. Watt said. "But now we're in great shape, and I have wrinkles on my face from smiling."
Severe erosion kept people away from Fire Island and a few other hard-hit Long Island beaches last year despite a persistent heat wave and water conditions so clear bathers were frightened by fish they could see for the first time. Rentals have picked up this season though property sales continue to lag, said Deborah Alter, owner of Fire Island Summer Space, a real-estate agency.
Long Island's 10 state beaches head into the summer in good shape, said Susan Gordon Ryan, regional director of the state park system. "There were a lot of snowstorms last winter, but none of them caused much beach erosion," she said.
 
'It Must Be the Cabin Fever'
 Memory of excellent beach conditions apparently merged with a terrible winter to induce many people to start reserving accommodations early for this year. On eastern Long Island many of the summer rentals are already booked in a market with season prices ranging from $3,000 for a one-room cabana to $170,000 for a house on the ocean with amenities like a private tennis court.
In Sea Girt, N.J., typical houses rent for $12,000 to $15,000 a summer, $30,000 if they are on the beach, said Kathryn Matthews, owner of G. A. Murphy Realtors.
"There are very few rentals left and our beach was already crowded last weekend like it was already July," she said. "It must be the cabin fever feeling of being locked up by all the snow last winter."
While it's possible to board a New York City subway or bus for Coney Island or the Rockaways, many people believe going to the beach means getting far away from the city. In the case of Lara Abrash and Gary Gugh of Hoboken, that means going to the Hamptons -- and paying for the privilege.
Ms. Abrash, a seasoned veteran of the Hampton scene, says she pays $28 for a round-trip ticket on the Long Island Rail Road. For those who make the trip by car, parking at the beach costs $10 a day, she added, and bars have a $10 entrance fee in the evening.
"It can easily cost me $100 for the weekend, and that's with eating pizzas or having barbecues," she said.
To reduce their costs, she and Mr. Gugh pay $150 apiece to have access on five weekends to a one-room bungalow that rents for $3,000 a summer. That means, she said, that as many as 10 to 12 people pile into the structure on a weekend, with most sleeping on the floor.
Rental agents and owners say that they discourage such overcrowding but that it makes the summer affordable for young people of modest means.
New Jersey this year has a new law called the seasonal rental ordinance, more popularly known as the "Animal House" law, that forces landlords to post bonds as high as $5,000 if they rent to rowdy groups that persistently draw the attention of the police. It is aimed at giving oceanfront communities the power to shut down rental units crammed with late-night revelers.
 
Radio-Free Areas
 Other additions aimed at keeping the peace at beaches this summer are radio-free zones on state beaches on Long Island. The aim of the clearly designated sections will be to preserve the natural ambience while heading off potential duels between heavy metal and grunge rockers, or salsa and rap aficionados.
Another trend -- nature and local history tours -- is propelled by the increasing number of people who love the beach but fear too much exposure to the sun.
"People are not sunbathing as long as they used to, and there's an effort to develop things that appeal to them," said Barbara Steele, director of tourism development in Ocean County.
On Long Beach Island there is the Jolly Trolley, sponsored by the Alliance for a Living Ocean, that generates interest in the seaside environment. In Monmouth County, Maryann Sabanskas, an environmental planning official, is knitting together the Bayshore Trail system, a waterfront network of bike and walking paths that will lead visitors from the beach along a string of historic and cultural sights on the southern edge of Raritan Bay.
 
Lasers, and Symphonies
 Moreover, competing beach towns are doing more to expand free activities to hold on to beachgoers after the sun goes down. In Point Pleasant Beach, which bills itself as a family destination, there are laser light shows on Sundays, symphony nights on Wednesdays, fireworks on Thursdays and weekly comings and goings of shows featuring elephants, tropical birds, clowns and cowboys.
Everyone agrees, however, that while all these diversions are welcome additions, the success of the summer comes down to one element only.
"If the sun shines we make money, if it rains we don't," concluded Tom Santorielli, a 67-year old counterman at Little Mac's, a boardwalk booth at Point Pleasant Beach that serves pizzas and traditional fare like sausage with peppers and onions on a roll.
After 40 years of summer work on the boardwalk, he observed, the ocean still rolls up the beach with a foamy hiss, youths fall in and out of love on a weekend, and people eat cotton candy and salt water taffy as a ritual.
"The only things that change are the prices," he added, saying that when he started on the boardwalk a whole pizza cost 75 cents, and now a slice goes for $1.70.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Commerce Department said the economy grew at a brisk rate of 3 percent in the first quarter as faster spending contributed to an upward revision in the gross domestic product. [Page 1.] 
 The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, told the Senate Banking Committee that the recent increases in interest rates had not slowed the economy and that economic growth would continue at its current pace in the second quarter. [35.]
The Clinton Administration abandoned its effort this year to overhaul regulation of the banking system. [35.]
 
Companies
A new type of telephone calling card is giving people a low-tech, prepaid way to make long-distance calls. [1.]
I.B.M. overhauled management of its software development programs to try to regain business it has lost to Microsoft. [35.]
McDonald's announced a 2-for-1 stock split and raised its quarterly dividend by 12 percent, to 12 cents. [38.]
H. J. Heinz bought the Farley's baby-food line from Boots Company for $140 million. Farley's is the leading maker of infant formula in Britain. [38.]
Digital Equipment named Bernhard Auer vice president and general manger of its personal computer business unit. Mr. Auer had been vice president and general manager of the unit's European arm. [38.]
Bike couriers in Washington have been meeting with Teamsters since early April to start their own union. Currently, full-time couriers have no health benefits or workers' compensation. [8.]
 
International
The recent takeover of two big Italian banks by Mediobanca is new evidence of the power and corporate insider skills of Enrico Cuccia, the investment bank's chief. [35.]
The worst banking scandal in Indonesian history is threatening to expose corrupt ties among prominent Government officials, bankers and business leaders. [35.]
The chairman of Groupe Schneider of France was arrested in Brussels on fraud charges stemming from a dispute involving Belgian shareholders. [38.]
 
Markets
The stock market closed up slightly in quiet trading as traders streamed out of Wall Street for the Memorial Day weekend. The Dow rose 3.68 points, to 3,757.14. [36.]
Cattle futures extended their rapid recovery from near six-year lows in anticipation of stronger beef demand next week. [39.]
The dollar ended lower against most leading currencies after failing to pierce a key technical resistance level against the German mark. [39.]
Prices of Treasury securities declined moderately after erasing opening gains in abbreviated preholiday trading. The Treasury long bond was down 11/32 , to 8614/32 , for a yield of 7.39 percent, up 3 basis points from Thursday. [45.]
 
Your Money
Retirees are responding to turmoil in the market by tinkering with their portfolios. They are increasing their cash positions, shifting to bonds with shorter maturities, and some are putting more money into stock funds. [33.]
Fund managers see continued growth in small-capitalization stocks and mention a few of their favorites. [33.]
Changing mortgage rates have focused attention on "relocks," which let borrowers shift to a lower rate if rates decline. But borrowers sometimes trip up using these loan provisions. [33.]
More court systems are sending divorce cases to mediation, which can sharply reduce the legal costs of divorce. [34.]

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 3.68 In a Quiet Trading Day

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
As traders streamed out of Wall Street yesterday for the long Memorial Day weekend, the stock market closed up, but just barely, in quiet trading.
Stocks in the indexes did not rise by much, perhaps held back by a surprising economic report and falling bond prices that on another day might have stampeded traders into a strong selloff. 
 Nonetheless, McDonald's rose 1 1/8, to 61, after splitting its stock 2 for 1 and raising its quarterly dividend. Wal-Mart rose 1/4, to 23 7/8, and Bell Atlantic rose 1, to 53 1/2, on no immediate news.
General Electric rose 1/2, to 49, despite the filing of a G.E. shareholder lawsuit against Kidder, Peabody & Company, a G.E. unit, and Joseph Jett, a bond trader whom G.E. accused of creating $350 million in phony profits. Mr. Jett, who was dismissed, has denied any wrongdoing.
An exception to the mild stock movement was DSC Communications, a telecommunications equipment maker that is still suffering market consequences from losing a large Bell Atlantic contract to AT&T last week. DSC stock fell 15/16 , to 223/16 . At 4.3 million shares in Nasdaq trading, DSC was the most heavily traded stock yesterday.
The number of shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange was off sharply at about 186.4 million shares, more than a third lower than this year's average of 301 million shares.
The surprising Commerce Department report, for revised first-quarter gross domestic product growth, showed that the economy was growing faster than expected, but not by much -- a 3.0 percent pace, instead of the initial estimate of 2.6 percent.
What sent bond prices falling was Wall Street economists' expectation that the revision would be downward to 2.3 percent rather than upward, mainly because of the severe winter weather and the huge earthquake in California. The first-quarter revised number underscored the strength of the economy and its potential sparking a jump in inflation later this year. The inflation rate now is around 2.5 percent.
Long-term interest rates rose, in part over these inflation concerns. The most closely watched fixed-income investment, the 30-year Treasury bond, fell 10/32 , to 8614/32 , and the yield rose to 7.39 percent, from 7.36 percent the day before. Trading stopped at 2 P.M. for the holiday.
For the few stock traders left yesterday, a closely watched inflation indicator added to trading anxieties. The Commodity Research Bureau futures price index rose yesterday after falling for three straight days. It rose 1.27 points, to 230.88, mainly on rises in futures contracts for cattle, coffee and pork bellies.
And Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, could not have relieved trader anxieties, either. In his defense of the Fed's four increases in interest rates this year, Mr. Greenspan appeared to leave the door open even for more increases because of "uncertainties regarding the economic outlook."
 
Stock Indexes Barely Budge
 Whatever the case, the leading stock indexes barely budged. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.68 points, to 3,757.14, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.27 point, to 457.33. But the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 1.50 points, to 733.14.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.18 point, to 252.79, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,128 to 913. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.32 points, to 440.94.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, only 12 rose, led by McDonald's and Bethlehem Steel, which rose 7/8, to 19 5/8, following increased assessments by stock analysts.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, only 215 rose, led by General Electric and Wal-Mart.
The most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange, at 4 million shares, was Philip Morris, which fell 5/8, to 50, as investors continued to register their disappointment with the Philip Morris's board declining to spin off the controversial cigarette operations.
The most active stock on the American Stock Exchange, at 3.3 million shares, was the Exploration Company of Louisiana, which fell 1/8, to 1 5/8, after rising this week in heavy trading. Earlier this week, an analyst at Gaines Berland Inc., citing his own sources, said the oil company had made a "commercial discovery" of oil in China. He raised his recommendation to "strong speculative buy" from "buy." Exploration Company declined comment.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Dip as G.D.P. Is Revised

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
In abbreviated pre-holiday trading yesterday, prices of Treasury securities declined moderately after rebounding from sharp early losses.
The market dropped after the Government reported an upward revision in the first-quarter gross domestic product to an increase of 3 percent, from the 2.6 percent estimate a month ago. This surprised a bond market that had been expecting a downward revision to around 2.3 percent. 
 Dealers and traders were also focused on the appearance of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, before the Senate Banking Committee. But traders said there was little reaction to his remarks.
Mr. Greenspan did not break new ground for the bond market because traders and investors still expect short-term interest rates to move higher. Last week the Fed raised the Federal funds rate half a percentage point. That was the Fed's fourth rate increase of the year and lifted the central bank's target to 4.25 percent.
 
Long Bond Down
 The Treasury long bond was down 11/32 , to 8614/32 , for a yield of 7.39 percent, up 3 basis points from Thursday and 9 for the week. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said: "Going forward, the focus will clearly be on the economy's growth path and the potential dangers of inflation. Currently the business expansion seems quite balanced and shows no signs of overheating. As a result, the Fed is likely to keep the funds rate at 4.25 percent for some time."
Analysts said the unexpected strength in the revision to first-quarter G.D.P. stemmed largely from Government purchases, which were revised to a decline of 3.6 percent from a decline of 6.2 percent. The rest of the Commerce Department's report differed only slightly from some of the forecasts.
"Inventories were revised down, though not quite as much as expected, while personal consumption and net exports were revised up, also as expected," said Michael Englund, chief economist at MMS International.
Traders said the sharp selloff in bonds on the G.D.P. data appeared to be exaggerated by the thin pre-holiday conditions.
 
Added Downward Pressure
 "Given the size of yesterday's revision to Government spending, one has to wonder why they didn't compute this in the first G.D.P. estimate," Mr. Fine said.
With most market participants reluctant to hold long positions over a three-day weekend, there was added downward pressure on prices.
Other data released yesterday included the final tally of the Michigan Sentiment index of consumer confidence, which was 92.8, up slightly from the 91.5 preliminary May figure as well as the 92.6 April reading.

HEADLINE: White House Drops Bank-Regulation Bid

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today abandoned its effort to overhaul banking regulation this year, concluding that not enough time was left for Congress to act on it and that other initiatives should take precedence.
"It is becoming increasingly evident that this is just not going to be the year to get regulatory consolidation done," said Frank N. Newman, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance. 
 The Treasury had sought to combine several agencies that regulate banks and savings and loan institutions, so as to save money for the Government and reduce the regulatory burden on financial institutions.
The decision to delay action represents a political victory for the Federal Reserve, which had bitterly fought the Administration's plan because it would have stripped the central bank of much of its influence over the banking system. Mr. Newman and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen made several concessions this spring to the Fed and the two sides had nearly reached a compromise.
But when Treasury officials began to outline the proposal this week to members of the House and Senate Banking Committees they found limited enthusiasm and a lot of concern about the need for Congress to focus on health care and to deal with two other banking bills before the November elections, said Government officials who insisted on anonymity.
Joseph R. Coyne, a spokesman for Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said an overhaul plan would be presented next year. "They have some other things they'd like to push," he said, "so we just put it on pause. We hope we can get to the committees a complete version early next year."
Some officials have also suggested that the White House was not enthusiastic about the plan, which was developed by the Treasury Department with fairly little initial interagency consultation. But Robert E. Rubin, the head of President Clinton's National Economic Council, emphatically denied that the White House had stopped the planning.
The decision to postpone legislative action, he said, "has nothing to do with the White House -- that has to do with Secretary Bentsen and chairman Greenspan deciding, as is true of a lot of things, that the legislative calendar was so full that they couldn't do it."
The Administration's original plan called for creating one Federal Banking Commission that would have combined the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision and Office of the Comptroller with most of the bank regulatory functions of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Reserve. The Fed would have been left with the oversight of a handful of the nation's biggest international banks.
The Treasury's plan initially won support from large bank holding companies that report to several regulators. But support dwindled as regional Federal Reserve officials all over the country began explaining their worries about the plan to local banks. The Fed argued that it needed bank regulatory powers to be able to set monetary policy effectively and respond quickly to financial crises.
Mr. Newman said the arrival of the Memorial Day Congressional recess had persuaded him that the Administration had run out of time.
Complicated health care legislation and two other banking bills have left important committees and members of Congress too busy to begin the lengthy process of working on new legislation from scratch, Mr. Newman said. As a result, the Treasury's banking experts will focus instead for the rest of this year on insuring that the two banking bills reach the President's desk, he said.
One of these bills would make it easier for banks to buy other banks and savings and loans in other states. The other is a collection of many small pieces of banking legislation, notably subsidies for small community financial institutions that lend money to small businesses and individuals in poor neighborhoods.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading; Gold Prices Move Higher

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower against most leading currencies yesterday after failing to pierce a technical resistance level against the German mark.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for June delivery rose to $384.70 an ounce, from $383.80 on Thursday. A late quote from the Republic National Bank put the spot gold contract at $384.50 an ounce. 
 Trading in the dollar was sluggish, with many dealers squaring their positions ahead of the long holiday weekend. Financial markets in the United States will be closed on Monday for the Memorial Day holiday.
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6430 marks, down from 1.6480 marks on Thursday. Earlier in London, it was up slightly to 1.6445 marks, from 1.6425 marks Thursday.
The dollar also slipped to 104.30 yen, from 104.68 yen on Thursday.
The dollar edged up in early trading after the Commerce Department reported that the economy expanded at a revised rate of 3 percent in the first quarter. The result was above analysts' expectations and the Government's initial estimate of 2.6 percent.
But after moving above 1.65 marks, the dollar ran into considerable resistance, finishing lower on the day, traders said. "There was no appetite to take in dollars at those levels," said David Gilmore, partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics.
There was also little reaction to comments from the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, who said in testimony before Congress that the recent weakness of the dollar was a source of concern for policy makers.
"He hinted that there was scope for perhaps another quarter-point rise in Fed funds if need be, but he couldn't afford to come out with anything that would upset the bond or equity market," said Jeremy Hawkins, senior economic adviser at BankAmerica in London.
The British pound rose to $1.5100 in New York, from $1.5080 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.4025 Swiss francs, off from 1.4058; 5.6110 French francs, down from 5.6275 Thursday; 1.3860 Canadian dollars, little changed from 1.3855, and 1,588 Italian lire, down from 1,600.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Borrowers Putting Rate Locks To the Test

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
As interest rates have risen the last few months, home buyers have become very eager to lock in a rate when applying for a mortgage. In the last few weeks, fluctuations in rates have also heightened interest in "relocks," a variation allowing borrowers to shift to a lower rate if rates decline during the lock-in period.
But borrowers fixated on the absolute best rate sometimes trip up when using either of these loan provisions. 
 Gary Sweatt, vice president of Mortgage Information Service, a mortgage broker in Wellesley, Mass., said people often failed to allow enough time for closing on a property. He recommends getting a rate that is guaranteed for 60 days. Locks are commonly offered for 30 days or 60 days, though 90-day terms may be available.
Any relock provision in the loan agreement can be exercised once between the application date and the closing date. Many borrowers do not understand that this is a one-time opportunity and that they must notify the lender on the new date to get the rate, Mr. Sweatt said.
"A lot of people who relock assume that they will just get the best rate during the 60 days it takes to close," he said, "and that's not true."
The average rate on a 30-year mortgage as reported by the Federal National Mortgage Association has risen almost two percentage points since the beginning of February, to 8.45 percent, but not without some backsliding. It reached 8.68 percent in early May, its high so far this year. After falling a week ago, it bounced back this week.
 "There has been a lot of interest in relocking because the market has been so volatile, up one day, down the next," said Bruce Lublin, president of Homerica Inc., a mortgage broker in Harrison, N.Y.
The charge for a lock and a relock is usually built into a loan in its interest rate or its points. (A point is a fee paid at closing equal to 1 percent of the loan.) Sometimes, though, a separate fee is charged at the time of application. It is generally a quarter-point to a half-point of the loan amount.
Some lenders offer what they call a buy-down, in which borrowers pay a half-point of the loan amount when they apply to lock in a rate for 60 days. If the rate stays the same or rises, the borrowers get the lock-in rate and the half-point payment is returned at closing. If rates drop and they relock, they forfeit their half-point payment.
"If rates go down more than a quarter-point, it generally pays to do it," Mr. Lublin said.
Lenders offer several other variations on guaranteed mortgage rates. A "look and lock" allows a borrower to hold on to a guaranteed rate for 30 days while shopping for a home. Once a contract is executed, the period is extended 45 days, and, for a small fee -- generally a quarter-point to a half-point -- it will be extended 60 days longer.
"It is really good for somebody who has found a property and is just going to contract," Mr. Lublin said.
A "list and lock" allows a seller to offer prospective buyers a locked-in rate, with a relock option, for 30 days and, after a fully executed contract is presented, for an additional 45 days. For a fee, the guaranteed rate will be extended 60 more days.
"If you have somebody interested, it is a really good inducement," Mr. Lublin said.
Of course, the amount saved by locking or relocking a loan rate may be less than the amount paid for the flexibility.
"If you're looking for the best rate," Mr. Sweatt said, "it is often just a matter of luck."

HEADLINE: We Need Watershed Protection and Filtration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I agree with the headline "Save the Watershed" (editorial, May 15), but disagree that "saving" the watershed would make filtration unnecessary. The Catskill-Delaware watersheds are so extensively developed, with some 200,000 residents in summer, 50 towns, 400 dairy farms and the discharges of 35 sewage treatment plants, that restoration to its earlier pristine state is not politically or economically feasible. 
 I chaired an Environmental Protection Agency expert panel drawn from outside New York, which issued a report in April 1993 after eight months study. We concluded that both watershed protection and filtration are essential to provide safe water for the people of New York. We based this conclusion in part on the risk of cryptosporidiosis, a serious intestinal disease caused by the parasite cryptosporidium, which comes from cattle and humans, and has been found in Catskill-Delaware waters.
Cryptosporidiosis is relatively new and similar to, but far more serious than giardiasis, which was reported by health authorities in about 2,500 people annually in New York City. Chlorination, the only treatment now available in New York City, while effective in inactivating the cysts of giardia, is not effective against the oocysts of cryptosporidium. New York City has not begun collecting data on cryptosporidiosis, but there is every reason to believe it will be at least as prevalent as giardiasis.
Shortly after the report was published, some 400,000 people in Milwaukee became seriously ill with cryptosporidiosis, with more than 100 deaths and many others permanently incapacitated. This was one of six recent major cryptosporidiosis outbreaks in the United States in the last 10 years. Cryptosporidiosis can be fatal to immuno-compromised individuals such as those who test positive for the human immunodeficiency virus, AIDS patients, cancer patients undergoing treatment, very young children and the elderly.
Watershed protection can help reduce the risk from microbial contamination. North Carolina, for example, recently enacted legislation requiring all local authorities that have domain over drinking water watersheds to develop land use plans to be approved by the state. (All surface water supplies in North Carolina are already filtered.) Such legislation, along with land purchases, are valuable. They reduce the health risk and the cost of treatment, but they cannot eliminate the impact of development that has taken place, nor prevent all new development on 1,800 square miles of watershed.
Your conclusion that "To give in to filtration is to concede that New Yorkers cannot strike a sensible compromise between man and nature" is parochial. More than 90 percent of all surface water supplies in the United States, many with much better protected watersheds than New York's, provided filtration for safer water for their communities long before E.P.A. regulations required filtration. The price tag of $8 billion that the New York City Department of Environmental Protection floats and that you repeat is more than fourfold higher than is realistic.
Appropriate filtration would add only about 10 percent to 15 percent to the water bills of customers in the city, part of which should be offset by the excellent conservation and metering programs under way.
The assumption that watershed protection or filtration would be adequate is faulty. Almost all professionals agree that where substantial development has occurred on a watershed, as in New York, watershed protection and filtration are both necessary. New York City does not meet the letter, let alone the intent, of the surface water treatment rule of the Safe Drinking Water Act. Without filtration it is not likely to do so.
Because of far-sighted investments in developing mountain watersheds, New York City has one of the best sources of water of any large city in the world. Filtration will make it one of the safest.
 
DANIEL A. OKUN
Chapel Hill, N.C., May 17, 1994
 
The writer retired as Kenan Professor of Environmental Engineering at the University of North Carolina.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Steady Economy

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Having raised short-term interest rates four times in the last four months, the chairman of the nation's central bank said today that the increases had not slowed the economy and that economic growth would continue at its current pace in the second quarter of this year.
Rather than make explicit predictions about future levels of interest rates, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, devoted most of his appearance today before the Senate Banking Committee to explaining the reasoning behind the rate increases that have already taken place. It was Mr. Greenspan's first appearance before a Congressional committee since Feb. 22, and three of the four increases have come since then. 
 Responding to complaints by Democrats on the Senate Banking Committee that the rate increases so far would put a drag on economic growth, Mr. Greenspan said today that it would take a year or so for the higher rates to have their full effect. While retail sales may have fallen lately, he added, preliminary economic indicators show that growth has not slackened in the second quarter.
 
Concern Over Bank Lending
 The Commerce Department surprised many economists today by revising upward its estimate of first-quarter economic growth, to 3 percent from 2.6 percent, suggesting that the economy remained more robust this winter than expected, despite severe weather and the California earthquake.
Early in his testimony, Mr. Greenspan signaled particular concern about rising bank lending, which stimulates the economy and which the Federal Reserve can control directly by raising the short-term rates that banks pay to borrow money. Other Federal Reserve officials have expressed similar concerns in recent weeks, and the Fed announced on Monday that its latest surveys showed strong increases in lending.
One reason that higher interest rates have not slowed the economy may be that banks are lending on easier terms even as they charge higher rates, Mr. Greenspan said. Although he did not specify these terms, they presumably include requiring less collateral or smaller down payments.
Some Wall Street analysts interpreted Mr. Greenspan's comments -- including a remark that mutual fund and pension fund managers were right to worry about future inflation -- as a possible hint that the Fed would tighten monetary policy again this summer. "He certainly left plenty of room for additional tightening but he didn't actually make a case for one," said Marc W. Wanshel, an economist at J. P. Morgan in New York.
Other analysts saw few clues in the testimony. "I don't think it shed any new light," said Robert Giordano, an economist at Goldman, Sachs.
Seeking to explain the sharp rise in long-term interest rates this year, Mr. Greenspan said that when the economy began showing signs of greater strength this spring, investors sold long-term bonds and chose shorter-maturity securities that would be less affected by inflation.
"Given the change in economic conditions and the market's perception of them," he said, "longer-term rates eventually would have increased significantly even had the Federal Reserve done nothing this year."
While Mr. Greenspan gave lengthy reviews of many other monetary policy issues as well, today's hearing was partly about politics. Three Democratic Senators gave long speeches criticizing the recent increases as unnecessary and urging Mr. Greenspan not to go further.
The Clinton Administration has not been critical of the Fed's interest rate increases because of concern that Presidential criticism of the Federal Reserve would alarm financial markets and perhaps prompt the central bank to raise interest rates even higher to show its independence.
In addition, many Administration officials feel that the Fed may be right to raise rates now to restrain inflation. And, in any case, they seem to prefer a modest rise in interest rates now to a possibly steeper increase closer to the 1996 election.
 
Criticism of Rate Rises
 Two of the three Democratic Senators who criticized the Fed's recent interest rate rises, Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland and Jim Sasser of Tennessee, are up for re-election this year but have called for a less restrictive monetary policy for many years. The third Senator, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, is not running for re-election.
None of the committee's Republican members showed up for the hearing, which came at the beginning of Memorial Day recess for Congress.
Mr. Sarbanes emphasized the problems that higher interest rates were creating for many Americans, and urged Mr. Greenspan to consider their needs as well as Wall Street's desire for higher interest rates to protect the value of bonds. "We're getting calls in my office from people who can't make commitments on new homes because of higher interest rates," he said.

HEADLINE: Let Brooklyn and the Other Boroughs Share Tourism Spotlight

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your May 12 report on a hotel-restaurant-arts package deal to lure tourists to New York City quotes Deputy Mayor John Dyson stating the Convention and Visitors Bureau has been "asleep at the wheel." I agree wholeheartedly. While it sleeps, tourist dollars are spent elsewhere. 
 But any pain Manhattan has suffered is minor compared with that endured by Brooklyn. Despite the bureau's receiving $3.5 million to $4 million a year from the city under the dedicated hotel tax, it allocated a paltry $27,000 to Brooklyn last year.
Unfortunately, the new package deal follows the same agenda of indifference the Convention and Visitors Bureau has demonstrated for years. Brooklyn tourist destinations and attractions, restaurants and retail outlets are virtually absent from the new promotion, a campaign that is supported by more than $2 million in city and state funds.
Brooklyn has more tourism sites than any other borough outside Manhattan. The Brooklyn Bridge, the Brooklyn Museum, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Prospect Park, the world-renowned Brooklyn Academy of Music, Coney Island, and the Aquarium for Wildlife Conservation attract millions of visitors each year. And with virtually no tourism promotion assistance from the city.
My hope is this administration will seize the opportunity and reap the reward that Brooklyn tourism offers.
Tourists support Brooklyn restaurants, stores and attractions. This results in an increase in our tax base and expanded employment opportunities. Tourism also contributes to the stability of our commercial shopping districts and residential neighborhoods. It is critical to the economic future of all five boroughs.
New York City must bring Brooklyn out of Manhattan's shadow and allow its cultural and historic attractions to shine in the eyes of the world. Why not let Brooklyn and the other boroughs share the tourism spotlight?
 
HOWARD GOLDEN
Brooklyn Borough President
Brooklyn, N.Y., May 17, 1994

HEADLINE: Retired Investors Adjust To Market Flip-Flops

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES 

 BODY:
Retired people who tried to escape the dismalreturns of "safe" investments like certificates of deposit by putting some money in stocks, bonds and mutual funds have gotten a taste of adventure this year.
The financial markets' overall declines, and intermittent flip-flops, have left plenty of small investors queasy. But they're particularly unsettling for older, more conservative people who have shorter time frames and who may want or need their money before the stock and bond markets recover. This group depends on investment income to supplement retirement checks and tends to keep close tabs on portfolios and cash flow. 
 Recent interviews with retired investors, and their financial planners and investment managers, showed that these people were responding to the market turmoil by tinkering with their portfolios -- not by making drastic changes. Generally, they are keeping a long-term perspective, a testament to their growing financial sophistication.
Around the edges, they are increasing their cash positions, turning to money market funds in particular. That trend could gather steam as recent interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve Board continue to ripple through the financial system and make fixed-rate investments more attractive.
Holders of bonds with long-term maturities, which have eroded in value this year, are often getting out altogether or shifting to bonds with shorter maturities, which would be less damaged by continued increases in interest rates, financial advisers said.
Most retired investors, though, are sticking with their stocks and equity funds because these investments offer the best prospect of higher income. A surprising number said they were even taking advantage of the stock market's low prices to put more emphasis on growth investments.
G. B. Mann, who is 82, a retired civil engineer living in Dallas, owns about 100 stocks -- and he's looking for more. "There are lots of good buys right now," he said. Mr. Mann has acquired stocks on his own and through an investment club affiliated with the National Association of Investors Corporation in Royal Oak, Mich.
Younger retirees, envisioning perhaps 30 years of retirement ahead, are showing the most willingness to ride out the market volatility.
Sally Duplaix, 58, a retired library director living in Branford, Conn., has invested in many mutual funds and plans to begin buying individual stocks through an investment club. The stock market and its recent setback is merely a blip on her screen. "I have a lot of confidence that if it goes down, it will come back up," she said. "I got through the 1987 downturn, and it didn't frighten me. I'm not concerned about the downtick we've had."
David Bugen, a financial planner and principal in the Individual Asset Planning Corporation in Morristown, N.J., said about half his clients were retired and were holding steady with their portfolios so far. "The question is," he said, "four or five months down the line, if we're having a protracted bear market, which is unknown at this time, will they still stick to their strategies?"
 Stocks, bonds and mutual funds represent only a small slice of retired people's assets. The Census Bureau, in a 1991 report on household wealth, found that only 9.4 percent of the net worth of people 65 years and older was in stocks and mutual funds. Not surprisingly, the largest portion of their assets was in homes or interest-earning accounts with banks. So retirees who are heavily invested in the stock and bond markets are not typical of their age group. They are more affluent and more likely to be concerned about maintaining their life style than worried about paying for necessities.
 Harold Evensky, a financial adviser and principal with Evensky, Brown & Katz in Coral Gables, Fla., said the retirees who could not stomach the recent market fluctuations were those who knew little about their investments. "The ones we see rolling back are the people who had a chunk of money in C.D.'s and moved it to bond funds that they didn't understand," Mr. Evensky said.
One way to gauge what retired investors are doing is to look at the eight mutual funds managed by Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc. for the American Association of Retired Persons. Howard Schneider, vice president of the A.A.R.P. Investment Program from Scudder, said: "We're seeing some fine-tuning, seeing people move into conservative, growth-oriented investments. We're seeing some modest redemptions."
Among the eight A.A.R.P. funds, the most significant outflow has been from the G.N.M.A. and U.S. Treasury fund, which shrank more than 5 percent in the 12 weeks ended May 18, according to AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif. The big gainer has been the High-Quality Money Market fund, whose assets grew 32 percent in the period. Also posting an increase was the Growth and Income fund, up 6.2 percent. Scudder said all the equity funds had experienced inflows of money.
Because retired people are especially concerned about cash flow, the market volatility has made them take a second look at their asset allocations, said Don Underwood, a vice president of retirement plans and services at Merrill Lynch & Company and co-author of "Grow Rich Slowly."
Merrill Lynch puts most retired people in the category of income and growth investors, and recommends a portfolio of 50 percent in equities, 40 percent in bonds and 10 percent in cash. Those benchmarks have remained the same this year, Mr. Underwood said. For more aggressive investors, Merrill now calls for 30 percent in bonds and 20 percent in cash, up from 5 percent in cash early this year.
Despite the tremors caused by the stock market's slide, Mr. Underwood said older people should have more in equities than the popular rule of thumb tied to age. That rule says to subtract your age from 100 to determine what portion of your portfolio to put in equitites. For someone 80 years old, it results in 20 percent in equities.
"If you're 80, you should not just settle for 20 percent if you're in good health," Mr. Underwood said, noting that people are living longer and are remaining more active. "We continue to recommend that our clients have a considerable portion, if not the majority, in equities."
 Retirees with money to invest heed the advice, in part out of concern that they could outlive their money. John B. Rice, 58, a retired state employee living in Salt Lake City, said he planned to cash in his bank C.D. when it matures and invest in more stocks. He described himself as a conservative investor, with holdings primarily in blue-chip stocks like General Electric and growth funds like Alliance. "I think the stock market will likely go up again," he said.
So does Lenore Rallis, a retired Dallas real estate broker and secretary who has invested in stocks through an investment club. Ms. Rallis said she planned to invest the proceeds from the sale of some real estate into growth stocks and mutual funds over the next 18 months and to "ease into the market."
"Over the long term, stocks are going to go up," she said. "As broad as I hope to be in it, then the whole world would have to go down the tube."
No one strategy, of course, works for all retired people, a diverse group to say the least. Mr. Bugen, the financial planner, described a retired man who recently called him after visiting a doctor. "He said that since he had moved his money out of the bank and into stocks and long-term bond funds, he couldn't sleep at night," Mr. Bugen said.
"Some people are saying, 'I'll live on less, but I won't live with the fluctuations,' " he added.
The litmus test for retired investors is whether they are comfortable. "Above all, you should be able to sleep at night," Mr. Schneider of Scudder said. "If your investments are keeping you up at night, they may not be worth it."

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
With Costs Down, a Builder Trumpets Affordability

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
IN New York City the term "affordable housing" has come to be associated with new houses built with city and state capital grants on city-owned land. The land is provided at virtually no cost to the buyer. The land contribution and the grants make possible prices that are affordable to households earning about $25,000 to $50,000 a year.
In purely private housing development, there are no such subsidies. But with the drop in land prices in recent years, builders can set prices lower (meanwhile hoping market strength will push them up again). Accordingly, they are ready to promote as affordable housing the offerings they plan for the middle-income market. 
 Queens has been a center of conventionally financed small-home construction, driven in recent years by the upsurge in middle-income Korean- and Chinese-Americans with the savings to pump into housing. With the recession in the late 80's production dropped sharply and has yet to revive.
But a few days ago, in the College Point section of Queens, Joseph Kiel and Michael Blau, who are brothers-in-law building under the name B.K. Development, took a visitor to a vacant site on which they are about to start construction. They will produce "affordable housing," Mr. Blau emphasized.
The land is between 14th Avenue and 14th Road on 121st Street, which runs parallel to College Point Boulevard, one block away, the main commercial street of this venerable residential community in northwest Queens.
It was acquired from another developer who had filed plans for four three-family houses. Instead, the new owners will produce four two-family houses. The end houses will sell for $279,000 and the middle houses for $259,000, the builders say.
"In Flushing in '88 we would have gotten $450,000 for the end house," said Mr. Blau, who in addition to his home-building activities runs the family plumbing business, Blau Mechanical Corporation, in Bayside.
He would also have paid much more for the land. In College Point the land price was 30 percent of what it would have been in the 80's. Moreover, subcontractor prices are lower now. And savings are planned on materials to hold prices down further. The facades will be brick and aluminium siding, for example, instead of all brick.
IN the 80's, B.K. Development built about 30 two- and three-family houses a year in Queens, with developments in Briarwood, Flushing, Whitestone and College Point. But when the sales market fell they found it necessary to rent out their buildings. Mr. Blau said that they still hold everything they built over the last six years -- 15 houses with two or three rental tenants in each.
But little by little builders are finishing off projects on land that others were unable to hold. In Bayside, for example, George Greene, president of Red Oak Development Corporation, based in Great Neck, L.I., has acquired land for five two-family houses off Clearview Expressway at 204th Street and 42d Avenue. A bank foreclosed on the land, which another builder had owned.
Sale prices will be about $290,000 to $300,000, Mr. Greene said, for two-family houses for which buyers a few years ago would have paid $340,000 to $350,000. Sites are selling in foreclosure at about 65 percent of their value in the 80's, he said.
Not that loans are readily available to assist the building process. B.K. Development's College Point project will be done with the company's own resources rather than bank financing.
The slow pace of activity is reflected in figures that the Census Bureau worked out from information supplied by the Department of Buildings. Surprisingly, the Buildings Department itself keeps track only of the number of permits issued, not the number of housing units for which permits are sought, and is not even able to report relative changes in the pace of residential as opposed to commercial development. The Census Bureau, however, does its own analysis of total permits granted.
The census figures show that permits authorizing only 531 new privately owned housing units were issued last year. By contrast, more than 2,000 units a year were authorized from 1984 through the end of the decade. The pace plunged in 1990 and has remained slow ever since. Only the steady production under the New York Housing Partnership program -- new "affordable" houses built with city and state grants on city-owned land -- has kept production going at even its current low pace.
If there is a revival of home construction on mid-density land in Queens, typically zoned R-3 to R-5, the character of it will reflect the contextual zoning districts adopted in the late 80's. The change is graphically illustrated in College Point.
Gone are the "six, six and three" houses that were built in volume in the 80's under what was called infill zoning. This was a three-story, three-family house with six rooms on the second floor, six on the third and three on the first, plus a garage within the building.
Mr. Blau and Mr. Kiel built two of them side by side on Ninth Avenue between 117th Street and 119th Street in College Point in the mid-80's, and rented them out.
BY the time they came to develop another lot on the same street in 1989, three-story buildings had effectively been eliminated from R-4 zones that were predominantly built with the lower-density one-and two-family homes. Their Ninth Avenue land was on such a block.
They could therefore build only two stories in the three houses at 117-09 through 117-13 Ninth Avenue, though they managed to put three units in the two end houses. They put one duplex apartment at the rear and two flats in the front half of the structure.
Another change is the absence of the on-site garage. Instead, in the newer strip, parking is provided on pads at the sides of the houses as well as in the front.
The new buildings on the 100-by-100-foot lot on 121st Street will also reflect the new contextual zoning. There will be a three-bedroom apartment on the second floor and a two-bedroom with a garage on the first floor.
"The two-story, two-family contextual house is more in harmony with the area, and probably easier to sell as a result," said Leo D. Fakler, partner in the Fresh Meadow firm of Fakler & Eliason. One new touch will be a cathedral ceiling in the living room of the second-floor apartment, with a glass window a story-and-a-half high, he said.
As for the sales market, there will be little competition from new construction. But the builder's prices will conform with reality in the resale market, where prices are down about 30 percent from 1987.
Resale housing -- often about 60 years old -- is selling in the range of $170,000 to $200,000 for two-families and $160,000 to $180,000 for one-families, said Henry Skoros of the Suydam Agency, which Mr. Skoros's grandfather founded in 1890.
But the sales pace is picking up, he said. In a good year in the past, about 200 houses sold in College Point. On the basis of the pace so far "we'll probably get close to that this year," he said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Lower Manhattan BID;
An 'Engine for Economic Improvement' Downtown

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT'S finally happened: Downtown Manhattan's landlords have grouped into a Business Improvement District. Armed with a budget of $8.6 million and scheduled to start operating on Jan. 1, the new BID will try to accomplish as a group what neither individual landlords nor city officials nor residents have been able to do: Revive the flagging fortunes of an area that has been singularly resistant to economic recovery. 
 It will take more than cleaner streets, extra security or prettier signs, the top priorities for so many New York BIDs. The Lower Manhattan district will have to be an "engine for economic development," as Meyer (Sandy) Frucher, an executive vice president of Olympia & York USA, put it.
How should the new BID set its priorities and carry out its mandate? Six real estate experts offer their views.

Meyer (Sandy) Frucher, executive vice president, Olympia & York USA.
The BID has to identify industries other than the traditional FIRE industries -- finance, insurance, real estate -- that have traditionally made the Wall Street area their home. And it must figure out a strategy to attract those industries down here.
Top on the strategic list has to be transportation. The BID should push for a bus terminal, which could also provide parking for tourist buses. It should push for better connections with the suburbs, including extension of the Long Island Rail Road, maybe through Brooklyn. It has to find new landing sites for waterborne transportation and then ways to connect those to businesses.
The BID also has to identify the infrastructure needs of new types of companies. If it goes after small companies, do they need a central data-processing center? Do they need more restaurants, because they do not have internal dining rooms?
And do they need different financial incentives? A big processing company might be wooed by cheap power, but that won't do much for, say, an advertising agency.

Edward S. Gordon, chairman, Edward S. Gordon Company.
The agenda for the BID is, how do you make the area more appealing for business, which by definition makes it more productive and a place that provides more employment. Yes, sanitation and security are part of that, but they are side issues. Taxes and zoning are what is important.
I strongly believe that taxes are the curse of the city in general, and of downtown in particular. There's never been a cohesive group of people focusing on this, and the BID can finally provide this.
If I could wave a magic wand, I'd turn a section of downtown into a free-trade zone, a place where you don't pay taxes or tariffs on materials you bring in. That could bring light manufacturing back to the area.
I'd also like to see the BID work to loosen up zoning regulations, so you can get more residential and retail operations in the area.

Charles J. Maikish, director, World Trade Center.
In lower Manhattan we have the ingredients for a great cultural banquet. There's a historic trail, like Boston's Freedom Trail. There are great architectural gems like the Woolworth building. There's City Hall and right nearby are TriBeCa and Chinatown.
The BID must put that banquet together, and then publicize and promote it. It can sponsor the redevelopment of City Hall Park, and it can provide the kinds of experiences in Battery Park that you're now seeing in Bryant Park in midtown. It can operate a Freedom Trail walk. It can give TriBeCa's artists places to show their work.
The BID should certainly work with us. The Plaza of the Trade Center itself is intended to become a year-round place for events. We are looking at ways to temper the winds, and the temperature, to make that feasible.
The BID should try to attract the museum industry to lower Manhattan. it would be great to get a branch of MOMA or of the Met. And the maritime museum that we already have should be better promoted.
But first we must do something about the congestion down here. The BID should look at a trolley or jitney station, and at better connections to Grand Central and other hubs.
And it must work on security. Right now this is probably one of the safest areas in Manhattan because there is no populace here at night for criminals to prey upon. Yet it is perceived as unsafe. It is not well lit, and it is not well populated, and at night you get the sense of being in a desolate area.
The BID can provide street lighting, after hours security and information services. It can hold cultural events in the evening. And once it does that, and people do remain for functions and events, then we really will need the added elements of security.

Steven Spinola, president, Real Estate Board of New York
The BID must create a common theme for the area, one that pulls together the Statue of Liberty, Wall Street, the Seaport, Fraunces Tavern, all of the historic stuff.
They need to concentrate on proper signage, on prominently showing that when you walk out of the South Street Seaport there are other interesting places to go nearby. Maybe there should be a one-dollar bus that lets you ride all day across lower Manhattan.
The BID should form a relationship with the Visitors Bureau. There needs to be a consolidated marketing of all of the things that lower Manahttan has to offer. Let's have the proper maps, the brochures, the fliers, the proof that you can spend days in lower Manhattan and still not see everyting. That can encourage people to stay at the hotels.
And maybe it should promote some of the wonderful restaurants down there, even orchestrate a program whereby some of those restaurants will give local employees discounts if they stay for dinner. That's one way to liven the area up after 5 P.M.
But tourism certainly isn't all of it. The BID also has to refocus on bringing new business down here. They need to work with Con Ed to deal with false perceptions about energy problems in the area. In fact we have seven substations, we have significant power redundancy, yet no one's talking about it.
The BID should identify buildings on the outskirts of the business community that should be converted to residential use, and others that should be torn down. And it should spearhead sitting areas, maybe open markets that could temporarily be put in the open spaces left when the buildings are torn down.
But it should think in terms of eventually putting up new buildings again. And that means we should grandfather the floor area ratios.
Current zoning rules mean that many of the existing obsolete buildings could only be replaced by buildings half their size, and that is a disincentive to pull them down.
The BID should look at this as if lower Manhattan was a large office park or shopping center, and think of running it as such. Whatever it takes -- marketing, cleanliness, whatever -- is what the BID must do

Lewis Rudin, co-chairman, Rudin Management
If there had been a downtown BID in 1974 we'd have never lost the Westway project. But we did, and now the East Side highway is overcrowded and there is no West Side highway.
The BID should be lobbying Albany and City Hall to get a road built. If you can get in your car and be at the World Trade Center in 12 minutes or less, it feels like downtown is accessible. But now it feels like you can't really drive to Wall Street from Connecticut or Westchester.
And why not have mass transit on that road also, a monorail that would start at Grand Central? And shorter term, why not give a discount on the new Metrocard for anyone traveling to lower Manhattan from, say, Grand Central?
I believe the international community will save downtown. Maybe we should start advertising in The International Herald Tribune and tell the world that Wall Street is alive and well and that it now has a BID to look out for owners' and tenants' interests.
The BID should focus on drumming up the money and tax incentives to make it worthwhile to restore the buildings in the district's center. You have buildings like 40 Wall or 55 Broad that are totally empty, you have 60 Broad, which is 75 percent empty. These buildings, if they get filled up, would put millions of dollars in city coffers.

Arthur J. Mirante 2d, chief executive, Cushman & Wakefield
I wouldn't downplay the importance of a greater security presence on the street, of more guys in white uniforms with brooms, or of parks in areas that are now eyesores.
But after that, they have to attack the occupancy tax, the most visible penalty for doing business in New York City in general. This is the one economic item that doesn't favor any special interest groups. Maybe the BID should advocate giving relief from the tax to companies that sign leases downtown in the next couple of years, maybe they should suggest phased-in relief for existing tenants. That would reduce a company's projected cost of occupancy in Manhattan and thus would give it hope that a few years from now it'll get a little more for its money. That can keep a company from leaving the area.
In the past we have shown that we can redirect business activity with bonuses and zoning changes, without hurting the areas that are already thriving. Look at the office buildings we brought to the west side of Manhattan. We've actually moved the business center to Sixth Avenue, and it hasn't hurt Lexington or Third Avenue at all. Does downtown Manhattan qualify as an important enough area to deserve special benefits to attract business? I think it does.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
A Whirlwind of Plans for a Hot Newtown Property

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
A PRIZED piece of property in the center of Newtown with almost 2 million square feet in 60 handsome brick buildings on an 800-acre campus has become a hotspot of contention among local and state officials and civic leaders.
Built in the 1930's as the Fairfield Hills state mental hospital, the now diverse operation is outmoded and its buildings are almost empty. But the grounds and buildings have been well maintained and are suitable for recyling to other uses. 
 Proposals for redevelopment on long-term leases from the state, which will maintain ownership, are being sought by a task force appointed by the General Assembly. Preliminary recommendations will be presented next month and in 1995 the legislature will decide what the new uses will be, based on the task force's findings.
Meanwhile, a deluge of proposals has poured in.
"I've been here for 36 years," said State Representative Julia R. Wasserman, a Newtown Republican who heads the 20-member task force, "and I've never seen this much material on one issue. We sent out requests for proposals six months ago and got almost 400 replies."
When the downsizing of the complex is completed next year, there will be 1.5 million square feet available in the buildings and about 500 acres of open space ready for redevelopment, according to Gary Mullaney, a task force appointee from the state's Department of Mental Health. The rest will be retained for existing substance-abuse and mental-health quarters for patients and staff, a minimum-security women's prison and to house the Second Company Governor's Horse Guards, a volunteer unit of the state militia involved mainly with ceremonial functions.
Three proposals among the many under consideration by the task force head the list:
* A major equestrian center for horse shows, submitted by the Newtown Bridle Lands Association and endorsed by the Connecticut Horse Council.
* A conglomerate of small produce farms and an incubator operation for developing and packaging food products, submitted by the state's Department of Agriculture.
* A research and development park, submitted by the Newtown Economic Development Commission.
All three projects are proposed for the only large tract of open land -- about 270 acres at the north end of the property.
Other proposals include a new elementary school to accommodate increased enrollments, housing for low- and moderate-income people, a golf course, soccer and ballfields, a larger Town Hall, and a community center. In addition, several state and local agencies have submitted requests for space.
"Newtown has an enormous horse population," said the First Selectman and task force member, Robert Cascella, "so the horse park is the most emotionally charged issue." There are 2,500 horses in the town of 20,700 residents.
"There is nothing like what we are proposing in the entire Northeast," said Kurt Schneider, chairman of the Newtown Bridle Lands Association, a land trust dedicated to riding trails and green-space preservation. "We could handle indoor-outdoor Olympic style three-day events rivaling those in Virginia, Kentucky and North Carolina, where they operate more than 300 days a year."
"It would boost tourism," he added, "creating a west-to-east swing through the state that would take a few days, instead of the shoreline pass-through that visitors do now, stopping briefly at the Norwalk Maritime Center and Mystic Seaport on their way to Massachusetts."
SINCE the Danbury State Fair grounds became a shopping mall in 1981 "the Connecticut Apaloosa, Morgan, Arab, Quarterhorse and Reining Horse Championships have all been held in West Springfield or Northampton, Mass.," said Richard Woolam, board chairman of the Connecticut Horse Council. "That's where all our money for food, lodging, gas, even laundry, goes. One cleaner did 1,900 shirts in five days."
"The Connecticut horse industry," said John J. Filchak 3d, Deputy Commissioner of Agriculture. "is one of the top five agricultural money-makers in the state, bringing in about $350 million out of the department's estimate of $1.7 billion annually."
The state is home to at least 18,000 horse owners and 60,000 horses. Despite this, Mr. Filchak is squarely behind the farming proposal, because, he says, "there are prime agricultural soils on that property that we are committed to preserve."
His agency supports a horse park "somewhere in Connecticut," Mr. Filchak said, "but the state is not convinced that private funding has been thoroughly explored."
Private equestrian centers have been informally proposed in the rural towns of Plymouth and Harwinton. But without support services, little local enthusiam and no financial underpinnings, such proposals do not seem promising.
In 1986 State Representative John Mordansky, Democrat of Stafford Springs, tried unsuccessfully to get state bonding for a horse park. A state study had indicated that in its first five years revenues from a major operation would rise from $2.08 million to $17.3 million annually.
Last year Mr. Mordansky sponsored another bill, requesting a $21 million bond issue to establish a horse park. Introduced after the biennial budget's bonding package was set, it passed the Environmental Committee unanimously, he said, "but the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee would not reopen the package so it died." He will resubmit it when the Legislature convenes in January.
"In my opinion," he said, "Newtown has all the criteria to make a horse park successful -- access to highways, lodging, and restaurants.".
BUT, asks First Selectman Cascella, "would we lose control of the community if we became host for a large horse park, and which proposal will most benefit the town economically?"
"We could realize about $2 million a year in real estate taxes from a research and development park," added Elizabeth Stocker, the town's Community Development Director.
Because the proposed research and development park would abut the town's existing industrial park, the proposal has raised fears among detractors that additional companies would be hard to find and once found they could fail, shifting the tax burden onto homeowners.
Curtis Clark, managing editor of The Newtown Bee, called additional industrial activity "inappropriate on prime land in the center of town." The newspaper's editorial board and the majority of letters to the editor support the horse park, he said.
If the legislature is receptive to the Mordansky bill it could follow the precedent of Virginia, Kentucky and North Carolina, where horse parks have been financed by the states, and private nonprofit groups manage their operations.
"Private parks are not feasible," said Mr. Schneider, chairman of the Bridle Lands Association, "because of the land costs."
He cited as an example the privately developed Great Southwestern park outside Houston, which became the instrument of its own own destruction.
"Hotels, restaurants and support services grew up all around it," he said, "increasing the tax rate to a point where the park couldn't survive."
