HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY GUIDE

BYLINE: By MARY L. EMBLEN; ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:

SILK STRIKE RECALLED
This week, students from Eastside High School in Paterson will re-enact the pageant presented at the end of the historic five-month strike against 292 Paterson silk mills in 1913. The re-enactment will be at 1 P.M. Thursday and 1 and 7 P.M. Friday at Passaic County Community College, College Boulevard.
Silk workers marched 900 strong from the Paterson mills, rode the ferry and continued their march to Madison Square Garden in New York City to portray highlights of the strike, which the workers won by establishing the eight-hour day and better working conditions that were eventually put into effect. 
 Four students, following an outline by a mural artist, Mike Alewitz, recycled a 28-foot-by-14-foot Gannett Outdoor Inc. billboard canvas in painting an interpretation of the 45-foot-by-17-foot backdrop used in the original pageant. The original showed the red brick facade of a mill with the castle built by Catholina Lambert, one of the mill owners, to survey his domain.
Although the strikers in 1913 included Polish, German, Syrian, Italian, English and French immigrants, the Eastside students involved in the entire production, most of whom are black or Hispanic, developed such a close identification with the strikers that they insisted that Botto House, the strike headquarters, be added to the left side of the mural.
Eighteen students from the senior honors English class taught by Cindy Mamakos wrote the pageant's script under the guidance of Rosemary McLaughlin, a playwright, and Steve Golin, an author.
Major roles will be played by 10 students from Anjenett Ray's drama classes. The school's 40-voice Concert Choir, directed by Cora Quince, will sing some selections, and the audience will be invited to join in the rallying songs from the strike.
The American Labor Museum, situated in the Botto House at 83 Norwood Street in Haledon, will sponsor the pageant. The museum is home to a vast collection of labor history materials, including documentary and feature film videotapes.
Admission to the pageant at Passaic College is $1 for students and the elderly and $3.50 for adults for the matinee performances; $3.50 for students and the elderly and $7.50 for adults for the evening performance.
Information: (201) 595-7953 (Monday through Friday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.).
 
SAMPLERS ON DISPLAY
 "Next onto God, dear parents, I address myself to you in humble thankfulness for all your care and charge on me bestowed," was cross-stitched onto a large sampler in 1778, along with the alphabet, about 20 more lines and the name of the author, 11-year-old Elizabeth Barnard.
She would undoubtedly be surprised to know that her fervent message survived the intervening centuries and will be among more than 40 samplers on display next Sunday at the Hendrick Van Allen House in Oakland.
A booklet containing transcriptions from all the samplers in the exhibition will be included with the admission of $3. A textile and sampler conservationist, Kathleen Craughwell, will be available by prearranged appointment for consultations on samplers at $5 each.
The show, "Antique Needlework Samplers," will be presented by Dixie Francis for the Oakland Historical Society, which has its home in the historic house on Route 202 (Ramapo Valley Road) at Franklin Avenue.
Information: (201) 825-9049.
 
NEWARK EVENTS
 Entertainment in Newark for the coming weekend will include an avant-garde band and a major fire apparatus muster.
Sekou Sundiata and his innovative ensemble, Dadahdoodahda, will present the performance art of poetry and music as part of a "poetry works" festival at 2 P.M. Saturday at the Newark Public Library.
Tanya Tyler-James will be the host for the program, co-sponsored by the Newark Writers Collective. The library is at 5 Washington Street, and admission is free.
Information: (201) 643-3606.
The 27th annual Antique Fire Apparatus Muster and Parade will be held from noon to 4:30 P.M. next Sunday at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street.
Antique fire engines and equipment, slides of Newark firefighters and scale models will be featured. The displays will be sprawled over the museum parking lot, the Newark Fire Museum in the garden and the garden itself. Admission is free.
Information: (201) 596-6550.
 
HORSE MONTH
 Carrying forward a cherished tradition, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has proclaimed June as Horse Month in New Jersey. Open houses and other programs will be offered statewide throughout the month.
Home to more than 60,000 horses representing about 60 breeds, the state has some 7,000 equine sites on more than 120,000 acres of land and counts the industry as a $4 billion component of the agricultural economy.
The New Jersey Department of Agriculture works with the New Jersey Equine Advisory Board, the Standardbred Sire State Program and the Thoroughbred Breeders Incentive Program to encourage the breeding and racing of outstanding horses.
Observances will begin on Saturday with a dressage show at the Meadow in Mount Holly (information: 609-261-0601) and the Ramble Farm Arabians open house from 1 to 4 P.M. in Warren (908-560-3519).
Next Sunday, events will include the Monmouth County Hunt's Hunter Pace in Allentown (609-259-9728); the Spring Show Series at the Meadow; an open house at Riding High Farm from noon to 4 P.M. in Allentown (609-259-3884); the New Jersey Bred Hunter Association Horse Show in Allentown (215-847-2613) and others. A full schedule of events is available.
Information: (609) 292-8896.
 
HOME AQUARIUM SHOW
 The Home Aquarium Show on Saturday and next Sunday at the New Jersey State Aquarium in Camden will feature the best in tanks, technology and accessories as well as special displays and experts on hand to answer questions and offer tips.
Since June is also National Zoo and Aquarium Month, visitors may enter a drawing to win a behind-the-scenes tour of the aquarium.
The show is free with the regular admission of $9, or $6 for children 2 to 11, free for younger children and $7.50 for students and the elderly. The aquarium, at 1 Riverside Drive, is open from 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. daily, with the hours extended to 8:30 P.M. on Sundays through the summer.
Information: (609) 365-3300 or (800) 922-6572 (advance tickets). MARY L. EMBLEN
 
TRIANGLE SHOW

After its first musical in 1891 ("Po-ca-hon-tas"), the irreverent all-student Triangle Club show became a once-a-year event at Princeton University.
Those who missed the Triangle's 103d spring musical, which was presented last month, need not fuss. "The Bermuda Love Triangle: A Spanish Imposition," as it is called, is being revived in time for Reunions Weekend -- and before a national tour.
Instead of the customary revue format, this one falls into the category of a book musical. The Princeton Weekly Bulletin, the student newspaper, describes it as "a simple love story with sword fights, an exorcism, the traditional politically incorrect all-male kick line, penguins and dance hall girls named Tequila, Sangria, Kahlua, Pina and Colada." The setting is the rustic village of Buenas Noches; the triangle of the title is a voodoo artifact.
Jesus Villa, a sociology major (class of '94), conceived and wrote the show. Peter Mills, an English major (class of '95), composed most of the music. Eleven other students contributed lyrics and additional material.
The cast and the orchestra are immense. Two professionals, Robert Duke, the director, and Ken Leigh Rogers, the choreographer, got it all together.
Performances take place Friday and Saturday at 8:30 P.M. at the McCarter Theater on the university campus. Tickets are $15 to $21.
Information: (609) 683-8000. ALVIN KLEIN

HEADLINE: Democrats Pick Their Champions

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON 

DATELINE: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER'S northern Democrats, meeting in convention, endorsed Hamilton Fish Jr. last week as their candidate to fill the seat being vacated by his father, a Republican, but the closeness of the vote indicated a likely bruising primary in September.
Mr. Fish outpolled Dennis Mehiel, the former Westchester County Democratic Party chairman, on a second ballot after the initial count showed Mr. Fish ahead -- with 9,932 votes to 9,222 for Mr. Mehiel -- but failing to win a majority. 
 A third candidate, Neil McCarthy, a Lewisboro resident and member of a Manhattan law firm who ran unsuccessfully against the 13-term incumbent two years ago, got 4,741 votes, and a fourth entrant, Al Lynn, a businessman from Pound Ridge with a specialty in home health care, got 2,390 votes.
Under the terms of the convention, the candidate with the smallest total dropped out, and the delegates, representing the Westchester cities and towns in the 19th Congressional District, voted again. This time, with support flowing to the younger Mr. Fish from all three of his rivals, he won.
The candidates arrived in the convention hall just before the balloting, having come from a similar Democratic gathering in Orange County where Mr. Mehiel outpolled Mr. Fish by 60 percent to 40 percent. To complicate matters further, Mr. Fish had won the endorsement of Dutchess County Democrats the night before.
All four candidates had indicated earlier that they would seek recognition in a primary election if they failed to win their party's endorsement. With the closeness of the vote and the feeling among leading Democrats that this election represents the best chance in years to wrest the Hudson Valley seat from the Republicans, a primary appears certain for at least the two top vote getters.
 
State Senate Race
 No such ambivalence existed in another convention contest, this for the seat in the State Senate being vacated by the Republican Party's designated candidate for Governor, George E. Pataki. By an overwhelming margin, the delegates cast their ballots for Alfred B. DelBello, a former Westchester County Executive and the first Democrat to hold that post.
Mr. DelBello, who moved from Yonkers, where he was Mayor in the early 1970's, to Lewisboro, a largely rural town in northern Westchester 15 years ago, left the County Executive post in 1983 to run for Lieutenant Governor. He quit that job two years later because the Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, never folded Mr. DelBello into his inner circle.
Since then Mr. DelBello has worked as a consultant in the solid-waste management field and is a partner in a White Plains law firm. He has remained active in politics, supporting candidates and policies, and is considered to have retained his name recognition.
His support among delegates was so strong that one of his rivals for the candidacy in the 37th District, Linda D. Puglisi, Supervisor of Cortlandt, coupled her appreciation for candidacy with the announcement that she was withdrawing for the sake of harmony. Mr. DelBello handily beat another rival, Robert W. Elliott, Mayor of Croton-on-Hudson.
Facing election in what the Democratic Party chairman, Andrew J. Spano, described as "the second most heavily Republican district in the state," Mr. DelBello pledged to help restore the state's pre-eminence.
He said the state had suffered more in the last three and a half years of recession than any other state, "and the Hudson Valley more than any other region in the state." He was referring to corporate downsizing and the loss of jobs in companies like International Business Machines.
 
30 Percent Democratic
 He called for a "revolution" in the "Neanderthalic" State Senate, which he said was inbred by Republicans who block progress. The 37th District seat, he added, "has been taken for granted for too long by Republicans."
Mr. DelBello's likely Republican rival for the Senate seat is Assemblyman Vincent L. Leibell 3d, who had resisted announcing his candidacy until he was certain that his Republican colleague, Mr. Pataki, was firmly set in the race for Governor.
The district consists of 10 communities of northern Westchester, including part of White Plains, as well as all of Putnam County and six towns in Dutchess County. Enrollment is 40 percent Republican and Conservative, while Democrats represent 30 percent, most of the remaining being independent voters.
Variations on Mr. DelBello's theme -- that the Hudson Valley needed economic assistance -- were also heard from the Congressional candidates, with each coupling the issue with reasons they felt they could wrest the district from Republican control.
Mr. Mehiel used his "28 years of corporate experience" as an example. With his brother, he founded the Four M corporation, one of the country's largest independent makers of corrugated packaging. It employs 1,800 workers in 21 plants nationwide.
He said he had his employees covered by health insurance in 1967. "The family-leave law was only passed recently by Congress, but we had it in 1978," he said. He spoke of similar ideas for innovative policies in the environmental field.
He suggested that these experiences with "14 years of community service" were essential to being a strong candidate. He said he had been told not to take on the party's chairmanship if he ever wanted to run for office, but "I'm doing it anyway," he said.
In 1988, he sought the Democratic nomination in the 20th Congressional District as did his current rival, then known as Hamilton Fish 3d because his grandfather, a former Congressman, was still alive. Both Mr. Mehiel and the younger Mr. Fish lost a three-way primary to Nita M. Lowey, who beat the then-incumbent, Joseph DioGuardi.
Mr. Fish, at last week's convention, spoke of his lifelong allegiance to the Democratic Party, saying his father, who is giving up the seat because he has cancer, "supported me in my first race," adding to laughter, "and my grandfather less so."
 
Endorsed by a Roosevelt
 Mr. Fish is senior adviser to Human Rights Watch, an international human rights organization based in Manhattan, and is development consultant to Doctors of the World, a human rights and medical relief organization.
He spoke of his commitment to the region and of the need to open it up to the more realistic Democratic policies. He was endorsed by Christopher Roosevelt, a grandson of the nation's wartime leader, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
Al Lynn said his business background, operating Medlinc Inc., with 14 offices in the New York City area, suited him for the Congressional post. He has had no political experience, a fact that he said will help with a public out of work or facing layoffs. "Many share a cynicism about the democratic process," he said.
Mr. McCarthy, the only candidate among the four seeking their party's support to have run against Representative Fish, said the experience put him in a position to know the issues in the Hudson Valley region, thus making him the most viable candidate in the field.
The 19th Congressional District extends from White Plains to include all of Putnam County, 4 towns in Orange County and 10 municipalities in Dutchess County, including the city of Poughkeepsie.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
As Goes the Trade Status, So Goes the Nation Fund

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
IF every person in China drank one cherry cola, ate one cheeseburger and bought one toothbrush, lots of Americans would become very rich. That may seem like a bit of a stretch, but it's the story that for years has attracted investors to companies that claimed to be China plays, and, more recently, to funds that are poised to take advantage of the growing Chinese economy.
Earlier this year, that tale seemed less likely to have a happy ending. United States officials' concerns about China's human rights record cast some doubt on whether the nation could continue to export goods to America under the advantageous terms of most-favored-nation status. In addition, the shares of the China Fund, a closed-end issue, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange, were also depressed by a rights offering that ended in April. 
 But as optimism about China's trade status rose, so did the share price of the China Fund, which by Friday was at a 25 percent premium to the value of the fund's underlying portfolio. LESLIE EATON

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Sorting Out a Doomsday Argument

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
THE stage is set, Donald Christensen argues, for a new "bust" in mutual funds.
Twice before in this century, in 1929 and after the go-go 60's, fund investors lost a lot, Mr. Christensen, a New York investment analyst, tells us in his soon-to-be-published book, "Surviving the Coming Mutual Fund Crisis." And now elements of both crises have resurfaced, he says, to haunt the millions who have flocked to funds in recent years in a mania he likens to the Dutch tulip bulb craze and the flighty period leading to the stock market crash in 1929. 
 The book's apocalyptic vision may be overdrawn. While a spike in inflation would surely hurt the financial markets, the leverage that magnified the 1929 losses is absent. Regulation is stronger now, too. In part, the book's advice is extreme, but over all Mr. Christensen offers some solid counsel.
What worries Mr. Christensen is the re-emergence of high-risk investing and secrecy that contributed to the previous fund crises. During the go-go 1960's, for instance, the most successful funds were those using risky investing techniques -- buying shares in small, new companies, concentrating their portfolios, owning shares that could not be traded publicly. And when the market plummeted at the end of the decade, some of the highest fliers went with it.
Since 1990, many high-risk policies have crept back. The number of "nondiversified" funds, which can concentrate their portfolios in one industry or country, has risen markedly. More funds have also changed fundamental investment policies, allowing the use of options, leverage or derivative securities. The latter created losses for adjustable-rate mortgage funds during recent years.
Some sophisticated techniques have been untested. The short world income funds were built on complicated currency hedging techniques that did not work. In the late 1980's, two heavily marketed fund concepts based on option-writing -- government plus and option income funds -- disappeared after poor showings.
Ken Gregory, who edits the No-Load Fund Analyst in San Francisco, warns against generalizing about these developments, pointing out that many changes have been made because new financial instruments are available, and that many of the strategies are used to limit losses, not lift returns.
Still, Mr. Christensen says, investors should steer clear of funds that use the riskier strategies. His concern is echoed by John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds. "If it's a new and complex strategy that the fund companies are introducing and they say 'trust us,' don't," he said.
Mr. Christensen advises avoiding stock funds with yearly expenses exceeding 1.25 percent, about the group's average. Expenses for funds owning government bonds should not exceed 0.8 percent, he says; corporate bonds, 1 percent.
And potential investors in unseasoned companies must know there are big risks, Mr. Christensen says. Managers are moving into smaller stocks, many with short track records, and their belief that they can succeed if they "are smart enough and work hard," Mr. Rekenthaler added, can lead "to a dangerous self-confidence."
Mr. Christensen also expresses alarm about the fund industry's tendency to withhold or camouflage information and mislead shareholders about their investments. Prospectuses and annual reports often present information in ways that befuddle investors, he says.
Investors should know who manages their money. The Securities and Exchange Commission recently ruled that a fund must disclose the name of its manager in its prospectus, with this exception: funds managed by teams of two people or more. About 15 percent of all funds in the Morningstar data base were team-managed in 1989; that jumped to 30 percent by the end of 1993.
How should investors pick a fund? Mr. Christensen, who publishes "The Insider Outlook," a newsletter that tracks the stocks that corporate insiders buy and sell, advises avoiding funds that lead the short-term performance charts as too risky. Instead, investors should look for strong three- to five-year track records.
And he urges shunning funds in the bottom 10 percent of the performance charts. But investors should make fair comparisons. Until recently funds that invest abroad, for instance, looked terrible compared with domestic equity funds.
Mr. Christensen also says stay away from funds labeled "high yield" or "high income," euphemisms for high risk. But junk bonds may well deserve a place in some investors' portfolios.
Investors should never buy shares on margin, Mr. Christensen says; doing so is very risky.
High-turnover funds should also be avoided, he says. But if investors shunned them all, Mr. Rekenthaler said, they would miss winners like Janus, Columbia Growth and Fidelity Magellan.
In the end, befitting his doomsday view, Mr. Christensen urges investors to stick with individual issues of stocks or bonds. But because funds can benefit some investors by offering diversification and professional management, this is an extreme approach.
The bottom line: remember that the fund industry's aim is sales. It is an investor's job, Mr. Christensen says, "to skeptically question and investigate the risk" of what the industry is trying to sell you.

HEADLINE: It's Small, Cheap and Not a Hyundai

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: ASAN, South Korea

 BODY:
A GIANT monster rampages through a city as people flee in terror. "There's only one thing more frightening to Japan," reads the text accompanying this clip from a science fiction movie. "A well-made car for under $8,500."
The commercial, being shown in some parts of the United States, is for the Sephia, a compact car with a base price of $8,495 that is being introduced into the American market by Kia Motors Corporation, South Korea's No. 2 auto maker, behind Hyundai. The Sephia will be followed at the end of the year by the Sportage, a small sport-utility vehicle that is drawing rave reviews. 
 Breaking into the United States will not be easy for Kia. Few Americans have ever heard of the company. It faces numerous competitors, including Chrysler's hot new Neon, which has a base price only $500 higher than the Sephia's. And Kia must overcome the image Korean cars have among American consumers for poor quality, a result of Hyundai's botched entry into the American market in the late 1980's.
But Kia is nothing if not audacious, and it has come far. When it started out 50 years ago, the company could not even manufacture a complete bicycle. It was not until 1973 that Kia developed Korea's first gasoline engine. And in 1981, the company nearly went bankrupt and was forced to quit the passenger car business for five years.
Kia's ambition is shared by the rest of Korea's auto industry. Helped by a growing home market more protected than Japan's, Korean output rose to two million vehicles last year, twice 1987's level. This year it might reach 2.4 million, enough to make Korea No. 5 in world auto production, behind Japan, the United States, Germany and France.
Exports, buoyed by the rise in the Japanese yen, which has made Japanese cars less competitive, soared 40 percent last year, to 640,000 vehicles.
And the industry, led by the "big three" of Hyundai, Kia and Daewoo, is investing more than $2 billion a year to double its capacity to more than four million vehicles by the year 2000.
A sign of the ambition is seen at Kia's four-year-old Asan Bay complex, which sprawls 3.8 miles from end to end on Korea's west coast, housing a factory and a modern test track. Capacity is being doubled to 650,000 vehicles a year by 1997 as part of a plan to double overall capacity to 1.25 million.
In doing so, Kia is taking on high debt, which analysts say could get the company in trouble again if business turns sour. But Kia officials say the debt is not too large and is necessary.
"Unless an auto maker reaches a production capacity of one million units a year, it will be difficult for that company to survive," said Kim Sun Hong, Kia's chairman.
Mr. Kim, 63, knows what it is like to be on the brink. He is known here as the "Lee Iacocca of Korea" for his role in saving Kia in 1981.
In an economy dominated by family-owned conglomerates, known as "chaebol," Mr. Kim is a rarity -- a professional manager, not an owner, who worked his way up from the shop floor. That, plus the fact that Kia is focused on only one business, has made it a model in the eyes of Korea's Government, which is trying to loosen the power of the chaebol.
In trying to enter the United States, Kia is being helped by the fact that the American market is booming and the strong yen has forced the Japanese to raise prices. "There's a hole in the market" for a low-priced compact car, said Greg Warner, executive vice president of Kia Motors America in Irvine, Calif.
Mr. Warner used to work for Hyundai and is eager to avoid the mistakes that company made in entering the American market. Sales soared to 264,000 cars in 1988 as buyers snapped up Hyundai's inexpensive Excel. But sales fell almost as rapidly as drivers began finding problems.
Hyundai, Korea's most advanced car maker, has improved its quality, and its sales elsewhere in the world continue to grow. But in the United States its image has proved more difficult to repair than its product, and sales remain at just 110,000 a year. "We are more cautious now," said Juhn Myung Hun, director of export marketing for Hyundai's America group.
Kia has, in a sense, already succeeded in the United States. It has made the Festiva, a subcompact sold by Ford, which owns 10 percent of Kia. The Festiva has recently been succeeded by the Aspire, also made by Kia.
But Kia is still mindful of the lessons of Hyundai. Its advertising does not mention the word "Korea." It has made it easy for dealers to take on a Kia franchise for an investment of as little as $25,000. It is offering an extensive warranty program. Above all, its initial sales goals are modest and it is expanding slowly. It now has 66 dealers in 11 Western states and won't have nationwide coverage until the end of 1995.
"Our strategy is to avoid big damage," Mr. Kim said, adding that some setbacks are inevitable. "The Japanese faced a great deal of difficulties and some failures in the first 10 years," he said. "We need to have our own experience firsthand."
Kia's American efforts could get a big lift when the car maker begins selling the Sportage. "That, I think, is going to be the franchise," said Chris Cedergren, senior vice president of AutoPacific Inc., a market research firm in Santa Ana, Calif.
The Sportage, which has little competition in its price range other than the Suzuki Sidekick, has drawn such positive reviews that both Ford and Mazda, which owns 8 percent of Kia, are thinking of selling it under their own names.
Kia was founded by Kim Chul Ho, who at 18 went to Japan to work at a steel mill. In 1930, he set up a company in Japan making nuts and bolts, and he prospered. In 1944, Mr. Kim returned to Korea and set up a company to make bicycle parts, later moving to complete bicycles. The name "Kia" in Chinese characters means to rise in Asia toward the world. By 1973, when Mr. Kim died, his company was about to begin passenger car production.
The current chairman (no relation to the founder) joined Kia after studying engineering at Seoul National University and rose quickly through the ranks, becoming president of Kia's machine tool subsidiary in his early 40's.
In 1981 Kia suffered huge losses after the second oil shock, which sent Korea's economy into a tailspin. Kia's president at the time, the son of the founder, had to bail out, selling his shares to employees and handing the reins to Mr. Kim.
That same year, Korea's Government decided to restructure the ailing industry. Kia was forced to give up passenger car production, but in exchange was given a monopoly on certain trucks and buses.
Mr. Kim bet the company on the Bongo, a small van made under a license from Mazda. Mr. Kim put the logo of the minivan on the uniform of every employee. And instead of saying "good morning," employees greeted one another each day with "Let's sell Bongos." The campaign was so intense it became known as "Bongoism." But sales took off and Kia's recovery began.

AROUND 1985, Mazda approached Kia about manufacturing a subcompact that Mazda had designed for Ford. Lured by the prospect of exports of what was to become the Festiva, the Government let Kia back into making cars.
Kia's share of Korea's passenger car market quickly climbed to 30 percent. Last year, its overall vehicle production reached 600,000 units, double the level in 1989. The company is now planning, with help from Mazda, to make a mid-sized sedan.
Earnings, however, have been weakened by expansion. Last year, Kia had net income of 18.7 billion won, or $23.1 million, on sales of $5.1 billion. But Don Lee, auto analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd in Seoul, forecasts that Kia's earnings will double this year and double again in 1995.
While Kia and the other Korean companies are now growing rapidly, there are still doubts about the future. Korean companies are still behind Japan in product quality, productivity and variety, and they are dependent on Japan for technology and production equipment. Kia's factory, for instance, was largely designed by Mazda, and the Sephia has a Mazda-designed engine.
What has been sustaining the Koreans has been the price advantage over Japan because of the strong yen, but Japanese companies are taking steps to offset the yen's rise. "Korean auto makers will not be able to depend on price alone," said Mr. Lee, the analyst. "They have three years or so to boost their competitiveness."
Some analysts say the industry is due for a shakeout because it is building far more cars than are needed. Such fears were heightened recently by the decision of the Samsung Group, a huge conglomerate, to enter the passenger car business with technology and designs provided by Nissan Motor Company of Japan.
The existing auto makers have protested, and Korea's Government is reluctant to approve Samsung's move, worrying that a glut would undermine the entire Korean industry. Growth of the domestic market is slowing, having increased only 13 percent last year, down from growth rates as high as 45 percent in the late 1980's.
Whether Samsung goes ahead or not remains to be seen. Last year, it bought a stake in Kia, raising fears of a hostile takeover. Some analysts say the conglomerate might eventually decide it makes more sense to enter the auto business through an acquisition. If Korea's Lee Iacocca wants to maintain the independence of the company he rescued, Kia cannot falter.
 
Growing Wings In a Sheltered Nest
 IT is the common wisdom in South Korea that buying a foreign car invites a tax audit. It is little wonder, then, that only about 2,000 foreign cars were sold in Korea last year, accounting for less than 0.2 percent of the market. Even in Japan, imports hold a 3 percent share.
Korea has borrowed a page from Japan by using a protected home market as a launching pad. Now Washington, which has spent much of its time trying to pry Japan's market open, is putting some pressure on Korea as well.
The barriers are formidable. Japanese cars are banned completely, in part because of Japan's history as a colonial ruler of Korea. All car purchases are taxed at percentages that rise sharply for larger and more expensive cars. While Korea says the tax system is meant to discourage excessive consumption, the United States has charged that the system effectively discriminates against foreign cars, which tend to be larger.
Korean officials say they are opening the market. Tariffs on imported cars were reduced this year to 10 percent, the same level as in Europe, down from 30 percent in the mid-1980's. (The United States tariff is 2.5 percent on cars and 25 percent on commercial vehicles.) And the Government has declared that buying a foreign car will not be grounds for a tax audit.
"From 1988 on, our automobile market has been completely open," said Cho Kwan Hyun, executive vice chairman of the Korea Automobile Manufacturers Association.
But Washington is not buying this. It is a safe bet that as Korea becomes a major auto exporter, the pressure to accept more imports will only grow.

HEADLINE: Profile;
Even in a 'Big Tent,' Little Insults, Little Compromises

BYLINE: By TERESA RIORDAN; Teresa Riordan writes the Patents column on alternate Mondays.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN Bruce A. Lehman swore before God and his country to uphold the laws of the land, his mother was holding the Bible.
Nothing extraordinary about that. But then, in a paneled sanctum of the Commerce Department, with a military color guard standing by, Mr. Lehman introduced to the assembled officials and well-wishers not only his mother and sister but also his male partner of 15 years, their 8-year-old child, and her lesbian mother, with whom Mr. Lehman and his companion share child-rearing duties. 
 The dignity of last September's swearing-in -- an unusual one even in the Clinton Administration's big-tent embrace of diversity -- suggested that Mr. Lehman had risen above society's prejudices as he stepped into his role as Assistant Commerce Secretary and Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks -- the first openly gay man ever to be confirmed by the Senate as a high-ranking Government official. But the truth is that even for someone as successful and savvy and mainstream as Mr. Lehman, the uncharted territory of a public gay man can be strewn with insult and compromise.
As if to emphasize the Patent Office's link to industry, as well as its historic remoteness from the corridors of power, Mr. Lehman's office in Crystal City, Va., looks out on a highway, an elevated train line, National Airport, and, finally, the ruddy Potomac.
Northward along the Potomac lies the distant profile of monumental Washington, with the view dominated by the Capitol, where Mr. Lehman worked from 1974 to 1983 as a congressional aide -- and where he had two revelations that have shaped his life.
One, that he was gay. In 1978, after nine years of monogamous marriage to a "wonderful" woman, he finally acknowledged this both to himself and to her.
The other revelation was professional: Long before just about anyone else, Mr. Lehman foresaw that the field of intellectual property, far from being an arcane technical specialty, could be an important economic and policy tool -- and the basis of a career for an ambitious young man.
"I knew back then this was an uncut diamond," Mr. Lehman said.
While his predecessors have been seen as mere stewards of a backwater bureaucracy, Mr. Lehman has leveraged his perch into a central policy-making role.
His boss, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, stops short of dubbing his patents commissioner an intellectual property czar, but acknowledges that "in many respects, he plays that role in a de facto way."
Mr. Lehman somehow avoided the conservative wrath that Roberta Achtenberg, an Assistant Secretary at the Housing and Urban Development Department, the highest-ranking openly gay woman in the Administration, drew at her confirmation hearings.
"The Washington Times wrote a big story on my nomination trying to stir up some outrage from conservative Republicans," Mr. Lehman said. "The problem is, they all know me, and they kind of like me, and they didn't want to make a martyr of me."
While Mr. Lehman's long friendships on Capitol Hill and among his colleagues have insulated him from public attacks, he has not been spared anonymous barbs. A few weeks ago someone posted on the Internet's Intellectual Property bulletin board a note about the "queer commissioner."
Earlier this year, Mr. Lehman prepared a speech for the Bay Area Lawyers for Individual Freedom, in San Francisco. In the speech, which he gave to his director of media affairs, Ruth M. Ford, to look over, he said he had not been the target of much anti-gay bias. "Ruth came back and said, 'We've got to change this,' " Mr. Lehman recalled. "I said, 'Why?' She said, 'We just haven't shown you the hate mail.' "
Ms. Ford said most such mail was thrown away, but mentioned one -- "somebody had written 'faggot faggot faggot' across it."

THE main criticism of Mr. Lehman's nomination as patents commissioner from some corners came not because he is gay but because his specialty has been copyright law rather than patents.
In the early 1980's, Mr. Lehman applied for the job of the Registrar of Copyrights. When he didn't get it, he did a lucrative stint as a copyright lawyer and lobbyist at the Washington firm Swidler & Berlin, where his clients included Lotus and Microsoft.
Part of the clash with the patent world was over style as much as substance. "Patent lawyers tend to be the type of people who wear plastic pen liners in their shirt pockets," said one intellectual property expert who declined to be quoted by name, "while copyright people tend to be wild and crazy artist types who became lawyers only because they had to to make a living."
The new patents commissioner has clearly spiced up the bland bureaucracy. Mr. Lehman, who at 48 exudes a boyish air, dresses impeccably, his stylish suits detailed with a fresh white handkerchief, and displays a touch of exotic color, perhaps a mint-colored watchband or the ruby background of a Brooks Brothers tie.
On a glass side table in his office sits a handsomely framed photograph taken at last year's White House Christmas party. Bill and Hillary Clinton stand in the middle. Mr. Lehman is to the left, under a portrait of George Washington. To the right is Mr. Lehman's partner, smiling, a trimmed tree behind him.
At about the time that picture was taken, Mr. Lehman threw a party of his own at his Georgetown home in honor of a visiting patent delegation from Russia, with Mr. Lehman's personal assistant, Mary Ann Villemi, playing the role of greeter and coat taker. His partner's conspicuous absence seemed to symbolize the subtle but constant compromises Mr. Lehman must make.
Being openly gay, though, may have helped him get this job, while it might have stymied his appointment in a previous administration. Both he and Ms. Achtenberg were considered to be at the top of a short list of people backed by gay activists.
Mr. Brown said that while he was "certainly conscious" that the gay community had backed the nomination, "Bruce Lehman is not here because he's gay. He's the absolute best person for the job."
At a recent meeting, Mr. Lehman jumped into a spiel by a diversity consulting team from Boston hoping to renew its contract with the patent office. The lead consultant was telling Mr. Lehman and his associates that of course her approach would not be to force antidiscrimination concepts down workers' throats. Mr. Lehman interrupted.
"As far as I'm concerned," he said, "it's got to be forced down their throats. If they want to be bigots, they can go work for someone else's department."
Later that day, between meetings, Mr. Lehman agreed to spend some time talking about his life. He suggested stopping at the Four Seasons in Georgetown for drinks before his final obligation of the day, a dinner put on by the Gertrude Stein Democratic Club, a gay organization that was honoring him that night.
On the way, Mr. Lehman picked up the phone in his Government car and called his daughter's mother, who conceived the child through artificial insemination with Mr. Lehman's partner. Although the girl lives mainly with her mother, and her companion, she spends weekends and vacations with the men. On the phone, Mr. Lehman sorted out who would take care of her the next night.
Sitting in the highly civilized lounge at the Four Seasons, Mr. Lehman reflected that, professionally, he had suffered little discrimination. "I'm involved in an area where it's hard to say where I'm going to push a gay-rights agenda," he said.
But halfway into his first glass of wine, Mr. Lehman made a startling proclamation, one that proved a clear reminder that whatever his professional achievements, the marriage between his public and private lives is an uneasy one. His longtime partner, Mr. Lehman said, does not consider himself publicly gay and does not want his name used.
That is surprising, Mr. Lehman was told. After all, he was introduced publicly at the swearing-in, they have been to the White House together as a couple, and some of Mr. Lehman's friends casually mention the partner's name during interviews. Indeed, his partner, a prominent scientific researcher, is arguably a public figure himself. Close to the time Mr. Lehman was sworn in, his partner made a major scientific discovery that received front-page attention worldwide.

THUS far Mr. Lehman had not shown a glimpse of what some consider his trademark temper. But now he started to grow testy. On this deeply personal subject, he worked himself up to a roar, capturing the attention of a sizable portion of the Four Seasons crowd.
"What right is there for anybody to tie my partner into this?" he said. "I've been very careful never to say his name. The reason he doesn't want to be outed is that the right wing will attack him. This is not an abstract thing. This is something we live with every day."
He also talked about his daughter, saying, "There are places in this country where people would take such a child away from their parents, including right here where I'm sitting, in Virginia."
"Nothing could be a better example of the discrimination we suffer -- this is like being a Jew in the 1930's," he said.
Mr. Lehman did not bring it up, but the next day a colleague recalled that three years ago Mr. Lehman and his partner were beaten near Dupont Circle. Asked later, Mr. Lehman reluctantly elaborated. Until now only close friends had known about it.
A carload of "college boys shouted epithets at us," Mr. Lehman said. His partner shouted back. The car lurched onto the sidewalk. "I said, 'You touch me and you're going to jail.' Before you knew it, we were on the ground, being kicked and beaten."
He and his partner, bloody and bruised, went to the hospital.
Mr. Lehman testified against his assailants, and several of them become the first people ever convicted under the District of Columbia's hate-crime law. "The only way you can overcome this kind of intolerance is to stand up to it," he said.
On the way to the Gertrude Stein dinner, the car stopped to pick up Mr. Lehman's partner. It was an awkward ride. Mr. Lehman's partner, apparently taken by surprise by a reporter's presence, said nothing.
At the dinner, the cocktail hour was well under way, and Mr. Lehman and his partner melted into a crowd that included the Mayor of Washington and other politicians. Mr. Lehman's companion was asked if he was available the next day to discuss whether his name could be used in this article. He said he did not talk about his personal life with reporters. And then, this nameless, silent man sat down, clinging to anonymity in a room full of 200 people. A short while later, Mr. Lehman walked to the podium to accept his award.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Democrats Rediscover Knack of Losing

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE battle for Owensboro, Ky., may be the straw that broke the donkey's back.
Democrats never expected this year's Congressional elections to be easy. But the loss Tuesday of a House seat in rural Kentucky that had been Democratic for 129 years washed away the plaintive excuses Democrats have embraced since their defeat in the Georgia Senate race two weeks after Bill Clinton's election. The outcome in Kentucky marked the eighth in a streak of big defeats by Republican upstarts. 
 Could these be the stirrings of a grand realignment that will send Democratic voters fleeing to the Republican Party in November? Maybe not. Still, the results from these early contests will probably send Democratic candidates fleeing from their own President.
"Democrats are wise not to dismiss this as a series of random accidents," said Gary Jacobson, a professor of political science at the University of California at San Diego. "If you're the Democratic Party, you're now the party of government. And you're the party to blame if voters want to send a message of unhappiness."
Yet the reality is far more complicated than whether Mr. Clinton has coattails, or reverse coattails. As much as they like to ascribe their successes to what they view as Mr. Clinton's emergence as a pariah, the Republicans should get credit for taking a lesson from their disastrous national convention in 1992.
Scorned by voters who were offended by their strident stands in Houston, Republicans are soft-pedaling issues like abortion, homosexual rights and school prayer that were once such successful calls to ideological arms. To the unknowing voter, the Republicans are sounding like Democrats.
But the Republicans have an advantage: If they are not too obvious, they can benefit from the mobilization of the far right, and they can also exploit voter discontent, since it is a Democrat who sits in the White House, the citadel of politics-as-usual. Such is the strategy of New York Republicans, who last week nominated State Senator George Pataki for Governor -- a move that could give Gov. Mario M. Cuomo his most serious opposition since 1982. Mr. Pataki, who supports a woman's right to an abortion, strikes a more mainstream tone on social issues than Mr. Cuomo's past opponents. To salve the far right, the Republicans nominated Herbert London, Mr. Pataki's far more conservative rival, as comptroller.
The Republican victor in Kentucky, Ron Lewis, is a fundamentalist minister who owns a religious bookstore. But his handlers carefully did not let his work become a big part of the dialogue. With money from the national Republican Party, he stuck to attacking the Democrat, former State Senator Joe Prather, as a tax-and-spend Clinton clone. That did not keep the religious right from working the churches and helping turn out the vote.
"They're hiding the social issues under a rock, they're going underground," said Peter Fenn, a strategist both for Mr. Prather and for Dan Webber, another Democrat who lost a special election for a House seat in Oklahoma earlier this month. "On gays in the military, Prather had a modified 'don't ask, don't tell' policy. They creamed him with it in the Christian churches, but it didn't show up in Lewis's advertising."
This is not to say that the Republicans have been entirely skillful in handling social issues. In some cases, Republicans have been so fearful of a backlash that they have forfeited issues they had championed, like family values, that have since been taken up by Mr. Clinton. And in many states, Republican parties are in turmoil over conservative extremists' attempts to gain control.
The best measure of how the election results have shaken Democrats is that the President himself lashed out at the religious right as fanatics in a private meeting with Democratic leaders the day after the Kentucky voting. He implored Democrats to fight back, telling them that Mr. Prather should have responded to a Republican commercial in which Mr. Prather's image dissolves into the face of Mr. Clinton and then back again. Mr. Prather, he said, should have retaliated with a commercial of himself and the late Representative William Natcher, a beloved Democrat who held the seat for 41 years until he died two months ago.
 
No Lack of Explanations
 Democrats have offered an assortment of explanations for their losses of the two House seats, for last year's losses of the governorships of Virginia and New Jersey and mayoral races in New York and Los Angeles and the Senate seat in Texas, and for the Georgia Senate seat the year before that. (Not to mention the loss of the lieutenant governorship in the President's home state.) In the same period, the Democrats have not won any pivotal seats from Republicans.
While it is common for the party out of power to win seats in special elections, the uninterrupted pattern of Republican victories is noteworthy. The most popular explanation among Democrats last week was that many of their party's recent standard-bearers have been lousy candidates. In the case of Mr. Prather, the party assembled 12 "talking points" to explain the loss. (The defeat prompted a snide comment by Paul Begala, a political adviser to Mr. Clinton: "This was a test of a candidate's low I.Q., not a test of the President's popularity.")
But in politics, excuses count for nothing -- and perceptions count for everything. And the perception that Republicans are on a roll certainly energizes the party faithful. By contrast, Mr. Clinton cannot seem to get on a roll -- at least one that lasts. Democrats hoped that passage of a health care proposal would save them, but thus far Republicans have had success ridiculing the plan as wildly expensive. Nor is Mr. Clinton benefiting from the economic recovery, perhaps because the improving conditions have yet to touch the lives of many individual voters appreciably. "We've come out of the recession, but there's still insecurity about the economic future," said Senator Joe Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat who is seeking re-election.
The trial heats only compound the fears of Democrats. Just as the Republicans may have learned from their losses after the 1992 convention, Democrats are paying the price for their victory. After a party wins the White House, it almost always suffers in the following mid-term elections. The Democrats are also more at risk because they have more seats to defend, especially across the South, where many conservative white Democrats are retiring from Congress in districts that have been close to turning Republican.
With Republicans effectively defusing the social issues, the challenge for the Democrats is to prove that even as the incumbents they are best positioned to help the people. "Health care has got to be passed by November," said Mr. Fenn. "This is a symbolic issue of Mr. Clinton and the Democratic Party. Putting it off until after the election would be a devastating mistake." Mr. Fenn is still reeling from his clients' losses in Oklahoma and Kentucky, and he is not about to advise his other candidates to embrace the Clinton agenda.
And Ben Sheffner, an analyst of Congressional contests, saw reasons for the Democrats to worry about their numerical advantage in the House. Just suppose, he said, that voters are in a "throw the bums out" mood and their resentment results in "throwing out three Democratic bums for every two Republican bums."

HEADLINE: The World;
Balkan Road Signs: This Way to Chaos

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia

 BODY:
PART museum pieces, part twisted jokes, the road signs of the former Yugoslavia now chart a nation's destruction. There are countless signs to towns that cannot be reached, countless towns for which there are no longer any signs, and countless reasons for supposing that towns indicated have been reduced to rubble anyway or are swiftly headed that way.
Drive east from Zagreb and a strange thing happens. There is nothing to the east of Croatia. Europe plunges into a nameless abyss, for Serbia, and its capital, Belgrade, are too malevolent to mention. 
 They have disappeared without trace from road signs on what was once the main Yugoslav highway linking Zagreb and Belgrade.
This highway, known under Tito as the "Road of Brotherhood and Unity," was cut during the 1991 Serbian-Croatian war. Then, in September 1992, Cyrus R. Vance, a United Nations mediator in the Balkans, announced that he had secured an agreement between Croats and Serbs to reopen the road and rename it -- of all things -- "Road of Peace." The road never opened, peace never came, and Serbs never gave up their hold on about one-quarter of Croatia.
Signs on the highway near Zagreb now indicate Slavonski Brod, and even the bustling village of Lipovac (once about as well known in Zagreb as South Orange, N.J., but now thrust to prominence by the fact that it stands on the Croatian side of the border with the Serbian vacuum).
Budapest -- anathema to Croats during the nation's long subjection to the Austro-Hungarian Empire -- has also gained favor as a mentionable foreign capital.
"Mass psychology here does not allow any road sign to Belgrade," said Zarko Puhovski, a political scientist in Zagreb. "The hatred is too great. It would be destroyed."
Hatred. There is a rough equation here: With the same velocity as road signs have lost their sense, hatred has grown in the former Yugoslavia. Neighbors have lost touch with each other. Companies have lost access to their raw materials. People have lost their livelihoods, their homes, and their psychological bearings.
In the same month as the Channel Tunnel was opened in one corner of Europe, linking Britain and France for the first time since the Ice Age, this Balkan corner of Europe continued its headlong retreat toward the paleolithic era of transport and communication.
To travel in Bosnia is to understand that only when road signs mean something and links are restored between communities will peace finally come, and, with it, some chance of making a living.
Consider a sign on the main road out of Tuzla, the largest Bosnian town after Sarajevo that is still in the hands of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government. It reads: "Zagreb 325 kilometers. Belgrade 227 kilometers. Sarajevo 120 kilometers."
The sign points to roads that were the main arteries of Yugoslavia and are still essential to any economic revival in this region. But because roads north of Tuzla are cut by the Serbian lines in and around Brcko, Zagreb is in fact well over 1,000 kilometers -- 650 miles and more -- away, via the southern coastal towns of Split and Rijeka.
Belgrade lies beyond enemy territory and can scarcely be visited by the Muslims of Tuzla. For anyone else, a journey to the Serbian capital that avoided the front lines of the Bosnian war would involve a three-day trek through Croatia and Hungary.
As for Sarajevo, it lies at the far end of a labyrinth of primitive mountain roads the United Nations has put to use in an attempt to steer its aid convoys away from front lines. These trails -- which boast names like "Acorn," "Finch" and "Skoda" bestowed upon them by the United Nations -- must be taken because the main road to Sarajevo is cut by Serbian forces south of Kladanj.
So the 120-kilometer Tuzla-Sarajevo journey -- about 80 miles -- takes about 12 hours.
It takes that long because of scenes like this: ten hulking United Nations trucks escorted by a couple of armored personnel carriers stalled, amid scrawny goats, begging children and heavily armed Bosnians, on a 10-foot-wide mountain trail that has a 45-degree gradient. The road, awash in mud and dotted with suspension-busting potholes, was employed only for the occasional ox-drawn cart in the days before war tore up the maps of Bosnia.
 
A Fatal Turn
 Patience is, however, very strongly recommended, even when traffic simply stops. Wrong turns often lead to ambushes by bandits after money, or straight into mine fields.
One such wrong turn led two American journalists -- one from the popular culture magazine Spin and the other from a Seattle weekly, Magnolia News -- to their deaths this month on the road between Sarajevo and Mostar (this road gets tricky because two bridges have been blown up and traffic has to find its way onto a makeshift ferry operated by the United Nations on the Neretva River).
To get into Sarajevo itself involves taking a winding trail over Mount Ig- man, the scene, in happier days, of the Olympic ski jump. The ski jump is still there, but is now flanked by United Nations and Bosnian soldiers.
Sarajevo is still there, too, at least some vestigial bits of it; but the city is full of signs that only point to Europe's new curtains of iron.
One indicates the road to Grbavica, a Serbian-held part of town that cannot be visited from the Muslim side. Another points to Pale -- previously 45 minutes away by car, now accessible most quickly through a United Nations flight to Zagreb, followed by flights to Vienna and Budapest, and then a long drive south through Belgrade (where the airport has been closed by United Nations sanctions) and on to Pale.
There is at least one honest sign in the former Yugoslavia. It stands on the outskirts of the front-line Muslim-held town of Kladanj, south of Tuzla. It points east, across the lines, to the Serbian-held town of Vlasenica, about 20 miles away. Somebody has scratched out "Vlasenica" and scrawled one word: "Death."

GRAPHIC: Map of Bosnia and Herzegovina shows areas controlled by Serbs and the Muslim-dominated Government and Croats. (pg. 12)

HEADLINE: Clinton and China: How Promise Self-Destructed

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times; The following article is based on reporting by Thomas L. Friedman, Elaine Sciolino and Patrick E. Tyler and was written by Ms. Sciolino.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
Warren Christopher was in China, and the President was furious.
The Secretary of State's high-profile trip in March was supposed to have been the capstone of the Administration's strategy of working intensively with Beijing to resolve their dispute over human rights. Instead, things were getting worse by the day. Mr. Christopher was trading insults with the Chinese authorities, who were preoccupied with their annual National People's Congress, and he was facing harsh criticism from the American Chamber of Commerce in Beijing. 
 As President Clinton watched his China policy heading over a cliff, he exploded in front of aides in the Oval Office, "What the hell is Chris doing there now?"
The President's outburst, say aides, reflected his frustration not only with his Secretary of State but also with a policy that was supposed to have been an effortless success but was turning into a diplomatic tar baby.
In the end, Mr. Clinton would renew China's trade privileges and abandon an agonizing annual ritual of linking renewal of trade benefits to improvements in Beijing's human rights performance. The story of how he got there, reconstructed in interviews with senior Administration officials, lawmakers and business and human rights leaders, is a tale of broken campaign promises and fierce inter-agency battles, secret diplomacy and 11th-hour indecision.
Mr. Clinton decided on the central issue of extending the trade benefits months before his announcement on Thursday, though he was still changing his mind about the details until the final moment. He called former President Jimmy Carter with a last-minute offer for him to head an independent blue-ribbon human rights panel recommended by Mr. Christopher that would press China to make more progress. Mr. Carter not only said no, he advised Mr. Clinton to scrap the idea, saying it would not be taken seriously by human rights organizations.
Mr. Clinton discarded it just before heading to the White House briefing room to make his announcement.
 
The Prelude
Campaign Promise And an Order
 When Mr. Clinton began his Presidential campaign, his views on China were shaped as much by immediate political needs as by geopolitical strategy. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. favored using the threat of withdrawing "most-favored- nation" benefits from China if it did not improve its human rights record. Candidate Clinton, who needed their support to win the Democratic Party nomination, was not about to contradict them.
When it came time for the new President to draw up his policy, Senator Mitchell and his allies in Congress threatened to pass legislation withdrawing China's trade benefits if Beijing did not do more to ease repression. To head off such a law, with its inherent inflexibility, Mr. Clinton asked his aides to draft an executive order that would mollify the Democrats in Congress but remain vague enough to allow the President to change course a year later.
With no senior member of the Administration opposing the idea, Mr. Clinton signed Presidential Executive Order 12850 at the White House on May 28, 1993. It renewed China's trade benefits for another year but said China must meet two "mandatory" conditions to win another extension in June 1994: end restrictions on emigration by close family members of dissidents and comply with a 1992 agreement banning the export of prison-labor products to the United States. China was also supposed to make "overall, significant progress" on a number of other issues, ranging from easing the crackdown on Tibet to accounting for political prisoners.
Chinese dissidents, liberal Democrats, conservative Republicans, Asia Watch, members of the U.S.-China Business Council and even a representative of Tibet's leadership gathered at the White House for the signing of the order, which was widely hailed as a masterful solution.
But it was a false consensus, because each side saw in the executive order what it wanted to see. The liberal Democrats thought the directive had finally put some muscle into the trade threat, and the business sector thought that it was ambiguous enough finally to eviscerate the trade threat.
 
Policy Shift
 'Downward Spiral' Forces a Change
 China was not impressed, and over the next few months, the relationship with the United States deteriorated. The Chinese loaded chemicals for making weapons on a freighter headed for Iran, shipped technology for M-11 missiles to Pakistan in violation of an international missile agreement and rejected pleas from the Clinton Administration to cancel a long-scheduled underground nuclear test.
As it became apparent that the executive order was not having its desired effect and that the threat to revoke China's trade benefits might actually have to be carried out, the American business sector mobilized.
"We consistently sent the President and his advisers letters and short papers arguing that extending trade with China was critical for helping the economy and jobs," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "That was argument No. 1. There was a subordinate argument -- that it would also advance human rights."
In mid-July, Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for Asian Affairs, argued in a classified paper that the relationship was on a "downward spiral" and urged an entirely new strategy of intensive engagement with Beijing in which incentives would substitute for threats. But it took more than two more months before Mr. Clinton signed an "action memorandum" putting the strategy into effect with a series of high-level exchanges, including a meeting between Mr. Clinton and China's President, Jiang Zemin, in Seattle in November.
The high-profile meeting yielded little. But within weeks a consensus began to emerge in the Administration that the United States had to find a formula to allow the extension of China's trade benefits.
Shortly after the New Year, Secretary Christopher ordered his legal advisers to prepare an analysis of exactly how little China had to do to meet the executive order. Their conclusion: As long as China met the two mandatory conditions, on emigration of dissidents' families and the export of prison goods, Mr. Christopher could recommend renewal; the rest could be finessed.
 
Christopher Trip
Clinton Is Angry And 'Disappointed'
 One incident more than any other threatened to derail this approach, however: a meeting in late February in Beijing between Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent democracy campaigner, and Assistant Secretary of State John Shattuck. Shortly before Mr. Christopher was to pay his first visit to Beijing as Secretary of State, Mr. Shattuck held the 90-minute encounter in a very public setting -- the coffee garden of the China World Hotel.
He never informed Mr. Christopher or Mr. Lord what he was planning, and the embassy took a hands-off approach, deciding not to report back to Washington on the impending meeting or its expected impact. Mr. Wei quickly publicized the meeting, and China furiously denounced the United States, calling Mr. Wei a "criminal on parole" and charging Mr. Shattuck with breaking Chinese laws.
Over the next few days, China rounded up dissidents in an effort to insure an uneventful National People's Congress. Mr. Christopher decided to go ahead with his visit to Beijing anyway, arguing that if he canceled, the Chinese would make no more concessions and the President would be forced to revoke China's trade benefits. But Mr. Christopher found himself on the defensive throughout his three-day trip, and the furor obscured the few concessions he won from Beijing.
Mr. Clinton was so distraught by the public criticism of his China policy set off by the Christopher episode that he made no effort to support his Secretary of State in public and told reporters that he was "disappointed" with the trip.
Returning to Washington, Mr. Christopher immediately requested a meeting of senior national security and economic advisers in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, where he defended his trip and convinced the group that their backbiting had been "counterproductive." The President did not attend.
 
The Decision
Several Influences, Including Carter
 From the beginning of the process, senior Clinton officials had issued the same warning to Beijing: Don't think you can come in at the last minute with a few cosmetic concessions on human rights and win renewal of your low tariffs. But as the deadline approached, and it became clear that China was not going to move very much, the strategy shifted. China was told directly that a few, last-minute, face-saving concessions would do.
During Richard M. Nixon's funeral in late April, Anthony Lake, the President's national security adviser, and other officials met with Li Daoyu, China's Ambassador to the United States, in a cramped meeting room in the Nixon Library in Yorba Linda, Calif., and proposed that a secret emissary be sent to Beijing. Mr. Christopher recruited Michael H. Armacost, a former Ambassador to Japan, who was sent with a proposal for the Chinese leadership: If Beijing made enough minor gestures to cover the basics of the executive order, the Administration was prepared to drop the link between trade and human rights permanently.
China's leaders moved a bit. They invited an American technical team to discuss the jamming of Voice of America broadcasts, and promised to release an important democracy protester and give visas to the families of certain dissidents.
Since the Chinese had already agreed to abide by an understanding with Washington on banning exports of goods made with prison labor, the concession on the visas gave the Clinton team just enough to be able to say that the two "mandatory" conditions of the executive order had been met.
Mr. Christopher drafted his recommendation to the President as he flew home from the Middle East on May 19. He stated bluntly that there had been no "overall, significant progress" on the five other conditions in the executive order. In fact, he wrote, China's human rights record remained far below basic international standards.
Mr. Clinton rejected sweeping sanctions against China's military establishment after aides pointed out that it would be impossible to identify most items made at sites controlled by the military. He even wavered in the final days over whether it would be better to make a clean break with the past and impose no sanctions at all, an argument made by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the economic team. He accepted Mr. Christopher's recommendation to impose high tariffs on Chinese-made munitions, but ended the agonizing annual ritual linking human rights and trade.
 
How the U.S. Needs China
 Aides say several arguments tipped the balance for Mr. Clinton.
His experience as President had taught him something that he had not understood as Governor of Arkansas. It was not just how much America needed China for business reasons; it was how much the United States needed China for national security reasons -- to deal with North Korea, the United Nations Security Council and the spread of nuclear weapons.
Mr. Clinton was also moved by Mr. Bentsen's argument that when the United States acts unilaterally to impose sanctions against China because of human rights abuses, it has the worst of all worlds: the policy is not effective and markets are lost. Sanctions must be imposed by allies or not at all.
In the end, it may have been Mr. Carter who, in a series of long conversations, had the greatest impact on Mr. Clinton's thinking. As President, Mr. Carter had normalized relations with Beijing, and in a last-ditch effort to wrench more concessions from the Chinese, the Clinton Administration summoned him to Washington to help. In a meeting with Ambassador Li on May 19, Mr. Carter asked the Chinese to do two things -- set a date for talks with Tibet's leadership and release more political prisoners.
The Chinese did neither.
Mr. Carter later balked when Mr. Clinton asked him to head a human rights panel. With both business and human rights leaders with vastly different agendas sitting on the committee, it would end up doing embarrassingly little, the former President said.
In announcing the decision to extend China's trade benefits on Thursday, Mr. Clinton cited Mr. Carter's support, and told reporters, "We do not do this with rose-colored glasses on." He told his aides that he was counting on the Chinese to live up to their argument that taking threats out of the relationship will make it politically much easier for them to improve their human rights performance.
Mr. Lord drove that point home to Ambassador Li when he formally informed him of the President's decision. "You said this way was going to be more productive," the Assistant Secretary of State said. "Now prove it."

HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA FOILS EFFORTS TO HALT ITS NUCLEAR PLANS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 28

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's latest plan to stop North Korea's nuclear program appeared on the verge of collapse today as North Korea declared it would "never allow" outsiders to derail its nuclear plans, and officials from the International Atomic Energy Agency left the country saying their inspection efforts had failed.
North Korea's announcement came as reports here indicated that Pyongyang appears to be preparing to test a new medium-range missile over the Sea of Japan. 
 In the past, the Central Intelligence Agency has said North Korea's extensive missile program is part of an effort to prove that its nuclear arsenal could strike all the major cities in Japan and South Korea. The last test, a year ago, prompted considerable alarm here after the missile, which was not armed, landed near Japan's west coast.
Taken together, the latest events suggest that Clinton Administration officials may have been too optimistic last week when they expressed confidence that a new approach to North Korea -- including an offer of high-level talks about diplomatic and economic links that the North has long sought -- could break a yearlong impasse over keeping the Korean peninsula free of nuclear weapons.
"The fact of the matter is that we don't really understand what they are doing," an American official based in Asia who follows the situation closely said today. "They may be toying with us, or they may have suddenly decided that they have to save the nuclear program at all cost."
While the talks with North Korea over the last year and a half have often seemed an endless cycle of optimistic predictions followed by warnings of impending confrontation, they have never before seemed to carry so much urgency.
The International Atomic Energy Agency, which dispatched an inspection team to observe the removal of the fuel rods from the reactor at Yongbyon, says that North Korea is within days of obliterating evidence of how much, if any, nuclear fuel has been diverted to its weapons program. Washington has said that if the evidence is destroyed, it will have no choice but to seek economic sanctions, a measure Pyongyang has said it will consider an act of war.
With the collapse of the talks with the atomic energy agency, an arm of the United Nations, the Security Council was considering a weekend meeting to issue another warning to the North. But it is unclear whether China, which has veto power, will back the sanctions it has consistently opposed and what effect the Administration's decision to renew China's favorable trade status might have on China's position.
A call for sanctions would be a major reversal for the State Department, which just two weeks ago began a new effort to engage the North. Both South Korea and Washington dropped several conditions they had required North Korea to fulfill before another round of talks on diplomatic and economic ties. On Friday, Secretary of State Warren Christopher described that effort, along with the renewal of China's most-favored-nation trade status this week, as part of a strategy to press American interests throughout Asia without isolating important countries.
 
North Steams Ahead
 But from the start, many American officials have viewed the diplomatic engagement of the North as an exercise in self-deception that disregarded evidence that Pyongyang was speeding ahead with its nuclear program. That argument has gained credence as North Korea rushes to replaced more than 8,000 fuel rods, a process that ultimately could produce enough fuel for four or five nuclear weapons.
The rods can be reprocessed into bomb-grade plutonium, and North Korea has expended much of its scarce hard currency in recent years building a reprocessing center near the reactor.
The atomic energy agency has been insisting that North Korea comply with the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and permit the agency to track the fuel rods. It also wants to take samples from selected rods, which would reveal how much plutonium was extracted during the last reloading in 1989, when inspectors were barred.
So far North Korea has allowed the agency to observe part of the reloading from a distance, but has refused to allow the taking of samples, or "segregation" of about 300 specific rods for future tests.
Today the agency announced that officials sent to Pyongyang to negotiate had left after the North Koreans "rejected all I.A.E.A. proposals put forward with the aim of maintaining the I.A.E.A.'s ability to select, segregate and secure fuel rods for later measurements, so as to be able to verify the history of the reactor core." Two inspectors remain, but their activities appear to be severely restricted.
 
A Whisper of Flexibility?
 Referring to the agency's demand to mark and sample the rods, North Korea said today that "we can never allow this under the present condition, no matter what others say and what counteraction they may take," an apparent reference to economic sanctions. It said that stopping the refueling, as the agency has demanded, would result in "colossal economic losses and formidable danger."
Offering one hint of flexibility, North Korea said it might place all the rods under unspecified surveillance and suggested the agency might be allowed to measure them "when the nuclear problem is solved in a package deal in the future." However, the agency said last week that such a process would obscure critical rods under thousands of meaningless ones and would prevent the measurements from being taken.
On Friday the agency's director, Hans Blix, alarmed officials in Washington when he said North Korea was removing rods "at a very fast pace" and would begin, within days, to remove the crucial rods. If that occurred, he said, his agency "would not be in a position to verify, with any degree of confidence," that all nuclear material in North Korea was under the prescribed safeguards.
 
Uneasiness in Japan
 North Korea today accused the energy agency of taking "an arrogant stance" and insisted that Pyongyang enjoyed a "unique status" that enabled it to pick and choose what inspections it would undergo. It has claimed that status since it threatened in March 1993 to withdraw from the nonproliferation treaty.
Several Japanese newspapers reported today that the United States had passed along to Tokyo satellite reconnaissance suggesting that a test launch of the Rodong 1, North Korea's experimental missile, was imminent.
The satellite imagery, the reports said, showed mobile-launcher trucks operating near the coast, and North Korean ships staking out positions off the coast, perhaps to monitor a test launch. Last year Japan was taken by surprise when North Korea tested the missile and did not have enough tracking equipment focused on the launch to determine with any accuracy how far the missile had flown. The American warning was presumably intended to assure that both Japanese and American surveillance was ready to pick up a new launch.
The C.I.A. has said the Rodong 1 missile could be fitted to carry a nuclear warhead -- if the North Koreans have learned how to detonate one. North Korea has also been active in exporting missiles to the Middle East, especially to Iran. The Rodong 1 is believed to have a range of 600 or so miles, which would place Osaka, Japan's second-largest metropolitan area, in striking distance from the North Korean coast.
