HEADLINE: The Titans of Tint Make Their Picks

BYLINE: By DEBORAH L. JACOBS; Deborah L. Jacobs, an independent journalist based in New York, specializes in legal and business topics.

 BODY:
THE titans of tint came to town this month.
Dressed in hues they describe as firethorn, cornmeal and purple haze -- or just in suits of plain old gray flannel -- the men and women of the Color Marketing Group gathered at a New York hotel for their spring ritual of secret caucuses and swatch exchanges. Their mission: to determine which colors will be big sellers on the nation's clothing racks, showroom floors and supermarket shelves the next two years. 
 The group, based in Alexandria, Va., is a powerful trade association whose 1,400 members include in-house color marketers at Fortune 500 companies as well as color consultants who charge tens of thousands of dollars for a two-week assignment. But the group is just one part, albeit a highly organized one, of an elite industry of colorists. Their job is to help steer multimillion-dollar marketing decisions using colors and their psychological undertones. Specific goals range from building corporate images to improving sales.
The marketers say they forecast the popularity of colors rather than force their choices upon a helpless public. But just try to find a pink this year that isn't peachy. And good luck getting away from green -- and a weathered brick color called Smithsonian, named last year at a Color Marketing Group meeting in Washington, which also seems to be everywhere.
The 15 new colors identified in workshops during the Color Marketing Group's latest meeting will start to appear next year and, the group predicts, will flourish in 1996. Announced with fanfare at the close of the three-day gathering, the new colors include three shades of gray -- wet gray (like the sky on a cloudy day), highway (reminiscent of the interstate) and purple veil (lavender-tinted) -- and yellowy greens named plantain (like an unripe banana) and winter moss (evergreen with a yellow tinge).
Does this mean yet more of the earth tones that now permeate the stores? Yes, said Nada Napoletan Rutka, a color consultant in Pittsburgh who is president of the Color Marketing Group. During the affluent 1980's, colors in the marketplace were considerably brighter and changed quickly as conspicuous consumers snatched up new hues, said Ms. Rutka, who attended the recent Color Marketing Group meeting dressed in a suit of "purple passion" (or was it "plummet?").
Given today's economic uncertainties, consumers spend more cautiously and look for colors that don't shift drastically each year, she said. Concern about the environment is another influence on current and future palettes.
Using information gleaned at past Color Marketing Group meetings, Reebok International has toned down the trim of its sneakers, phasing out the bright reds, oranges and yellows of the 1980's, said Pamela Boucher, a trend and color forecaster at the company, which is based in Stoughton, Mass. To match the back-to-nature colors that people are wearing from the ankles up, the company is also offering shoes of "blackened green," Ms. Boucher said.
Color Marketing Group palettes are not models for exact imitation, in-house color advisers say. "Those colors are just directions," said Linda Trent, director of the color and design marketing department at the Sherwin-Williams Company, the Cleveland paint manufacturer. The company relies on them "to develop paint colors that are going to be responded to positively in the marketplace."
Still, industries that are tightly linked will strive to coordinate their palettes, so that car manufacturers, for instance, can find exterior paint that matches the upholstery inside their latest models.
While color "plays a role in creating momentary appeal," color marketers also address more long-term goals, said Anita Hersh, president of Lister Butler Inc., a New York consulting firm in corporate and brand identity. When color is part of a brand's identity, it "needs to be selected with longevity in mind," she said.
Since 1987, for example, the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, in Toledo, Ohio, has owned a trademark on the pink used in its insulation.
THEN there is the case of Best Western International Inc. As part of a continuing $1.3 billion effort to upgrade the quality of its hotels, Best Western considered the effect of color on the company's image. Among the conclusions of its two-year research effort: people associated the stark colors of the company's logo -- a bright yellow and black emblem -- with budget hotels, fast-food chains and convenience stores. The old signs were "telling the customer that we were lower quality than we really were," said William S. Watson, senior vice president for worldwide marketing at the Phoenix-based company. The new logo features refined golden letters against a deep blue background.
Fiskars Inc., which introduced its popular orange-handled scissors in the late 1960's, has stuck with the color in succeeding decades. Since the scissors were initially designed for industrial use, the company chose "safety orange" to make them visible in factories. During the decades since then, Fiskars had become "so synonymous with orange" that it hasn't made sense to change, said Sandra Cashman, a spokeswoman for the Wausau, Wis., company.
Fiskars' strategy defies the popular assumption that orange -- along with chartreuse and sulfur -- is one of the colors people most dislike. These are colors commonly associated with "bodily functions," said Leatrice Eiseman, a color consultant in Seabek, Wash., who has studied the psychology of color.
Blue is still America's favorite color, Ms. Eiseman said. And the current popularity of soft, pastel shades reflects the quest for calm during volatile social and economic times.
But color consultants caution against looking for a "magic bullet" to bolster sales. "Everyone has an opinion about what color means," Ms. Hersh said.
Indeed, the willingness of consumers to try new colors varies. The Cooper Marketing Group, a research company in Oak Park, Ill., has surveyed consumers the last several years and divided them into three color personalities. [See chart.]
Such studies suggest that marketers should keep their customers in mind when choosing palettes. Lands' End Inc., for instance, knows that many of its customers prefer brighter colors, rather than the dusty shades that now seem popular, said Andrea Sapon, a manager in the brand integrity group of the mail-order clothing company. The company has recently added some terra-cotta clothing, but kept the old standby reds and blues that its audience expects.
Color is more than an abstract preference for some consumers. "People who are fair skinned with dark hair don't look good in the new colors," said Lori Solinger, a television journalist in Providence, R.I., who reports on health and fitness. Limited by the options on a recent shopping trip, Ms. Solinger came home with a jacket of pale yellowy-green -- a shade color marketers might describe as "romaine" or "green tea." When Ms. Solinger wore the jacket to work, colleagues asked her whether she was feeling ill. She has since relegated the item to the back of her closet.
"Stores will lose revenues from people who cannot wear those colors," Ms. Solinger said. "Designers and forecasters are totally shutting them out."
Marketers say the new palettes offer something for everyone, but acknowledge that if the goods don't sell, the consequences will be costly.
Color is "like a seed," said James King, a researcher at DuPont Automotive in Troy, Mich., one of the largest producers of top-coat paint for cars. "It has to fall on receptive ground."
 
How They Choose the Colors of the Future
 MOST of the decisions by the Color Marketing Group are made in secret caucuses at the association's meetings, which are held in the spring to consider consumer colors and in the fall for industrial colors.
In advance of the meetings, participants mail in assessments of trends they perceive, along with color samples. Past submissions have included leaves, pieces of yarn, photos clipped from magazines and even an onion skin, said Nada Napoletan Rutka, president of the group.
Using such materials as a starting point, participants in the meetings divide into workshops to negotiate color directions. Each workshop then sends a representative to a final round of discussions from which the marketing group's palette of new colors emerges. These are the hues that the group formally predicts will be popular two years down the line.
People who go to the marketing group meetings (nearly 650 attended the most recent one) can also take away samples of colors developed during the previous year. To do that, they help themselves to snippings from giant spools of yarn.
During this month's meeting, Janice E. Rybinski, a manager for the 3M Company in Southfield, Mich., collected yarn in espresso, craft and manatee -- various shades of brown. "The public has to get used to these colors before they'll buy a $20,000 car," said Ms. Rybinski, who helps design the graphics used to sell cars.
Paper reproductions of the new palette will be available to Color Marketing Group members several months from now. The six-inch by two-inch packet fans out into samples of the 15 colors that were just picked as well as colors chosen at meetings during the last two years.
Nonmembers can buy the set of samples for $7,000. Why so expensive? "If you consider how many people have input into it," Ms. Rutka said, "$7,000 is cheap."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Noises Off at the Venerable Actors Studio

BYLINE: By WENDY SMITH; Wendy Smith is the author of "Real Life Drama: The
Group Theater and America, 1931-1940."

 BODY:
MENTION THE ACTORS studio, and the image is usually immediate: a shabby rehearsal room crammed with folding chairs in which the small and intense Lee Strasberg is guiding Robert De Niro or Ellen Burstyn or Al Pacino through a Method acting exercise that packs enough energy to blow a few fuses.
 But that is theatrical history. Strasberg died 12 years ago. Since that time, his baby, the Studio, has had to make its way in the world with an often contentious group of surrogate parents hovering around it. 
Patty Ewald, the Studio's executive director, sees the most recent controversy as instigated by "a group of old-timers who want to bomb the place and take it back to ground zero." But Rob Barron, who became a member in 1988 (like all Studio members, he was invited to join and pays no fees), said, "It doesn't matter who raised these questions or if Strasberg telegrammed us from the dead; the point is what the issues are."
 They are familiar at many nonprofit institutions, particularly those struggling to reinvent themselves after the demise of a strong leader. In the Studio's case, a major question involves its tradition as an almost cultish place in midtown Manhattan that imparts to a chosen few a special theatrical style. Must it grow beyond this to survive? If so, how does it change from a personalized shoestring operation to a formal program with a budget and steady income?
 An announcement last month that the Studio and the New School for Social Research are establishing a joint master of fine arts program seemed to answer the latter question, at least. Under this plan, the once-secretive Studio, founded in 1947 by Cheryl Crawford, Robert Lewis and Elia Kazan as a training ground for professional actors, will now impart to beginners the techniques developed by Strasberg and other acting teachers influenced by the Russian director Konstantin Stanislavsky.
 But further answers are not so easy for the dozen or so members of the executive committee that administers the Studio with its artistic director, Frank Corsaro (widely known as an innovative director of operas). And the last nine months are the proof.
 While negotiating with the New School, the executive commitee discovered that long-unresolved issues about the Studio's artistic goals and administration had flared into open debate. They became public when a letter from a disgruntled member turned up in the mailboxes of the general Studio membership (about 900 people), several journalists and various New School officials.
 The dispute centers on the efforts of the 69-year-old Mr. Corsaro -- backed by a majority of the executive committee and Ms. Ewald, the executive director -- to make the Studio less cloistered and to refashion it into a more dynamic, even businesslike organization.
 Since 1988, when Mr. Corsaro became its artistic director at the urging of Paul Newman, its president, the Actors Studio has added more than 100 new members, opened up its famous "sessions" to diverse stylistic approaches, presented workshop productions for invited audiences of nonmembers and revived -- at least tentatively -- the dream of a full-fledged Actors Studio Theater.
 These expanded ambitions have required money, as did the decision to professionalize the Studio administration by paying salaries to a few staff members, including Mr. Corsaro and Ms. Ewald, who each receive $75,000 annually. (The cash crunch became so acute in November 1993, however, that both Mr. Corsaro and Ms. Ewald deferred their salaries.) But the costs of these changes were not immediately felt because for several years Mr. Newman covered most expenses.
 Eventually, though, Mr. Newman, who declined to be interviewed for this article, and the executive committee agreed that the organization had to become more self-sufficient. In the early 1990's, the Studio found itself with a vastly expanded budget -- $450,000 this year -- that was no longer being provided by one source. The onerous task of raising funds, everyone agrees, now eats up too much of the executive committee's time.
 The Studio, in short, is a different institution from the one presided over by Lee Strasberg from 1951 until his death. Then it was a shrine to a single technique: the famous Method that Strasberg distilled from his understanding of Stanislavsky's teachings, an emotionally charged acting style made famous in the film and theater performances of such Studio members as Ms. Burstyn, Mr. De Niro, Mr. Newman, Mr. Pacino, Marlon Brando, James Dean, Harvey Keitel, Kim Stanley and Eli Wallach.
 Strasberg ran the organization virtually by fiat and did not draw a salary; there was hardly any administration, and most jobs were handled by unpaid volunteers. The Studio existed to enable its members to experiment and explore through scene work, called sessions in Studio terminology, that was commented on by Strasberg and their peers.
 To a vocal minority whose most outspoken advocate, the actress Vivian Nathan, is an executive committee member, that is the way the Studio should remain. While Mr. Corsaro insists that "the organization must move forward or die," Ms. Nathan retorts that the "business can be run as simply or as complicatedly as we make it." In a "statement of conscience" delivered to the executive committee last September, she bemoaned what she called declining artistic standards at the Studio and said a swollen administration was consuming its funds.
 By the time a general membership meeting was held in New York in January, Ms. Nathan's statement (and an equally disgruntled letter from members of the Studio's Los Angeles branch) had been widely disseminated. The tumultuous meeting, described by an observer as "one of the best pieces of live theater we've had in years," revealed that finances and administration have become flashpoints for a wider unease about the Studio's direction and administration.
 Jacqueline Knapp, who organized a celebrity auction for the Studio last September that netted about $160,000, was one of several members distressed by the news that the money had been spent. "Evidently, the Studio's budget is very high," she said, "which concerns a lot of people. How many benefits can you do to keep the Studio growing?"
 That's where the New School comes in. On April 6, the New School and the Studio announced that this fall (pending approval by the New York State Department of Education) they would begin a three-year master of fine arts program in theater arts, administered by and offered at the New School but with a curriculum created and taught by Studio members. Selected students will be permitted to attend Tuesday and Friday sessions at the Studio, which is still in its original home, a former church on West 44th Street.
 Executive committee members, like the director Arthur Penn, are frank about the economic imperatives behind the New School program. Without it, he says, "the Actors Studio is, I'm afraid, struggling in a fairly terminal illness. The financial handwriting is on the wall; to succeed and survive, smaller cultural organizations have to affiliate."
 Those who support the teaching idea hope it will give the Studio a higher profile. "I think that finally the Studio will become a community asset," Mr. Corsaro said. James Lipton, an executive committee member and the curriculum's principal creator, added: "Many of our members already teach, but they're often lone voices within their departments for the Studio's policy of dealing with all aspects of theater as a unified process with a guiding central methodology."
 The exact nature of that methodology, however, is not as clear as it was when the Studio was ruled by Strasberg's iron hand. The fierce debates of recent months suggest that the changes that have taken place since his death have created uncertainty about the Studio's -- and Mr. Corsaro's -- focus.
 At the heart of the Actors Studio stand the legendary Tuesday and Friday sessions. In Strasberg's day both were led by the artistic director; now the Tuesday sessions are run by a rotating roster of moderators that includes Ms. Burstyn, Ms. Nathan, Lee Grant and Estelle Parsons, while Mr. Corsaro moderates on Fridays. "Frank, being a director, has a viewpoint more toward finished performance," said Ms. Burstyn, who succeeded Strasberg as artistic director but resigned in 1988 to devote more time to her career. "The Tuesday moderator's focus is more on the acting instrument. It's like a violinist running scales and working on fingering on Tuesday, performing a whole piece on Friday."
 Purists regard Mr. Corsaro's acting sessions with suspicion, believing that the Studio's basic function as a place for actors to deepen their craft is abrogated when the emphasis is on producing polished work. Mr. Corsaro makes it clear that he wants the Studio work to evolve toward a finished product; his hope is to revive the Actors Studio Theater, which presented several professional productions in the early 1960's.
 "That is at the heart of what I'm trying to do," he said. "The whole Stanislavsky system evolved out of having a theater. It wasn't a hothouse bloom. Eventually, the educative and theatrical elements must be fused to keep the Studio in the public eye."
 THESE DAYS, THE FRIDAY sessions are attended by a noticeably younger group of members, who are undoubtedly more receptive to Mr. Corsaro's philosophy. They do not have the opportunities their elders did to perform regularly in the commercial theater. "People can't just train; they need a place to put their training," said Barry Primus, a director and West Coast member. "That's why today we have to supply not just the training but the theater itself."
 When Mr. Corsaro speaks about the need for such a theater, he can be eloquent. "We have a treasure in our work that we must not be afraid to make full use of," he said. "We should be the National Theater of the United States, not its best-kept secret." For his part, Mr. Corsaro is getting mixed reviews. Comments by a range of Studio members indicate that many feel he does not spend enough time at the Studio and that even when he is there his mind sometimes seems to be elsewhere.
 "I have great admiration for Frank," said one member, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But it takes a lot to get him to pay attention." Another member said: "When I first came to the Studio I was very pro-Frank; I think he breathed a lot of life into the place. But if, in the middle of a session, somebody said, 'Hey, Frank, the Toronto Opera just called; they want you to go up there this afternoon and start directing "La Boheme," ' he would stop in mid-sentence and be out the door."
 Mr. Corsaro is aware of the criticisms: "When I made the agreement with the Actors Studio, I warned them that it was sprung on me rather suddenly and that I had contractual commitments; in opera you're booked several years ahead. However, I made sure that whatever opera I did was either in New York or at a time when I wasn't needed at the Studio. I have never on any occasion neglected my duties there."
 Contention is nothing new at the Actors Studio, where memories are long and the past weighs heavily on the present. Its leaders and members are aware that while the Method remains the most popularly known acting style in the world, the Studio is no longer the mecca it was, partly because its basic technique is available elsewhere.
 "I don't think the Studio means the same thing in the world today," says Michael Howard, one of many Strasberg-trained actors who now teach privately. "But it had to change; it was so much a matter of Lee's point of view. I think Frank is searching for a way to make the Studio viable and useful."
 The valuable thing, said Estelle Parsons, "is to have a place to do the work. It was never that someone was going to bring you a message from God."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 29, 1994, Sunday

HEADLINE: Pedestrian Safety Needs a Higher Priority

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Prof. James Donald Wynne, an original member of the faculty of York College in Jamaica, Queens, was killed while crossing the busy boulevard that cuts through the York campus by a car with a suspended driver at the wheel (news article, May 19). His death was a tragedy, more so because the site was long known as dangerous. 
 By 1991, the New York City Department of Transportation had given the site an 83 rating, on a scale of 0 to 100, with 100 as the most dangerous. The city's inspectors should then have inspected the site and recommended a traffic light, but with only five inspectors for the entire city -- as opposed to 25 in 1991 -- they still have not got around to it. With their current workload, they do not often visit sites with ratings lower than 90.
We would like to see a higher priority for pedestrian safety. Not only would lives be saved, but the economic vitality of New York would also benefit. We hope the city will inspect sites with a rating of 75 and higher, make sure there is adequate staff to follow through on recommendations by inspectors and install lights (or other appropriate safety measures) within two years of a first complaint.
It is odd, and troubling, that 2,200 intersections in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx will have their traffic signals replaced by new computerized signals to increase traffic flow at a cost of $5.8 million over four years, yet the city can manage to install only 60 lights a year for reasons of safety.
But, that much said, it should also be noted that pedestrians still have the legal right of way within crosswalks.
 
RANDY WADE
Director, Walk New York
New York, May 20, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Turnover in Congress Won't Match That of 1874

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I agree entirely with the substance of "Self-Limiting Terms in Congress" (editorial, May 16). Why impose mechanical term limits when retirements have swelled, and elections can give voters the last word? 
 But you include a piece of supposed fact that has been floating around the press for some little while -- that 183 incumbents lost their seats in 1874, following the "pay grab" of 1873, in which, as you state, "Congress voted to give itself a big pay raise and made it retroactive for two years."
The total membership of the House was then only 292, which would mean that some 63 percent of the total membership turned over. That kind of outcome lies at the extreme edge of legislative elections in any country or any time -- as, for example, the 1993 elections in Canada or 1994 in Italy. In no American case was turnover so large, not even 1854, when the explosive forces of the coming Civil War blew the party system apart.
Some may think this an exercise in pedantry, but one aspect of professional work in any field is to get rid of bad data when they appear. The number of incumbents actually defeated for re-election in 1874 was not 183, but 52: 51 Republicans, 1 Democrat.
For the Republicans, 1874 was the worst defeat in the party's 20-year history. George Templeton Strong, that prominent New Yorker of his day, observed in his diary that it was "the Waterloo or Sedan of the Republican Party," a rout. Strong's judgment about the causes of this defeat stressed (1) reaction to corruption and scandals in Washington; (2) economic slump, and (3) Southern fatigue with the excesses of Reconstruction. This is how subsequent historians have also viewed the matter.
Nowhere does Strong mention the pay grab as an issue, though it might have been subsumed under general public fed-upness with corruption and scandals in Washington. Strong's analysis, like that of his contemporaries and later historians, is cast in purely partisan terms. In those days, incumbency had zero effect on the outcome of Congressional elections. This effect remained negligible until the 1950's, when the party system began showing signs of unraveling.
In 1874, all incumbents of both parties contested only 153 of the 292 House seats, 30 fewer than the supposed number of those defeated. This share of seats contested by incumbents, little more than half the total, was typical for that period. There were no primaries then, so there's no way of getting a picture of how many incumbents might have been forced out for renomination by their party's convention because of the pay grab (or any other) issue. That the 1874 result was so typical implies there were few, if any, such cases.
Then as now, most of the time most of this turnover did not involve shifting of the seat from one party to another. Political Waterloos don't happen in just any election -- and 16
years more had to go by before the next major partisan upheaval.
Since the 1874 partisan turnover was abnormal for its era, the House that met in December 1875 had only 101 surviving incumbents, scarcely more than one-third of the total. Despite the accelerated retirement rates of 1992 and 1994, nothing of the sort seems conceivable in the wake of this year's election.
But none of this detracts from the valid argument you make on term limits.
 
WALTER DEAN BURNHAM
Austin, Tex., May 20, 1994
 
The writer holds the Frank C. Erwin Jr. Centennial Chair in Government, University of Texas.

HEADLINE: Tyranny of the Minority

BYLINE: By Arthur S. Flemming and Ray Marshall; Arthur S. Flemming, a Republican, is a former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Ray Marshall, a Democrat, is a former Secretary of Labor.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Many Americans think the primary cause of gridlock in Congress is the inability of a majority to agree on action. The real problem is more basic. In the Senate, majority rule is becoming the exception rather than the rule.
Week after week, we see as many as 59 of the 100 senators ready to act on legislation -- to pass or defeat it. But Senate rules permit a minority of 41 or fewer to filibuster -- to prevent the majority from voting at all. To stop a filibuster, 60 votes are needed. A minority -- sometimes one senator -- can demand ransom in exchange for providing the 60th vote; often, the price is either watered-down legislation or "pork." Today, once a filibuster is announced -- no speeches are necessary -- the Senate takes up other business until deals can be struck for the 60 votes. 
 The threat of a filibuster affects nearly every issue, forcing dilution and deal-making even before bills are introduced. On May 17, it led to the Government's giveaway sale of Nevada land containing gold worth $10 billion to a Canadian mining company for only $9,765.
This year in an 11-day period filibusters delayed or weakened the Federal Workforce Restructuring Act, National Competitiveness Act and the Goals 2000 education bill. In 1993, they blocked, delayed or altered majority action on the Brady gun control bill and bills dealing with jobs (economic stimulus), national service, voter registration, and environmental and campaign finance reforms.
The Framers wrote a Constitution that protected minorities in many ways, but they insisted on majority rule in Congress. As Alexander Hamilton explained in "The Federalist": "If the majority, in order that something may be done, must conform to the views of the minority, the smaller number will overrule the greater. Hence, tedious delays; continual negotiation and intrigue; contemptible compromises of the public good."
Even after senators discovered they could filibuster to circumvent the intent of the Constitution, most of them respected the distinction between opposing legislation and obstructing democracy, and reserved their filibusters for extraordinary matters.
Since 1990, senators have had to attempt to end filibusters 89 times -- an average of 22 times a year -- compared to fewer than one attempt a year from 1917 through 1967 and just over 10 a year from 1968 to 1989.
Today's filibuster epidemic means that in effect the Senate needs nearly as many votes to pass legislation (60) as it does to override a veto, enact a constitutional amendment or impeach a President (67).
Americans may differ over the details of health care reform, how to combat violence and protect the environment and strengthen families. But few differ on respect for that bedrock principle of democracy, majority rule.
As advisory committee members of Action, Not Gridlock!, a new nonpartisan organization concerned with effective democracy, we urge Democrats and Republicans, conservatives and liberals to tell all senators to respect majority rule and to give the Senate back its right to vote.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Searching Its Soul: The U.S. Catholic Church -- Second of four articles.;
Wellspring of Priests Dries Up, Changing Much of Parish Life

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOLEDO, Ohio

 BODY:
To a traditional Roman Catholic, Sunday at St. Mary of the Assumption parish would come as a shock.
The morning services are mostly run by Sister Virginia Welsh, who greets the worshipers, directs the choir and offers "reflections" in lieu of the sermon that under Vatican rules she is not allowed to preach. On hand to say the Mass itself is an elderly priest who divides his time between this parish and another. 
 Later, as Sister Welsh chats with the congregation, hatches plans for the parish school and presents prospective church members at a regional ceremony, she leaves no doubt that she is the parish leader, and a popular one.
Yet this is no renegade group: Sister Welsh, 45, was appointed to leadership of this struggling inner-city parish by the Toledo bishop. Today, even as theorists debate the future of the Roman Catholic Church, a deepening shortage of priests is already forcing a transformation of Catholic life in the United States, among other things handing vast new responsibilities to women.
The scarcity of priests, who for centuries have been the personification of Catholicism, is also confronting church leaders with a serious dilemma. Either the church must relax the centuries-old rules that limit priesthood to celibate men -- which the Vatican shows no sign of doing -- or it must accept a decline in regular access to the sacred rites that are the soul of the Catholic faith, but can be carried out only by the ordained.
"The Catholic Church cannot reproduce a celibate male clergy," said Richard A. Schoenherr, a sociologist and former priest at the University of Wisconsin who has documented the emerging shortage. "This is a major event in its history, with far-reaching consequences."
Between resignations of unhappy priests and a drastic drop in new recruits, the priesthood is aging and shrinking. Over the 30 years from 1975 to 2005, the number of priests in relation to Catholics in the United States is expected to fall by half, to one priest for every 2,200, leaving far too few to perform all their time-honored functions.
Already, more than 10 percent of the 20,000 parishes in the United States, mainly in rural and inner-city areas, do not have a resident pastor, instead sharing increasingly weary priests with other congregations. Many large parishes that once had several priests who not only said Mass but also ran the schools, visited the sick and worked with youth may now have just one or two aging priests, their customary duties increasingly filled by lay people if at all.
More than 300 parishes around the country, including St. Mary's in Toledo, are led by "pastoral administrators," most of them sisters, some of them married women or married men who increasingly are studying to become permanent deacons. These parish leaders perform nearly all the tasks once done by priests except for the rites that are the spiritual backbone of Catholicism, like absolving sin, anointing the sick and dying and especially celebrating the eucharist, the memorial of the Last Supper that according to church teaching makes Jesus truly present in the bread and wine at Mass.
In such parishes, the sacraments are usually performed by part-time or "circuit-rider" priests who lack the intimate ties to the community once so characteristic of parish life. Alternately, lay leaders lead communion services distributing bread already consecrated by a priest, a truncated ritual that lacks the spiritual meaning of a full Mass.
Many Catholics see the infusion of lay people into administrative and pastoral functions as invigorating. But the changes are altering the texture of Catholic life and raising new questions about the future of the church.
"It creates a strain," said the Rev. Philip J. Murnion, director of the National Pastoral Life Center in New York. "It's the Catholic style for there to be a connection between leading a parish in its general work and leading a parish in its worship."
A global phenomenon, the deepening scarcity of priests is also causing more Catholics to question the rules, set by the Vatican, that restrict ordination to celibate men. A majority of American priests and church members oppose the ban on marriage, surveys show, and even some bishops have publicly questioned the ban, which scholars argue is rooted more in tradition than religious doctrine. The priest shortage is also adding fuel to calls for ordaining women, a change also supported by a majority of Catholics.
But the Vatican has held fast, calling for prayer and stronger efforts to recruit celibate priests. And so the American church is improvising, experimenting with new roles for lay people and the more thinly spread priests alike, cautiously watching as parish life changes.
 
The Decline
The Workers Become Few
 The dwindling supply of priests reflects deep changes both inside and outside the church. The Second Vatican Council that ended in 1965, which affirmed that married people as well as the celibate could attain holiness, led to an unanticipated exodus of younger priests. Resignations, especially over the issue of celibacy, continue to plague the church.
More significantly, the supply of new recruits has drastically shrunk. Long gone are the days when good Catholic families expected to give a son to the priesthood: from 1966 to 1993 the number of students in seminaries, high school through graduate level, fell by 85 percent, to 6,244 from 42,767, according to data collected by Georgetown University. Graduate theology students, in the final stages of preparation for ordainment, fell to 3,416 from 8,325, and their average age rose as a higher proportion of men who had finished college and even worked in secular jobs decided to take vows.
The Rev. William Kubacki of the Toledo diocese, whose job is to find and nurture recruits, has worked strenuously to find just two or three candidates a year. The No. 1 constraint, he said, is the difficulty many men have today with the notion of such a permanent, total commitment; concern about celibacy is close behind. In addition, he said, far fewer parents than in the past actively encourage their sons to enter religious life. "To me it's a whole sense of values," he said.
Others say the lurid sex-abuse scandals of recent years must also be taking a toll. "People aren't going to encourage young men to become priests when it's got such a taint," Dr. Schoenherr said.
Church leaders are concerned about the quality as well as the quantity of the next generation of priests, who will face more daunting tasks than ever. Dean Hoge, a professor of sociology at Catholic University, said seminaries were being forced to relax their admissions standards. He said he sensed a growing restlessness with the quality of leadership among younger priests, who are increasingly required to preside over large parishes and lay staffs.
"The job is tougher than it used to be and the expectations are higher than ever," he said. "The laity are educated people now, and they want inspiring, capable leadership."
 
The Changes
Women in Charge, Up to a Point
 The new face of Catholicism is visible in northern Ohio, in the traditional Catholic heartland. The diocese of Toledo includes 163 parishes, many of them in small towns and rural areas, serving 325,000 Catholics. Two hundred priests are active today, not enough to meet the needs, and the diocese already knows there will be 50 fewer in just six years.
Bishop James R. Hoffman says he is determined to keep parishes going whenever feasible, but doing so has required some creativity. Already, more than 30 parishes in the diocese are served by visiting priests. Another six, including St. Mary of the Assumption in Toledo, have full-time nonordained leaders like Sister Welsh. In the coming year, as 10 to 12 parishes lose priests to retirement, these new models will spread.
St. Mary's was once the thriving hub of a German community, with 800 people attending Sunday Mass. That population has largely moved to the suburbs, and the church now serves an ethnically mixed membership of about 600, with perhaps 220 attending each Sunday. For sacramental purposes, this and a nearby church, also run by a sister, share the Rev. James O'Reilly, a 67-year-old Jesuit who had previously worked in education and as a missionary.
"You see a crumbling of the structures we once had because of the shortage of priests," said Father O'Reilly, who praised Sister Welsh for her energetic leadership. "It's change or die."
Parish members say that while a few people were disturbed when Sister Welsh took over four years ago, most have been pleased. "I think we were ready for a change," said Ellen McComis, whose family has attended St. Mary's for five generations. Arthur and Ellen Jones, parishioners for 20 years who moved across town but still drive back to St. Mary's, were effusive in their praise. "She does a fine homily," Mr. Jones said.
Sister Welsh, who calls herself middle of the road on church traditions, knew early on that she wanted a religious life, attending a convent high school before joining the Franciscan order in Tiffin, Ohio. "I never dreamed I'd be leading a parish," she said; she had expected to end up teaching school. But as opportunities opened, she began doing pastoral work, obtained a master's degree in pastoral ministry from Loyola University in Chicago and, she believes, found her true calling.
"At this point we're able to meet the needs of the people pretty well," she said of St. Mary's unusual structure. Still, she can hardly conceal the frustrations caused by theological boundaries.
"The person leading the parish in every other way should preside at the great prayer on Sunday," she said. "But I can't."
She nurtures potential new members of the church, but she cannot preside over their baptism. She counsels members on their personal problems, but cannot absolve them in confession. When a member dies she counsels the family and may lead a funeral prayer, but she cannot perform full rites.
"We pastor the people, but the high point, the privileged point, is to be able to call the presence of Jesus among us through the eucharist," Sister Welsh said. "It's at that point that we have to step aside for someone else.
"The person who knows the community best is not the person leading the prayer."
 
The Threat
When Practical Dilutes Mystical
 Some Catholics welcome the emerging arrangements, arguing that they elicit more active and democratic participation in the church by its members. Ruth Wallace, a professor of sociology at Georgetown University who has studied parishes around the country run by women, said, "I came away thinking that I was looking at the Catholic Church of the future, and I was inspired by it."
But theologians worry about a diminishment of Catholicism as priests become less available, and as a gap opens between management of parish life and sacred functions. Communion services using previously consecrated bread, for example, while officially approved as a stopgap, lack the resonance of a full Mass because nonpriests cannot ceremonially recite the words of Christ as he broke bread and drank wine at the Last Supper ("This is my body. . . . This is my blood. . . .").
"You miss the sense of participation across time with the action of Christ at the Last Supper," Father Murnion said. "You miss the transformation of the elements into the presence of Christ among us."
Catholicism is not just about words and prayer, he noted, but also about a mystical physical bond with Christ. "The bread and wine, the water we pour, the oil we anoint people with -- these are the physical reality, how Christ works through people," he said. "It's a complicated symbolic thing that's lost. It's not rational."
To many Catholics, the threat to essential rites has become a powerful argument for allowing married men and women into the priesthood. If the church maintains current restrictions, said Dr. Schoenherr, who left the priesthood himself because of the marriage ban, a sacred experience "that is uniquely Catholic will be gradually leached out of the system." He predicts that over the coming decade or two the building tensions, theological and economic, will force the Vatican to relax the rules.
Others are less sure of that. Conservatives maintain that ordaining married men would be too drastic a departure from the tradition of the Roman church. And they argue that by tradition and also by Scripture, women cannot take on the priest's role as representative of Jesus at Mass.
But all agree that the decline in the priesthood is raising fundamental questions that must be confronted. "What is at stake is not just whether we'll have more priests, or women and married priests, but what is the mission for the priesthood," Father Murnion said. "I think we're struggling with what's the mission of the church at the end of the 20th century, and what is the priest's role in that."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1856 words

HEADLINE: WEIGHING OPTIONS, U.S. AIDES ASSESS INVASION OF HAITI

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
United States intelligence officials have concluded that an American-led invasion to restore the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power in Haiti would succeed easily. But they warn that it would not bring a quick end to the turmoil and violence that have swept the country, and that an international force to maintain order could be needed there for years.
The view, which represents a broad consensus among intelligence agencies and some of Father Aristide's staunchest supporters, comes as the Clinton Administration is struggling to develop a plan both to return the deposed President and to create conditions so he can govern peacefully. 
 While President Clinton is relying on economic sanctions to persuade Haiti's military leaders to leave, he has pointedly refused to rule out military force if sanctions fail.
Pentagon officials are confident that Haiti's minimally equipped 7,500-man armed forces could easily be swept aside. And a force of 650 marines -- the kind of force officials said might serve as an invasion vanguard -- was sent for training to Guantanamo Bay last week.
Whether Mr. Clinton uses diplomacy or force to return the Haitian President to power, he faces the difficult task of trying to rebuild Haiti's military and political institutions while avoiding an open-ended commitment of American troops. Determined not to repeat the mistakes of Somalia, Administration officials say Washington will not launch any military operation in Haiti without a firm plan for disengagement.
"The view of the intelligence community is unambiguous that restoring Aristide through military force would be a simple proposition, but withdrawing international forces quickly after that step would be extremely unlikely," a senior intelligence official said. Even in the case of a diplomatic solution, he said, "maintaining order represents a long-term proposition."
So far, the Administration's plan for keeping the peace in Haiti after Father Aristide's return is sketchy.
Senior Administration officials said Washington saw a need for a peacekeeping force of several thousand to help protect Father Aristide, retrain the Haitian military and keep order through December 1995, the end of Father Aristide's term.
But the United States and its allies have not yet agreed on the exact size and duties of the peacekeeping force, on the extent of the American role or how long the force would need to stay.
Since allies are being told that the peacekeeping force would be sent in after a diplomatic solution, it is unclear which countries, if any, would be willing to send troops if Father Aristide were returned through military action.
In addition, the United States and its allies are struggling to define some of the fundamental tasks they would face after Father Aristide's return.
At a recent meeting in Ottawa, for example, Defense Secretary William J. Perry told his Canadian counterpart that deep-seated opposition to Father Aristide extends into the lower ranks of the Haitian military. But the Canadians said the depth of the problem might not be so bad, suggesting more intelligence on the Haitian military might be needed.
Struggling to devise a way to turn the daunting task of maintaining security over to the Haitians, the two sides discussed a plan to train and equip Haitian expatriates from Montreal and New York to form the nucleus of a new Haitian police force.
"he problem is not getting in," one Pentagon-based general said. "It is getting out."
 
Restoring Aristide: An Urgent Situation
 In interviews and speeches in recent weeks, President Clinton and his top aides have described the situation in Haiti as a serious threat to American security, implying that Father Aristide, who was elected in December 1990 with two-thirds of the vote, needed to be restored to power in a matter of months. Mr. Clinton has cited the threat of a surge in refugees trying to come here, and has said Haiti is used as a staging area for drug shipments to the United States.
Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, said in an interview: "It is our intention to send a very clear signal to the military and police leadership in Port-au-Prince that this situation is urgent, and at the end of the day, they'e going to be gone, and that the end of the day is not that far off." To that end, the Administration has pushed for tougher and more rigorously enforced economic sanctions.
William H. Gray 3d, the Administration's new special envoy for Haiti, said it was far too soon to conclude that sanctions would not be effective since they had only recently been put into effect and the United States was pressing the Dominican Republic to seal its border with Haiti.
"The sanctions are at a level totally different than in the past," Mr. Gray said. "What we've really got to do is restore democracy. Along with that, we have to insure that the military and police are compatible with democratic values. And we've got to bring economic growth and the prospect of hope. All three have to be done together."
But top Bush Administration officials contend that the economic sanctions will backfire by raising the general level of misery in Haiti, the poorest county in the hemisphere, unleashing a new flood of refugees and putting pressure on the Administration to take military action.
Even some Administration officials are skeptical that sanctions will work in the months that Washington seems to have alloted for the military rulers to be removed.
"We have less of a chance of achieving a negotiated outcome than at any time since Aristide was overthrown," said a State Department official. "It's by a process of subtraction that we're getting to the military option."
By this view, a solution will be found only when it is clear to Haiti's military that the United States is on the verge of an invasion, or through military intervention itself.
Senior Administration officials said invading Haiti would be one of the easier American military operations in years.
Haiti's military is ill equipped and poorly trained, they say, armed with sufficient firepower to terrorize the civilian population but not enough to pose serious resistance to an American invasion.
"The system that runs Haiti now runs it through what they're pleased to call the Haitian military, but it is not a military in the normal sense of the word," a senior Administration official said. "It's more like a combination of an old-fashioned political machine and the Mafia."
According to Administration officials, the Haitian armed forces consist of about 7,500 to 7,700 men. About half of the force, including about 1,300 police officers, are stationed in the capital, Port-au-Prince. The military's 925-member officer corps offers only broad guidance to the enlisted ranks, which have an unusual degree of autonomy to decide what operations they will join.
The military is equipped with six American-made lightly armored vehicles, which are rolled out occasionally for effect, but not all are in working order.
The army has four or five 105-millimeter artillery pieces and a similar number of 75-millimeter guns. But the Haitian troops do not train with them and they were last seen fired this month at the inauguration of the military-backed "provisional president," Emil Jonassaint. "They are the kind of things you would see on the lawn of an American Legion post," a Pentagon official said.
The Haitian air force consists of two Italian training aircraft and some cargo planes, and the navy consists of four patrol boats. "On a good day, two work," the Pentagon official said.
To hold down American casualties, an invasion would probably involve a division's worth of troops -- some 15,000 soldiers -- and could feature special operations forces, Army Rangers, Army airborne units and marines.
Military experts said American forces would seize the airport and ports and take over Government buildings and communications centers.
Unlike Somalia, which was awash in arms and run by violent, closely-knit clans, the Haitian military is not expected to offer much resistance. One Administration official said its response would be "surrender and dispersal."
But if Haiti is not Somalia, neither is it Panama or Grenada, where the United States mounted lightning invasions, installed friendly governments and then quickly withdrew.
 
Long-Term Problem: And After Aristide?
 The real problem, officials say, would be what to do after Father Aristide was installed. It is not that maintaining order and trying to build Haiti's institutions are impossible, intelligence officials say, but that the United States and its allies must go in with their eyes open and be prepared for the long haul.
To build a peacekeeping force, the Administration is engaged in high-level consultations.
Some options under consideration would keep the American role to transport and logistics, while drawing on Canadian, Argentine and French-speaking forces from African nations like Senegal and the Ivory Coast. Among the 1.7 million members of the American military, there are only 124 troops who speak Creole, the language most Haitians speak.
Administration officials tick off several potentially vexing scenarios if Father Aristide is returned: If he and the Haitian Parliament renew their confrontation, who should peacekeepers support? If crowds loyal to Father Aristide try to retaliate against military or police officials, should the peacekeepers prevent it? What if Father Aristide tells the force to leave after a few weeks? Can the force prevent foes from trying to kill the Haitian leader?
Much, officials say, will depend on Father Aristide's political skills.
Pentagon officials, in particular, worry about what they see as deep-seated resistance within the Haitian military to Father Aristide.
"Both sides would be afraid of each other," a Pentagon official said. "There are no viable institutions that make this work. There's the potential for mob violence, chaos and disorder."
Representative James L. Oberstar, a Minnesota Democrat who serves on the House Foreign Affairs Western Hemisphere subcommittee and is a strong supporter of Father Aristide, disputed the Pentagon's view of the depth of the opposition.
Mr. Oberstar, who taught Enlish to Haitian troops from 1959 to 1962, said many of the enlisted force and most of the public would welcome the restoration of Father Aristide and the intervention of American troops.
But even Mr. Oberstar said that the Haitian military would have to be rebuilt and that peacekeeping troops would need to stay three to five years.
And if the Administration is ambivalent about the military option, so is the man they want to return to power. "If I ask for military intervention, I will be impeached by my Constitution," Father Aristide said in an interview with the Rev. Jesse Jackson on CNN on May 7.
When pressed if he would support removing the military under any conditions, Father Aristide, said: "We should stop those thugs. It's possible to remove them. It's a question of having the political will to do that."

HEADLINE: For High School Graduates, A Job Market of Dead Ends

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
For hundreds of thousands of people graduating from high school this spring, the diploma is a one-way ticket to low-paying, part-time jobs at best.
Most graduates who are planning to go straight to work are offered the same low wages, the same part-time hours and the same assignments in the restaurants, supermarkets, motels and gasoline stations where they worked in after-school jobs they held as students. 
 And they might consider themselves lucky. In 1993, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports, nearly a quarter of high school graduates who did not go on to college and wanted jobs were still unemployed in October, compared with 21 percent of each year's new graduates in the 1980's and 16 percent in the 1970's. For the first time, unemployment grew among graduates while the economy was growing.
"The market is fraught with dead ends," said Alison Bernstein, the head of education programs at the Ford Foundation. "Unless they have certain kinds of skills, they can get locked on a path that doesn't take them anywhere. They could be among the working poor very early."
Not long ago, a graduate of Craigmont High and Middle School in Memphis could walk from graduation into the factory of International Harvester or Firestone Tire and Rubber and start earning real money.
"If you could hit a nail every time one went by on an assembly line," Ada Jane Walters, the principal, said, "you got a job that in today's market would pay $12 or $13 an hour."
But Harvester and Firestone, like many other manufacturers, have flown, leaving behind fast-growing, lower-wage industries. Today, Federal Express, the biggest employer in Memphis, offers high school graduates 20-hour-a-week jobs for $8 an hour. "We try to be very up front about it," said Chuck W. Thomson, a vice president for personnel at Federal Express. "We tell them they should take this job with the understanding that it will be part time indefinitely."
Kroger supermarkets here offer $4.50 an hour for entry-level jobs like stock clerks. Jack Overbrook, the head of personnel, said promotion to full time and a wage of $7 or $8 "could take three or four years."
So it goes around the nation.
Adjusted for inflation, the starting pay of people with at least four-year college degrees has slipped a bit in two decades, said Lawrence Mishel, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. But in the same period, wages have plunged 25 percent to 30 percent for men with only high school diplomas and 15 percent to 18 percent for women in that category.
The nation's economy is producing two million new jobs a year, but they come with wages typically below $8 an hour, or about $16,000 a year, and without fringe benefits, much opportunity for promotion or promises that the jobs will last.
Many students have taken the statistics to heart by going to college and vocational schools. The Labor Department said on May 20 that 63 percent of last year's 2.3 million high school graduates had entered two- or four-year colleges by October, compared with 50 percent in 1980. Labor experts say the wisest young people persevere in looking for jobs and seek a special edge by cultivating skills that better-paying employers covet.
But even college degrees, good attitudes and skills do not guarantee a decent job. The growth of low-paid, low-skilled jobs is outpacing the growth of more-skilled jobs in fields like health care and data processing.
At the same time, industry is shedding layers of middle-management jobs held by college graduates, creating an additional challenge for high school graduates: People with college degrees have invaded their blue-collar turf. As a result, of last year's 736,000 new high school graduates who joined the labor force a year ago, 24 percent -- nearly four times the rate for all workers -- were still unemployed in October.
 
Aware of the Realities
 Students at Craigmont, a three-story yellow brick building on the working-class fringe of north Memphis, are well aware of the world that awaits them.
Stephen Sigman, a senior and a part-time waiter at a Shoney's restaurant, seems to be the kind of worker that employers crave. "You learn teamwork," he said of his job. "How to pace yourself. Take responsibility. If you slack off, you get complaints."
He wants to go to college, but, he said, a D-plus average and serious dyslexia will hold him back at least a year or two while he spends $60 a week from his wages for tutoring.
"I don't want to be a bottom man," he said. "I want to be something you can look up to. But a lot of people come out of college with no place to go. Me and my friends, that's the biggest fear that teen-agers have."
Craigmont, the city's largest public school with 1,928 students in grades 7 through 12, resembles many urban schools outside the impoverished cores of bigger cities like New York and Chicago. Thirty-six percent of the students are black, and most others are white. Eighteen percent are poor enough to qualify for free lunches.
Dr. Walters, the principal, said Craigmont was like most other high schools in that it had done little to refine its vocational education to meet the needs of the marketplace.
Craigmont has had some success in beefing up courses in fields like food service management and data processing. Susan Brooks, who teaches data processing, has set up an advisory council of executives, and this year she helped one senior land a data-processing job at the Paine Webber stock brokerage and another find one at First Tennessee Bank.
But of Craigmont's 214 graduating seniors, less than the national average of 63 percent will go straight to two- or four-year colleges.
The guidance counselor, Mary Beth Yates, said 142 seniors, or 66 percent, say they would like to go, but for lack of money or ambition or adequate grades and test scores, only 80 have been admitted to colleges in the fall.
Some students are considering six months or a year of trade school or plan to join the armed forces. But around half of the seniors will head straight for the job market the day after the graduation on June 6.
 
Goals and Wanderlust
 The realities of the job market have taken a psychological toll. "For some reason," Ms. Yates said, "our kids are not real adventuresome."
Rebecca Powell, the class valedictorian, is a rarity in having a specific career goal and some wanderlust. She will study music at Indiana University. "I want to be a professional flutist in an orchestra," she said.
By contrast, few Craigmont students, college bound or not, speak of becoming President, a new Elvis Presley or Martin Luther King Jr. or Golda Meier, or a woman who builds cathedrals or the black who cures cancer, or even of becoming master machinists or crack computer programmers. They want the security of homes and wages that pay the rent, not adventures and risks.
"This is the era of lowered expectations," said Harold Hodgkinson, an expert in American education who is director of the Center for Demographic Policy in Washington. "For this group of kids, lowered expectations is a mentally healthy way for some of them to go. You can't get hurt if your expectations are low."
Tim Ferguson has been working part time as peer counselor at a drug treatment center where he was once a client. And he might make a career of it. "I'm not trying to be an adult right now," he said.
Joi Taylor thinks of moving from her cashier's job at Kroger's to a cashier's job at a Mississippi casino. Any job, she said, is less important than other goals -- "a husband, a dog, a son and a house."
Christy Johnston said of her aspirations: "Maybe college. Maybe going to flight attendant school. Helping the homeless." Pressed, she confided: "Falling in love. Staying with him. Not getting divorced."
Still, some students here embody their elders' theories about skill and work-ready attitudes.
 
High Hurdles, Hard Worker
 Wadena Heard, who faces bigger hurdles than most, is 20 and the single mother of a 4-year-old girl. She works four hours a day after school at a Kroger's and lives in a three-room, weather-battered bungalow with seven people -- three generations of women and little girls. She reads to her child, Tyresea, in the single bed they share in a tiny bedroom. A corner of the ceiling has been pulled away and a large bucket in the corner collects leaks; their clothes hang on nails on the wall.
But Ms. Heard threw herself into Craigmont's vocational courses in food service. She often presides over the kitchen where food is prepared for guests, and she organizes student and faculty receptions. "She could go right out today and run a catering service," her English teacher, John Hester, said. "She's always looking for things that go beyond the call of normal classroom procedure."
Ms. Heard's goals? "I want my own house," she said. 'I want to be married to my baby's daddy. I want to get me a car so I can have transportation. I want to go to college and be a registered dietitian."
College will have to wait. "I'm scared," she said. "I'd say in a year I'd be ready." College or no college, Dr. Walters said: "She will be a very productive member of society. There's something inside of her. She will work very hard for the money she makes."
Terrance Burtis wants to tackle the job market now. In the middle of his senior year, he became hooked on computers, staying through lunch and after hours to master them. "He's the most improved student I have in my classroom," said Ms. Brooks, his teacher, who added that he could go to college or vocational school and become a programmer.
But Mr. Burtis says he has been assured $8 an hour for a kitchen management job at Shoney's, and he is also taking a test for a job in the United States Postal Service. He intends to grab one or the other, he says, or some college graduate will.
"Pretty much the people I know who have college still have jobs like at restaurants, jobs that ordinary people can do," he said.

HEADLINE: At Wellesley, or 'First Lady Central,' the Talk Is About, Well, First Ladies

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WELLESLEY, Mass., May 27

 BODY:
At Wellesley College graduation on Friday, there was talk of first ladies, as there often is on a campus where, when women refer to Hillary, it can mean only one Hillary, their Hillary, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Class of 1969.
"It's been sort of First Lady central," the commencement speaker, Cokie Roberts, a correspondent for ABC News and National Public Radio, and a Wellesley alumna, told the graduates. 
 Four years ago the speaker was Barbara Bush, and students protested on the ground that she was selected only because she was the wife of the President. Mrs. Bush brought another first lady with her, Raisa Gorbachev, wife of the then-Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
This year, a week after her death, the women were thinking about another First Lady, though not a Wellesley grad, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. The graduates had not even been born when she became the widow of the assassinated President, but still she had been a part of their lives. They had learned about her through their mothers.
 
The Two Jackies
 "I remember my mom and the other mothers on the block talking about her," said Jennifer Vanasco, 22, from Garden City, L.I., who gave the student commencement address. "I remember them all running out to buy the book 'Jackie O.' "
As a little girl listening to her mother talk, Ms. Vanasco said, she just assumed there were two women named Jackie: Jackie Kennedy and Jackie Onassis. "Jackie Kennedy was the graceful, elegant hostess type who gave White House tours and was the perfect mother and the perfect wife and the perfect feminine woman all the time," said Ms. Vanasco, who is known at Wellesley as Jay. "Jackie Onassis did what she wanted. She was more aggressive. If she wanted to marry Onassis, she did. If she wanted to become a book editor, she did."
It wasn't until high school that Ms. Vanasco learned, in history class, that Jackie Kennedy and Jackie Onassis were the same woman. "I was just shocked that people had talked so differently about the same person," Ms. Vanasco said. "I thought they couldn't have known the first incarnation of her very well."
 
Editor of Student Paper
 Ms. Vanasco, who worked at a day-care center to help pay her college bills, and was the editor of the student newspaper, The Wellesley News, said she had come to admire Jackie Kennedy Onassis. "I thought it was wonderful that she was a book editor," she said. "She would have been fascinating to talk to."
The mothers remembered where they were when Jack Kennedy was shot; they remember watching it all on television. The daughters saw the film of the shooting years later, in school. "The first time I saw it I cried," said Eugenie Bisulco. "Jackie was looking straight at him when his head was blown apart. That's why I think she's so strong."
Surrounded by bold young women determined to become doctors, lawyers, physicists and teachers, the mothers seemed intent on giving the First Lady of their youth her due. "Jackie was always more than just a wife," said Eugenie's mother, Genevieve Bisulco, who is an art teacher.
"I was a little upset about all the money she spent on clothes," said Dorinda Pell Cruickshank, whose daughter, Blair Cruickshank, was among the graduates. "But maybe if I was having a tough married life, I'd go out and shop, too."
 
Chicken and Strawberries
 Talking about Jackie as they ate chicken sandwiches and strawberries on the lawn in the afternoon sunlight, some of the graduates seemed to echo their mothers. "Grace and elegance has a power of its own," said Tanya Jelacic, who majored in biology and English. "I grew up in Washington, and when we'd go downtown and see pictures of the First Ladies, my mother would always point her out and say, 'This lady has style.' "
Leigh Condon, an American Studies major, said she had written her thesis about the Sixties. "The Kennedys and Camelot were a wonderful thing," she said. "They gave the country a lot of hope. From a cultural, sociological point of view, there was something amazing about the Jackie Kennedy look. I respected Jackie for that -- her beauty, grace and charm. At a woman's college in the Nineties, that's not something to be admired. You're supposed to have a strong, powerful front."
Another graduate, Nichole Peterson, said: "In order to be taken seriously, you're not supposed to dress too femininely."
At Wellesley, an elite woman's college founded in 1870, rolling wooden hoops across the lawn is an end-of-the-year ritual for graduating seniors. The legend used to be that the woman who won the hoop rolling race would be the first to get married (the president of Wellesley, Diana Chapman Walsh, who is an expert on public health policy, won in 1966, and was married two weeks after graduation). Now, the winner is said to be destined to become the first C.E.O.
 
Hillary Clinton Most Admired
 And so the First Lady that many of today's graduates, and their mothers, too, most admire is Hillary Rodham Clinton. Ask them about her, and they all have the same response: "She's incredibly smart."
And, added, Sheila Kiernan, 21, who was an intern last summer at the White House: "She's incredibly articulate. She fabulous. She's someone I hold in awe. When she testified before Congress, she was so articulate. I can't go through the newspaper without focusing on articles about her. She's so different from Jackie. Jackie was from another time."
Yashika Olden, an international relations major, said that as much as she looked up to Jackie Kennedy, she hoped that people would also remember another widow of a slain leader, a woman who is still alive. "I have to admire Coretta Scott King," said Ms. Olden, who is black, referring to the widow of the Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. "She held her family together as well."
 
Cornell University
 Special to The New York Times
ITHACA, N.Y., May 29 -- As Cornell University awarded degrees to 3,615 undergraduates and 2,329 graduate students, the university president, Frank H. T. Rhodes, singled out two in particular for recognition today: Helene Rosenblatt, who at age 70 earned her degree in human ecology, 53 years after starting, and Mary Jo Fink, who received a master's degree in hotel administration nine weeks after she was told she had cancer. He said the love of those around them and their hope in the future had spurred them on.
 
Vassar College
 Dr. Bernadine Healy, the former head of the National Institutes of Health, was the speaker at the Vassar College commencement, where 525 seniors received diplomas. Dr. Healy, a 1965 graduate, spoke of the changes wrought by medical technology in the last half-century and said: "Today we are confronting the economic challenge -- the dollar cost -- of the extraordinary success of the wonders of biology and medicine. But tomorrow we will confront ethical, social and moral challenges that will make the problems of economics we are facing now seem very easy."

HEADLINE: Economics By Ripples

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Trying to maneuver the economy with a series of interest rate increases is like trying to change the heading of a supertanker on a collision course: each decision is followed by an agonizing wait before any effect is discernible.
But for the economy, unlike the supertanker, this waiting period will last as much as a year, rather than minutes. So nobody can answer definitively the question of whether the Federal Reserve's four short-term interest rate increases in four months will be effective in preventing future inflation without drastically slowing economic growth now. 
 "Anybody who gave you an honest answer to that would have to say, 'I don't know,' " Lyle E. Gramley, a former Federal Reserve governor, said today in a telephone interview.
The Fed directly controls only the rates that banks pay to borrow money overnight. Increasing these rates makes it more expensive for banks to raise money for new loans to companies and individuals and in turn forces them to charge higher loan rates. But it takes time for the number of loans to slow down, and even more time for the slowdown to ripple through the economy as loan-starved businesses and consumers begin to buy less.
When rising short-term interest rates happen to touch off a sharp increase in longer-term rates, as occurred this year, then the effects are somewhat accelerated. Higher long-term interest rates usually tend to slow the construction and sale of homes, although thousands of Americans blunted that effect this spring by rushing into the housing market before rates could go higher.
 
Luck or Prescience?
 A year from now, the effects of the higher interest rates will still not be entirely clear. If economies in Western Europe are evolving from leaden to sprightly and American exports soaring, the Fed's critics may say that it was just lucky not to have tipped the economy into a recession.
If oil prices jump, the Fed's defenders will, on past performance, blame that rather than higher interest rates for any economic slowdown that may come.
Even if a year from now economists agree on the effects of the series of interest rate increases, they will almost certainly still be divided over whether the Federal Reserve was right. The reason is that while a collision course may be clear to a ship's captain, who may see a rocky shoreline ahead or another vessel, considerable debate remains over whether the economy was headed for trouble when the Federal Reserve began to act.
Federal Reserve officials are concerned that growth in the coming years may consistently exceed 2.5 percent, their best estimate of the economy's speed limit at full capacity. Break the speed limit for too long and sooner or later the penalty will be inflation, they warn.
The central bank's critics, like Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat, contend that the economy can grow as fast as 3.5 percent without risk of inflation. The critics see Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, as resembling a ship's pilot who stays well below the speed limit and slows down before every turn. The economy grew at an annual pace of 3 percent in the first three months of this year.
At a Senate Banking Committee hearing on Friday, Mr. Sarbanes held up an enlarged print of an editorial cartoon that appeared recently in Florida. The cartoon showed Mr. Greenspan looking especially glum and carrying a large sign that read, "The economy is picking up! We are doomed!"
Mr. Greenspan, who usually has a tight-lipped smile if he smiles at all, flashed a toothy grin when he saw the cartoon. He responded later during the hearing that he favored economic growth but thought that keeping inflation low was one of the best ways to assure that growth would be sustainable over the long term.
 
Gauging Sustainable Growth
 The argument over the economy's maximum sustainable growth rate lies at the heart of the question of whether the Federal Reserve has been right to raise interest rates. To back up his argument, Mr. Greenspan cited on Friday new research by the Fed showing that companies and individuals work more efficiently and productively when inflation is low.
"We've done a lot of work on demonstrating that there is a quite robust relationship between the rate of inflation on the one hand and the rate of growth and productivity on the other," he said. "With the lower the inflation, the higher the productivity growth rate."
Some research at central banks around the world has suggested that for every percentage point shaved off the inflation rate, the productivity of a nation's people may increase by an extra tenth or two-tenths of a percentage point each year, said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
The enthusiasm of central banks for such research is predictable. Their main responsibility is to keep prices stable, so central bank economists have long looked for extra benefits to low inflation.
But many other economists are skeptical of such claims. While extremely high inflation clearly hurts productivity, the United States did not reach such levels even during the late 1970's, said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. "I don't think it has been well documented at lower levels," she said.
The debate over the link between productivity and inflation is important because a growth in productivity helps determine the economy's speed limit. When experts like Mr. Greenspan estimate the economy's fastest sustainable growth at full capacity to be about 2.5 percent, they are adding together annual productivity gains of about 1.5 percent and annual increases in the labor force of 1 percent or so.
Productivity actually grew 1.7 percent last year, but changes considerably from quarter to quarter, according to Labor Department figures.
 
High-Productivity Model

 
 When people like Mr. Sarbanes use figures like 3.5 percent, they are assuming a much faster growth in productivity. Support for such a view comes from a scattering of business leaders, like George M. C. Fisher, the chairman and chief executive of the Eastman Kodak Company.
Mr. Fisher said in an interview earlier this month that he thought productivity growth had permanently accelerated because American companies had learned to develop products and put them on the market much faster than before.
Mr. Greenspan contended on Friday that although higher interest rates might slow the economy now, they would increase the economy's maximum growth rate in the future. The higher rates would hold down inflation and thereby increase the growth in productivity.
