HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
A commission created by President Clinton has concluded that the American workplace cannot become truly efficient and globally competitive until hostility is greatly reduced between labor and management -- particularly when unions are trying to organize a company. [Page 33.] 
 Trying to steer the economy through interest-rate moves involves an agonizing wait before any effect is discernible. So no one can yet say whether the Federal Reserve's four short-term rate increases in four months will prevent future inflation without drastically slowing economic growth. News Analysis. [33.]
Manufacturers' orders for American-made machine tools rose in April to the highest level in 12 months, up 11.7 percent from March and 18.8 percent from a year earlier, the Association for Manufacturing Technology reported. [34.]
Despite objections from Congress, the Clinton Administration is establishing a Federal system to buy, store and distribute most of the childhood vaccine used in the United States. The program is a radical shift from the current distribution, which is handled by manufacturers and state health departments. [1.]
For hundreds of thousands of people graduating from high school this spring, the diploma is likely to be a one-way ticket to low-paying, part-time jobs. And some may do worse yet. In 1993, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports, nearly a quarter of high school graduates who did not go on to college and wanted jobs were still unemployed in October. [1.]
 
The Media Business
CBS has concluded that despite the loss last week of several big affiliated stations to Fox Broadcasting, it is in no real danger. But some CBS executives were considering a question also being discussed by media analysts: Is the time drawing near when control of the network changes hands? Bill Carter: Television. [33.]
The marketing of D-Day's 50th anniversary is in full force, and magazines in particular face a daunting task because the anniversary is in many ways a made-for-television event. [35.]
A fierce competition among magazines for photographs to illustrate memorial tributes to Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis has left Newsweek facing an angry photographer, who asserts that there has been copyright infringement. [35.]
While new glossy magazines for gay and lesbian readers are getting attention from national advertisers, gay newspapers have remained largely in their shadow, despite an estimated total readership of nearly three million. [35.]
 
Companies
The tennis-equipment industry is reeling from tumbling sales, insufficient technical innovation and a lack of inspiration from the current crop of players. At the wholesale level, racquet revenue in the United States fell 22 percent last year and tennis-ball sales fell 8 percent, the Tennis Industry Association says. Racquet exports fell 27 percent and tennis-ball exports, 18 percent. [33.]
 
International
Yasushi Mieno's tenure as governor of the Bank of Japan covers one of the most tumultuous and humbling periods in the country's financial history. Under his stewardship, the central bank raised interest rates to check soaring stock and land prices, leading to the longest Japanese recession in the postwar period. He then reversed course and engineered the lowest official rates ever, yet the cheap credit has failed to produce an economic recovery. [33.]
 
Today's Column
A New York architect has patented a small-scale enclosed soccer court for inner cities and other places where outdoor space is hard to come by. Teresa Riordan: Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: A Call for Easing Labor-Management Tension

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
A commission created by President Clinton has concluded that the American workplace cannot become truly efficient and globally competitive until the hostility between labor and management -- particularly when unions try to organize a company -- is greatly reduced.
The White House wants the findings of the 10-member commission, which includes three former Secretaries of Labor, corporate executives and union leaders, to serve as the centerpiece for whatever labor legislation it might propose in the President's first term. 
 "What we want is a new framework for worker-management relations that breaks the stalemate that now exists and holds back innovation and efficiency at the workplace," said Thomas Kochan, a professor of management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a commission member.
To this end, the commission is trying to broker a compromise that would give workers and managers shared power in running their companies. That is a tall order, but part of the commission's mandate from the Clinton Administration.
Having received word of the findings, which will not be made public until Thursday, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is interpreting them as evidence that the National Labor Relations Act, passed in 1935 and still the nation's basic labor law, should be amended to make union organizing, guaranteed in the 1935 act, easier and faster.
But management is unlikely to embrace that view.
"It is my sense of the business community that it would not be very supportive of making it easier for unions to organize," said Jeffrey C. McGuiness, president of the Labor Policy Association, a Washington group subsidized by corporations. "I would question whether a brokered deal is possible that takes into account all the different employment issues raised by the commission."
Labor and management usually give in to fundamental change only during periods of great crisis. The labor law that emerged from one of those periods, the Great Depression, drew some of its provisions from a similar, detailed study of the American workplace by a Presidential commission. There has been no such study since, and a question now is whether there is enough of a crisis to again force significant change.
The panel, formally known as the Commission on the Future of Worker-Management Relations, asserts that the necessary crisis does indeed exist -- fed by such factors as stagnant wages, global competition, polarized incomes and high unemployment for the unskilled.
The commission hopes this crisis will encourage workers and managers to accept the commission's findings as "facts" -- and then to agree on solutions.
 
 
'First Step'
 "Before we can make progress, we have to agree on the reality, the facts, what the trends show," said Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, "and this first step is an important predicate to further debate over what to do about the facts."
But the commission's principal findings, disclosed by members in interviews in advance of the report's public release on Thursday, might not go down so easily.
The commission found, for example, a rising number of conflicts when unions try to organize a company's workers. These conflicts have a ripple effect and "can create an atmosphere of confrontation in worker-management relations throughout the economy," the report says. It also says that 40 million to 50 million workers -- more than 30 percent of the nation's work force -- yearn to participate in making decisions on the job, a yearning that many managers welcome, but many others reject.
 
 
More Basic IssueRole of Unions
 Apart from organizing, the Clinton Administration has sidestepped the issue of whether unions are necessary in the modern workplace, although organized labor supported Mr. Clinton in the last election. The commission reflects that middle-of-the-road approach. While unions, which have seen their membership decline in recent years, have made positive contributions, the commission found, nonunion companies also function well.
The 150-page report offers three major findings, and they are intertwined. All three require a solution, in the commission's view, for a fair and efficient workplace to emerge.
The report found that when workers have tried to organize unions, the rate at which workers have been dismissed illegally has risen in recent years. In addition, the number of first contracts successfully negotiated after a union is formed has declined, the commission found.
All this might seem to imply that management is the heavy in this process. But the findings include an important, balancing caveat: the illegal resistance has occurred at relatively few companies.
 
 
'Quite Small'
 "We basically say that the number of illegal dismissals is quite small in relation to the total workers engaged in organizing, but it has increased," said Paul A. Allaire, the chairman of the Xerox Corporation and a management representative on the commission. "But even if it is small, reducing this conflict could have quite a positive impact on labor-management relationships in all their aspects. The conflict colors the relationship nationally."
Getting rid of this conflict, in turn, would foster the trust and information-sharing that is necessary to make greater use of teams in the workplace, teams in which workers and supervisors share decision making, in effect running their operations together.
In its second major finding, the commission reported that employee participation is a growing phenomenon, involving more than 20 percent of the work force, but operating successfully in only a small number of "high performance" corporations, like Xerox, AT&T and Motorola. Where it operates well, employee participation improves product quality and efficiency, the commission found. But in weeks of hearings and gathering information, the commission found a disconcerting dichotomy in Corporate America.
"In the mornings, at most of our hearings, we would hear from executives and union leaders, talking about the high-production workplaces, and we would say, 'That is wonderful; that has to be the future,' " Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist, said. "And in the afternoon you would hear from workers who tried to form a union and were fired or in other ways were treated like dirt. The people in the morning were the best companies, representing the skilled and the educated. And the people in the afternoon were the unskilled and the minorities."
Some of the high-production companies had unions. But the commission, holding to the middle ground, found that worker-management teams had operated successfully in both union and nonunion settings. As a commission member, Douglas A. Fraser, former president of the United Automobile Workers, accepted that finding. But he disagreed personally.
 
 
'Protect Workers'
 "I say absolutely that worker-management committees work better in a union setting," he said. "If you are going to have true labor-management cooperation, then you have to have equal partnership, and that requires unions to protect workers."
Protection in the new workplace ties in with the commission's third major finding: an explosion of court litigation involving worker-manager disputes. Declining union membership has added to the problem, the unions having once played a larger role in resolving disputes. The litigation is costly for management and labor, and unavailable to low-wage workers who cannot afford lawyers.
The alternatives to the courts -- mediation, arbitration and informal procedures for resolving disputes -- are not being used to their full potential, the commission found.
But in this area, like the others, the commission stops short of recommending solutions or changes in the law, although its original mandate from the Clinton Administration was to do so by now. Instead, a "discourse" is to proceed, as John T. Dunlop, the commission's chairman, puts it, in which labor and business are to agree on solutions. These are to be embodied in the commission's final report in the fall. The chief broker emerging in this process is Mr. Dunlop, a Secretary of Labor in the Ford Administration.
But the task this time is not easy. Union leaders, for example, want to allow workers at a company to affiliate with a union as their bargaining representative simply by persuading a majority of them to sign union cards. That would mean amending the National Labor Relations Act, which requires elections -- a more complicated procedure easier for managers to block.
Similarly, the act also prohibits unions created by companies, on the ground that such unions would fail to represent worker interests in issues like pay and benefits. Now this ban has become an obstacle to the organization of worker-management teams. Several have been challenged and disbanded as company unions. One solution would be to change the Labor Relations Act. Another would be to leave the law alone and hope the teams will proliferate anyway. Still a third would be legislation that authorizes the teams and protects from dismissal workers whose actions anger managers.

HEADLINE: Washington's Decline Is the Issue

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Four years after a blue-ribbon panel found that the District of Columbia was facing an immediate fiscal crisis that was undermining the quality of life, the city appears to be in worse shape than ever.
Beyond the gleam of the White House, Capitol Hill, embassies and the tourist stops, more than 2,200 public housing units are boarded up while 8,200 families are on waiting lists, the crime rate is higher than ever, children pass through metal detectors in every high school and nearly every junior high school, one of every eight residents receives financial aid from the city and one of every six receives food stamps. 
 And don't even think about finding a convenient parking space.
There's more: the tax revenue to address these problems is shrinking and a steady migration to the Maryland and Virginia suburbs is continuing. After falling 3 percent from 1985 to 1990, the city's population fell another 5 percent through last year, to 578,000, the lowest since 1934.
Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly balanced the current $3.4 billion budget by delaying pension fund payments; by 1999 the deficit is projected to reach more than $825 million.
 
Who Gets the Blame
 How the city got this way and who is to blame have emerged as the central issues in a mayoral campaign being waged by the three-term former Mayor who presided over most of the decline, Marion S. Barry Jr., and Mrs. Kelly, his successor for the last three and a half years.
With the race toward the September primary barely a week old, Mr. Barry and another challenger, John Ray, have begun attacking Mrs. Kelly for doing little to reverse the trends. At the same time, Mrs. Kelly has criticized Mr. Barry for the situation she inherited, the District council for not always supporting her and Congress for not providing more money and more power to tax suburbanites who work in the city. Both Mr. Barry and Mr. Ray are members of the council.
"Everybody wants to point a finger at somebody else," said Richard Berendzen, the former president of American University here. "But it's not a matter of blame. The point is to see what has happened and figure out how to deal with it."
Dr. Berendzen headed the blue-ribbon panel when it was formed in 1989, at Mr. Barry's request, until he pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges of making obscene telephone calls. He was replaced by Alice M. Rivlin, now the deputy Federal budget director.
 
Study Group Reconvened
 Last month, Mrs. Kelly asked Dr. Berendzen to reconvene the group and report by mid-July on any progress since the initial work was delivered to Mrs. Kelly in November 1990. Mr. Barry resigned as Mayor in 1990 and served a six-month sentence on a drug conviction. He returned to politics two years ago with his election to the District council.
But recognizing the potential for Mrs. Kelly and her two challengers to use the scorecard for their own political gain, commission members told the Mayor on Friday that they would prefer to present their report after the general election in November.
In a statement, Mrs. Kelly said she understood the commission's concerns and would welcome the report whenever it was ready.
While the candidates might disagree on who should bear the blame for the city's troubles, the three candidates at least agree that relations between the District and the Federal Government should be changed.
Washington relies on four main sources of revenue: sales tax, property taxes, income taxes and the annual Federal payment, which is intended to compensate for the loss of property tax revenues from the 57 percent of Washington real estate that is exempt, mostly Government buildings and embassies.
 
The Federal Connection
 But in recent years, the formula has become a chicken-or-the-egg nightmare in that the Federal payment, less than 19 percent of the overall budget now, increases only if the other revenues rise.
Property tax revenues, which contribute the largest share, increased almost 68 percent in five years through 1993, while the average sale price of a single-family house increased only 13.6 percent. Yet now, the city estimates that property tax revenues will drop through the next four years.
And with thousands of middle-class residents -- nearly equal numbers of blacks and whites -- moving to suburbs that promise safer neighborhoods and better services, the situation can only grow worse.
"I've never seen so many 'for-sale' signs around town," Mr. Barry said in a speech announcing his candidacy.
In addition, the District has a higher top income rate, 9.5 percent, than either Maryland, at 7.5 percent, or Virginia, at 5.75 percent, and it is shackled with costs that other cities generally share with counties or states, like welfare, prisons and hospitals.
Picking up what promises to be the theme of her re-election campaign, Mrs. Kelly argued this week before the House subcommittee that authorizes the District budget that those realities have prevented her from doing more to improve life in the city.
Many of Mrs. Kelly's detractors, including Mr. Barry and members of the original commission now called back into service, contend that much of the city's financial strain is her fault, that she could have cut more. For example, the panel recommended reducing the police force by 1,605 positions. By March of this year, 555 slots had been eliminated.
In the Mayor's view, however, that was enough to count as meeting the recommendation. Using similar standards, her staff determined that she had met 75 percent of 89 commission proposals, and she has told Congress and supporters that she had complied with 80 percent of the proposals.
The figures are high enough to raise a few eyebrows.
"I've been quite vocal and open in front of the Mayor that I am very proud of what we did," said Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., a member of the commissioner and a former chairman of the Republican National Committee. "But many feel the report was just thrown up on the shelf for three and a half years."
 
Little Talk of Decline
 Mr. Barry makes little mention of Washington's steady decline during his administration after the economic boom years of the early 1980's. In a speech announcing his candidacy, he skimmed across his 12 previous years in office, reminding people only that he always balanced the budget and began programs to help the needy.
Mr. Ray, who has run three unsuccessful campaigns for mayor, has charged that the city has been "nonmanaged and mismanaged" under both previous mayors.
There have been some signs of encouragement. A recent study by Smithy Braedon Oncor, a real estate services company, showed that retail vacancy rates dropped for a second-straight year in 1993. And Andrew Florence of Realty Information Group, a research company, said the commercial office vacancy rate had fallen to under 10 percent for the first time since 1990.
But Dr. Berendzen and others said that only significant structural changes in the fiscal relationships between the district and the Federal Government could save the city from a bailout in the short-term and the disturbing trends that had brought the city to this point.

HEADLINE: The Evolving Outlook Of Japan's No. 1 Banker

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 27

 BODY:
Only a few years ago, an awesomely wealthy Japan was in the vanguard of the international financial system that used joint control of currency and interest rates to solve big economic crises. There was great optimism here over the benefits of active policy coordination.
It takes only a few minutes with Yasushi Mieno, the plain-spoken governor of the Bank of Japan, to get a sense of how much things have changed. Mr. Mieno, (pronounced mee-AY-no), a gregarious 70-year-old whose passion outside of monetary statistics is sumo wrestling, may well become known as the governor of diminished expectations.
 
Discussion Replaces Action
 With Japan getting little help in halting the punishing rise of the yen these days, the Government being criticized for not doing enough to end the recession and the flood of Japanese capital abroad having become a trickle, coordinated action by the industrialized nations has been largely transformed, in Mr. Mieno's words, into a passive exchange of information about basic policy goals. 
 "That is the notion of policy coordination that I have," Mr. Mieno said in an interview.
His admission reflects the sober mood at the top of Japan's financial system as Mr. Mieno nears the end of his controversial five-year term. His tenure, which ends in December, covered one of the most tumultuous and humbling periods in the country's financial history.
Under his stewardship, the Bank of Japan for the first time increased interest rates, not as a remedy for a burst of consumer price inflation -- which was almost nonexistent when he took office in 1989 -- but to check soaring stock and land prices.
The policy punctured what is now called the "bubble economy" of the 1980's, a speculative period that sent asset prices to astronomical levels. At the peak, the land beneath the Imperial Palace in central Tokyo was said to be worth more than all the real estate in California.
The central bank's action produced the longest recession in the postwar period. Mr. Mieno then reversed course and engineered the lowest official interest rates ever, from a peak of 6 percent to the current 1.75 percent. Yet the cheap credit has failed to ignite an economic recovery because, some argue, Mr. Mieno's experiment in controlling asset prices went on too long.
 
A Burden of Bad Debts
 More than $6 trillion in asset values have been wiped out, the property market is all but moribund and commercial banks are saddled with a huge burden of bad debts. It is no wonder that Mr. Mieno is regarded with a combination of fear, respect and anger -- but never indifference.
Some Japanese consider him a hero for having stopped the orgy of speculation during the 1980's, putting the economy on a more solid footing for the future, even if the medicine has been painful.
"My view is that nobody could have behaved better during such an unlucky period," said Yoshio Suzuki, chairman of the advisory board at the Nomura Research Institute and a former top executive at the Bank of Japan. Others, however, share the view of Shin Kanemaru, formerly the country's most powerful politician, who suggested several years ago that someone ought to behead the central bank governor.
 
Several Difficult Problems

The years under Mr. Mieno have left the Bank of Japan with several perplexing problems that could influence policy well into the future. For one, the bank has to decide if Mr. Mieno's campaign against soaring stock and land prices was a one-time foray or a long-term policy. And if it is a long-term policy, it raises the question: When does a bull market cross the line into becoming the dangerous "asset inflation" that Mr. Mieno attacked?
The central bank must also decide where to draw the line between ridding Japan's financial markets of their heavy burden of regulation -- Mr. Mieno's long-stated policy -- and using regulation to maintain the kind of order with which the bank is obsessed.
"It is uncertain to what extent financial liberalization affected behavior during the period of the financial bubble," Mr. Mieno said. What is certain, he said, is that "under the process of deregulation there was some excessive aggressiveness on the part of the banks."
He said deregulation had to continue, since competition was the only way to teach banks to manage their risks better.
But he also insisted that the Government's heavy-handed manner of handling the bad-debt crisis at the commercial banks would continue because of the central bank's need to protect the financial system against panic. The commercial banks have been pressured by the Government to keep many ailing borrowers afloat with new loans below market rates.
"Our greatest concern is systemic risk in the financial system," he said.
Mr. Mieno spent most of his 47-year career at the Bank of Japan being groomed for his current post. He spent part of his youth in northern China, which Japan was transforming into an engine for its military expansion of the 30's. When Japan lost the war, Mr. Mieno's father, a commercial banker, lost everything. Mr. Mieno was able to attend Tokyo University, the country's most elite institution, but had to live and work in a sumo stable, where he cultivated his interest in the sport. He is now a member of the council that selects the wrestlers to be elevated to the sport's highest status.
He also spent two years in New York in the early 1960's, studying for a short time at Columbia University. But for the most part his career was spent in the bank's domestic departments, where he developed a reputation for being smart and decisive.
Mr. Mieno was engulfed in criticism almost from his first day as governor in December 1989. The press reported that the Finance Minister was resisting a proposed increase in the Bank of Japan's discount rate, which influences what banks charge customers for loans.
The discount rate was raised and, within days, the stock market hit what remains its record high. When the rate went up three more times in the next 10 months, the market plunged and Mr. Mieno became known as the disciplinarian who ended one of the most powerful bull runs ever. Many experts say that he was right to raise interest rates but that he moved too fast.
"It was a question of degree," said Makoto Utsumi, the vice minister of finance at that time and now a professor at Keio University. "The point all along was to avoid a hard landing. I think if we had tightened more slowly we could have had a soft landing."
There was virtually no price or wage inflation, but Mr. Mieno acted because of a belief that soaring asset prices would eventually provoke consumer price inflation. Some still question that view.
"We still don't know the connection between monetary policy and asset prices," said Mikio Wakatsuki, a former deputy governor at the Bank of Japan and now chairman of the board of councilors at the Japan Research Institute. "What benchmark do you use? Which prices do you follow? We don't know, and didn't know then."
 
On One Hand -- and the Other
 Even Mr. Mieno seems ambivalent. He explained that steep rises in asset prices could not be given the same emphasis in policy making as could broader measures of consumer prices. On the other hand, he said, they cannot be ignored.
"The lesson that we learned from that," he said, " is that when we see the symptom of such asset price inflation we have to act immediately."
With the interest rate increases so unpopular at that time, Mr. Mieno put the issue in moral terms: He said that rocketing land prices put a home out of reach of the average Japanese and threatened social harmony.
"The bubble hurt the soundness and stability of Japanese society," Mr. Mieno said in another interview several years ago. "The efforts of labor, which is to work with sweat on your forehead, have been weakened. Morale was reduced and there was unfairness in the distribution of wealth."
In the latest interview, however, Mr. Mieno backed away from that kind of preaching.
"I am a central banker and not a sociologist," he said. "Neither I nor the Bank of Japan is in the position of being able to provide a guideline as to how the public should earn its income. Also, we are not playing the part of Robin Hood -- I like him, but I'm not Robin Hood."

LENGTH: 805 words

HEADLINE: Balaguer Says He'll Enforce Curbs on Haiti

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Re public, May 29

 BODY:
Faced with American pressure and widespread accusations of voting fraud in his latest election, President Joaquin Balaguer now says he will do what he has scoffed at for months: enforce the international embargo against neighboring Haiti.
The Dominican border is the weakest point of the embargo, which is the major element in President Clinton's troubled effort to unseat the Haitian military. The embargo was toughened a week ago to include everything but food, medicine and cooking gas. 
 Gasoline in particular -- in plastic jugs rowed across lakes in the mountains, in tanker trucks waved through customs checkpoints and in rusty tramp steamers hugging the coast -- has enriched not only the smugglers but also the military and business executives behind the rulers of both countries.
But in this steamy and languid capital, the talk was that President Balaguer had bought himself a reprieve from United States and international pressure in elections that were held on May 16. Among other things, there have been complaints that the names of nearly 200,000 registered voters, mostly opposition supporters, had disappeared from the rolls and that 7 of the nation's 29 provinces had produced remarkably enthusiastic turnouts of more than 100 percent.
 
Recount Under Way
 According to the latest official election results, with a recount under way, President Balaguer is clinging to a razor-thin margin of some 30,000 votes out of three million cast.
Mr. Balaguer's public position on the embargo had been that increasing hardship in Haiti would bring an unwanted influx of refugees. The turnabout came after he met for two hours on Wednesday with William H. Gray 3d, Mr. Clinton's new point man on Haiti, and Dante Caputo, the special representative of the United Nations and the Organization of American States.
On Thursday, Mr. Balaguer called in his military chief, Lieut. Gen. Constantino Matos, who promptly announced a fusillade of measures, including the deployment of thousands of additional troops and the transfer of every officer and soldier who had been on the border for more than two months, presumably to break up corruption. The army, General Matos insisted, was "doing serious and honest work."
But given the real difficulty in enforcing the embargo in rough mountain and coastal terrain and the sudden, unaccustomed wealth that breaking the embargo has brought to poor areas and underpaid soldiers, it is unclear how effective the effort will be or how long it will be pressed.
 
'Political Reasons' Cited
 "President Balaguer will enforce the embargo for his own political reasons," said Jorge Botello, the president of the Chamber of Deputies. "After the meeting, he is of the belief that if he gives in on the problem of the border, that he will be guaranteed to remain in power."
At 87, President Balaguer is blind, partly deaf and walks with tiny steps. But both friends and enemies say he has lost none of the wiliness that has kept him the main player here for three decades.
Even opponents, like Leonel Fernandez, a lawyer who ran unsuccessfully for Vice President on the third-place ticket of Mr. Balaguer's old enemy, Juan Bosch, salute Mr. Balaguer's guile.
"He has his own ways, his own tricks," Mr. Fernandez, who grew up on the West Side of Manhattan, said of the President, not without admiration. "He understands the need to negotiate the Haitian matter to be left alone in the electoral process. But he can outplay Clinton, he can outplay anyone. You can make an agreement with him, but he's always outwitting you."
 
An Election Issue
 Haiti was a more immediate, and visceral, issue in the election campaign.
Mr. Balaguer's main opponent was Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, 57, a former Mayor of Santo Domingo. Ebony-skinned in a country where the entrenched political and economic elite is of light complexion, Mr. Pena Gomez was born of a Haitian mother and raised by a Dominican family.
The President's campaign and television advertisements sought to portray him as a sort of closet Haitian who might give the country away to its neighbors.
"This was the most negative campaign ever, very racially oriented," said Mr. Pena Gomez's running mate, Fernando Alvarez, a longtime associate of the President, who broke with him when Mr. Balaguer changed his mind about a pledge not to run again.
For his part, Mr. Pena Gomez threatened that if President Balaguer was certified the winner, opposition members would refuse to take any offices they had won. Since Mr. Pena Gomez's party is estimated to have won about half the municipal posts and legislative seats, this could cause chaos.
"I am a humble man, the color of the night," Mr. Pena Gomez said at a news conference. "This is perhaps why they think they can run over me. But I am not alone."

HEADLINE: Supporters and Critics Equally Ardent in Judging Hynes

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Charles J. Hynes appeared to have all the ingredients for success when he took over as Brooklyn District Attorney in 1990: the prosecutor's background, the air of independence and integrity that came with winning convictions for the Howard Beach racial killings, and the support of major figures in the Democratic Party.
"He was the great hope," said Joyce David, president of the Kings County Criminal Bar Association. 
 Mr. Hynes ridiculed the work of his predecessor, Elizabeth Holtzman, calling her office "dismal," "reckless," and "nothing short of incompetent," and he privately told an audience of Brooklyn judges that their "long nightmare" was over.
 
'Total Pro' or Blatant Politician
 It has, however, been no dream four years for Mr. Hynes and Brooklyn, as the the District Attorney himself admits.
Opinion about Mr. Hynes's resume, after all, is rather badly split. His ardent supporters speak of an unconventionally effective prosecutor's office -- "he's been a total pro," said one admirer who is a criminal defense attorney -- that has become humanized and more representative of Brooklyn's diverse population. Mr. Hynes, they say, is dedicated to equal treatment for everyone under the law.
But his detractors draw a portrait of a blatantly political office -- one former prosecutor called it a cult of loyalty -- that has failed to bring forth major cases and that has bungled many cases both major and minor. These critics cite an unimpressive conviction rate that judges, defense attorneys and former employees say is symptomatic of an office without great training for its prosecutors, one directed by a man whose heart is not in the job.
The full range of Mr. Hynes's performance is destined for a lengthy public airing, for he is one of three candidates aiming for the Democratic nomination to become state attorney general.
His rivals are G. Oliver Koppell, the veteran Assemblyman from the Bronx who was appointed to serve the remainder of Robert Abrams's term as Attorney General and who has significant statewide support in the Legislature, and Karen S. Burstein, a former Family Court judge in Brooklyn who has already gained the Liberal Party nomination. Mr. Hynes, who has support from party leaders in Brooklyn, is said to be placing third in most opinion polls, and could face a difficult task trying to get on the ballot at this week's Democratic convention.
"The No. 1 issue is crime, and what this is all about is two resumes for the job of the people's lawyer," said Mr. Hynes, who clearly figures Mr. Koppell to be his chief threat. Mr. Hynes said that he was proud of his work as District Attorney, and that he believed the state should profit from it.
"I never considered myself a historic figure," he said. "But you'd have to be fairly myopic to say I haven't done unique, nontraditional things. If the final epitaph is that I was an innovator for law enforcement, I'll be happy with that."
 
'More Creative'
 There are those who agree. "Perhaps his political instincts are what have allowed him to be more creative than all the other district attorneys," said Richard H. Girgenti, the director of criminal justice services for New York State.
Mr. Girgenti and others point to innovations by Mr. Hynes, like his program offering residential drug treatment to second-time nonviolent felony drug offenders, and his decision to divide Brooklyn into five zones as part of an effort at "community prosecution." The program was started to let the police work more closely with prosecutors and law enforcement operate more familiarly with specific neighborhoods.
He has also begun an unorthodox policy of allowing defense attorneys to have access to the prosecution's evidence early. The policy might allow defendants to build stronger cases, but Mr. Hynes asserts that it has quickened case dispositions by an average of 74 days.
"I have my fans and my detractors, and I understand that," Mr. Hynes said in a recent interview. "It doesn't bother me to take the shots. I'm a big boy."
 
'Politician on the Make'
 But Mr. Hynes has detractors who accuse him of placing politics before his job.
"He's another politician on the make, and his office is run in service to that," said Alan Broomer, a former prosecutor in Manhattan and State Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn who criticized Mr. Hynes's early impact on the District Attorney's office before the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary in 1991. Mr. Broomer was later denied reappointment after 12 years on the bench.
"He's used the office for his own ends."
Certainly Mr. Hynes is seen as a vastly more complicated public figure than when he was first elected in 1989. Then, on the heels of his successful turn as the special prosecutor in the Howard Beach racial killing trial, he was widely perceived as a welcome figure of integrity and character. His work record -- which included jobs as special prosecutor for nursing home fraud and later police corruption, as well as the city's Fire Commissioner -- seemed tailor made for future success.
But then came all the difficulty of running law-enforcement efforts in a diverse, violent, politically volatile and economically imbalanced borough of more than two million people.
There was Crown Heights, with its failed prosecution of Lemrick Nelson Jr. in the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum, and the political tug of war over Mr. Hynes's efforts to have the Justice Department in Washington take over the prosecution. There was the police corruption scandal in the 73d Precinct, a case that also had to be turned over to Federal prosecutors, and a Police Department report on police corruption that faulted Mr. Hynes's previous work as special prosecutor.
There were charges of cronyism, too, as Mr. Hynes hired a number of high-salaried senior assistants with limited prosecutorial experience or none at all. He added as well a handful of his colleagues from his days as special prosecutor.
 
'Have I Fallen Down? Yes.'
 Mr. Hynes dismissed the charges of cronyism as frivolous and motivated by embittered former employees. "Everyone who is out of the prosecutorial loop in my office has defined responsibilities meant to deal with public safety in its broadest sense," he said.
"Am I capable of doing things that are wrong? Have I fallen down?" Mr. Hynes asked. "Yes. I'll let the people decide who I am."
According to statistics provided by the Office of Court Administration, over the last four years Mr. Hynes's office has lost jury verdict cases at a rate exceeded only by the Bronx District Attorney's office, where the District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, refuses to allow plea bargaining.
Mr. Hynes's office, once formally criticized by a State Supreme Court justice as possessing "little or no accountability," prevailed in only 67 percent of cases decided by juries in State Supreme Court in 1990, 64 percent in 1991, 62 percent in 1992 and 66 percent last year, the office's records say. The corresponding percentages in Manhattan range from 10 to 14 points higher.
 
Disputes Conviction Figures
 Mr. Hynes's office disputes those figures. Citing records that he said are kept by the Division of Criminal Justice Services, Mr. Hynes said the rate for 1993 was 73 percent. He said further that his own office's records indicated a conviction rate so far in 1994 of 76 percent.
"I don't know the internal workings of the office," said Ms. David, a supporter of Mr. Hynes who has contributed to his campaigns. "In the trenches, I haven't seen that it is that different from Liz Holtzman's tenure."
Mr. Hynes, who said he was concerned about the conviction rates, last year required every assistant district attorney trying a case to be accompanied by a supervisor in court. He said it is a sound method of training. His critics assert that he wanted to raise conviction rates in a hurry as he prepared for his 1993 re-election campaign and perhaps beyond.
No single case has drawn more attention to Mr. Hynes's office than the Crown Heights case, and no case has generated more fire. After one failed prosecution, Mr. Hynes decided to turn the case to the Justice Department when a new suspect emerged; critics say the move exemplified his tendency to let political concerns overwhelm his job as prosecutor.
Mr. Hynes argued that having Attorney General Janet Reno pursue a Federal civil-rights prosecution would cut down on further delays and offer maximum sentences for Mr. Nelson and another suspect, a stance scoffed at by some legal experts.
To others, the end result made sense.
"Did he handle it politically?" asked Noach Dear, a City Councilman who monitored the case. "He's a politician. You have to expect that. It's not a bad word. He saw to it that he got rid of it any way that he could."

HEADLINE: Building Owners May Face Fines for Leaving Graffiti

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 29

 BODY:
The City Council wants to fight graffiti, but rather than going after those who deface property, it is considering penalizing the owners of buildings who do not clean up graffiti fast enough.
The Council is scheduled to vote on June 7 on an ordinance saying that the owners of defaced buildings have 21 days to clean them up before being issued summonses and then fines from $100 to $1,000. An owner who does not cooperate could have a lien placed on his property for the amount of the cleanup. 
 "Sure, it'll be an expense, but it's probably covered under vandalism insurance," said Peter M. Beronio, director of the Englewood Economic Development Commission. "Maybe some people think it's unfair, but look, if someone throws a rock through your window you'd love the police to fix it, but you have to do it yourself or you'd get a property code violation."
Bob Benecke, Englewood's city manager, said the theory is that if graffiti is removed quickly enough, those who produce it will eventually get discouraged.
"These people want to see their art on the wall," he said. "Paint over your wall once and the artist comes back. But after you do it three or four times, eventually he'll get frustrated and move on."
 
Painted 'Again and Again'
 Not all property owners agree with him.
"I've painted over those initials and scribbles again and again, and before the paint dries, they're out there drawing again," said Victor Gurunathan, whose strip of eight stores downtown on West Palisade Avenue is a frequent target of graffiti. "My tenants say they're losing business because their stores are so unsightly."
Mr. Gurunathan said he considered himself twice victimized: first by the vandals and then by the city.
But another business owner, Joe Pizzari, proprietor of the Eagle paint store, said he thought Englewood was being generous in giving store owners three weeks to remove graffiti.
"It's a reflection of your business and of everyone else's, too, if you don't get rid of this stuff promptly," Mr. Pizzari said. "Look, if you're one of five landlords on a strip and you don't clean up the same day, pretty soon not only won't customers come to you, but they won't come into your neighbors' stores, either. At the very least, you owe it to them to treat your problem."
A veteran of the graffiti wars, Mr. Pizzari and his neighbors got together a year and a half ago, cleaning up any overnight vandalism by 8 the next morning. Soon the vandalism stopped.
"Leave it up and it's a cancer," Mr. Pizzari said. "But if you paint over it, they can't point it out proudly to their friends, which is what they want to do in the first place. I can't see why any landlord or homeowner should make such a big deal about this ordinance."
 
Night Patrols
 The graffiti ordinance grew out of the work of a task force set up to combat the problem. As part of the crackdown, the Council has also put a civilian zoning officer on night patrol each evening to ferret out fresh cases of graffiti; the officer is to notify the police if he sees work in progress.
A second part of the ordinance states that anyone under the age of 18 must must be accompanied by a parent to buy cans of spray paint from any paint or hardware store in town. Mr. Beronio said that he has also advised those store owners to move spray cans to the back and put them under cover.
Communities like neighboring Teaneck, Cliffside Park and Fort Lee in Bergen County have similar ordinances. Little Falls in Passaic County gives business owners 14 days to erase graffiti.
In Teaneck, violation notices go out to property owners in 10 days. Initial fines are $25 plus court costs.
"We're not being punitive, but you have to maintain your property," said Curtis Caviness, Teaneck's sanitary inspector. He cited a graffiti-marred Pic and Pay store, across from an elementary school, whose owner has been repeatedly fined.
"He keeps painting over with white paint," Mr. Caviness said. "Paint it over with dark brown paint. Maybe it won't look that attractive, but it would cover up all the graffiti."

HEADLINE: U.S. Machine Tool Orders Climb to a 12-Month High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Manufacturers' orders for American-made machine tools rose to the highest level in 12 months in April, up 11.7 percent from March and 18.8 percent from a year earlier, the Association for Manufacturing Technology reported yesterday.
Machine tool orders totaled $413.7 million in April, up from $370.4 million in March. The monthly report covers metal-cutting and metal-forming machine tools, which are used to manufacture goods from household appliances to aircraft engines. 
 Machine tool orders are considered a gauge of future economic activity. A rise is viewed as an indication that businesses feel confident enough that their sales will grow to justify investing in new equipment.
Albert W. Moore, president of the association, said the continued growth in domestic orders coupled with the nearly doubling of foreign orders was an especially good sign.
"Continued growth in domestic orders reflects a broadening of demand beyond the auto industry," Mr. Moore said. "The pickup in export orders is a good sign. A rebound in export demand is essential to a sustained growth of demand for U.S. manufactured products."
Machine tool shipments totaled $343.6 million in April, up 7.9 percent from March's $318.6 million and 35.4 percent ahead of the year-earlier amount of $253.7 million.
So far this year, machine tool shipments have totaled $1.16 billion, up 8.3 percent from the $1.07 billion shipped during the first four months of last year.
The most significant rise in orders was in foreign markets. Total export orders rose 85.1 percent in April, to $21.1 million, from $11.4 million in March. Total domestic orders for April rose 9.4 percent, to $392.6 million, from $359 million the month before.
The backlog of unfilled orders for machine tools in April was $1.68 billion, up from $1.61 billion in March and $1.4 billion in April 1994.

HEADLINE: For 4 Collegial Congressmen, Life Looks a Lot Like College

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Sam cooks, Dick cleans, George collects the rent and Chuck raids the refrigerator. Weeknights, they shoot the breeze in their underwear in the Capitol Hill town house where two of them sleep in unkempt beds in the living room like so many superannuated frat boys, and check to see if anyone they know turns up on "Nightline."
Weekdays, as members of Congress, these four help make the trade, farm, environmental and crime laws of the United States. Their little den on D Street may be the capital's highest-powered political domicile outside 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, so celebrated that it became the subject of a proposed TV sitcom called "Four in the House." (The President has a standing invitation, but hasn't come so far.) 
 For Representatives Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut, Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, George Miller of California and Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, Washington life is not all beer and roses. It's more like beer and frozen soy burgers, stale tortilla chips, lost laundry, monthly trips to Price Club and weekly commutes to their districts and families back home.
"My father was in the California State Senate, and he used to say that the worst thing was going home to an empty hotel room in Sacramento," said Mr. Miller, a 20-year veteran from the San Francisco area who bought the two-bedroom house in the late 1970's and began sharing it to save money in 1983 when his wife moved back to California so his second son could go to school there. "If you don't have a family here, and don't do something like this, you succumb to the receptions. We've seen a lot of members who've gotten in trouble here, and it's usually out of loneliness."
The other night, as the Congressmen shared pizza amid the clutter of golf clubs, a doorside basketball hoop and ancient albums like "The Mamas and the Papas 20 Golden Hits," the worst trouble they got into was installing a huge air-conditioner in the front window. The only argument was what to watch on television (the vote was 3 to 1 for the Knicks game, with Mr. Gejdenson a lone holdout for the Discovery Channel).
Yet over the years, the house has provided much more than fellowship for its Democratic kitchen caucus. Its original foursome included Representative Leon Panetta of California, who had to move out after he became President Clinton's budget director last year (bequeathing his bed to Mr. Schumer, who had been stuck on a fuzzy orange fold-out couch). Marty Russo of Illinois left after losing his seat in 1992, but not before talking out his proposal for a universal health-care bill with his roomies one midnight when he was not indulging his penchant for doing laundry.
 
A Tradition of Sleeping Cheap
 It was here, too, that proposals for the alternative minimum income tax and clearer disclosure of credit-card interest rates were hatched.
"You put your idea out there, and the first instinct is not to applaud you," Mr. Gejdenson said drily. "You can run the traps pretty well here. Chuck always talked to us before he called Janet Reno and told her what to do on the crime bill."
Sleeping cheap is a Congressional tradition. In the late 1840's, Representative Abraham Lincoln shared space in a Capitol Hill boardinghouse, and more than a century later, Allard Lowenstein lived on his office couch as a Congressman from Nassau County. What makes the Miller house special is its combination of diverse and influential members.
Mr. Miller, 49, is chairman of the Committee on Natural Resources and was mentioned as a possible Interior Secretary when it seemed President Clinton might nominate Bruce Babbitt to the Supreme Court. Mr. Schumer, 43, leads the Judiciary Committee's panel on crime and criminal justice; Mr. Durbin, 49, heads the Appropriations Committee's subcommittee on agriculture (and is thus a member of the so-called College of Cardinals who guard the gates of spending), while Mr. Gejdenson, 46, runs the subcommittee on economic policy and trade of the foreign affairs committee and is close to Speaker Thomas S. Foley.
"Tip O'Neill used to see us in the morning and say, 'Uh-oh, what's gone on in the house last night," Mr. Miller recalled of the former Speaker.
 
Better Than a Futon
 For Mr. Durbin, who commutes to Lincoln's old hometown of Springfield, Ill. (48 round trips last year), his current home is a step up from his old digs, with Representative Richard Lehman of California. "I slept on the floor on a futon deal," he said. "Here I had a chance to get a bedroom," because Mr. Schumer waived his seniority rights and let him take one of the private rooms on the second floor.
When Mr. Durbin, a former staff member for the Illinois State Senate, came to Washington 11 years ago, the oldest of his three children had just started high school, and moving the whole family was "never really a viable financial option for me." The alternative, he said, "was to live two hours out in the suburbs and commute, and there was no way to have a home as I knew it."
So instead, he heads home each week, Thursday nights if possible, and has endured the guilt of nearly missing one child's eighth-grade graduation and constant delays. "My best time ever was 3 hours and 15 minutes," he said. "You don't want to know the worst."
Mr. Gejdenson is the only one among the group who doesn't have to go far to see his 14-year-old daughter and 11-year-old son; they live a few blocks away with his wife, from whom he is separated pending a divorce. "The hardest part is there's really no place for my daughter to stay here," Mr. Gejdenson said, since his bed is just a few steps from Mr. Schumer's on one side and the big open kitchen on the other.
Last summer, the group was joined by Mr. Miller's younger son, Stephen, who had an internship at the Natural Resources Defense Council. "He refused to sleep with me, so he slept on the floor," Mr. Miller said.
Mr. Schumer almost never stays more than two nights a week, preferring to fly home -- one night at a time, if necessary -- to his wife and two daughters in Park Slope. When his colleagues changed into khakis, blue jeans and moccasins to greet a visitor, he stayed in his blue suit and sock feet, the only clothing he brings with him except for a change of underwear and shirts. What if he spills something?
"He wears it anyway," Mr. Miller answers. "Can't you tell?"
 
Call It 'Ironic Crazy'
 After years of friendship, the housemates communicate in a Morse code camaraderie that Janice Berman, the wife of Representative Howard L. Berman of California, sought to reflect when she wrote her sitcom scenario four years ago. The show got as far as a pilot script by the Broadway librettist Peter Stone, but was never produced, in part because Ms. Berman vetoed the final version.
"It didn't capture the essence of what I wanted to show," Ms. Berman said in a telephone interview. "Things happen here that are kind of crazy. But they're not stupid crazy, they're just ironic crazy. If it's a sitcom, everyone is stupid."
It is hard to imagine how fiction could be stranger than the truth of Mr. Schumer's once killing crickets with paint cans in the middle of the night. ("Leon and I heard this chirping, and what do I know?" he said. "I never slept in a tent.") Or the upstairs roommates creeping down one night to whisper to the sleeping Mr. Schumer, whose sweet tooth they knew too well, "Chuuuck, Chuuuck . . . there are Klondike Bars in the freezer," only to hear his barefoot trek and the sounds of eating in bed.
Or Mr. Gejdenson, the designated shopper whose culinary specialty is pre-cooked frozen onions atop premade all-vegetable patties, buying new padded folding chairs in anticipation of a Presidential visit.
"We were going to invite the First Lady," Mr. Durbin deadpanned. "She was doing a tour of Congressional homes. But then we thought, nooooo."
Often, their schedules are so hectic, and different, that the housemates see one another just a few minutes a week. Other times, they have group gatherings.
"Once we watched 'Dr. Strangelove' on TV as we were getting dressed in the morning," Mr. Miller said, his broad face creasing into a grin. "You remember that? There we were, tying our ties, just laughing."
And at lights out, do they end the day as a family?
"Yeah, we do that," Mr. Miller said. "We say, 'Goodnight, Chuck-boy."

HEADLINE: For Graduates of 1994, Praise, Caution, Cajoling And Words to Leave By

 BODY:
Raising a family and finding religion, rejuvenating feminism, promoting racial equality and understanding, looking (with unease or enthusiasm) to the future of technology: these were among the many messages delivered to the graduating classes of 1994 at colleges and universities nationwide. The speakers ranged from the cartoonist Cathy Guisewite to the Presidential adviser David R. Gergen. These excerpts were taken from transcripts provided by the respective universities and colleges.
 
 
North Carolina Central University, May 14
VERNON E. JORDAN JR.
Lawyer
Those students of the 1960's, your mothers and fathers, were in the grip of a powerful idea -- the idea of equality -- whose time they hastened and whose force overcame the tread of mighty armies of racism and segregation. They took that maturing experience to become pioneers themselves, blazing trails in corporate America in government and in the professions. You may think that's ancient history, events that happened before you were born. But the struggle is not over. Yesterday's students began something that today's young people must finish. For despite the tremendous gains that have taken place over the past three decades, too much -- far too much -- remains the same. Discrimination still flourishes, although it is now illegal. . . . You must enter into the serious business of helping black people survive and thrive in the 21st century.
 
 
Catholic University, May 14
TED KOPPEL
Television journalist
 Our society finds truth too strong a medicine to digest undiluted. In its purest form, truth is not a polite tap on the shoulder. It is a howling reproach. What Moses brought down from Mount Sinai were not the Ten Suggestions. They are commandments. Are, not were. The sheer brilliance of the Ten Commandments is that they codify in a handful of words acceptable human behavior, not just for then or now, but for all time. . . . The tension between those commandments and our baser instincts provides grist for journalism's daily mill. What a huge, gaping void there would be in our informational flow and in our entertainment without the routine violation of the Fifth through Tenth Commandments. . . . Tell me if this doesn't remind you of something: 'Honor thy mother and father. Thou shalt not murder. Thou shalt not steal. Thou shalt not bear false witness.' Sounds like a script outline for the story of the Menendez brothers, doesn't it?
 
 
Juilliard School, May 20
JANE ALEXANDER
Chairman, National Endowment
for the Arts
This occasion lends itself to speculation, to the bittersweet. The poet Samuel Hazo writes about life's journey in a poem called "The First and Only Sailing," of which I'll quote the last few lines:
Expect nothing,
and anything seems everything.
Expect everything, and anything
seems nothing.
To live
you leave your yesterselves
to drown without a funeral.
You chart a trek where no
one's sailed before.
You rig. You anchor up. You sail.
Your time at Juilliard has been spent learning when to tack or when to open your sails to the wind; it has been filled with hard work and wild ideas, friendship, love, the camaraderie of community.
 
 
Ithaca College, May 14
JEAN-MICHEL COUSTEAU
Oceanographer
As a culture, we are coming to our senses after a 40- or 50-year bad trip of raping the natural and human environment as if there is no tomorrow. Today, we recognize that current industrial society is literally unsustainable. We admit that trashing the future is bad business. . . . You will inherit a planet that, while remarkably resilient, is unmistakably damaged. But today we have the opportunity to turn society around and point our policies, our technology, our dreams in a more positive direction.
 
 
State University of New York
at Geneseo, May 14
DAVID R. GERGEN
Counselor to President Clinton
People who are willing to get off the sidelines and get into the arena make the difference. Your generation has been dismissed as too cynical, too skeptical, and you have reason. After all, the faith has been broken too many times in the past. There is no guarantee that we as a people will succeed. But if you don't get into the arena, I guarantee you we will fail.
 
 
Syracuse University
KURT VONNEGUT
Novelist
I had a bad uncle named Dan, who said a male can't be a man unless he'd gone to war. But I had a good uncle named Alex, who said, when life was most agreeable -- and it could be just a pitcher of lemonade in the shade -- he would say, "If this isn't nice, what is?" . . . Now, if he hadn't said that so regularly, maybe five or six times a month, we might not have paused to notice how rewarding life can be sometimes. Perhaps my good Uncle Alex will live on in some of you members of the Syracuse Class of 1994 if, in the future, you will pause to say out loud every so often, "If this isn't nice, what is?"
 
 
Gettysburg College, May 22
ANDY ROONEY
Television commentator
I was thinking -- just as an example of how much the times influence what a person does with his life -- if Abraham Lincoln were alive today, would he be standing here making his Gettysburg Address and saying, "Four score and seven years ago, our forefathers brought forth upon this continent a new nation . . ."? Of course not. The nation isn't new any more. He'd have to say, "Ten score and 18 years ago." . . . Lincoln would probably be a relatively obscure lawyer who was turned down for the Supreme Court because he and Mary had a live-in maid for whom they never paid Social Security.
 
 
Haverford College, May 15
CORNEL WEST
Harvard University professor
I have only a brief word for the class of 1994, namely that you are now part of a tradition of rich Quakerism on the one hand, but also of grand but still flawed democratic tradition on the other. I think T. S. Eliot was absolutely right when he wrote in 1919 that tradition is not something you inherit. If you want it, you must obtain it with great labor. It is a perennial process. And it means then that one is going to have to cut radically against the American grain, because it means on the one hand, you are going to have to have a sense of history and understand the present as history. And in my own humble opinion, the major forms of idolatry of our day are the market way of life and the tribal way of life.
 
 
The Citadel, May 14
SENATOR BOB DOLE
American leadership is still required. And sometimes that leadership will mean that Americans will make the supreme sacrifice. . . . Is it America's destiny to be the world's policeman? No. There are crimes against humanity and against freedom committed every day in countless countries across the world, and America does not go in, guns blazing, to make it right. Instead we lead by example. . . . If we are to maintain our credibility as an economic and moral influence, then we must deal with our problems, like the deficit and crime. And we must remember and teach the values that made America great -- values like decency, honesty and individual responsibility.
 
 
Wesleyan University
LOWELL P. WEICKER JR.
Governor of Connecticut
 A few weeks ago I went to South Africa to attend the presidential inauguration of Nelson Mandela. An event so sweeping as this was undreamed of even by its most ardent supporters. . . . Decades of legally dehumanizing all races but white were buried under an avalanche of paper ballots. Yet there was not one of us witnessing history in Pretoria, as representatives of the United States, who didn't comprehend that what was ending in South Africa as a matter of law was thriving in our own country as a matter of practice. The long moral finger of outrage that we for so long had pointed at South Africa was now more properly directed at ourselves.
 
University of Michigan, April 30
CATHY GUISEWITE
Cartoonist
I graduated with a class committed to open love, open thinking open doors, open everything. . . . Twenty-two years later, the people of my class are getting cash out of a machine, dinner out of a clown's mouth and it isn't even possible to get a human being on the phone at the phone company. In Los Angeles, my only chance of having a meaningful encounter with a person is if I smash into one with my car. . . . You've grown up in a strange time where people seem more bonded by the bad stuff than the good. Where in a lot of communities the main common link between neighbors is that everyone knows someone who's been mugged. Everyone knows someone in rehab. And everyone's been touched by a life that ended way too soon. If you want something to change, you personally have to do something different. You have to take a stand when it isn't convenient. Try something nobody else has tried. Defy your own group. Rebel against yourself. Knock down your walls and get out of your way.
 
 
University of Southern California, May 6
STEVEN SPIELBERG
Film maker
It doesn't matter what path we take, we have to remain curious and fearless. We have to look at the world and question what we see. We have to be unafraid to say no and change what is unacceptable. Each of us has the ability to do this. Each of us has the responsibility to do it.

JAMES EARL JONES

 You are facing new worlds of technology so fast that if they don't throw you into a catatonic fit, they will challenge your imagination just to keep up, and threaten to overwhelm your ability to absorb it. It has been predicted that the social implications of this technology promise to be somewhere between the eruption of a volcano and the discovery of fire.

CHAIM POTOK
Novelist
You can detach the two lines that form an X and realign them so that they take the shape of a gallows, a crucifix, a plus sign, an equals sign. What will it be, this X Decade? A decade of growing hatreds, hardening separations and Balkan tribalism? A decade of continuing postmodern, American-style lynchings and crucifixions? Or a decade in which we add to the well-being of the country? A decade in which we learn more about the true nature of equality for all Americans?

LAWRENCE ELLISON
Software-company executive
Within a decade or so, anyone will be able to view anything from anywhere at anytime. Text, numbers, audio and high-resolution video will all be integrated on your screen. . . . The impact of these innovations will be no less than that of Westinghouse's electric power on demand. They will so profoundly change our world that 20 years from now, scarcely anyone will be able to remember what life was like without them.

Former Presidential candidate
Financial success and happiness are unrelated. . . . I'm no happier today than I was as a boy in the depression in Texarkana. I was rich then because of my parents. . . . SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Defaults Rise, Posing Peril For Housing

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
As the Giuliani administration tries to rid the city of the expensive task of managing thousands of homes and apartment buildings taken for nonpayment of taxes, a new wave of defaults is threatening to burden the city with thousands of additional units.
The number of buildings in which owners have fallen seriously behind in their taxes has risen sharply in the last five years, from 13,737 in 1989, to 18,003 in 1993. 
 Even more troubling to city officials is that as the number of buildings in default has risen, the number of owners rescuing their properties by paying off taxes has dropped precipitously.
The properties are mostly decrepit structures ranging from single-family homes to large apartment buildings with more than 100 units, generally in poor neighborhoods.
 
Priority on Mayor's Agenda
 The city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which has the task of managing these properties, puts the annual average cost at $3,000 per housing unit. The city is expected to spend about $100 million this year. And that cost does not include the taxes lost when the city takes over.
Since his campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has made it clear that a priority on his housing agenda would be to cut this management burden. Earlier this month he reiterated the goal when he told the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a research organization, that divesting of city-owned property was more than a solution to a fiscal problem.
"By saving millions through the process of divesting itself of property," he said, the city "can, instead of trying to run property, concentrate on stimulating private ownership." The money saved with divestiture, he suggested, could be used to restore properties, for low-cost loans and to rehabilitate abandoned brownstones.
Because of the lingering effects of the recession, which has made it difficult for tenants to pay their rents and landlords to pay their taxes, housing and taxation experts have been warning of a surge in property tax foreclosures for more than two years. But the impact has been delayed because the number of takeovers by the city -- a process known as vesting -- has slowed to a trickle.
The most recent round of vestings was in Queens last September. In Brooklyn, where the number of buildings in default is the highest of any borough with 6,224 in 1993, the city has not foreclosed on any property in two years.
Eamon Moynihan, a spokesman for the Finance Department, the city agency responsible for assessing and collecting taxes, said staff cuts and the increase in properties whose owners are in arrears have substantially slowed the foreclosure process.
The city must search the titles of each delinquent property, Mr. Moynihan said, so anyone who has an interest can be notified before foreclosure.
 
Vulnerability of Tenants
 But some housing advocates say the longer the city postpones the day of reckoning, the higher the eventual cost will be and the more vulnerable tenants in these buildings are to being left homeless.
"By putting off the vesting process for months on end, the city is spending more in the long run," said David R. Jones, executive director of the Community Service Society, a housing, health and education advocacy group for the poor. "As disinvestment in these building escalates, there is no one around to hold things together. By the time the city takes the buildings, they are in terrible shape and what could have been a moderate rehab is a $100,000 job. No one has that kind of money anymore."
The Finance Department's backlog may have bought some time for tax-delinquent landlords. But in addition to the prospect of losing their properties in foreclosure, owners with outstanding tax bills face interest penalties when they settle.
A report by the society showed that most vulnerable buildings were in central Harlem in Manhattan, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Crown Heights and Bushwick in Brooklyn, and Mott Haven in the Bronx.
The statistics show the potential for a crisis. At the end of 1989, the city had tax-arrears notices on file for 13,737 properties. By the end of last year, there were 18,003 properties on the list. In the same period, however, the number of owners getting off the list in a given year declined sharply, from 12,472 in 1989, to 5,691 last year.
The city moves to take buildings when owners fall behind on taxes, sewer and water charges. Mr. Moynihan, the Department of Finance spokesman, said the city files a notice of foreclosure when a property is 12 months behind if its annual tax bill is $2,750 or more. For buildings with lower tax bills, the notice goes out after 36 months of arrears.
Despite the trouble on the horizon, the number of defaults does not match those of the 1970's, when tax arrears and abandonments peaked and the city was taking as many as 10,000 properties a year.
In the mid-1980's, as property values rose, owners were more inclined to try to hold on to their buildings. Since then, the housing department has made steady gains in reducing its housing responsibility, mostly by devising programs to turn buildings over to tenants or nonprofit housing groups or by selling then to private landlords.
In 1986 the department managed 39,551 units in 3,944 properties. As of March of this year, the agency was in charge of 30,826 units in 3,098 buildings. City officials cannot indicate precisely the composition but estimate that one-third are in one- to four-family homes, with the rest in apartment buildings and large multifamily dwellings.
But as the department was working to rid itself of these buildings, the city's real-estate market began to unravel after the stock market crash of October 1987. Landlords had less incentive to try to keep their buildings, and as the recession began reducing the number of jobs in the city, tenants fell behind on their rents.
At the same time, landlords faced higher operating costs, particularly increases in water and sewer fees that resulted from the city's move to a metering system for water charges. Because of the burden on some owners, the city is reviewing the practice and has declared a moratorium on increases in such fees.
Landlords and their advocates link the problem of rising defaults largely to the city system of rent regulations that limit rent increases for many owners. The margin of profit for owners of small buildings like many of those now in arrears is so narrow, they say, that if only one or two tenants stop paying rent can been the kind of financial drain from which an owner cannot recover.
Christine Lippus, the owner of a six-unit building in Bushwick, said she was barely hanging on. So far she has kept up with her tax bills, but she said she did not know how long she would be able to say that. "Some months I don't have enough to pay for this place," she said. "But I live here, too, and if I give up, where will I go?"
Monthly rents range from $218.32 to $476.61 on the apartments, which are all four-room units. Housing experts say it costs about $450 a unit to operate a building.
 
'Bad for the City'
 City Councilman Archie Spigner, a Democrat whose Brooklyn district includes some of the most distressed neighborhoods, has held hearings on abandonment and disinvestment throughout the city.
"We are on the verge of a catastrophe," said Mr. Spigner, chairman of the Committee on Housing and Buildings. "We need to alter public policy to allow private owners a way of keeping their buildings. The current situation is bad for tenants, bad for communities and bad for the city."
Mr. Spigner has advocated loosening regulations limiting rent increases in privately owned apartment buildings. He said one reason for the high number of defaults was that owners who paid inflated prices for properties in the 1980's have high mortgages and other expenses that cannot be covered by regulated rents.
Frank P. Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, said the city would be troubled by these properties as long as the ownership and management of low-income housing was not an economically viable enterprise.
"The root cause of the problem is that there are a lot of poor people in the city who cannot afford to pay rent at a level that makes it economical to maintain their buildings," said Mr. Braconi, who added that he did not believe that rent decontrol would solve the problem.
"The solution," he said, "will come only through a combined effort at the local and Federal levels that includes support for owners of low-income housing and for tenants."

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk
