HEADLINE: Ambivalence Like Rye's May Re-elect Cuomo

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RYE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Ask the residents of this Westchester County town to assess the state of New York State and the response sounds at first like a living advertisement for why Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is sure to be swept from office this November.
Their property taxes drift upward each year. Jobs keep fleeing once-redoubtable local companies like I.B.M. And while their azalea-filled town remains safe enough that car keys are sometimes left in the ignition overnight, they look at crime in New York City and plead for the death penalty. 
 But among the affluent, educated residents here who typify the suburban swing voters vital to Mr. Cuomo's re-election, politics, it seems, is not such a clear-cut thing: as many would give him a fourth term as would oust him. Indeed, as Mr. Cuomo prepares to receive the Democratic nomination in Buffalo this week, he might look to the ambivalence of Rye to understand both why he is in deep trouble this year, and why he is still in the race.
In dozens of recent interviews, people repeatedly said they longed for changes in the state government. "A change of blood always is better," said Alexander Litvinoff, 53, who owns a dry-cleaning shop in town. "New York is a stale state. There has been nothing good for the last three years."
 
Wary of the G.O.P.
 But that didn't always translate into a throw-the-bum-out mentality. Even many of his detractors said they admired Mr. Cuomo's intellect, integrity and speech making. And though the majority were registered Republicans, many expressed wariness of the Republican Party, whose 1990 gubernatorial candidate, Pierre A. Rinfret, was referred to time and again as "a joke."
"I'm a Republican and I vote the Republican line," said Jim Finneran, 47, who owns The Pub, a bar in town. "But I don't think they stand a chance. They just don't match up against the Democrats statewide."
Rye is not exactly Everytown, U.S.A. The shirts in the stores are made of silk and linen, the coffee at the grocery store is Sumatran, the cars along the dogwood-lined streets are typically Volvos and Mercedeses. At a recent City Council meeting, the main topic of discussion was whether to hire a new caterer at the city golf course.
According to the 1990 census, 90 percent of Rye's 15,000 residents were white, 43 percent had a college education or better and two out of three owned their own homes. The median household income was $72,863, about double the rest of the state.
In three previous elections, Mr. Cuomo has won because he and the Republicans split the vote in suburban towns like this one. In Rye itself, where independents are almost as numerous as Democrats and where Republicans outnumber both by three to two, Mr. Cuomo has easily outpolled Republican rivals in his last two races.
But this year Mr. Cuomo's approval rating, at about 36 percent, is near the lowest in his tenure as governor. Crime and taxes, the voter concerns cited most in polls, are traditional Republican issues. And the endorsed Republican candidate, State Senator George E. Pataki, is almost the embodiment of the typical swing voter: grandchild of immigrants, Westchester native, Roman Catholic, Ivy League-educated.
"To some degree Pataki is the swing voter," said a Democratic Party strategist. "The question now is, can he prove he's as attuned to their problems as the Governor is?"
At The Pub, in the heart of Rye's small, boutique-filled shopping district, that question seemed premature because no one knew much about Mr. Pataki. But the patrons were sure of one thing: they were tired of Mario Cuomo.
"He's putting us into the poor house with taxes," said Philip McGovern, 42, a general contractor, as he sipped beer and munched on a hot dog. "This is the only state where you can get a vasectomy on state aid, but the average guy can't get his teeth cleaned. They pay $3,000 a month for putting homeless people in hotels. Who's in charge? Mario wants the kudos, but he doesn't want to make the hard political decisions."
But many residents' disgust with Mr. Cuomo was accompanied by disenchantment with what they saw as a perpetually weak Republican Party.
"If the Republicans put up a viable candidate, my vote is open," said Ted Carroll, 37, the chief financial officer for a Manhattan media company, as he rushed for a morning train clutching a newspaper. "But if it's another Rinfret, forget it. Maybe Howard Stern is the guy."
Citing the two issues that Republicans think will be Mr. Cuomo's downfall, almost everyone interviewed said they supported the death penalty -- Mr. Cuomo has vetoed it 12 years running -- and believed that taxes were too high.
But most people said Mr. Cuomo's stand on capital punishment was not reason enough to vote against him because it seemed rooted in deep moral principles. "I'm for the death penalty, but it doesn't bother me that he's not," said Terry Demas, 56, who runs a video and film store in town. "It's what he believes in."
And unlike in New Jersey, where former Governor Jim Florio drew intense voter ire by raising sales and income taxes, few could pinpoint a single tax that Mr. Cuomo was directly responsible for raising.
That, however, did not mitigate all the anger. "How do we feel about Mario Cuomo? I can sum it up in one sentence: we're moving out," said Emanuel Mafilios, 35, a national sales representative for a plastics company.
Mr. Mafilios, his wife and young daughter are looking to buy a house in nearby Westport, Conn., because property taxes there are 40 percent lower than in Rye, they said. Though Mr. Mafilios knows Mr. Cuomo does not set local property taxes, he ticked off a litany of complaints about the Governor's tenure: climbing welfare costs, inadequate budget policies, higher automobile registration fees and faltering schools.
"He's really slick; he's got an answer for everything," Mr. Mafilios said. "But things don't get better."
Residents were divided over whether to blame Mr. Cuomo for the state's job losses in recent years: more than 500,000 between 1989 and 1993. Some said it was a result of the national recession; others said it was the result of high business costs directly attributable to Mr. Cuomo's policies.
"I don't think you can point a finger at the recession anymore," said Peter Jovanovich, who works for a book publishing company in Manhattan. "You have to ask why is New York doing so much less well than other regions."
Still, Mr. Jovanovich, 45, a registered Republican, said he was pleased that Mr. Cuomo had proposed cutting some business taxes this year. "If he's recognizing he's killing the goose that lays the golden egg, I'll consider him."
 
Respect for Intelligence
 Just as his detractors often could not pinpoint taxes he had raised, Mr. Cuomo's supporters rarely could name a program or policy of his that they liked. More often, their approval was based on respect for what they consider his intelligence, articulateness and honesty.
"He's a fine person who works very hard and is a great speaker," said Andrea McDonald, 32, a mother of three and a registered Republican. "It's what you don't hear. All the things that happen in New York City and its scandals. You never hear about that with him."
Mark Anast, the owner of an upscale jeans store in downtown Rye, said: "I don't think he has anything to prove. He doesn't owe anyone anything. He's not in anybody's pocket."
But if Mr. Cuomo's aides fear any single thing this year, it is the sense among some voters that 12 years is long enough for anyone to be governor. Though that was not a universal complaint in Rye, it could be detected in the voices of a few who wanted someone like Ross Perot to run for governor.
"A guy like that can shake the tree a little, and you need somebody like that," said Harold Aken, 36, a local fireman and lifelong resident. "We're a little too complacent. A little change is good."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Some old assumptions about inflation may no longer hold. Business is booming at the Georgia-Pacific linerboard plant near Monticello, Miss., which is running at beyond 100 percent of its intended capacity. But the plant exhibits few characteristics of previous boom times. Defying the conventional inflationary assumptions, American factories appear to be undergoing a profound shift that finds them doing more with less. [Page A1.]
The Federal Communications Commission is about to overhaul its plan for selling off radio frequencies covering a new generation of wireless telephone and data "personal communication services" in an effort to make the licenses more attractive to bidders. [D1.]
After 12 years of perceived neglect by the Federal Communications Commission, the role of members of minority groups in broadcasting has moved up on the agenda as the commission tries to increase minority ownership and employment. [D1.]
 
International
Responsibility for millions of dollars in damages from certain types of nuclear accidents outside the United States could shift from private companies to the Federal Government, under a draft proposal for a new international nuclear liability treaty sought by the Clinton Administration. [D1.]
Germany's medical establishment is in turmoil over accusations by the nation's biggest health insurer that medical supply companies bribed surgeons at public hospitals to overcharge the national health care system by millions of dollars annually for artificial heart valves. [D1.]
Six years after Vietnam began changing to a market economy, the country's scientists have lost their Government subsidies for research and are now struggling to feed their families. [C9.]

HEADLINE: Farm Equipment Sales Make Surprising Gains

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 30

 BODY:
After more than a decade of drastic cost-cutting, losses and consolidation, farm equipment makers have been repeatedly surprising Wall Street lately with sharp earnings increases, thanks to stronger-than-expected sales of tractors, combines and other equipment.
The latest sign of revival came last week when Deere & Company, the venerable market leader, reported earning $189.3 million, a big gain over last year's performance, in its fiscal second quarter and far more than Wall Street stock analysts had expected. Its worldwide agricultural equipment sales for the quarter jumped 19 percent from a year ago, to more than $1.3 billion.
 
Restructuring Praised
 "Deere and the entire industry have done a fantastic job of restructuring," said John McGinty, who follows the equipment makers from Boston for CS First Boston. "When volume goes up, earnings take off." 
 Sales of tractors and combines in the United States were up 16 percent in the first four months of this year, an acceleration from the overall rate of just under 10 percent in 1993, according to the most recent estimate by the Equipment Manufacturers Institute, a trade group based here. The growth puts the industry on track for its best year since 1990, and analysts say conditions are ripe for the recovery to continue.
Farm incomes are high, interest rates are relatively low and debts are at the lowest levels since the early 1960's. Also, many farmers need new equipment because they bought so little during the 1980's and much of what they are using now is aged, patched-up and limping along or is ill suited to newer, conservation-oriented planting techniques. And with total acreage planted in corn and soybeans up this year, many farmers need new machinery to deal efficiently with the larger workload.
"There comes a time when you've just got to do something," said Dan Troyer, an Indiana farmer who has spent about $285,000 for two new Case International tractors and a combine in the last year, his first major purchases in five years.
Robert Combs, a Deere spokesman, said, "The excitement at the retail level is higher than it's been in years."
All of this has caught the attention of investors, who have bid up the shares of Deere and other publicly traded farm equipment makers. Tenneco Inc. responded last month by announcing plans to raise about $500 million by selling at least 35 percent of its J. I. Case subsidiary to the public. The deal will make the 152-year-old Case, based in Racine, Wis., a public-traded enterprise for the first time since 1970.
 
Makers Moving Gingerly
 Still, rather than rushing to stoke the current sales upturn, Deere, Case, the Ford New Holland subsidiary of Fiat and other equipment makers are moving gingerly, as if they scarely recognize the economic terrain confronting them after so many wrenching changes. Rather than letting inventories rise in anticipation of robust demand, they are keeping production schedules tightly matched to orders and gradually scaling back on discounts, extended warranties and other inducements they have used to increase sales in the past.
The biggest reason for caution is that American farming has changed too much for history to be a reliable guide to demand. To start with, there are fewer farmers, and the biggest ones, who buy most of the equipment, shop cautiously after having seen the disastrous results of borrowing too heavily in the 1980's.
Also, many farmers are more willing than before to hire others to harvest, spray or plant, rather than invest in new equipment.
They also use soil-conserving planting and tilling methods that may require new attachments but that allow their tractors, which are much more expensive, to last years longer than they did in the past.
The equipment producers are also worried about overextending themselves at home because the outlook in Europe is so dismal. Many American manufacturers have major operations there that focus on equipment suited for Europe's smaller farms. Unit sales in Europe have fallen 50 percent since the early 1980's and no end to the decline is in sight. Farmers' incomes there are declining as government subsidies are reduced.
 
Constant Price Wars in Europe
 With a highly fragmented market, weak local farm equipment companies there engage in constant price wars as they struggle for enough of the shrinking pie to avoid bankruptcy. And while developing countries are potentially huge markets, few farmers there can afford the technology-rich machinery now being made in the developed world.
The quest for higher sales volumes is crucial to prospects for higher profits because equipment makers are finding growing resistance to price increases. Farmers are upset that prices for tractors and combines, the industry's two big-ticket items, have jumped more than 225 percent since the 1970's while crop prices have risen just 40 percent. Manufacturers say the new equipment is worth it because it is much more productive, but experts who track equipment purchases, like Dennis M. Conley at the University of Nebraska, say that sales drop 2.3 percent every time tractor prices are raised 1 percent.
One sign of resistance is the strong market for used equipment. Another is the accelerating sales of Belarus Machinery Inc., the Milwaukee-based distributor of tractors and combines from the former Soviet Union. Belarus's machinery has a reputation for being ponderous, less reliable and primitive compared with the newest models from companies like Deere, Case, and Ford New Holland, but it sells for as much as 40 percent less.
"The big guys have moved away from what farmers can afford," said E. W. Muehlhausen, Belarus's manager of operations.
 
A Chastening Tumble

The industry has certainly had plenty of practice at belt-tightening, having struggled through a crash in demand in the early 1980's followed by a chastening tumble in 1991 and 1992 that cut short a rebound.
Some big names did not survive. International Harvester, the one-time industry leader whose origins date to the invention of the mechanical reaper in 1831, was absorbed by Case in 1985. That was one of five major deals in the mid-1980's that cut production capacity in half as demand plummeted and the industry lost billions of dollars. Overall employment fell nearly 60 percent, from almost 160,000 people in 1979 to 66,000 in 1986.
The consolidation continued after a rebound in the late 80's. Ford, having previously merged with New Holland Inc., ended up last year as a wholly owned subsidiary of Fiat of Italy, ending ties to agriculture dating to Henry Ford's days as a pioneer tractor builder. And Massey-Ferguson, still the world's largest tractor maker despite having lost much of its North American market, was sold last month to the AGCO Corporation, a holding company based in Norcross, Ga.
One old face angling to squeeze back into the fray is Caterpillar Inc., which began as a maker of steam-driven farm tractors more than a century ago in California. Cat, the world's largest construction equipment company, had all but disappeared from agriculture by 1987, when it introduced high-powered tractors that roll on rubber tracks instead of wheels. Next year it will begin shipping the first lower-horsepower Challengers, aimed at grain farmers with operations as small as 800 acres, promoting them as vehicles that can operate in fields too wet for wheeled tractors.
 
Sales Peaked in 1973
 No one expects a return to the glory days of the 1970's, when huge export deals with the Soviet Union and high inflation rates that encouraged heavy borrowing and expansion had equipment flying off the dealers' lots and had factories operating at more than 80 percent of capacity. Domestic tractor sales peaked at nearly 157,000 in 1973, and 139,000 were sold in 1979. More than 30,000 combines a year were sold during the decade.
The bottom came in 1986, when annual sales of tractors fell to 47,000 units and combines to below 10,000. Dealers desperate to move inventory were selling products at half their list price. A strong dollar only made matters worse for the manufacturers, crimping exports and giving companies like Kubota of Japan a chance to invade the American market. At one point, Case simply stopped manufacturing entirely for 75 days.
Today, inventories are down to a half a year's sales for major companies, less than half of the level they stood at when the current rebound began. Dealers complain that they have to order some products as much as a year in advance.
Some smaller "short-line" companies that focus on one or two types of products are actually stretched beyond capacity. Kinze Manufacturing Inc., which makes planters and grain wagons, increased production capacity by 50 percent last year but still had to stop taking 1994 orders just six weeks after it opened the books last summer.
"We're completely sold out," said Jon Kinzenbaw, president of the privately held company based in Williamsburg, Iowa.

HEADLINE: Job Market Gains Expected

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The job market is expected to improve slightly this summer, bolstered by strength in construction, manufacturing and retailing, a quarterly survey said yesterday.
The forecast, by Manpower Inc., a temporary-employment company based in Milwaukee, showed increased optimism for all regions, with the South and Midwest having the most job opportunities and the Northeast and West lagging. 
 Manpower said that 29 percent of employers interviewed said they intended to increase hiring in the July-September quarter and that 7 percent projected decreases.
"It will be the best summer since 1989," said Michael Evans, an economist and president of the Evans Group, based in Boca Raton, Fla.
Manpower said the biggest gains were expected in construction, wholesale and retail businesses and manufacturing and the weakest in transportation, public utilities, education and other service industries.

HEADLINE: New York Hospitals Are Facing A Sharp Increase in Empty Beds

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

 BODY:
The number of empty hospital beds in the New York City area is growing steadily, only a few years after patients faced a critical shortage of space. The reduced demand has already shut down entire wings and caused layoffs of almost 2,000 workers over the last two years, hospital officials say.
The decrease in demand comes after a similar trend emerged nationwide, driven in part by a turn to health maintenance organizations that emphasize preventive and outpatient care. And the decline is expected to continue. 
 "They were having trouble finding space for their patients, and now they're having trouble finding patients for their space," said Peter Slocum, a spokesman for the state Health Department. "In the late 80's they were concerned about having the capacity to keep their business going, but in the brave new world of reform there's a much more long-term concern about the hospitals' survival."
The average daily census of patients in New York City hospitals last year was 19,667 people, or 81.6 percent of available beds, according to the state Health Department. That was a decline of more than 4 percent from the average of 20,536 two years earlier.
Public health experts also attribute the decline to medical advances that have shortened patient stays, and to some extent, a reduction in the length of stay of AIDS patients, as more care has become available at home, in hospices or on an outpatient basis.
As a result, state health department officials say they expect the size of hospitals in New York City, its suburbs and the state as a whole to shrink by 20 percent in the next five years. And inevitably, said Dr. Mark R. Chassin, the state health commissioner, a number of institutions will be forced to close.
"I think there are going to be a lot of hospital closures," Dr. Chassin said, "and I hope we can manage that in a way that won't cause access problems in rural as well as inner-city areas."
Marc H. Lory, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, said, "I'd be lying if I said we weren't nervous, but I guess all of us are sort of hoping it's the other guy."
Columbia-Presbyterian recently laid off 350 of its 6,735 workers and closed a unit with 166 of its 1,460 beds -- temporarily, he said, until administrators see whether the trend holds. He said the hospital started thinking about closing beds and taking other economy measures about 18 months ago.
Large institutions are not as vulnerable as smaller, community hospitals, which are most at risk. But excess capacity is encouraging larger hospitals to merge with smaller ones that will feed them patients who need high-tech care in return for protection from extinction.
And ultimately, proponents of community health care say the declining demand for inpatient services will force all hospitals to redefine themselves, by shifting much of their work to outpatient clinics that provide primary care, with fewer, smaller hospitals left to tend only the sickest patients.
Gerry Hudson, executive vice president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care workers, said the future of the health care system depends upon the hospitals' ability to convert to a primary care system that will transfer its resources to community clinics, where health care is in short supply.
"We're looking for funds for a conversion plan pretty much like the military has," he said, to retrain health care workers for employment in new settings. "If you do it any other way you'd have huge layoffs." He said a vast reduction would devastate the local economy, in which the health care industry in a leading employer.
In some ways, the situation is analogous to the downsizing of the military, with some in the industry arguing that major reductions could leave communities vulnerable to surprise assaults like the AIDS epidemic and the resurgence of tuberculosis.
"AIDS teaches us we ought to expect the unexpected, and there are reasons to be cautious about how much smaller the system gets," said David A. Gould, vice president of the United Hospital Fund of New York, a philanthropic, policy and research organization.
He said a new generation of surgical procedures still being developed, like gene therapy, for example, could soon create new demand for hospital beds. "Volatility makes it difficult to plan," he said, adding that the real danger for patients in a shrinking industry is not the hospitals that have closed but those that are struggling to remain open. "The two or three years before they close, do you really want to be a patient in one of those places?" he asked.
But in both public and private New York City hospitals, the number of empty beds has increased sharply since mid-1992, with an occupancy rate dipping from over 90 percent at the height of the hospital bed shortage in the late 80's to 85.7 percent in 1991 and 81.6 percent in 1993, according to the state Health Department.
As the trend continues, some hospitals are trimming excess capacity as aggressively as possible, convinced that hospitals of the future will be significantly smaller. Others have taken a wait-and-see approach, hoping to protect their investment in the beds they have now.
 
Shorter Stays, More Patients
 The average length of stay also decreased by half a day over the last year, said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
"We dropped a full day in length of stay in a little over a year," said Mr. Lory, of Columbia-Presbyterian. "That may not seem like a lot, but if you take the size of our institution, one day equals 1,400 empty beds."
Columbia-Presbyterian is at relatively low risk, he said, because it maintains a high turnover of patients.
To remain solvent, hospitals are in the difficult and rather paradoxical position of trying to attract more patients but for shorter stays. That is because New York is one of only two states in the country -- Maryland is the other -- that reimburse the hospital based on the diagnosis rather than the number of days a patient stays, even if the patient is privately insured. The state's reimbursement policy means the hospital makes more money by discharging patients quickly, since it is paid the same whether the patient stays a day or a month.
Other hospitals that have cut their inpatient capacity include St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, which this spring eliminated a total of 53 beds in two medical and surgery units and two psychiatric inpatient units, resulting in some layoffs. New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center cut 80 beds in two medical and surgery units between 1989 and 1992 after a concerted effort to reduce their patients' length of stay. The hospital reports that since the cutbacks its occupancy rates have risen to about 90 percent.
"We've been proactive and tried to move on this ourselves," said George Vecchione, director of New York Hospital.
The emptiest wings in most hospitals these days are in the medical and surgery areas; in pediatric wards, absent the young patients eating ice cream after their tonsillectomies, which is now day surgery, and in maternity wards, which keep women for increasingly shorter stays after delivery. At the same time, there is a shift in emphasis to intensive-care beds as hospitals increasingly concentrate on sicker patients.
 
More Space in Other Areas
 There is even more excess capacity in some areas of the region, with New Jersey reporting a 70 percent occupancy rate in 1993, down from 73 percent in 1992.
And across the country, hospital occupancy rates began declining more than a decade ago, with an national average occupancy rate that now hovers around 65 percent, according to the American Hospital Association.
New York is actually the last state in the country to see its hospitals emptying, primarily because it is the nation's most highly regulated health care system; while other regions overbuilt, New York forced its hospitals to prove the need for every new bed, which must be certified by the state health department.
"I can't think of a new hospital built in New York in the last 20 years, while across the country you had enormous growth," said Jeffrey Merrill, a professor at Columbia University's School of Public Health.
Health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care were also slow to take hold in New York, because of the opposition of an unusually strong medical community. Unlike the business people who run most hospitals in other parts of the country, health officials said, the top executives of many major New York hospitals are doctors.
 
The AIDS Factor
 And in the late mid-1980's, just as medical advances were starting to create some excess capacity, the AIDS crisis hit New York with particular virulence, devastating communities but reviving several hospitals.
"AIDS and TB had a dramatic impact on why we haven't lost" more inpatient demand, said John Billings, an associate professor of health policy management at New York University. "But we're starting to manage AIDS in a different way and patients have decided they'd rather be treated in other settings."
Preliminary state health department figures for the last quarter of 1993 indicate that the hospital census of AIDS patients has leveled off, Mr. Slocum said.
Sidney Pitter, a 33-year-old opera singer who has AIDS, is among those who, with the help of a visiting nurse and a nurse and lay volunteer with the supportive care program at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medcical Center of New York, has been able to stay out of the hospital for most of the three years since his illness was diagnosed.
"In Sidney's case, we really have clearly been able to keep him out of the hospital because he's forgetful about taking and refilling his medication" for toxoplasmosis, a parasitic infection of the brain that responds to the medicine he takes daily, said Patricia Moule, a nurse with the St. Vincent's supportive care program.
During a recent visit from Ms. Moule, Mr. Pitter offhandedly mentioned that his vision had been slightly blurred; he was immediately hospitalized with retinitis, and doctors said the nurse's timely intervention probably saved Mr. Pitter's sight. When he was released on Friday, after his second hospital stay in three years, Ms. Moule also helped him home.
Some of the older patients who once filled New York's hospital beds because there was no room in the state's tightly regulated nursing homes have also been moved out of hospitals now, with the building of 5,000 new beds statewide over the last several years.
 
More Outpatient Service
 And the number of procedures that can be done on an outpatient basis, or as day surgery is growing rapidly, now including such serious operations as a partial mastectomy, hernia repair, and the setting of broken bones that have penetrated the skin. Exploratory surgeries are increasingly rare, and admissions for a battery of tests are all but unheard of.
In the newly competitive environment in New York, hospitals have started aggressive public relations campaigns, including mailings and advertisements.
In the future, Dr. Chassin said, the institutions that survive will specialize. "You'll have cardiac surgery in one, obstetrics in another, instead of hospitals that have seen themselves as full service providers," he said. Many others, he said, "should be looking for a new mission in life."

HEADLINE: Slow Gains by Minority Broadcasters

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
After 12 years of perceived neglect by Republican-dominated Federal Communications Commissions, the role of minorities in broadcasting has moved up on the agenda as the commission tries to increase minority ownership and employment.
In February, the agency decided to increase greatly the fines it may impose on stations that do not meet its standards for employment of women and minorities. Under its new rules, fines of up to $250,000 may be imposed on a station owner, compared with a previous maximum of $20,000. 
 The commission and its chairman, Reed E. Hundt, are also looking into whether the ground-breaking rules adopted in 1978 to increase minority ownership have produced sufficient gains. Those rules created tax and other incentives to encourage purchases of radio and television stations by minorities.
The Federal regulations have roughly tripled the number of minority-owned stations, to nearly 3 percent of the total, from less than 1 percent. But "over all, the increase has been relatively small," James H. Quello, an F.C.C. commissioner, said.
And members of minority groups and others say it will take more than the support of the F.C.C. to do more, mainly because of daunting economic hurdles.
"In the best of economic times, the bank is only going to lend you a portion of the purchase price," said James S. Winston, executive director of the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters, whose 110 members represent 202 stations. "Even if you get the loan, where do you get the personal equity capital? We have been a community of working people, not business owners."
Others say a succession of Republican chairmen at the F.C.C. have turned a blind eye to minority issues. "Part of the difficulty for minorities has been economics, but that has been compounded by successive Republican administrations that have sought to frustrate its implementation," said Andrew Jay Schwartzman, executive director of the Media Access Project, a watchdog group based in Washington.
Mark Fowler, the chairman of the agency from 1981 to 1987, suggested several times that the F.C.C. should discard the procedures that awarded station licenses to members of minority groups when all the other qualifications were equal. Even after Congress passed legislation that retained the preferential policy, the commission showed little enthusiasm, preferring to concentrate on the larger issue of deregulation, according to some broadcasting experts.
But deregulation, too, has set back minority ownership, allowing larger broadcasting companies with deeper pockets to acquire additional licenses, increasing the pressure on smaller companies like those owned by minorities.
One reason for encouraging minority ownership is to increase minority employment. "The absence of minority owners meant the pressure to hire people unlike oneself was very low," David M. Rubin, dean of the S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University, said. "So white owners hired white males. Minority owners are more willing to hire minorities."
But it is unclear how either minority ownership or employment influences programming. "There is very little research yet determining how their presence in the programming and news-making process affects decisions on news coverage and entertainment," Dr. Rubin said. "The assumption has been that it would. But others feel that the medium and career pressures mold the individuals."
If the minority stake is small in media regulated by the Government, it still compares favorably with minority ownership of print media. While members of minority groups own hundreds of daily and weekly newspapers and monthly magazines aimed at minority audiences, they own no mainstream newspaper or magazine in America.
Yet there are some success stories. One of the nation's leading black business executives is J. Bruce Llewellyn, whose diverse business interests include WKVW-TV, the ABC affiliate in Buffalo, and Garden State Cable Television, a cable system in New Jersey. U.S. Radio L.P., a limited partnership in Philadelphia controlled by Ragan A. Henry now owns 10 radio stations. Raul Alarcon Jr.'s Spanish Broadcasting System, based in New York, owns seven radio stations.
 
 
Exceptions to the Rule
 Still, such successes do not represent a trend. "They do not speak to the question of overall opportunities available," Mr. Winston of the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters said. "One or two exceptions don't disprove the rule."
And some owners of broadcast properties say that the minority ownership numbers are misleading. "Many are small stations in small markets so they don't even get the proportionate amount of advertising dollars that ownership suggests," Mr. Henry said.
When the F.C.C. adopted the new regulations, less than 1 percent of the nation's broadcasting properties -- 49 stations -- were owned by members of minority groups. Today there are more, but the 300 stations owned by members of minority groups represent only 2.7 percent of the 11,021 stations in the United States, and many are the weakest in their markets. Of the nation's 1,151 television stations, minorities own 27; of the 9,870 radio stations, 273 are minority-owned.
To a large extent, the progress has been an outgrowth of the F.C.C.'s initiatives. In 1978, the commission instituted a two-part program. One allowed radio and television station owners to defer capital gains if they sold to a minority bidder. This "tax certificate" program was invoked in the sales of 275 television and radio stations, and of 20 cable systems. The second part of the program allowed radio stations that were deemed to have violated the F.C.C.'s rules to sell to members of minority groups rather than lose their licenses. Thirty-eight sales were made under that provision.
Yet for most investors in radio stations in the 1980's, the timing could not have been worse.
"If you bought a station in that period, you generally overpaid, were overleveraged and are probably suffering now," said Erwin G. Krasnow, a partner at the law firm of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand and former general counsel for the National Association of Broadcasters, a trade group in Washington.
 
 
Lower Revenues
 A subsequent decline in advertising spending hurt both radio and television revenues, making it harder for new owners to pay off their debts.
That made it more difficult to get financial backing. "The recession dried up the financing in the industry and minorities were hit pretty hard," Mr. Henry of U.S. Radio said. That, perhaps, is one reason tax certificates dropped sharply in 1990, to 17, from 42 the previous year.
"This is a high-leverage business, and the banks do not consider us bankable," Mary Helen Barro, vice president of the American Hispanic-Owned Radio Association, said.
The worst casualties of the 1980's were mainly smaller stations that lacked the ability to vie for programming, which had often already been acquired by rivals.
Nowhere was the predicament clearer than at Blackstar Entertainment, a television company in Washington owned by John Oxendine. In 1987, Mr. Oxendine's three stations needed money and programming.
"In order to borrow money from banks, you have to have some cash flow," Mr. Oxendine said in a recent interview. "To have cash flow, you had to have programming."
Mr. Oxendine sold a 45 percent stake in Blackstar to Silver King Broadcasting, a division of Home Shopping Network Inc., for $5 million in nonvoting stock. Under the contract, Blackstar must carry Home Shopping Network's programming for 22 hours a day on its three stations, and buy Silver King's shares back if it does not.
 
 
New Ownership Rule
 It is not only the lack of programming that squeezes minority owners. Despite the recent support from the F.C.C., the agency has been criticized for its decision last year that allows a single owner to own more than one AM and one FM station in a given area. Mr. Quello of the commission said the rule was adopted to save stations that might otherwise have gone bankrupt.
But Ms. Barro, who owns KAFY-AM in Bakersfield, Calif., and hopes to buy another FM station, said the changes hurt. "Now I have a competitor with three stations so they can promise advertisers a larger audience," she said.
Another sore point among some in the minority community is a practice known as "fronting" -- the purchase of a station by a group of investors led by a member of a minority group, who puts up little money and then sells out to his partners, generally nonminority buyers.
No data are available on the extent of fronting, but the practice was encouraged when the F.C.C., in 1984, opened the door to rapid resale by eliminating a three-year minimum holding period for station ownership. That change was made in the name of deregulation.
"That decision turned broadcast properties into commodities where for the first time you could make money from stations as investment vehicles and many people took advantage of that," Mr. Krasnow said.
 
 
Times Mirror Deal
 The most recent example was the $320 million sale in 1993 of the Times Mirror Company's four television stations to a group led by Ibrahim Morales, a New York-based businessman who put up $30,000 of his own money and another $123,000 he borrowed. The agreement let Times Mirror put off paying $80 million in taxes, while giving Mr. Morales the right to sell his control block for $1 million within two years of the deal.
Mr. Llewellyn, the black business executive, said he did not object to minorities selling their stakes, but said buyers should be required to put up more capital, so as to assume a significant risk.
But Mr. Oxendine of Blackstar said buyers should be able do what they want. He also suggested that the seller should have to put some of his gain into an escrow fund for minorities.
Mr. Oxendine also called Mr. Llewellyn a hypocrite. "Now that he has made his money, he is raising the hurdles for other buyers," Mr. Oxendine said. "You don't have to own 50 percent of a business to run it. Anybody in their right mind knows the real test is a control test. If the rules he is advocating were in place, he would not be in business. He is talking nonsense."

HEADLINE: U.N. Council Urges North Korea To Preserve Atom-Fuel Evidence

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
In a last-ditch effort to avert a political crisis, the United Nations Security Council urged North Korea today to preserve evidence of how much nuclear fuel it may have diverted to its weapons program.
Adopting a position worked out earlier today among the five countries with veto power -- the United States, China, Russia, Britain and France -- the Security Council issued what amounted to a final warning that the North Koreans not cross an important threshold. 
 The statement the Security Council approved unanimously today carries less weight than a full Council resolution, but was politically palatable to the Chinese, whose support is important. The statement also had no explicit threat of economic sanctions, another move to win China's approval.
In a parallel diplomatic move reflecting the situation's increasing urgency, Secretary of State Warren Christopher sent a message to the Chinaese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, over the weekend imploring Beijing to use its influence to persuade North Korea to abandon its nuclear program.
President Clinton cited China's ability to put pressure on North Korea as one reason he decided last week to renew China's favorable trade status with virtually no conditions. But it remained unclear whether the Administration's conciliatory approach toward Bejing would yield the benefits that the White House has claimed.
Other senior Administration officials have said publicly that they simply do not know whether Beijing is willing or able to influence the North Koreans, or support tough economic sanctions in the United Nations if North Korea continues to defy international efforts to halt its nuclear program.
China's concerns are twofold. American officials say Beijing shares Washington's goal of having a nuclear-free Korean peninsula. But China also does not want to risk the instability that imposing sanctions on the North could bring. China has historically opposed applying economic sanctions to rogue nations.
Today's debate among the five permanent members, in fact, centered on how tough the statement should be. American officials said France sought to make explicit the threat of economic sanctions if North Korea failed to comply, but China balked at that wording.
But no one doubts that the crisis has intensified in recent days as North Korea has stepped up a seemingly relentless effort to remove spent fuel rods from a nuclear reactor. One Administration official said today that the pace of withdrawal had accelerated even beyond the heightened tempo first detected last week.
The International Atomic Energy Agency, which sent inspectors to observe the removal of fuel rods at North Korea's main reactor at Yongbyon, has cautioned that the North is within days of destroying important evidence of how much nuclear fuel has been shifted to its weapons program.
Washington has threatened to seek economic sanctions against the North if the evidence is ruined. North Korea has denied that it has diverted fuel but at the same time has refused to agree to allow inspections to resolve the issue. The Government in the North has said it would consider sanctions tantamount to an act of war.
 
Time Slipping Away
 The hastily convened meeting of the five permanent members today reflected the view of many officials that the time to reach a diplomatic solution is slipping away, and that a Security Council debate on sanctions may come soon.
"There's a growing gloom that the possibility to preserve historical analysis will be destroyed," said one senior American official, who had expressed some optimism as late as Saturday that a compromise could be worked out.
Administration officials expressed exasperation at the latest twist in the tortuous talks with the North Koreans, where optimistic predictions have repeatedly collapsed under warnings of impending confrontation.
Just last week, the Administration signaled a conciliatory stance toward the North, offering to open a new round of high-level talks about diplomatic and economic ties that North Korea has long sought.
 
U.S. Goes the Last Mile
 "We've walked up to this point before, and there's always been some way in which that irrevocable action has been avoided by them," said a senior American official. "Whether this time we'll play the same cat-and-mouse game, or this will be the action to trigger stronger measures, like sanctions, we probably won't know until Tuesday or Wednesday."
The Administration has argued to countries reluctant to consider sanctions, like China, that Washington has gone the last mile diplomatically. The Administration has offered North Korea political and economic inducements if it would halt the removal of fuel rods, and would only resort to sanctions once all diplomatic options were exhausted.
At issue now is the atomic energy agency's demand that North Korea put aside 300 of the 8,000 fuel rods so that measurements might be carried out in the future to determine how much plutonium the North might have diverted to its weapons program in past years.
Hans Blix, the agency's director, said last week that the North had already removed more than 3,000 of the rods, effectively discharging nearly half the fuel in the reactor's core. Two international inspectors remain at the site.
American officials have held out hope that a technical compromise could be worked out in which the North identify the 300 crucial fuel rods for future analysis in a different way than how the atomic energy agency insisted.

SECTION: Section D; Page 9; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1071 words

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Ezra Taft Benson, the president of the Mormon Church since 1985 and a Secretary of Agriculture in the Eisenhower Administration, died yesterday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 94.
Mr. Benson, who had been in frail health in recent years and rarely appeared in public, died of congestive heart failure, said Bruce Olsen, a spokesman for the church. Mr. Benson suffered a broken hip several years ago when he was standing near a horse and it rolled over on him. 
 Mr. Benson took charge of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints nine years ago, as it was emerging as one of the world's fastest-growing denominations. It was also enjoying great prosperity (to remain in good standing, Mormons must donate 10 percent of their income to the church), and its political influence was growing, particularly among conservative Republicans. Indeed, Mr. Benson once questioned whether it was possible to be a good Mormon and a liberal Democrat at the same time.
Mr. Benson became well known in the 1960's and 1970's for his opposition to the civil rights and the women's movements and for his association with the John Birch Society. In 1980 he angered liberal Mormons when he declared in a speech that the church might begin endorsing political candidates, something it had not done since its leaders told Mormons to choose President Herbert Hoover over his Democratic challenger, Franklin D. Roosevelt, in 1932.
 
Mission Work in Youth
 Mr. Benson's family had been prominent in the church for generations, and he himself had been committed to its cause since his days as a youthful missionary in the British Isles. He had been next in line to the leadership since 1973, when he became president of the Council of the Twelve Apostles, the second-ranking Mormon Board after the First Presidency, consisting of the church president and his two-man council.
The council chose its senior member, Mr. Benson, as president of the church in 1985, on the death of 90-year-old Spencer W. Kimball, who had himself been in frail health for several years. As president of the council, Mr. Benson was in line to become president of the church; church officials said the selection of anyone else would have been a departure from established procedure. The current president of the council and probable successor to Mr. Benson is Howard W. Hunter, 86.
Mr. Benson was made leader of the Mormon Church at a time of some uncertainty and turmoil for the Mormon Church at large and in its headquarters in Salt Lake City.
Mr. Kimball, the president for 12 years, was widely regarded as a progressive force for modernization in a church distinguished by conservative values.
Under Mr. Benson, membership in the church grew to 8.7 million, church officials said.
 
A Professor of Agriculture
 Mr. Benson, a professor of agriculture who founded an organization of farm cooperatives, came to national prominence in 1953 as Secretary of Agriculture in the Eisenhower Administration. He was one of the few Cabinet-level appointees to remain in office for both Eisenhower terms, an accomplishment attributed to Mr. Benson's doggedness in the face of opposition. On a trip to Sioux Falls, S.D., he was pelted with eggs by farmers. Testifying before the Senate Agriculture Committee, he was hectored; it took him an hour and a half to get through a three-page statement. His only displays of anger were a reddening of his neck and a defiantly outward thrust of his lower lip.
In later years he was openly critical of Eisenhower's views, calling them socialistic. He also condemned welfare programs as "galloping socialism" leading to Communism.
After leaving Washington, he became closely associated with, but never joined, the John Birch Society, a right-wing political organization for which his son Reed eventually served as press officer.
In the 1960's and 1970's, Mr. Benson accused the civil rights movement of advancing Communist causes, called the graduated income tax "Marxist" and criticized detente with the Soviet Union.
He was outspoken in his belief that a Mormon woman's place was her home. "The undermining of the home and family is on the increase, with the devil anxiously working to displace the father as the head of the home and create rebellion among the children," he said in 1975. "Working mothers should remember that their children usually need more of a mother than of money."
 
Son of Early Settlers
 Ezra Taft Benson was born Aug. 4, 1899, in Whitney, Idaho. His parents were among the early settlers of southern Idaho. He was also the great-grandson of Ezra T. Benson, a church pioneer who trekked to the valley of the Great Salt Lake in 1847 with Brigham Young after Joseph Smith, founder of the church, was slain in Illinois.
Mr. Benson was distantly related to President William Howard Taft and his son Robert A. Taft, the Republican Senator from Ohio.
As a young man, he was active in scouting and church auxiliaries. He served as a missionary in Britain for two years, until 1923, when he enrolled at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah. He graduated with honors in 1927, and the university's yearbook, The Banyan, named him "most likely to succeed."
His missionary work also opened the door for him to the Mormon campus's most prestigious church club, the Young Doctors of Divinity.
 
Adviser to Roosevelt
 Mr. Benson earned a master's degree in farm economics at Iowa State College, now Iowa State University. He served for a year as a county extension marketing agent in Idaho before taking charge of a newly established Department of Agricultural Economics and Marketing at the University of Idaho at Boise.
Working in a time of economic hardship for farmers, he helped form the Idaho Cooperative Council, and in 1939 he was elected executive secretary of the National Council of Farmers Cooperatives. In World War II he was a member of an agricultural advisory board for President Roosevelt.
Meanwhile, Mr. Benson continued his church work. In 1943 he became a member of the Council of Twelve Apostles.
His wife, Flora Smith Amussen Benson, died in 1992 after 65 years of marriage. Mr. Benson is survived by their two sons, Reed of Provo and Mark of Salt Lake City; four daughters, Barbara Walker of Calgary, Alberta, Beverly Parker of Salt Lake City, Bonnie Madsen of Littleton, Colo., and Beth Burton of Frankfurt; 34 grandchildren and 55 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: High Homicide Rate Leaves New Orleans Fearful

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, May 30

 BODY:
The casual visitor here sees the city's beguiling facades, but, like the rows of boarded-up houses only a few blocks from the elegant ones, fear lurks nearby. Murder is booming in New Orleans.
In 1993, with nearly 80 homicides per 100,000 people, the city's homicide rate led Detroit and Washington, two other high-crime cities, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. In the first quarter of this year, the homicide rate for the city of New Orleans was up 36 percent over last year, and it was still leading the other two cities' rates. The homicide rate of the New Orleans metropolitan area led all others in 1992, the last year for which Federal figures are available. 
 This month, the homicide countreached a new intensity, with 195 for 1994 through May 30. Six people were killed in one day this month; the coroner said bodies were piling up so fast that his staff was overwhelmed. Also this month, New Orleans recorded its youngest shooting victims of the year: children 9 and 2 years old. And a tourist was killed, a relatively rare occurrence that nonetheless makes officials uneasy because tourism is the city's fastest-growing industry.
The new Mayor, Marc Morial, devoted his first big initiative to a series of crime-fighting measures, including a tough curfew for youths 17 and under.
Announcing the measures two weeks after he took office earlier this month, Mr. Morial said his city was in a "deep, deep crisis." In a poll taken on May 9, 10 and 11 for the Mayor, 86 percent of the 600 people surveyed listed crime as the city's biggest problem.
In a Central City neighborhood where houses need paint and boards sag, behind the barbed wire and "Bad Dog" sign of her aunt's house, Jessie Mae Brady, a neighbor of the 9-year-old shooting victim, said: "Here in New Orleans, you never know when they're going to strike. It pays to be afraid."
Fear has helped double the number of burglar-alarm companies operating in the city since 1980. New Orleans has lost over 130,000 residents since 1960, many of them whites who have fled to the safety of the suburbs.
Fear has also put guns in the pockets and desk drawers of merchants along Magazine Street, made Uptown residents circle the block before emerging from their cars if a stranger is spotted and forced residents of housing projects to sleep on the floor when gunfire is heard.
"Sometimes you think if it's less shots, no one got killed. If it's a whole lot, somebody got messed up," said Emma Brown, who lives in the grim St. Thomas Housing Development.
 
Unjustified Fear?
 Crime experts and some officials say the fear is not entirely justified. In 1993 New Orleans had lower per-capita rates of robbery and aggravated assault than Detroit and Washington. Nor can the city claim the distinction of being the nation's homicide capital, even though its metropolitan area was ranked number one. The city of Gary, Ind., had a higher homicide rate last year than New Orleans, which was ahead of the cities of Washington and Detroit.
Finally, tourists are relatively safe in New Orleans, if they do not stray from relatively well-traveled areas like the French Quarter and Uptown. One tourist was killed last year and one this year, the police said.
"I think the average citizen's fears are somewhat exaggerated," said Joseph F. Sheley, a criminologist at Tulane University here.
In New Orleans, people are killed for the same reasons as in other cities: casual arguments turn violent, drug deals go bad, robberies. Or the victims are innocent bystanders like James Darby, the 9-year-old who was slain. As in other American cities, most victims and killers are young, black and poor.
What may help explain this city's high homicide rate, experts here say, is widespread poverty. Nearly a third of its residents are poor, the second-highest rate in the nation after Detroit. New Orleans also has the nation's highest rate of abandoned housing and the third-highest rates for single-mother households and births to teen-agers.
"The things we see causing the problems are the same as they are elsewhere," Mr. Sheley said. "But it is unique in that we've got more of them."
 
Scarcity of Low-End Jobs
 New Orleans is only just emerging from a severe recession that cost the metropolitan area almost 10,000 jobs. Over a longer period, technology has eliminated thousands of low-skill jobs in traditional mainstays like the port. "It's very difficult to provide jobs for people at the lower end of the scale when the economy is so weak," said Tim Ryan, dean of the College of Business Administration at the University of New Orleans.
Hopelessness, like fear, is not hard to find. "I'm fed up," said Darrin Ellis, 23, as he wandered through the St. Thomas Housing Development. When it comes to seeking work, "I don't even get up and go looking," he said. Mr. Ellis's younger brother was fatally shot in the head earlier this year in a robbery.
In all, St. Thomas had 11 homicides last year, the police say.
"You know why it's like that?" Mr. Ellis asked angrily. "Because there's nothing to do. It's just simple and plain. They don't have nothing else to do. They pick crime as a hobby."
Crime casts its heaviest pall on the city's 10 public housing projects. An organized effort to encourage drug dealers to apply for real jobs was met with laughter, said Teresa Nicholas, a resident of the William Guste Sr. Home housing development and a member of the residents council.
Residents speak of nightly gunfire and drug deals. Nearly a third of the homicides committed by May 17 this year had taken place in housing projects.
"It's just scary," said Ms. Nicholas, whose son was shot and robbed earlier this year and who said she had seen men outside her apartment with guns drawn. "Now I'm inside every night. I'm actually afraid."
 
Many Stories to Tell
 The fear cuts across geographic and racial boundaries. In New Orleans, no resident -- black or white, rich or poor -- lives far from neighborhoods that resemble war zones. While some mixing of neighborhoods is found in many cities, it is found to an unusual degree in New Orleans, some sociologists say. As a result, gunshots from St. Thomas can be heard in the upper-class Garden District. And everybody has a crime story to tell.
But the crime stories told by the residents of poorer neighborhoods often differ from those of white Uptown residents. The former recount violent, recent crimes. Four Uptowners, members of a neighborhood anti-crime association who gathered on a recent morning, focused on homicides that had made headlines several years ago or on property offenses. "It makes me angry that we can't have anything, because somebody's going to take it," said Mehl Cimini, whose mother was robbed at gunpoint some years ago.
But in the housing projects, many seem to know someone who was shot or killed within the year, like Mr. Ellis's brother. "I don't see how on this earth he was chosen to get killed," Mr. Ellis said. "That just hurt me. I think about him all the time. Every day. Constantly."

HEADLINE: A Mixed and Light Day on World Markets

 BODY:
International financial markets were mixed yesterday in light trading, as exchanges were closed for holidays in the United States and Britain.
In Tokyo, the dollar ended at 104.40 yen, down 0.13 yen from Friday. It closed in New York on Friday at 104.28 yen. 
 In Hong Kong, stock prices were higher in moderate trading. The Hang Seng index, the Hong Kong market's blue-chip indicator, rose 53.50 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, closing at 9,523.63. On Friday, the index slipped 11 points.
In Frankfurt, the DAX index of 30 stocks declined 22.84 points, ending the session at 2,118.15. The CAC 40 in Paris rose 1.84 points, to close at 2,052.51. Last week, German stocks lost 6.2 percent as investors worried that German interest rate reductions might be put off. The belief that German and French central banks had paused in cutting rates was reinforced when the Bank of France left the intervention rate, the floor for money market rates, unchanged at 5.4 percent.
Stocks rose yesterday in Italy, Spain, Switzerland and the Netherlands, but fell in Belgium and Sweden. Trading in Mexico City left stocks little changed.
 
Dollar Rises in Europe
 The dollar was up against major European currencies, climbing to 1.6466 German marks from 1.6450 and to 5.6291 French francs from 5.6095. The British pound fell against the dollar, to $1.5087 from $1.5100.
In Zurich the late bid price of gold was $385.00, down from $385.50 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.39 to close at a bid of $385.38.
Traders described investors as cautious. "People are not worried about them going up," Matthias Tislev of Banque Worms said, referring to interest rates, "but they think they've stopped going down for the moment, or at least have slowed right down."
Bond prices recovered slightly and their yields, which move in the opposite direction, fell after steep declines throughout Europe last week.

HEADLINE: Japanese Rightist Fires Near Ex-Premier

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 30

 BODY:
A suspected right-wing militant fired a shot near former Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa tonight in apparent anger over Mr. Hosokawa's apologies for Japan's behavior in World War II.
Mr. Hosokawa, who resigned last month amid questions over his financial dealings, was unharmed. The bullet hit the ceiling of the Tokyo hotel lobby as the former Prime Minister was leaving a party held there. 
 The police immediately overpowered the assailant, who was identified as Masakatsu Nozoe, 52. The police said Mr. Nozoe had told them that he was angry at Mr. Hosokawa's comments about Japan's role in World War II and at his economic policies, according to the Kyodo News Service.
In his first news conference upon taking office last August, Mr. Hosokawa called World War II a "war of aggression."
Japan has hundreds of right-wing groups that embrace the idea that the nation did no wrong in World War II. These groups do not have a wide following, and most Japanese ignore their preachings from dark trucks equipped with deafening loudspeakers.
 
Occasional Violent Attacks
 But ultra-nationalists occasionally resort to violence. In January 1990, the Mayor of Nagasaki, Hitoshi Motoshima, was shot in the chest by a right-wing gunman. Mr. Motoshima, who recovered, had said Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II.
In March 1992, a rightist fired three shots, all of which missed, at Shin Kanemaru, who at the time was one of Japan's most powerful politicians but who has since been disgraced in a bribery scandal. The assailant said he had heard that Mr. Kanemaru had been trying to normalize Japan's relations with Communist North Korea.
The shootings have evoked memories the 1930's, when right-wing military officers committed a wave of assassinations as Japan moved toward involvement in World War II. Some analysts have said such attacks stifle free speech by causing people to think twice before condemning Japan's behavior in the war.
Nearly 50 years after the end of World War II, Japan is still having trouble coming to grips with its role in the conflict, and the issue can arouse fierce passions.
This month, Japan's Justice Minister, Shigeto Nagano, was forced to resign after only a week on the job because he said the so-called Rape of Nanking, a massacre of hundreds of thousands of Chinese people, was a "fabrication." The remark enraged Japan's Asian neighbors, who still have bitter memories of Japan's conquests and colonial rule.
The Government recently decided not to have Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko visit Pearl Harbor on their trip to the United States in June. Right-wing groups and officials opposed the visit, saying they did not want the imperial couple to have to apologize for the surprise attack that drew the United States into the war.
Just before tonight's shooting, Mr. Hosokawa was attending a rally at the Keio Plaza Hotel for the Japan New Party, the political organization he heads. It was one of his first public appearances since he resigned last month after heading the first government in nearly 40 years that was not controlled by the Liberal Democratic Party.
Since his resignation, Mr. Hosokawa has been trying to avoid questioning about his financial transactions, including a huge loan he received from a scandal-tainted trucking company.
The assailant fired a revolver after Mr. Hosokawa had come out of the party gathering into the lobby of the hotel, which was crowded with television cameras and reporters. Some early reports said the gunman's hands were deflected by policemen, causing the shot to miss, but Mr. Nozoe later told the police that he had meant to fire at the ceiling.

HEADLINE: First Settlers Domesticated Pigs Before Crops

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
DIGGING at the ruins of a village in southeastern Turkey, where people lived more than 10,000 years ago, archeologists expected to turn up the usual traces of a society on the verge of the agriculture revolution. There should be leftover grains of wild wheat and barley and perhaps the bones of butchered sheep and goats in some early stage of domestication.
The archeologists found nothing of the kind. Instead, to their complete surprise, they dug up the ample remains of pig bones. 
 The discovery, they said, strongly suggests that the pig was the earliest animal that people domesticated for food. The diminished size of the molars was one of several clues that the transformation of wild boars into pigs was under way at that time. Radiocarbon analysis put the date at 10,000 to 10,400 years ago.
So in the foothills of the Taurus Mountains at a site known as Hallan Cemi, the domestication of the pig appeared to have occurred 2,000 years earlier than once thought -- and 1,000 years before the taming and herding of sheep and goats.
Much earlier, at least 12,000 years ago, wolves more or less invited domestication as the dog, developing a symbiotic relationship with people. They became camp followers, sentinels and "best friend." Only in a few cultures later on were dogs served as food.
A broader significance, archeologists said, was the absence of any sign of wheat or barley at the settlement. The prevailing assumption, based mainly on research to the south in Syria and the Jordan River Valley, has been that with the end of the last ice age, wild grains were abundant in the more temperate climate over the entire Middle East. People settled down to harvest them, and this led to agriculture, animal husbandry and eventually the rise of cities and civilization.
"All early agricultural models are predicated on the assumption that people gathered wild wheat and other grains," said Dr. Michael Rosenberg, an archeologist at the University of Delaware and director of the Hallan Cemi excavations. "But this is the earliest settlement site so far north, and it has no cereals. So another resource must have made it possible to settle down."
In a report at a recent meeting of the Society for American Archeologists, Dr. Richard W. Redding, a University of Michigan archeologist and member of the discovery team, said that a heavy reliance on data from southern sites in the Levant might have resulted "in a very narrow view of the origin of food production." There may have been a variety of ways by which people made the transition from foraging to farming, and some of them did not include the intensive use of wild cereals as a crucial first step.
Dr. Patricia Wattenmaker, a University of Virginia archeologist with wide experience in Middle East excavations, said the new findings were among the first from this part of the Turkish highlands in prehistory and were certain to force a serious rethinking of theories regarding human subsistence patterns leading up to agriculture.
 
Roles of Environment and Culture
 "It looks as if the pattern varies from place to place," Dr. Wattenmaker said. "This takes the punch out of arguments that environmental factors" over a wider area triggered the transition toward agriculture, she added, and suggested that "cultural factors were really the key."
Dr. Robert J. Braidwood, a professor emeritus of archeology at the University of Chicago who is a specialist in research on early agriculture, praised the Hallan Cemi excavations for providing a much-needed examination of pre-agricultural cultures beyond the Levant. But the Turkish village of no more than 150 inhabitants was extremely small, he cautioned, and evidence from three or four more sites in the area might be necessary before drawing any sweeping conclusions.
The Hallan Cemi site is scheduled to be flooded next year by a new dam on the Batman River.
In three years of excavations at Hallan Cemi, though, archeologists have established that people there had left the wandering life of hunting and gathering for a more sedentary village existence. Ruins of small stone houses and stone sculptures indicated a permanent settlement, and the growth pattern in fresh water clam shells at the site revealed year-round occupation. Evidence of long-distance trade in obsidian, copper and Mediterranean shells reflected the expansion of economic horizons by an increasingly complex society.
All this was happening at the time of the Natufians, people in the Jordan Valley who were probably the first to adopt settling down as a permanent way of life. But if wild cereals were critical to the Natufians' transition, the people at Hallan Cemi apparently depended on gathering nuts and seeds, hunting wild sheep and deer and raising pigs. The absence of any wild grains at the site was determined by Dr. Mark Nesbitt, a paleobotanist at University College, London.
No single piece of the pig evidence is conclusive, Dr. Redding reported, but all the clues together "are congruent with the early phases of the domestication of pigs."
 
Clue on Domestication
 Not only are the bones plentiful and the molars smaller, he said, but they show that the people appeared to favor young male pigs more than would be expected if they were hunting wild animals. A preponderance of the bones were of male pigs under one year of age. If they were raising pigs, they would spare most of the young females for breeding. Survivorship patterns of hunted animals reveal a more normal age distribution.
Pigs may have been the villagers' insurance against famine caused by any sudden shortage of nuts and fruits and wild game. In a pre-agricultural sedentary culture, Dr. Rosenberg said, such shortages posed a greater risk because the people had a more limited foraging and hunting range.
"We think they fiddled around with maintaining animals to decrease that risk," he said, "and pigs make sense if they are not gathering and growing grains."
For one thing, young pigs are easily obtained and tamed. They require little labor to control since they can be left to forage for themselves throughout the community. And they are the most efficient domesticated animal, Dr. Redding said, in that they convert 35 percent of food energy into meat, compared with 13 percent for sheep or a mere 6.5 percent for cattle.
Pigs, the archeologist concluded, may have represented one more transitional step in some pre-agricultural societies; the pattern was not always a direct progression from settling down to growing cereals to raising animals. Perhaps the subsistent strategy of the highland villagers was to supplement their diets of nuts, fruits and grasses with pigs until cereal production was adopted. In time, Dr. Redding said, the highlanders took up grain cultivation, probably as an innovation borrowed from the south.
 
Decline of Pigs
 In any case, the archeologists said, as soon as the people of Hallan Cemi began growing grain, there was a sharp decline in domestic pigs, which were gradually replaced by domestic sheep and goats. It was a necessity. Pigs compete with people for cereals. They could no longer be left to forage unattended near the village and fields, and they are not as easily herded as sheep and goats.
Although some of the interpretations are tentative and more research is required, Dr. Rosenberg and Dr. Redding said they were increasingly confident in their evidence for the early domestication of the pig. And contrary to previous findings in the Levant, they said, there could be sedentary village life without an abundance of grains, wild or cultivated.
"Hallan Cemi is almost a mirror image of what's going on at this time in the Levant," Dr. Redding said. "We will have to rethink all the models we've been developing about early food production."
