HEADLINE: Vietnamese Scientists Struggle To Survive in a Market Economy

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam

 BODY:
SIX years after Vietnam's leaders began converting the country's economy from a rigidly controlled form of state socialism to a market economy, scientists have had to find a new way to carry on their work.
Although the country has modestly prospered since the 1988 decision, the change brought a collapse of government subsidies for research, and the beginning of a desperate struggle by Vietnamese scientists to feed their families. 
 Little if any "pure" research is carried on in Vietnam these days, but scientists are learning to live by their wits. In an environment where a scientist in a teaching post generally earns no more than $25 a month (comparable to the pay of other professionals, who also scramble for a living), ingenuity is a requisite for survival.
In some of their most successful ventures, chemists and chemical engineers are banding together to create commercial enterprises -- state-owned manufacturing enterprises that are allowed to operate almost as if they were private, profit-making companies.
Among the most successful of these new plants is the Essential Oils Enterprise (Enteroil) in the Tu Liem suburb of Hanoi -- a semi-independent branch of the government's National Center for Natural Science and Technology. Using improvised distillation columns, crystallization chambers and other simple industrial tools, the engineers and scientists at Enteroil extract volatile flavoring oils from various costly spices and herbs grown in Vietnam.
 
Improvising From Crude Supplies
 Neither time nor money is available for original research, but the chemists have created jobs for themselves by applying their technical knowledge toward improvising complex plant machinery from the crude materials on hand.
Products include cassia oil, which is used as an ingredient in cola beverages, menthol used in mentholated cigarettes, and citronella, anis and sassafras oils, used in food products and perfumes.
Dr. Le Trong Vong, general director of the enterprise, says it is the first privatized manufacturing company to be able to pay its workers regularly each week. Workers and managers share in the plant's profits, he said.
One of the main problems the organizers faced, they say, was convincing foreign buyers that they could count on consistent quality in Enteroil's products. Some visitors to the plant have been startled by its somewhat primitive appearance. A row of storage tanks in the plant's warehouse, for example, was assembled from tank trailers detached from abandoned United States Army trucks seized at the conclusion of the Vietnam War in 1975.
"Our first task in finding customers," said Dr. Nguyen Quyet Chien, "was to establish a reliable system of quality control."
This meant that each batch of each product had to be sampled and analyzed for purity, using analytical methods internationally recognized as accurate and valid.
 
Seeking American Equipment
 "We desperately needed modern laboratory equipment," said Dr. Chien, who received his doctoral degree from the University of Halle in the former East Germany. "But because of the United States embargo, we had problems getting the American apparatus we wanted."
Dr. Chien, who speaks fluent English, gestured toward a bench loaded with scientific equipment made by Hewlett-Packard and other American companies. "We had to buy this equipment through third-party intermediaries, and it was expensive doing it that way," he said, "but the important thing is that we can now offer our customers proof of the quality of our products."
Although many scientists have abandoned their specialties to become commercial traders, Dr. Pham Khoi Nguyen, vice director of the Ministry of Science, Technology and Environment, believes that his government's new emphasis on the development of national scientific information networks will stimulate industries and help scientists.
"We need appropriate technology -- the kind that will one day allow us not only to assemble computers but to manufacture their components," he said. "We are making progress. And at its last session, our National Assembly enacted a law requiring each proposed plant to prepare an environmental impact study, so we are not ignoring our environment as we push forward."
But scientific pursuits that cannot be directly applied to making money are starved of support.
 
Effect on Education
 Dr. Vu The Long, a scientist at Vietnam's Institute of Archeology in Hanoi, believes the shortage of money is having a devastating effect on both science and national education in Vietnam.
"It used to be that everyone in Vietnam had at least 10 years of education, but today far too many youngsters drop out after a few years, many unable even to read," he said. "We studied even during the war. When the B-52 raids on Hanoi got too bad in 1969, our whole class from the University of Hanoi moved into a forest out of town, where it was safer. We dug holes for shelter and lived on manioc root, but we worked and studied, because we had heart.
"But now scientists can hardly live on what we earn, and young people tell us, 'What's the point of studying, if you can't make a living from what you learn?' "
Dr. Long sometimes collaborates with foreign scientists in studies of Vietnamese fossils found in limestone caves. In a recent project with Dr. Ian Tattersall, curator of anthropology at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, and Dr. Jeffrey H. Schwartz, professor of anthropology at the University of Pittsburgh, Dr. Long and his colleagues identified some previously unknown species of extinct primates. Their discoveries suggest that early man, Homo erectus, had a large variety of contemporary competitors, including the huge extinct ape Gigantopithecus.
"But we have no money to undertake expeditions," Dr. Long said. "At present, the government is excavating a lot of limestone, partly to widen the main coastal road, and partly to quarry limestone used as a raw material in the cement plants. We get to look at some of this limestone for fossils, and that gives us something to examine," he said.
Along with foreign scientists who try to help colleagues in Vietnam, many overseas Vietnamese scientists are lending a hand.
Last December, Dr. Tran Thanh Van, a high-energy physicist who lives in Paris, organized an international conference on particle physics and astrophysics in Hanoi. Vietnam has no large particle accelerators or major astrophysical research programs, but the conference was intended as a gesture of support for Vietnamese science.
"We read of the complaints by American scientists about their lack of money these days," said a Vietnamese physicist, "and we can only sympathize. We know what it's like to have to live by hustling. That's how all of us in this country survive."

HEADLINE: In Mississippi, a Clue to Low-Inflation Economics

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MONTICELLO, Miss.

 BODY:
Two years ago, business was so bad that the Georgia-Pacific Corporation was forced temporarily to shut its thundering linerboard plant on the Pearl River a few miles outside of town, idling 600 people, in an effort to reduce inventory.
"The marketplace was completely flooded," Asa D. Hardison, the general manager, recalled. "The box plants filled up and there were no orders out there." 
 Now, the Monticello plant is churning out linerboard, the main component of cardboard cartons used to ship Downy fabric softener, Kellogg's Pop-Tarts and many other products, at a pace that not only breaks production records but even exceeds 100 percent of the plant's intended capacity.
The plant, however, exhibits few characteristics of boom times -- testimony to a profound shift in American factories. During previous economic expansions, when plants started approaching their maximum production capacity, economists started looking for signs of inflation, assuming that there would soon be more demand for goods in the economy than factories were capable of turning out. But in this expansion, American industry seems to be defying the old inflationary assumptions by finding ways of doing more with less.
So far this year, managers at the Monticello mill, on 2,200 acres surrounded by pine forest extending to the horizon, have added just 8 people to the work force of 585 and have put no new equipment on line, even as the operation squeezes out nearly 3,000 tons of linerboard a day. Virtually no one, other than workers maintaining machinery, is working overtime.
"The name of the game is to become the low-cost producer," Mr. Hardison said. "One thing about a recession -- it makes you innovative, it makes you think."
With the resurgence of economic growth since late last summer, many analysts have fretted as the utilization, or operating, rate of American industry has crept toward the danger zone that traditionally has meant overheating, reflected in faster inflation. For manufacturing, the operating rate in April reached 83 percent, up from 80.4 percent in September. For the paper industry, the rate is 91.7 percent, the highest of any business sector except for petroleum, which is at 93.6 percent.
The experience of this mill and others like it, however, suggests that inflation risks may well be less than at similar stages of previous business cycles. This could imply, among other things, that the Federal Reserve may need to make few, if any, additional increases in interest rates to keep inflation at bay.
There is a growing belief among economists that productive capacity is markedly higher than the statistics show, reflecting an apparently underestimated ingenuity of American managers and the benefits of computerization and other technology. Another, not unrelated, factor is worldwide competition, more prevalent in some industries than in others, that in effect puts foreign capacity at American disposal.
 
Benefits of Low Inflation
 Undoubtedly, another spur is the fact that inflation has already been low for a sustained period, with the annual rise in consumer prices halved, to 3.1 percent, in 1991, and reduced modestly again in both 1992 and 1993.
"In a low-inflation environment, companies find revenues flat to down so they have to economize, use less inputs," said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management, a Washington investment firm. He called the inability to hide fat and mistakes by raising prices "probably the least heralded benefit" of low inflation.
While it is the interplay of supply and demand, not costs, that most influences how prices are set, cost reductions of the kind achieved here constitute an addition to supply that may not be captured in official figures. Indeed, some economists doubt that the Federal Reserve's estimates of capacity have kept up with the recent capital-spending boom in American industry, for which figures are published, or that they adequately reflect the rapid spread of computerization.
Whatever the case for the economy at large, the Monticello mill, opened in 1968 and purchased by Georgia-Pacific from the St. Regis Paper Company in 1984 -- is clearly producing more linerboard than even its managers at one time thought possible. And it is doing this with fewer and fewer resources, particularly labor.
Judged by man-hour for each ton of output, the plant has raised efficiency nearly 35 percent in the last six years. The plant's overall costs are down about 8.5 percent in real terms and 27 percent before adjusting for inflation.
Mr. Hardison, a 45-year-old bear of a man who talks like a football coach at halftime, brushes aside a question about whether linerboard quality might suffer from strained production.
The plant has begun to harvest hefty profits in recent months. Unexpectedly strong demand for corrugated boxes, including export orders, has lifted linerboard prices to nearly $350 a ton from a low of about $295 in October, Walter Bone, the plant's controller, said.
Contributing to the plant's strong performance are a variety of measures, large and small, to hold down costs and pump up production. Mr. Hardison's new penny-pinching attitude shows up in such moves as halving the plant's typical woodlot stockpile to 15,000 cords, using computers to reduce processing variation and maximizing the use of bark for fuel and recycled cartons for fiber.
"In the past, we didn't scrutinize everything," Mr. Hardison said as he walked through the busy but orderly shop floor. "Now I know what I'm paying for, no more guessing at it."
 
Flying the Flag
 It also involves such psychological techniques as hoisting the American flag -- Mr. Hardison said he had found that the flag inspires tidier premises, contributing to fewer accidents -- and the introduction last year of a "gain sharing" plan. Under this plan, workers can earn quarterly cash bonuses of up to 5 percent of gross pay depending on the mill's, not an individual's, performance as gauged by manufacturing costs, output and safety.
The plant's rank and file, those on the cutting edge of cost-cutting, said they had few complaints about working conditions and that the extra effort involved in the new practices is well rewarded.
"Ninety-five percent of the time, what's good for the company is good for the union," said Billy Dan Little, president of Local 371 of the United Paperworkers International Union, representing about 145 workers who maintain machinery and plants. In the last year or two, Mr. Little said, "there's grown a pretty good deal of trust between us and management," with Mr. Hardison deserving "a lot" of the credit.
Their current squabble is mainly about 23 maintenance slots the company does not want to fill.
 
Sought-After Jobs
 Pay here, averaging $17 an hour, is roughly 40 percent more than the average for American factories -- and exceptionally high for this rural area. Jobs at the Monticello plant are so attractive that it routinely has 5,000 applications on file and keeps the list manageable only by starting it from scratch again every six months.
Generally in business, "management only knows so much," said James F. Smith, a professor at the Kenan-Flagler Business School of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. It is wise, therefore, to enlist the help of employees.
From 1990 to 1993, American factories raised output per hour an average of 3.8 percent a year, surpassing both the foreign competition and the nation's own typical performance.
"You've got managers who understand that nothing's forever, that markets can be lost," John M. Albertine, a Washington consultant and a former vice chairman of Farley Industries, said. "You're seeing the fruits of the long rationalization of American industry."
But those who find in this a "historic transformation," the term recently used by Business Week to describe the current surge of innovation and productivity, may be somewhat premature, some specialists contend.
Edwin R. Dean, head of the Office of Productivity and Technology at the Labor Department, pointed to the 1960's and 1970's, when similar claims were made on behalf of automation and numerically controlled machine tools.
Something important may indeed be going on, Mr. Dean said, but the evidence is almost entirely anecdotal and so far not convincing. "There is no survey," he added, "that will tell you how many unnecessary jobs have been eliminated."
Here in southern Mississippi, meanwhile, Mr. Hardison, Mr. Bone and Charles E. Hodges, the plant's production manager, keep bearing down in their campaign to extract as much linerboard as they can from pulp mill and paper machine.
"We're not at full capacity" quite yet, Mr. Hardison said, adding, "We think we've got 250" more tons a day to go.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Beijing's New Prisoner

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Soon it will start sinking in -- just how much President Clinton and the United States will have to pay for his broken official promises about China. The truth is that payment has started already.
Politically the Chinese Communists have taken a new prisoner -- the President. And at a time when misunderstanding about American intent could bring war with the North Koreans, how are they now supposed to figure out what Mr. Clinton means, really, or does not mean, really? 
 Children often think they can break their promises and get away without penalty if they just put on a sugar-face. But when grown-ups, particularly a Presidential grown-up, carry that fantasy into adulthood, life can get nerve-racking for everybody.
Some of the economic men-boys around the President told him to forget that order imposing a tariff penalty if Beijing continued to destroy dissent by arrest, torture and forced labor. Forget that Beijing, in your face, refused to budge. Tomorrow the voters will not remember if you break your word. Some of them will even forget that most of the China trade jobs were going from us to them. Do it -- American big business will remember and be grateful.
Chinese Communists do not play children's games. They know the President has put himself into their hands and they know how to squeeze.
From time to time they may release some political prisoners. The Clinton Administration will dance happily on the strings. It has committed itself to another fantasy -- that Beijing, in gratitude to Mr. Clinton for destroying his human rights pledge to the Chinese people, will relax rule by police terrorism.
That must astonish Beijing. Didn't the Communists say repeatedly that the "stability" of their Government depends on putting down opposition and that arrests are likely to go up over all, not down? No pretense there.
And now they know there is no possibility of economic reprisals by the U.S., the one thing that might have brought a bit more than a one-night stand on easing repression. Now the jailers can turn to the prisoners in the political cells and say, where are your American friends -- you fools?
When more arrests do come, the Clinton Administration will not be just an innocent bystander tut-tutting away. Washington did not arrest Chinese dissidents -- it just put on double locks, that's all.
Without outside pressure Beijing will not give up repression voluntarily. It fears freedom too much. But sporadically it can tighten or loosen a bit at will.
When it tightens, Mr. Clinton will look foolish. Then, as the reward for loosening repression for awhile, Beijing will collect political or economic reward from America. It will be a brand new game, but not for children.
The price Mr. Clinton will pay for his China turnabout will involve only him, America's honor, tens of millions of Chinese prisoners and forced laborers, Tibet's existence and such fringe matters.
But the price in Korea could arouse even economic bottom-liners in Washington. The last time North Korea misunderstood American intentions and resolve it started the war that devastated Korea and brought China and the U.S. into combat.
So far Mr. Clinton has played a bad Korea hand carefully and generally well -- few threats, much emphasis on negotiation and compromise.
But compromise what, when and how? One day the President says North Korea must not be allowed to have nuclear weapons. Another day U.S. defense and intelligence people say North Korea already has them. One day international inspection looks hopeful, another day it is one more Korean trick.
China helped North Korea get missiles and nuclear techniques. What Beijing does in the future does not depend on U.S. human rights policies. China will decide its Korean stand and what it thinks are the risks of war from North Korea. Even then Beijing may not be able to control its clients.
The North Koreans will make their own final decisions largely on how they read President Clinton. The world has some trouble doing that about Bosnia and Haiti. Now the President's whirlabout on China makes North Korea's reading light considerably dimmer.
That can be dangerous, for them, for South Koreans, for Americans and for Chinese -- in or out of the doubly locked cells.

HEADLINE: After College, a Search for a Job and for Health Coverage

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
As college seniors leave their dorm rooms, many will be leaving something else behind as well: health insurance.
Of the estimated one million students receiving college diplomas this spring, the American College Health Association says 20 percent will lose their health insurance when their college health plans expire or when they no longer qualify as dependents on their parents' policies. 
 Collin Winterbottom, a researcher in the Health and Long Term Care Department of the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research organization, said that although more college graduates obtained long-term coverage (60 percent) than young adults with only a high school degree (45 percent) or some college credits (53 percent), they still belonged to the most underinsured age group in the country.
But while President Clinton's proposal to reshape the health system has focused attention on the dangers of being uninsured, those dangers have not necessarily translated into a greater sense of urgency among graduates.
 
'Nothing Can Happen'
 "You're dealing with that mentality, 'I'm immortal, nothing can happen to me,' " said Cindy Launchbaugh of the American College Health Association. "There are a lot of young people out there who do not understand or do not totally accept the need for health insurance."
Jonas Stiklorius, 22, who is majoring in international politics at Georgetown University in Washington and is moving to New York this fall to work for a bank, said two weeks before graduation: "I think my parents' health insurance will cover me, but I honestly haven't even thought about it."
Few companies offer inexpensive, short-term insurance. Those plans geared toward temporarily insuring low-income people have a moderate pool of applicants for short stretches who pay low premiums, but those plans sometimes provide millions of dollars in coverage for catastrophic accidents. Many insurance companies regard these plans as bad business because they are not highly profitable.
Dr. Neal F. Kassell, vice chairman of the department of neurosurgery at the University of Virginia, said that young people might use far fewer medical services than older people, but that when they had problems they tended to require costly trauma treatment.
"The services they generally need are from accidents," Dr. Kassell said. "The most common form of injury or 'sickness' for that age group are drunk-driving related accidents."
 
Connecting With Parents
 Medical treatment for trauma is much more expensive than that for routine ailments, a difference that the insurance industry passes on through higher rates.
Graduates under age 23 who are still listed as dependents have the option, by Federal law, to "roll over" their university insurance to their parents' plan until they reach age 23.
Dr. Kassell comes to the debate as both a physician and a father. He said his policy would pick up coverage of his youngest daughter, who graduates college this month, "as long as she's completely dependent on me for money, housing and food."
But if Dr. Kassell's daughter becomes independent or reaches her 23d birthday before obtaining her own health care benefits, she will have to pay for individual health insurance.
Many university health plans are based on a 12-month schedule, which provides coverage for graduates until late August, though some students lose their insurance at the end of the month in which they graduate.
"I have to pay, and I'll do it as soon as I get home in June," said Christian Aviza, a senior at Georgetown. Between his May 28 graduation and rolling over his university coverage in June, Mr. Aviza admits he will be nervous about being uninsured.
In addition to graduates, there is a growing number of students who have no insurance, though there are no statistics on how many.
In 1992, Massachusetts, which has 282,164 college students enrolled in the state, became the first state to require both public and private college students to have health insurance. Last fall 97,754 students (35 percent) were required to enroll in the plan, indicating that more than one in three students were uninsured before the policy took effect.
Experts say Massachusetts' enrollment figures may be the most accurate that the country has on insured undergraduates.
Under the Clinton health care plan, everyone would be guaranteed health care, and people with low incomes would be eligible for subsidies, even temporarily unemployed college students. A senior policy analyst on the Clinton health task force, Christine Heenan, said, "Those not earning income will be fully subsidized, with no waiting period."
Using figures supplied by four of the largest insurance companies that offer coverage in the Washington and Chicago areas, a conservative estimate of the cost to insure a healthy, nonsmoking 22-year-old man for six months is $357, and for a woman of a similar profile it is slightly more expensive, $477, mainly because of gynecological and obstetric services. These figures are based on an average cost of those companies' individual packages in Washington and Chicago, two of the costliest areas in the country, and on their temporary plans with the highest possible deductible of $2,500.
 
Package Takes Legwork
 The prices of health insurance packages are substantially affected by the region of the country in which a student lives, whether a student smokes and the size of the deductible that a student is willing to pay.
According to Al Mainor of the Health Insurance Association of America, there are 1,200 commercial insurance companies in the United States, with 95 percent offering individual health insurance. But that does not ease the legwork for finding the most comprehensive and economical insurance package for a recent graduate.
A senior at George Washington University paused recently in cramming for her final finals. "I'm supposed to get a job, a place to crash, and health care insurance before Labor Day?" she asked. "That's just not realistic."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 31 about health care insurance for recent college graduates misstated the percentage of insurance companies offering individual coverage. It is 5 percent, not 95.
